l.#text: I know the number of the grains of sand and the extent of the sea,

l: And understand the mute and hear the voiceless.
The smell has come to my senses of a strong-shelled tortoise
Boiling in a cauldron together with a lamb's flesh,
Under which is bronze and over which is bronze.

l.#text: When the  have a mule as king,
Just then, tender-footed , by the stone-strewn

l: Flee and do not stay, and do not be ashamed to be a coward.

l.#text: The cast is made, the net spread,

l: The tunny-fish shall flash in the moonlit night.

l.#text: You have come to my rich temple, ,
A man dear to  and to all who have  homes.

l: I am in doubt whether to pronounce you man or god,

l.#text: But I think rather you are a god, .
You ask me for ? You ask too much; I grant it not.
There are many men in , eaters of acorns,

l: Who will hinder you. But I grudge you not.

l.#text: I will give you  to beat with your feet in dancing,

l: And its fair plain to measure with a rope.

l.#text: There is a place  in the smooth plain of ,

l: Where two winds blow under strong compulsion.
Blow lies upon blow, woe upon woe.

l.#text: There the life-giving earth covers the son of .
Bring him back, and you shall be lord of .
, king of many, greatly foolish ,

l: Wish not to hear in the palace the voice often prayed for
Of your son speaking.
It were better for you that he remain mute as before;
For on an unlucky day shall he first speak.

l.#text: Do not wall or trench the isthmus:
would have given you an island, if he had wanted to.

p.#text:
This is the display of the inquiry of  of , so that things done by man not be forgotten in time, and that great and marvelous deeds, some displayed by the , some by the barbarians, not lose their glory, including among others what was the cause of their waging war on each other.

The  learned men say that the  were the cause of the dispute. These (they say) came to our seas from the sea which is called Red,  and having settled in the country which they still occupy, at once began to make long voyages. Among other places to which they carried  and  merchandise, they came to ,

which was at that time preeminent in every way among the people of what is now called . The  came to , and set out their cargo.
On the fifth or sixth day after their arrival, when their wares were almost all sold, many women came to the shore and among them especially the daughter of the king, whose name was  (according to  and  alike), the daughter of .
As these stood about the stern of the ship bargaining for the wares they liked, the  incited one another to set upon them. Most of the women escaped:  and others were seized and thrown into the ship, which then sailed away for .


In this way, the  say (and not as the ), was how  came to , and this, according to them, was the first wrong that was done. Next, according to their story, some  (they cannot say who) landed at  in  and carried off the king's daughter . These  must, I suppose, have been . So far, then, the account between them was balanced. But after this (they say), it was the  who were guilty of the second wrong.
They sailed in a long ship to , a city of the , and to the river :  and when they had done the business for which they came, they carried off the king's daughter .
When the  king sent a herald to demand reparation for the robbery and restitution of his daughter, the  replied that, as they had been refused reparation for the abduction of the  , they would not make any to the .


Then (they say), in the second generation after this, , son of , who had heard this tale, decided to get himself a wife from  by capture; for he was confident that he would not suffer punishment.
So he carried off . The  first resolved to send messengers demanding that  be restored and atonement made for the seizure; but when this proposal was made, the  pleaded the seizure of , and reminded the  that they asked reparation from others, yet made none themselves, nor gave up the booty when asked.


So far it was a matter of mere seizure on both sides. But after this (the  say), the  were very much to blame; for they invaded  before the  attacked .

We think, they say, that it is unjust to carry women off. But to be anxious to avenge rape is foolish: wise men take no notice of such things. For plainly the women would never have been carried away, had they not wanted it themselves.
We of  did not deign to notice the seizure of our women; but the , for the sake of a  woman, recruited a great armada, came to , and destroyed the power of .
Ever since then we have regarded  as our enemies. For the  claim  for their own, and the foreign peoples that inhabit it;  and the  people they consider to be separate from them.


Such is the  account; in their opinion, it was the taking of  which began their hatred of the .
But the  do not tell the same story about  as the . They say that they did not carry her off to  by force. She had intercourse in  with the captain of the ship. Then, finding herself pregnant, she was ashamed to have her parents know it, and so, lest they discover her condition, she sailed away with the  of her own accord.

These are the stories of the  and the . For my part, I shall not say that this or that story is true, but I shall identify the one who I myself know did the  unjust deeds, and thus proceed with my history, and speak of small and great cities of men alike.
For many states that were once great have now become small; and those that were great in my time were small before. Knowing therefore that human prosperity never continues in the same place, I shall mention both alike.


 was a  by birth, son of , and sovereign of all the nations west of the river , which flows from the south between  and  and empties into the sea called .
This  was the first foreigner whom we know who subjugated some  and took tribute from them, and won the friendship of others: the former being the , the , and the  of , and the latter the .
Before the reign of , all  were free: for the  host which invaded  before his time did not subjugate the cities, but raided and robbed them.


Now the sovereign power that belonged to the descendants of   fell to the family of , called the , in the following way.

, whom the  call , was the ruler of ; he was descended from , son of ;  son of , son of , son of , was the first  king of  and  son of  was the last.
The kings of this country before  were descendants of , son of , from whom this whole  district got its name; before that it was called the land of the .
The , descendants of  and a female slave of , received the sovereignty from these and held it, because of an oracle; and they ruled for twenty-two generations, or five hundred and five years, son succeeding father, down to  son of .


This , then, fell in love with his own wife, so much so that he believed her to be by far the most beautiful woman in the world; and believing this, he praised her beauty beyond measure to  son of , who was his favorite among his bodyguard; for it was to  that he entrusted all his most important secrets.
After a little while, , doomed to misfortune, spoke to  thus: , I do not think that you believe what I say about the beauty of my wife; men trust their ears less than their eyes: so you must see her naked.  protested loudly at this.

Master, he said, what an unsound suggestion, that I should see my mistress naked! When a woman's clothes come off, she dispenses with her modesty, too.
Men have long ago made wise rules from which one ought to learn; one of these is that one should mind one's own business. As for me, I believe that your queen is the most beautiful of all women, and I ask you not to ask of me what is lawless.


Speaking thus,  resisted: for he was afraid that some evil would come of it for him. But this was ' answer: Courage, ! Do not be afraid of me, that I say this to test you, or of my wife, that you will have any harm from her. I will arrange it so that she shall never know that you have seen her.
I will bring you into the chamber where she and I lie and conceal you behind the open door; and after I have entered, my wife too will come to bed. There is a chair standing near the entrance of the room: on this she will lay each article of her clothing as she takes it off, and you will be able to look upon her at your leisure.
Then, when she moves from the chair to the bed, turning her back on you, be careful she does not see you going out through the doorway.


As  could not escape, he consented. , when he judged it to be time for bed, brought  into the chamber; his wife followed presently, and when she had come in and was laying aside her garments,  saw her;

when she turned her back upon him to go to bed, he slipped from the room. The woman glimpsed him as he went out, and perceived what her husband had done. But though shamed, she did not cry out or let it be seen that she had perceived anything, for she meant to punish ;

since among the  and most of the foreign peoples it is felt as a great shame that even a man be seen naked.


For the present she made no sign and kept quiet. But as soon as it was day, she prepared those of her household whom she saw were most faithful to her, and called . He, supposing that she knew nothing of what had been done, answered the summons; for he was used to attending the queen whenever she summoned him.
When  came, the lady addressed him thus: Now, , you have two ways before you; decide which you will follow. You must either kill  and take me and the throne of  for your own, or be killed yourself now without more ado; that will prevent you from obeying all ' commands in the future and seeing what you should not see.
One of you must die: either he, the contriver of this plot, or you, who have outraged all custom by looking on me uncovered.  stood awhile astonished at this; presently, he begged her not to compel him to such a choice.
But when he could not deter her, and saw that dire necessity was truly upon him either to kill his master or himself be killed by others, he chose his own life. Then he asked: Since you force me against my will to kill my master, I would like to know how we are to lay our hands on him.
She replied, You shall come at him from the same place where he made you view me naked: attack him in his sleep.


When they had prepared this plot, and night had fallen,  followed the woman into the chamber (for  was not released, nor was there any means of deliverance, but either he or  must die). She gave him a dagger and hid him behind the same door;

and presently he stole out and killed  as he slept. Thus he made himself master of the king's wife and sovereignty. He is mentioned in the iambic verses of  of  who lived about the same time.


So he took possession of the sovereign power and was confirmed in it by the  oracle. For when the  took exception to what was done to , and took up arms, the faction of  came to an agreement with the rest of the people that if the oracle should ordain him king of the , then he would reign; but if not, then he would return the kingship to the .
The oracle did so ordain, and  thus became king. However, the  priestess declared that the  would have vengeance on ' posterity in the fifth generation; an utterance to which the  and their kings paid no regard until it was fulfilled.


Thus the  robbed the  of the sovereignty and took it for themselves. Having gotten it,  sent many offerings to : there are very many silver offerings of his there; and besides the silver, he dedicated a hoard of gold, among which six golden bowls are the offerings especially worthy of mention.
These weigh thirty talents and stand in the treasury of the ; although in truth it is not the treasury of the  people but of  son of . This  then was the first foreigner whom we know who placed offerings at  after the king of ,  son of .
For  too made an offering: namely, the royal seat on which he sat to give judgment, and a marvellous seat it is. It is set in the same place as the bowls of . This gold and the silver offered by  is called by the   after its dedicator.


As soon as  came to the throne, he too, like others, led an army into the lands of  and ; and he took the city of . But as he did nothing else great in his reign of thirty-eight years, I shall say no more of him, and shall speak instead of  son of , who succeeded him. He took  and invaded the country of ; and it was while he was monarch of  that the , driven from their homes by the nomad , came into , and took , all but the acropolis.


 reigned for forty-nine years and was succeeded by his son , who reigned for twelve years; and after  came ,

who waged war against ' descendant  and the , drove the  out of , took  (which was a colony from ), and invaded the lands of . But he did not return from these as he wished, but with great disaster. Of other deeds done by him in his reign, these were the most notable:


He continued the war against the  which his father had begun. This was how he attacked and beseiged : he sent his army, marching to the sound of pipes and harps and bass and treble flutes, to invade when the crops in the land were ripe;

and whenever he came to the  territory, he neither demolished nor burnt nor tore the doors off the country dwellings, but let them stand unharmed; but he destroyed the trees and the crops of the land, and so returned to where he came from;

for as the  had command of the sea, it was of no use for his army to besiege their city. The reason that the  did not destroy the houses was this: that the  might have homes from which to plant and cultivate their land, and that there might be the fruit of their toil for his invading army to lay waste.


He waged war in this way for eleven years, and in these years two great disasters overtook the , one at the battle of  in their own territory, and the other in the valley of the .
For six of these eleven years  son of  was still ruler of , and it was he who invaded the lands of , for it was he who had begun the war; for the following five the war was waged by ' son , who, as I have indicated before, inherited the war from his father and carried it on vigorously.
None of the  helped to lighten this war for the , except the : these lent their aid in return for a similar service done for them; for the  had previously helped the  in their war against the .


In the twelfth year, when the  army was burning the crops, the fire set in the crops, blown by a strong wind, caught the temple of  called  of , and the temple burned to the ground.
For the present no notice was taken of this. But after the army had returned to ,  fell ill; and, as his sickness lasted longer than it should, he sent to  to inquire of the oracle, either at someone's urging or by his own wish to question the god about his sickness.
But when the messengers came to , the  priestess would not answer them before they restored the temple of  at  in the  territory, which they had burnt.


I know this much to be so because the  told me. The  add that  son of , a close friend of the  who then was sovereign of , learned what reply the oracle had given to , and sent a messenger to tell  so that his friend, forewarned, could make his plans accordingly.


The  say it happened so. Then, when the  reply was brought to , he promptly sent a herald to , offering to make a truce with  and the  during his rebuilding of the temple. So the envoy went to . But , forewarned of the whole matter, and knowing what  meant to do, devised the following plan:

he brought together into the marketplace all the food in the city, from private stores and his own, and told the men of  all to drink and celebrate together when he gave the word.

, who disclosed the oracle's answer to , was the son of , and sovereign of . They say that this , who spent most of his time with , wished to sail to  and , and that after he had made a lot of money there he wanted to come back to .
Trusting none more than the , he hired a  vessel to carry him from . But when they were out at sea, the crew plotted to take 's money and cast him overboard. Discovering this, he earnestly entreated them, asking for his life and offering them his money.

The men, pleased at the thought of hearing the best singer in the world, drew away toward the waist of the vessel from the stern. , putting on all his regalia and taking his lyre, stood up on the half-deck and sang the Stirring Song, and when the song was finished he threw himself into the sea, as he was with all his regalia.

, skeptical, kept him in confinement, letting him go nowhere, and waited for the sailors. When they arrived, they were summoned and asked what news they brought of . While they were saying that he was safe in  and that they had left him flourishing at ,  appeared before them, just as he was when he jumped from the ship; astonished, they could no longer deny what was proved against them.
This is what the  and  say, and there is a little bronze memorial of  on , the figure of a man riding upon a dolphin.


 the , his war with the  finished, died after a reign of fifty-seven years.
He was the second of his family to make an offering to  (after recovering from his illness) of a great silver bowl on a stand of welded iron. Among all the offerings at , this is the most worth seeing, and is the work of  the , the only one of all men who discovered how to weld iron.


After the death of , his son , then thirty-five years of age, came to the throne. The first  whom he attacked were the .

Then, when he had subjugated all the  of the mainland and made them tributary to him, he planned to build ships and attack the islanders;

but when his preparations for shipbuilding were underway, either  of  or  of  (the story is told of both) came to  and, asked by  for news about , put an end to the shipbuilding by giving the following answer:

O King, the islanders are buying ten thousand horse, intending to march to  against you. , thinking that he spoke the truth, said: Would that the gods would put this in the heads of the islanders, to come on horseback against the sons of the ! Then the other answered and said:

O King, you appear to me earnestly to wish to catch the islanders riding horses on the mainland, a natural wish. And what else do you suppose the islanders wished, as soon as they heard that you were building ships to attack them, than to catch  on the seas, so as to be revenged on you for the  who dwell on the mainland, whom you enslaved?

 was quite pleased with this conclusion, for he thought the man spoke reasonably and, heeding him, stopped building ships. Thus he made friends with the  inhabiting the islands.


As time went on,  subjugated almost all the nations west of the ; for except the  and , all the rest  held subject under him. These were the , , , , , , the  and , , , , , and ;


and after these were subdued and subject to  in addition to the , all the sages from  who were living at that time, coming in different ways, came to , which was at the height of its property; and among them came  the , who, after making laws for the  at their request, went abroad for ten years, sailing forth to see the world, he said. This he did so as not to be compelled to repeal any of the laws he had made,

since the  themselves could not do that, for they were bound by solemn oaths to abide for ten years by whatever laws  should make.


So for that reason, and to see the world,  went to visit  in  and then to  in . When he got there,  entertained him in the palace, and on the third or fourth day  told his attendants to show  around his treasures, and they pointed out all those things that were great and blest.
After  had seen everything and had thought about it,  found the opportunity to say, My  guest, we have heard a lot about you because of your wisdom and of your wanderings, how as one who loves learning you have traveled much of the world for the sake of seeing it, so now I desire to ask you who is the most fortunate man you have seen.

 asked this question believing that he was the most fortunate of men, but , offering no flattery but keeping to the truth, said, O King, it is  the .

 was amazed at what he had said and replied sharply, In what way do you judge  to be the most fortunate?  said,  was from a prosperous city, and his children were good and noble. He saw children born to them all, and all of these survived. His life was prosperous by our standards, and his death was most glorious:

when the  were fighting their neighbors in , he came to help, routed the enemy, and died very finely. The  buried him at public expense on the spot where he fell and gave him much honor.


When  had provoked him by saying that the affairs of  were so fortunate,  asked who he thought was next, fully expecting to win second prize.  answered,  and .
They were of  stock, had enough to live on, and on top of this had great bodily strength. Both had won prizes in the athletic contests, and this story is told about them: there was a festival of  in , and their mother absolutely had to be conveyed to the temple by a team of oxen. But their oxen had not come back from the fields in time, so the youths took the yoke upon their own shoulders under constraint of time. They drew the wagon, with their mother riding atop it, traveling five miles until they arrived at the temple.
When they had done this and had been seen by the entire gathering, their lives came to an excellent end, and in their case the god made clear that for human beings it is a better thing to die than to live. The  men stood around the youths and congratulated them on their strength; the  women congratulated their mother for having borne such children.
She was overjoyed at the feat and at the praise, so she stood before the image and prayed that the goddess might grant the best thing for man to her children  and , who had given great honor to the goddess.
After this prayer they sacrificed and feasted. The youths then lay down in the temple and went to sleep and never rose again; death held them there. The  made and dedicated at  statues of them as being the best of men.


Thus  granted second place in happiness to these men.  was vexed and said, My  guest, do you so much despise our happiness that you do not even make us worth as much as common men?  replied, , you ask me about human affairs, and I know that the divine is entirely grudging and troublesome to us.
In a long span of time it is possible to see many things that you do not want to, and to suffer them, too. I set the limit of a man's life at seventy years;

these seventy years have twenty-five thousand, two hundred days, leaving out the intercalary month. But if you make every other year longer by one month, so that the seasons agree opportunely, then there are thirty-five intercalary months during the seventy years, and from these months there are one thousand fifty days.
Out of all these days in the seventy years, all twenty-six thousand, two hundred and fifty of them, not one brings anything at all like another. So, , man is entirely chance.
To me you seem to be very rich and to be king of many people, but I cannot answer your question before I learn that you ended your life well. The very rich man is not more fortunate than the man who has only his daily needs, unless he chances to end his life with all well. Many very rich men are unfortunate, many of moderate means are lucky.
The man who is very rich but unfortunate surpasses the lucky man in only two ways, while the lucky surpasses the rich but unfortunate in many. The rich man is more capable of fulfilling his appetites and of bearing a great disaster that falls upon him, and it is in these ways that he surpasses the other. The lucky man is not so able to support disaster or appetite as is the rich man, but his luck keeps these things away from him, and he is free from deformity and disease, has no experience of evils, and has fine children and good looks.
If besides all this he ends his life well, then he is the one whom you seek, the one worthy to be called fortunate. But refrain from calling him fortunate before he dies; call him lucky.
It is impossible for one who is only human to obtain all these things at the same time, just as no land is self-sufficient in what it produces. Each country has one thing but lacks another; whichever has the most is the best. Just so no human being is self-sufficient; each person has one thing but lacks another.
Whoever passes through life with the most and then dies agreeably is the one who, in my opinion, O King, deserves to bear this name. It is necessary to see how the end of every affair turns out, for the god promises fortune to many people and then utterly ruins them.


By saying this,  did not at all please , who sent him away without regard for him, but thinking him a great fool, because he ignored the present good and told him to look to the end of every affair.


But after 's departure divine retribution fell heavily on ; as I guess, because he supposed himself to be blessed beyond all other men. Directly, as he slept, he had a dream, which showed him the truth of the evil things which were going to happen concerning his son.
He had two sons, one of whom was ruined, for he was mute, but the other, whose name was , was by far the best in every way of all of his peers. The dream showed this  to , how he would lose him struck and killed by a spear of iron.
So , after he awoke and considered, being frightened by the dream, brought in a wife for his son, and although  was accustomed to command the  armies,  now would not send him out on any such enterprise, while he took the javelins and spears and all such things that men use for war from the men's apartments and piled them in his store room, lest one should fall on his son from where it hung.


Now while  was occupied with the marriage of his son, a  of the royal house came to , in great distress and with unclean hands. This man came to ' house, and asked to be purified according to the custom of the country; so  purified him (

the  have the same manner of purification as the ), and when he had done everything customary, he asked the  where he came from and who he was:

Friend, he said, who are you, and from what place in  do you come as my suppliant? And what man or woman have you killed? O King, the man answered, I am the son of  the son of , and my name is ; I killed my brother accidentally, and I come here banished by my father and deprived of all.

 answered, All of your family are my friends, and you have come to friends, where you shall lack nothing, staying in my house. As for your misfortune, bear it as lightly as possible and you will gain most.


So  lived in ' house. About this same time a great monster of a boar appeared on the , who would come off that mountain and ravage the fields of the . The  had gone up against him often; but they never did him any harm but were hurt by him themselves.
At last they sent messengers to , with this message: O King, a great monster of a boar has appeared in the land, who is destroying our fields; for all our attempts, we cannot kill him; so now we ask you to send your son and chosen young men and dogs with us, so that we may drive him out of the country.
Such was their request, but  remembered the prophecy of his dream and answered them thus: Do not mention my son again: I will not send him with you. He is newly married, and that is his present concern. But I will send chosen , and all the huntsmen, and I will tell those who go to be as eager as possible to help you to drive the beast out of the country.


This was his answer, and the  were satisfied with it. But the son of  now entered, having heard what the  had asked for; and when  refused to send his son with them, the young man said,

Father, it was once thought very fine and noble for us to go to war and the chase and win renown; but now you have barred me from both of these, although you have seen neither cowardice nor lack of spirit in me. With what face can I now show myself whenever I go to and from the market-place?
What will the men of the city think of me, and what my newly wedded wife? With what kind of man will she think that she lives? So either let me go to the hunt, or show me by reasoning that what you are doing is best for me.


My son, answered , I do this not because I have seen cowardice or anything unseemly in you, but the vision of a dream stood over me in my sleep, and told me that you would be short-lived, for you would be killed by a spear of iron.
It is because of that vision that I hurried your marriage and do not send you on any enterprise that I have in hand, but keep guard over you, so that perhaps I may rob death of you during my lifetime. You are my only son: for that other, since he is ruined, he doesn't exist for me.


Father, the youth replied, no one can blame you for keeping guard over me, when you have seen such a vision; but it is my right to show you what you do not perceive, and why you mistake the meaning of the dream.
You say that the dream told you that I should be killed by a spear of iron? But has a boar hands? Has it that iron spear which you dread? Had the dream said I should be killed by a tusk or some other thing proper to a boar, you would be right in acting as you act; but no, it was to be by a spear. Therefore, since it is not against men that we are to fight, let me go.


 answered, My son, your judgment concerning the dream has somewhat reassured me; and being reassured by you, I change my thinking and permit you to go to the chase.


Having said this,  sent for  the  and when he came addressed him thus: , when you were struck by ugly misfortune, for which I do not blame you, it was I who cleansed you, and received and still keep you in my house, defraying all your keep.
Now then, as you owe me a return of good service for the good which I have done you, I ask that you watch over my son as he goes out to the chase. See that no thieving criminals meet you on the way, to do you harm.
Besides, it is only right that you too should go where you can win renown by your deeds. That is fitting for your father's son; and you are strong enough besides.


O King,  answered, I would not otherwise have gone into such an arena. One so unfortunate as I should not associate with the prosperous among his peers; nor have I the wish so to do, and for many reasons I would have held back.
But now, since you urge it and I must please you (since I owe you a return of good service), I am ready to do this; and as for your son, in so far as I can protect him, look for him to come back unharmed.


So when  had answered  thus, they went out provided with chosen young men and dogs. When they came to , they hunted for the beast and, finding him, formed a circle and threw their spears at him:

then the guest called , the man who had been cleansed of the deed of blood, missed the boar with his spear and hit the son of .

Distraught by the death of his son,  cried out the more vehemently because the killer was one whom he himself had cleansed of blood,

and in his great and terrible grief at this mischance he called on  by three names, , : the first, because he wanted the god to know what evil his guest had done him; the second, because he had received the guest into his house and thus unwittingly entertained the murderer of his son; and the third, because he had found his worst enemy in the man whom he had sent as a protector.

But it is not you that I hold the cause of this evil, except in so far as you were the unwilling doer of it, but one of the gods, the same one who told me long ago what was to be.

After his gifts to the ,  made a third inquiry of the oracle, for he wanted to use it to the full, having received true answers from it; and the question which he asked was whether his sovereignty would be of long duration. To this the  priestess answered as follows:






When he heard these verses,  was pleased with them above all, for he thought that a mule would never be king of the  instead of a man, and therefore that he and his posterity would never lose his empire. He found by inquiry that the chief peoples were the  among those of , and the  among those of  stock. These races,  and , were the foremost in ancient time, the first a  and the second a  people. The  race has never yet left its home; the  has wandered often and far.

What language the  spoke I cannot say definitely. But if one may judge by those that still remain of the  who live above the  in the city of who were once neighbors of the people now called , and at that time inhabited the country which now is called 

and of the  who inhabited  and  on the , who came to live among the , and by other towns too which were once  and afterwards took a different name: if, as I said, one may judge by these, the  spoke a language which was not .
If, then, all the  stock spoke so, then the Attic nation, being of  blood, must have changed its language too at the time when it became part of the . For the people of  and  have a language of their own in common, which is not the language of their neighbors; and it is plain that they still preserve the manner of speech which they brought with them in their migration into the places where they live.


But the  stock, it seems clear to me, has always had the same language since its beginning; yet being, when separated from the , few in number, they have grown from a small beginning to comprise a multitude of nations, chiefly because the  and many other foreign peoples united themselves with them. Now of these two peoples,  learned that the Attic was held in subjection and divided into factions by , son of , who at that time was sovereign over the . This  was still a private man when a great marvel happened to him when he was at  to see the games: when he had offered the sacrifice, the vessels, standing there full of meat and water, boiled without fire until they boiled over.

 the , who happened to be there and who saw this marvel, advised  not to take to his house a wife who could bear children, but if he had one already, then to send her away, and if he had a son, to disown him.

 refused to follow the advice of ; and afterward there was born to him this , who, when there was a feud between the  of the coast under  son of  and the  of the plain under  son of , raised up a third faction, as he coveted the sovereign power. He collected partisans and pretended to champion the uplanders, and the following was his plan.
Wounding himself and his mules, he drove his wagon into the marketplace, with a story that he had escaped from his enemies, who would have killed him (so he said) as he was driving into the country. So he implored the people to give him a guard: and indeed he had won a reputation in his command of the army against the , when he had taken  and performed other great exploits.

These rose with  and took the Acropolis; and  ruled the , disturbing in no way the order of offices nor changing the laws, but governing the city according to its established constitution and arranging all things fairly and well.


But after a short time the partisans of  and of  made common cause and drove him out. In this way  first got  and, as he had a sovereignty that was not yet firmly rooted, lost it. Presently his enemies who together had driven him out began to feud once more.
Then , harassed by factional strife, sent a message to  offering him his daughter to marry and the sovereign power besides.
When this offer was accepted by , who agreed on these terms with , they devised a plan to bring  back which, to my mind, was so exceptionally foolish that it is strange (since from old times the  stock has always been distinguished from foreign by its greater cleverness and its freedom from silly foolishness) that these men should devise such a plan to deceive , said to be the subtlest of the .
There was in the  deme a woman called , three fingers short of six feet, four inches in height, and otherwise, too, well-formed. This woman they equipped in full armor and put in a chariot, giving her all the paraphernalia to make the most impressive spectacle, and so drove into the city; heralds ran before them, and when they came into town proclaimed as they were instructed:

, give a hearty welcome to , whom  herself honors above all men and is bringing back to her own acropolis. So the heralds went about proclaiming this; and immediately the report spread in the demes that  was bringing  back, and the townsfolk, believing that the woman was the goddess herself, worshipped this human creature and welcomed .


Having got back his sovereignty in the manner which I have described,  married ' daughter according to his agreement with . But as he already had young sons, and as the  family were said to be under a curse, he had no wish that his newly-wedded wife bear him children, and therefore had unusual intercourse with her.
At first the woman hid the fact: presently she told her mother (whether interrogated or not, I do not know) and the mother told her husband.  was very angry to be dishonored by ; and in his anger he patched up his quarrel with the other faction. , learning what was going on, went alone away from the country altogether, and came to  where he deliberated with his sons.
The opinion of  prevailing, that they should recover the sovereignty, they set out collecting contributions from all the cities that owed them anything. Many of these gave great amounts, the  more than any,

and in course of time, not to make a long story, everything was ready for their return: for they brought  mercenaries from the , and there joined them on his own initiative a man of  called , who was most keen in their cause and brought them money and men.


So after ten years they set out from  and returned home. The first place in  which they took and held was Marathon: and while encamped there they were joined by their partisans from the city, and by others who flocked to them from the countrydemesmen who loved the rule of one more than freedom. These, then, assembled;

but the  in the city, who while  was collecting money and afterwards when he had taken Marathon took no notice of it, did now, and when they learned that he was marching from Marathon against , they set out to attack him.
They came out with all their force to meet the returning exiles. ' men encountered the enemy when they had reached the temple of  in their march from Marathon towards the city, and encamped face to face with them.
There (by the providence of heaven)  met  the , a diviner, who came to him and prophesied as follows in hexameter verses:




So  spoke, being inspired;  understood him and, saying that he accepted the prophecy, led his army against the enemy. The  of the city had by this time had breakfast, and after breakfast some were dicing and some were sleeping: they were attacked by ' men and put to flight.

The  did, and by this means  gained  for the third time, rooting his sovereignty in a strong guard and revenue collected both from  and from the district of the river , and he took hostage the sons of the  who remained and did not leave the city at once, and placed these in .

So  learned that at that time such problems were oppressing the , but that the  had escaped from the great evils and had mastered the  in war. In the kingship of  and  at , the  were successful in all their other wars but met disaster only against the .
Before this they had been the worst-governed of nearly all the  and had had no dealings with strangers, but they changed to good government in this way: , a man of reputation among the , went to the oracle at . As soon as he entered the hall, the priestess said in hexameter:

Thus they changed their bad laws to good ones, and when  died they built him a temple and now worship him greatly. Since they had good land and many men, they immediately flourished and prospered. When the  heard the oracle reported, they left the other  alone and marched on  carrying chains, relying on the deceptive oracle. They were confident they would enslave the , but they were defeated in battle.

In the previous war the  continually fought unsuccessfully against the , but in the time of  and the kingship of  and  in  the  had gained the upper hand. This is how:

when they kept being defeated by the , they sent ambassadors to  to ask which god they should propitiate to prevail against the  in war. The  responded that they should bring back the bones of , son of .
When they were unable to discover ' tomb, they sent once more to the god to ask where he was buried. The  responded in hexameter to the messengers:




When the  heard this, they were no closer to discovery, though they looked everywhere. Finally it was found by , who was one of the  who are called doers of good deeds.. These men are those citizens who retire from the knights, the five oldest each year. They have to spend the year in which they retire from the knights being sent here and there by the  state, never resting in their efforts.


It was , one of these men, who found the tomb in  by a combination of luck and skill. At that time there was free access to , so he went into a blacksmith's shop and watched iron being forged, standing there in amazement at what he saw done.
The smith perceived that he was amazed, so he stopped what he was doing and said, My  guest, if you had seen what I saw, then you would really be amazed, since you marvel so at ironworking.
I wanted to dig a well in the courtyard here, and in my digging I hit upon a coffin twelve feet long. I could not believe that there had ever been men taller than now, so I opened it and saw that the corpse was just as long as the coffin. I measured it and then reburied it. So the smith told what he had seen, and  thought about what was said and reckoned that this was , according to the oracle.
In the smith's two bellows he found the winds, hammer and anvil were blow upon blow, and the forging of iron was woe upon woe, since he figured that iron was discovered as an evil for the human race.
After reasoning this out, he went back to  and told the  everything. They made a pretence of bringing a charge against him and banishing him. Coming to , he explained his misfortune to the smith and tried to rent the courtyard, but the smith did not want to lease it.
Finally he persuaded him and set up residence there. He dug up the grave and collected the bones, then hurried off to  with them. Ever since then the  were far superior to the  whenever they met each other in battle. By the time of ' inquiry, the  had subdued most of the .


, then, aware of all this, sent messengers to  with gifts to ask for an alliance, having instructed them what to say. They came and said:

but the  themselves say that the  who were bringing the bowl, coming too late, and learning that  and  were taken, sold it in  to certain private men, who set it up in the the temple of . , mistaking the meaning of the oracle, invaded , expecting to destroy  and the  power.
But while he was preparing to march against the , a certain , who was already held to be a wise man, and who, from the advice which he now gave, won a great name among the , advised him as follows (his name was ): O King, you are getting ready to march against men who wear trousers of leather and whose complete wardrobe is of leather, and who eat not what they like but what they have; for their land is stony.
Further, they do not use wine, but drink water, have no figs to eat, or anything else that is good. Now if you conquer them, of what will you deprive them, since they have nothing? But if on the other hand you are conquered, then look how many good things you will lose; for once they have tasted of our blessings they will cling so tightly to them that nothing will pry them away.
For myself, then, I thank the gods that they do not put it in the heads of the  to march against the .  spoke thus but he did not persuade . Indeed, before they conquered the , the  had no luxury and no comforts.


Now the  are called by the , and these  before the  rule were subjects of the , and, at this time, of .

The reasons for ' expedition against  were these: he desired to gain territory in addition to his own, and (these were the chief causes) he trusted the oracle and wished to avenge  on ; for , son of , had conquered  and held him in subjection.

This was then ruled by , son of , son of .  at first treated the  kindly, as suppliants for his mercy; and, as he had a high regard for them, he entrusted boys to their tutelage to be taught their language and the skill of archery.

The , feeling themselves wronged by the treatment they had from , planned to take one of the boys who were their pupils and cut him in pieces; then, dressing the flesh as they were accustomed to dress the animals which they killed, to bring and give it to  as if it were the spoils of the hunt; and after that, to make their way with all speed to  son of  at .  and the guests who ate with him dined on the boy's flesh, and the , having done as they planned, fled to  for protection.


After this, since  would not give up the  to  at his demand, there was war between the  and the  for five years; each won many victories over the other, and once they fought a battle by night.
They were still warring with equal success, when it happened, at an encounter which occurred in the sixth year, that during the battle the day was suddenly turned to night.  of  had foretold this loss of daylight to the , fixing it within the year in which the change did indeed happen.
So when the  and  saw the day turned to night, they stopped fighting, and both were the more eager to make peace. Those who reconciled them were  the  and  the ;

they brought it about that there should be a sworn agreement and a compact of marriage between them: they judged that  should give his daughter  to , son of ; for without strong constraint agreements will not keep their force.
These nations make sworn compacts as do the ; and besides, when they cut the skin of their arms, they lick each other's blood.


 had subjugated this , then, ' own mother's father, for the reason which I shall presently disclose.
Having this reason to quarrel with ,  sent to ask the oracles if he should march against the ; and when a deceptive answer came he thought it to be favorable to him, and so led his army into the  territory.
When he came to the river , he transported his army across itby the bridges which were there then, as I maintain; but the general belief of the  is that  of  got the army across.
The story is that, as  did not know how his army could pass the river (as the aforesaid bridges did not yet exist then), , who was in the encampment, made the river, which flowed on the left of the army, also flow on the right, in the following way.
Starting from a point on the river upstream from the camp, he dug a deep semi-circular trench, so that the stream, turned from its ancient course, would flow in the trench to the rear of the camp and, passing it, would issue into its former bed, with the result that as soon as the river was thus divided into two, both channels could be forded.
Some even say that the ancient channel dried up altogether. But I do not believe this; for in that case, how did they pass the river when they were returning?


Passing over with his army,  then came to the part of  called  (it is the strongest part of this country and lies on the line of the city of  on the ), where he encamped and devastated the farms of the ;

and he took and enslaved the city of the , and took all the places around it also, and drove the  from their homes, though they had done him no harm. , mustering his army, advanced to oppose , gathering to him all those who lived along the way.
But before beginning his march, he sent heralds to the  to try to draw them away from . The  would not be prevailed on; but when  arrived and encamped face to face with , there in the  country the armies had a trial of strength.
The fighting was fierce, many on both sides fell, and at nightfall they disengaged with neither side victorious. The two sides contended thus.


 was not content with the size of his force, for his army that had engaged was far smaller than that of ; therefore, when on the day after the battle  did not try attacking again, he marched away to , intending to summon the  in accordance with their treaty 

(for before making an alliance with the  he had made one also with  king of ), and to send for the  also (for with these too he had made an alliance,  at this time being their sovereign),

and to summon the  to join him at a fixed time. He had in mind to muster all these forces and assemble his own army, then to wait until the winter was over and march against the  at the beginning of spring.
With such an intention, as soon as he returned to , he sent heralds to all his allies, summoning them to assemble at  in five months' time; and as for the soldiers whom he had with him, who had fought with the , all of them who were mercenaries he discharged, never thinking that after a contest so equal  would march against .


This was how  reasoned. Meanwhile, snakes began to swarm in the outer part of the city; and when they appeared the horses, leaving their accustomed pasture, devoured them. When  saw this he thought it a portent, and so it was.
He at once sent to the homes of the  interpreters, to inquire concerning it; but though his messengers came and learned from the  what the portent meant, they could not bring back word to , for he was a prisoner before they could make their voyage back to .
Nonetheless, this was the judgment of the : that  must expect a foreign army to attack his country, and that when it came, it would subjugate the inhabitants of the land: for the snake, they said, was the offspring of the land, but the horse was an enemy and a foreigner. This was the answer which the  gave , knowing as yet nothing of the fate of  and of the king himself; but when they gave it,  was already taken.


When  marched away after the battle in the  country, , learning that  had gone intending to disband his army, deliberated and perceived that it would be opportune for him to march quickly against , before the power of the  could be assembled again.
This he decided, and this he did immediately; he marched his army into  and so came himself to bring the news of it to . All had turned out contrary to ' expectation, and he was in a great quandary; nevertheless, he led out the  to battle.
Now at this time there was no nation in  more valiant or warlike than the . It was their custom to fight on horseback, carrying long spears, and they were skillful at managing horses.


So the armies met in the plain, wide and bare, that is before the city of : the  and other rivers flow across it and run violently together into the greatest of them, which is called  (this flows from the mountain sacred to the Mother  and empties into the sea near the city of ).
When  saw the  maneuvering their battle-lines here, he was afraid of their cavalry, and therefore at the urging of one , a , he did as I shall describe. Assembling all the camels that followed his army bearing food and baggage, he took off their burdens and mounted men upon them equipped like cavalrymen; having equipped them, he ordered them to advance before his army against ' cavalry; he directed the infantry to follow the camels, and placed all his cavalry behind the infantry.
When they were all in order, he commanded them to kill all the other  who came in their way, and spare none, but not to kill  himself, even if he should defend himself against capture.
Such was his command. The reason for his posting the camels to face the cavalry was this: horses fear camels and can endure neither the sight nor the smell of them; this then was the intention of his maneuver, that ' cavalry, on which the  relied to distinguish himself, might be of no use.
So when battle was joined, as soon as the horses smelled and saw the camels they turned to flight, and all ' hope was lost.
Nevertheless the  were no cowards; when they saw what was happening, they leaped from their horses and fought the  on foot. Many of both armies fell; at length the  were routed and driven within their city wall, where they were besieged by the .


So then they were besieged. But , supposing that the siege would last a long time, again sent messengers from the city to his allies; whereas the former envoys had been sent to summon them to muster at  in five months' time, these were to announce that  was besieged and to plead for help as quickly as possible.


So he sent to the  as well as to the rest of the allies. Now at this very time the  themselves were feuding with the  over the country called ;

for this was a part of the  territory which the  had cut off and occupied. (All the land towards the west, as far as , belonged then to the , and not only the mainland, but the island of  and the other islands.)
The  came out to save their territory from being cut off, then after debate the two armies agreed that three hundred of each side should fight, and whichever party won would possess the land. The rest of each army was to go away to its own country and not be present at the battle, since, if the armies remained on the field, the men of either party might render assistance to their comrades if they saw them losing.
Having agreed, the armies drew off, and picked men of each side remained and fought. Neither could gain advantage in the battle; at last, only three out of the six hundred were left,  and  of the ,  of the : these three were left alive at nightfall.
Then the two , believing themselves victors, ran to ; but  the , after stripping the  dead and taking the arms to his camp, waited at his position. On the second day both armies came to learn the issue.
For a while both claimed the victory, the  arguing that more of their men had survived, the  showing that the  had fled, while their man had stood his ground and stripped the enemy dead.
At last from arguing they fell to fighting; many of both sides fell, but the  gained the victory. The , who before had worn their hair long by fixed custom, shaved their heads ever after and made a law, with a curse added to it, that no  grow his hair, and no  woman wear gold, until they recovered ;

and the  made a contrary law, that they wear their hair long ever after; for until now they had not worn it so. , the lone survivor of the three hundred, was ashamed, it is said, to return to  after all the men of his company had been killed, and killed himself on the spot at .


The  herald came after this had happened to the  to ask for their help for , now besieged; nonetheless, when they heard the herald, they prepared to send help; but when they were already equipped and their ships ready, a second message came that the fortification of the  was taken and  a prisoner.
