This is how  was taken. When  had been besieged for fourteen days,  sent horsemen around in his army to promise to reward whoever first mounted the wall.
After this the army made an assault, but with no success. Then, when all the others were stopped, a certain  called  attempted to mount by a part of the acropolis where no guard had been set, since no one feared that it could be taken by an attack made here.
For here the height on which the acropolis stood is sheer and unlikely to be assaulted; this was the only place where  the former king of  had not carried the lion which his concubine had borne him, the  having declared that if this lion were carried around the walls,  could never be taken.  then carried the lion around the rest of the wall of the acropolis where it could be assaulted, but neglected this place, because the height was sheer and defied attack. It is on the side of the city which faces towards .
The day before, then, , this , had seen one of the  come down by this part of the acropolis after a helmet that had fallen down, and fetch it; he took note of this and considered it.
And now he climbed up himself, and other  after him. Many ascended, and thus  was taken and all the city sacked.


I will now relate what happened to  himself. He had a son, whom I have already mentioned, fine in other respects, but mute. Now in his days of prosperity past  had done all that he could for his son; and besides resorting to other devices he had sent to  to inquire of the oracle concerning him.
The  priestess answered him thus:


So at the taking of the fortification a certain , not knowing who  was, came at him meaning to kill him.  saw him coming, but because of the imminent disaster he was past caring, and it made no difference to him whether he were struck and killed.
But this mute son, when he saw the  coming on, in fear and distress broke into speech and cried, Man, do not kill ! This was the first word he uttered, and after that for all the rest of his life he had power of speech.


The  gained  and took  prisoner.  had ruled fourteen years and been besieged fourteen days. Fulfilling the oracle, he had destroyed his own great empire. The  took him and brought him to ,

who erected a pyre and mounted  atop it, bound in chains, with twice seven sons of the  beside him.  may have intended to sacrifice him as a victory-offering to some god, or he may have wished to fulfill a vow, or perhaps he had heard that  was pious and put him atop the pyre to find out if some divinity would deliver him from being burned alive.
So  did this. As  stood on the pyre, even though he was in such a wretched position it occurred to him that  had spoken with god's help when he had said that no one among the living is fortunate. When this occurred to him, he heaved a deep sigh and groaned aloud after long silence, calling out three times the name .

 heard and ordered the interpreters to ask  who he was invoking. They approached and asked, but  kept quiet at their questioning, until finally they forced him and he said, I would prefer to great wealth his coming into discourse with all despots. Since what he said was unintelligible, they again asked what he had said,

persistently harassing him. He explained that first  the  had come and seen all his fortune and spoken as if he despised it. Now everything had turned out for him as  had said, speaking no more of him than of every human being, especially those who think themselves fortunate. While  was relating all this, the pyre had been lit and the edges were on fire.
When  heard from the interpreters what  said, he relented and considered that he, a human being, was burning alive another human being, one his equal in good fortune. In addition, he feared retribution, reflecting how there is nothing stable in human affairs. He ordered that the blazing fire be extinguished as quickly as possible, and that  and those with him be taken down, but despite their efforts they could not master the fire.


Then the  say that  understood ' change of heart, and when he saw everyone trying to extinguish the fire but unable to check it, he invoked , crying out that if  had ever been given any pleasing gift by him, let him offer help and deliver him from the present evil.
Thus he in tears invoked the god, and suddenly out of a clear and windless sky clouds gathered, a storm broke, and it rained violently, extinguishing the pyre. Thus  perceived that  was dear to god and a good man. He had him brought down from the pyre and asked,

, what man persuaded you to wage war against my land and become my enemy instead of my friend? He replied, O King, I acted thus for your good fortune, but for my own ill fortune. The god of the  is responsible for these things, inciting me to wage war.
No one is so foolish as to choose war over peace. In peace sons bury their fathers, in war fathers bury their sons. But I suppose it was dear to the divinity that this be so.


 said this, and  freed him and made him sit near and was very considerate to him, and both he and all that were with him were astonished when they looked at . He for his part was silent, deep in thought.
Presently he turned and said (for he saw the  sacking the city of the ), O King, am I to say to you what is in my mind now, or keep silent? When  urged him to speak up boldly,  asked,

The multitude there, what is it at which they are so busily engaged? They are plundering your city, said , and carrying off your possessions. No,  answered, not my city, and not my possessions; for I no longer have any share of all this; it is your wealth that they are pillaging.


 thought about what  had said and, telling the rest to withdraw, asked  what fault he saw in what was being done. Since the gods have made me your slave, replied the , it is right that if I have any further insight I should point it out to you.
The  being by nature violent men are poor; so if you let them seize and hold great possessions, you may expect that he who has got most will revolt against you. Therefore do this, if you like what I say.
Have men of your guard watch all the gates; let them take the spoil from those who are carrying it out, and say that it must be paid as a tithe to . Thus you shall not be hated by them for taking their wealth by force, and they, recognizing that you act justly, will give up the spoil willingly.


When  heard this, he was exceedingly pleased, for he believed the advice good; and praising him greatly, and telling his guard to act as  had advised, he said: , now that you, a king, are determined to act and to speak with integrity, ask me directly for whatever favor you like.

Master, said , you will most gratify me if you will let me send these chains of mine to that god of the  whom I especially honored and to ask him if it is his way to deceive those who serve him well. When  asked him what grudge against the god led him to make this request,

 repeated to him the story of all his own aspirations, and the answers of the oracles, and more particularly his offerings, and how the oracle had encouraged him to attack the ; and so saying he once more insistently pled that he be allowed to reproach the god for this. At this  smiled, and replied, This I will grant you, , and whatever other favor you may ever ask me.
When  heard this, he sent  to , telling them to lay his chains on the doorstep of the temple, and to ask the god if he were not ashamed to have persuaded  to attack the , telling him that he would destroy ' power; of which power (they were to say, showing the chains) these were the first-fruits. They should ask this; and further, if it were the way of the  gods to be ungrateful.


When the  came, and spoke as they had been instructed, the priestess (it is said) made the following reply. No one may escape his lot, not even a god.  has paid for the sin of his ancestor of the fifth generation before, who was led by the guile of a woman to kill his master, though he was one of the guard of the , and who took to himself the royal state of that master, to which he had no right.
And it was the wish of  that the evil lot of  fall in the lifetime of ' sons, not in his own; but he could not deflect the Fates.
Yet as far as they gave in, he did accomplish his wish and favor : for he delayed the taking of  for three years. And let  know this: that although he is now taken, it is by so many years later than the destined hour. And further,  saved  from burning.
But as to the oracle that was given to him,  is wrong to complain concerning it. For  declared to him that if he led an army against the , he would destroy a great empire. Therefore he ought, if he had wanted to plan well, to have sent and asked whether the god spoke of ' or of ' empire. But he did not understood what was spoken, or make further inquiry: for which now let him blame himself.
When he asked that last question of the oracle and  gave him that answer concerning the mule, even that  did not understand. For that mule was in fact , who was the son of two parents not of the same people, of whom the mother was better and the father inferior:

for she was a  and the daughter of  king of the ; but he was a  and a subject of the  and although in all respects her inferior he married this lady of his. This was the answer of the priestess to the . They carried it to  and told , and when he heard it, he confessed that the sin was not the god's, but his. And this is the story of ' rule, and of the first overthrow of .


There are many offerings of ' in , and not only those of which I have spoken. There is a golden tripod at  in , which he dedicated to  of ; at  there are the oxen of gold and the greater part of the pillars; and in the temple of  at , a golden shield. All these survived to my lifetime; but other of the offerings were destroyed.
And the offerings of  at  of the , as I learn by inquiry, are equal in weight and like those at . Those which he dedicated at  and the shrine of  were his own, the first-fruits of the wealth inherited from his father; the rest came from the estate of an enemy who had headed a faction against  before he became king, and conspired to win the throne of  for .
This  was a son of , and half-brother of :  was ' son by a  and  by an  mother.
So when  gained the sovereignty by his father's gift, he put the man who had conspired against him to death by drawing him across a carding-comb, and first confiscated his estate, then dedicated it as and where I have said. This is all that I shall say of ' offerings.


There are not many marvellous things in  to record, in comparison with other countries, except the gold dust that comes down from .
But there is one building to be seen there which is much the greatest of all, except those of  and . In  is the tomb of , the father of , the base of which is made of great stones and the rest of it of mounded earth. It was built by the men of the market and the craftsmen and the prostitutes.
There survived until my time five corner-stones set on the top of the tomb, and in these was cut the record of the work done by each group: and measurement showed that the prostitutes' share of the work was the greatest.
All the daughters of the common people of  ply the trade of prostitutes, to collect dowries, until they can get themselves husbands; and they themselves offer themselves in marriage.
Now this tomb has a circumference of thirteen hundred and ninety yards, and its breadth is above four hundred and forty yards; and there is a great lake hard by the tomb, which, the  say, is fed by ever-flowing springs; it is called the . Such then is this tomb.


The customs of the  are like those of the , except that they make prostitutes of their female children. They were the first men whom we know who coined and used gold and silver currency; and they were the first to sell by retail.
And, according to what they themselves say, the games now in use among them and the  were invented by the : these, they say, were invented among them at the time when they colonized . This is their story:
In the reign of  son of Manes there was great scarcity of food in all . For a while the  bore this with what patience they could; presently, when the famine did not abate, they looked for remedies, and different plans were devised by different men. Then it was that they invented the games of dice and knuckle-bones and ball and all other forms of game except dice, which the  do not claim to have discovered.
Then, using their discovery to lighten the famine, every other day they would play for the whole day, so that they would not have to look for food, and the next day they quit their play and ate. This was their way of life for eighteen years.
But the famine did not cease to trouble them, and instead afflicted them even more. At last their king divided the people into two groups, and made them draw lots, so that the one group should remain and the other leave the country; he himself was to be the head of those who drew the lot to remain there, and his son, whose name was , of those who departed.
Then the one group, having drawn the lot, left the country and came down to  and built ships, in which they loaded all their goods that could be transported aboard ship, and sailed away to seek a livelihood and a country; until at last, after sojourning with one people after another, they came to the , where they founded cities and have lived ever since.
They no longer called themselves , but , after the name of the king's son who had led them there.The , then, were enslaved by the .


But the next business of my history is to inquire who this  was who took down the power of , and how the  came to be the rulers of . I mean then to be guided in what I write by some of the  who desire not to magnify the story of  but to tell the truth, though there are no less than three other accounts of  which I could give.

After the  had ruled Upper  for five hundred and twenty years, the  were the first who began to revolt from them. These, it would seem, proved their bravery in fighting for freedom against the ; they cast off their slavery and won freedom. Afterwards, the other subject nations, too, did the same as the .


All of those on the mainland were now free men; but they came to be ruled by monarchs again, as I will now relate. There was among the  a clever man called : he was the son of .

 was infatuated with sovereignty, and so he set about gaining it. Already a notable man in his own town (one of the many towns into which Media was divided), he began to profess and practice justice more constantly and zealously than ever, and he did this even though there was much lawlessness throughout the land of Media, and though he knew that injustice is always the enemy of justice. Then the  of the same town, seeing his behavior, chose him to be their judge, and he (for he coveted sovereign power) was honest and just.
By acting so, he won no small praise from his fellow townsmen, to such an extent that when the men of the other towns learned that  alone gave fair judgments (having before suffered from unjust decisions), they came often and gladly to plead before ; and at last they would submit to no arbitration but his.


The number of those who came grew ever greater, for they heard that each case turned out in accord with the truth. Then , seeing that everything now depended on him, would not sit in his former seat of judgment, and said he would give no more decisions; for it was of no advantage to him (he said) to leave his own business and spend all day judging the cases of his neighbors.
This caused robbery and lawlessness to increase greatly in the towns; and, gathering together, the  conferred about their present affairs, and said (here, as I suppose, the main speakers were ' friends),

Since we cannot go on living in the present way in the land, come, let us set up a king over us; in this way the land will be well governed, and we ourselves shall attend to our business and not be routed by lawlessness. With such words they persuaded themselves to be ruled by a king.


The question was at once propounded: Whom should they make king? Then every man was loud in putting  forward and praising , until they agreed that he should be their king.
He ordered them to build him houses worthy of his royal power, and strengthen him with a bodyguard. The  did so. They built him a big and strong house wherever in the land he indicated to them, and let him choose a bodyguard out of all the .
And having obtained power, he forced the  to build him one city and to fortify and care for this more strongly than all the rest. The  did this for him, too. So he built the big and strong walls, one standing inside the next in circles, which are now called .
This fortress is so designed that each circle of walls is higher than the next outer circle by no more than the height of its battlements; to which plan the site itself, on a hill in the plain, contributes somewhat, but chiefly it was accomplished by skill.
There are seven circles in all; within the innermost circle are the palace and the treasuries; and the longest wall is about the length of the wall that surrounds the city of . The battlements of the first circle are white, of the second black, of the third circle purple, of the fourth blue, and of the fifth orange:

thus the battlements of five circles are painted with colors; and the battlements of the last two circles are coated, the one with silver and the other with gold.


 built these walls for himself and around his own quarters, and he ordered the people to dwell outside the wall. And when it was all built,  was first to establish the rule that no one should come into the presence of the king, but everything should be done by means of messengers; that the king should be seen by no one; and moreover that it should be a disgrace for anyone to laugh or to spit in his presence.
He was careful to hedge himself with all this so that the men of his own age (who had been brought up with him and were as nobly born as he and his equals in courage), instead of seeing him and being upset and perhaps moved to plot against him, might by reason of not seeing him believe him to be different.


When he had made these arrangements and strengthened himself with sovereign power, he was a hard man in the protection of justice. They would write down their pleas and send them in to him; then he would pass judgment on what was brought to him and send his decisions out.
This was his manner of deciding cases at law, and he had other arrangements too; for when he heard that a man was doing violence he would send for him and punish him as each offense deserved: and he had spies and eavesdroppers everywhere in his domain.


, then, united the Median nation by itself and ruled it. The  tribes are these: the , the , the , the , the , the . Their tribes are this many.


 had a son, , who inherited the throne when  died after a reign of fifty-three years. Having inherited it, he was not content to rule the  alone: marching against the , he attacked them first, and they were the first whom he made subject to the .
Then, with these two strong nations at his back, he subjugated one nation of  after another, until he marched against the ; that is, against those of the  who held . These had formerly been rulers of all; but now their allies had deserted them and they were left alone, though well-off themselves. Marching against these , then,  and most of his army perished, after he had reigned twenty-two years.


At his death he was succeeded by his son . He is said to have been a much greater soldier than his ancestors: it was he who first organized the men of  in companies and posted each arm apart, the spearmen and archers and cavalry: before this they were all mingled together in confusion.
This was the king who fought against the  when the day was turned to night in the battle, and who united under his dominion all of  that is beyond the river . Collecting all his subjects, he marched against , wanting to avenge his father and to destroy the city.
He defeated the  in battle; but while he was besieging their city, a great army of  came down upon him, led by their king  son of . They had invaded  after they had driven the  out of : pursuing them in their flight, the  came to the Median country.


It is a thirty days' journey for an unencumbered man from the  to the river  and the land of the ; from the  it is an easy matter to cross into Media: there is only one nation between, the ; to pass these is to be in Media.
Nevertheless, it was not by this way that the  entered; they turned aside and came by the upper and much longer way, keeping the  on their right. There, the  met the , who defeated them in battle, deprived them of their rule, and made themselves masters of all .


From there they marched against : and when they were in the part of  called ,  king of  met them and persuaded them with gifts and prayers to come no further.
So they turned back, and when they came on their way to the city of  in , most of the  passed by and did no harm, but a few remained behind and plundered the temple of Heavenly .
This temple, I discover from making inquiry, is the oldest of all the temples of the goddess, for the temple in  was founded from it, as the  themselves say; and the temple on  was founded by  from this same land of .
But the  who pillaged the temple, and all their descendants after them, were afflicted by the goddess with the female sickness: and so the  say that they are afflicted as a consequence of this and also that those who visit  territory see among them the condition of those whom the  call Hermaphrodites.


The , then, ruled  for twenty-eight years: and the whole land was ruined because of their violence and their pride, for, besides exacting from each the tribute which was assessed, they rode about the land carrying off everyone's possessions.
Most of them were entertained and made drunk and then slain by  and the : so thus the  took back their empire and all that they had formerly possessed; and they took  (how, I will describe in a later part of my history), and brought all  except the province of  under their rule.


Afterwards,  died after a reign of forty years (among which I count the years of the  domination) and his son  inherited the sovereignty. had a daughter, whom he called : he dreamed that she urinated so much that she filled his city and flooded all of . He communicated this vision to those of the  who interpreted dreams, and when he heard what they told him he was terrified;

and presently, when  was of marriageable age, he feared the vision too much to give her to any  worthy to marry into his family, but married her to a  called , a man whom he knew to be wellborn and of a quiet temper: for  held  to be much lower than a  of middle rank.


But during the first year that  was married to ,  saw a second vision. He dreamed that a vine grew out of the genitals of this daughter, and that the vine covered the whole of .
Having seen this vision, and communicated it to the interpreters of dreams, he sent to the  for his daughter, who was about to give birth, and when she arrived kept her guarded, meaning to kill whatever child she bore: for the interpreters declared that the meaning of his dream was that his daughter's offspring would rule in his place.
Anxious to prevent this, , when  was born, summoned , a man of his household who was his most faithful servant among the  and was administrator of all that was his, and he said:

, whatever business I turn over to you, do not mishandle it, and do not leave me out of account and, giving others preference, trip over your own feet afterwards. Take the child that  bore, and carry him to your house, and kill him; and then bury him however you like.

O King,  answered, never yet have you noticed anything displeasing in your man; and I shall be careful in the future, too, not to err in what concerns you. If it is your will that this be done, then my concern ought to be to attend to it scrupulously.


 answered thus. The child was then given to him, consigned to its death, and he went to his house weeping. When he came in, he told his wife the entire speech uttered by .

Now, then, she said to him, what do you propose to do? Not to obey ' instructions, he answered, not even if he should lose his mind and be more frantic than he is now: I will not lend myself to his plan or be an accessory to such a murder.
There are many reasons why I will not kill him: because the child is related to me, and because  is old and has no male children.
Now if the sovereignty passes to this daughter of his after his death, whose son he is now killing by means of me, what is left for me but the gravest of all dangers? For the sake of my safety this child has to die; but one of ' own people has to be the murderer and not one of mine.


So saying, he sent a messenger at once to one of ' cowherds, who he knew pastured his herds in the likeliest spots and where the mountains were most infested with wild beasts. The man's name was , and his wife was a slave like him; her name was in the  language , in the Median : for spax is the Median word for dog.
The foothills of the mountains where this cowherd pastured his cattle are north of , towards the ; for the rest of Media is everywhere a level plain, but here, on the side of the , the land is very high and mountainous and covered with woods.
So when the cowherd came in haste at the summons,  said:  wants you to take this child and leave it in the most desolate part of the mountains so that it will perish as quickly as possible. And he wants me to tell you that if you do not kill it, but preserve it somehow, you will undergo the most harrowing death; and I am ordered to see it exposed.


Hearing this, the cowherd took the child and went back the same way and came to his dwelling. Now as it happened his wife too had been on the verge of delivering every day, and as the divinity would have it, she did in fact give birth while the cowherd was away in the city. Each of them was anxious for the other, the husband being afraid about his wife's labor, and the wife because she did not know why  had so unexpectedly sent for her husband.
So when he returned and stood before her, she was startled by the unexpected sight and asked him before he could speak why  had so insistently summoned him. Wife, he said, when I came to the city, I saw and heard what I ought never to have seen, and what ought never to have happened to our masters. ' whole house was full of weeping; astonished, I went in;

and immediately I saw a child lying there struggling and crying, adorned in gold and embroidered clothing. And when  saw me, he told me to take the child in haste and bring it away and leave it where the mountains are the most infested with wild beasts. It was , he said, who enjoined this on me, and  threatened me grievously if I did not do it.
So I took him and brought him away, supposing him to be the child of one of the servants; for I could never have guessed whose he was. But I was amazed at seeing him adorned with gold and clothing, and at hearing, too, the evident sound of weeping in the house of .
Very soon on the way I learned the whole story from the servant who brought me out of the city and gave the child into my custody: namely, that it was the son of  the king's daughter and  the son of , and that  gave the command to kill him. And now, here he is.


And as he said this the cowherd uncovered it and showed it. But when the woman saw how fine and fair the child was, she began to cry and laid hold of the man's knees and begged him by no means to expose him. But the husband said he could not do otherwise; for, he said, spies would be coming from  to see what was done, and he would have to die a terrible death if he did not obey.
Being unable to move her husband, the woman then said: Since I cannot convince you not to expose it, then, if a child has to be seen exposed, do this: I too have borne a child, but I bore it dead.
Take this one and put it out, but the child of the daughter of  let us raise as if it were our own; this way, you won't be caught disobeying our masters, and we will not have plotted badly. For the dead child will have royal burial, and the living will not lose his life.


Thinking that his wife advised him excellently in his present strait, the cowherd immediately did as she said. He gave his wife the child whom he had brought to kill, and his own dead child he put into the chest in which he carried the other,

and dressed it with all the other child's finery and left it out in the most desolate part of the mountains. Then on the third day after leaving the child out, the cowherd left one of his herdsmen to watch it and went to the city, where he went to ' house and said he was ready to show the child's dead body.

 sent the most trusted of his bodyguard, and these saw for him and buried the cowherd's child. So it was buried: and the cowherd's wife kept and raised the boy who was afterwards named ; but she did not give him that name, but another.


Now when the boy was ten years old, the truth about him was revealed in some such way as this. He was playing in the village where these herdsmen's quarters were, playing in the road with others of his age. The boys while playing chose to be their king this one who was supposed to be the son of the cowherd.
Then he assigned some of them to the building of houses, some to be his bodyguard, one doubtless to be the ; to another he gave the right of bringing him messages; to each he gave his proper work.
Now one of these boys playing with him was the son of , a notable ; when he did not perform his assignment from ,  told the other boys to seize him, and when they did so he handled the boy very roughly and whipped him.
As soon as he was let go, very upset about the indignity he had suffered, he went down to his father in the city and complained of what he had received at the hands of the son of ' cowherdnot calling him , for that name had not yet been given.

, going just as angry as he was to  and bringing his son along, announced that an impropriety had been committed, saying, O King, by your slave, the son of a cowherd, we have been outraged thus: and with that he bared his son's shoulders.


When  heard and saw, he was ready to avenge the boy in view of ' rank: so he sent for the cowherd and his son. When they were both present,  said, fixing his eyes on ,

Is it you, then, the child of one such as this, who have dared to lay hands on the son of the greatest of my courtiers?  answered, Master, what I did to him I did with justice. The boys of the village, of whom he was one, chose me while playing to be their king, for they thought me the most fit for this.
The other boys then did as assigned: but this one was disobedient and cared nothing for me, for which he got what he deserved. Now, if I deserve punishment for this, here I am to take it.


While the boy spoke, it seemed to  that he recognized him; the character of his face was like his own, he thought, and his manner of answering was freer than customary: and the date of the exposure seemed to agree with the boy's age.
Astonished at this, he sat a while silent; but when at last with difficulty he could collect his wits, he said (for he wanted to be rid of  and question the cowherd with no one present), I shall act in such a way, , that you and your son shall have no cause of complaint.
So he sent  away, and the attendants led  inside at ' bidding. When the cowherd was left quite alone,  asked him where he had got the boy and who had been the giver.
The cowherd answered that  was his own son and that the mother was still with him.  said that he was not well advised if he wished to find himself in a desperate situation, and as he said this made a sign to the spearbearers to seize him.
Then, under stress of necessity, the cowherd disclosed to him the whole story, telling everything exactly as it had happened from the beginning, and at the end fell to entreaty and urged the king to pardon him.


When the cowherd had disclosed the true story,  took less interest in him, but he was very angry with  and had the guards summon him.

 came, and  asked him , how did you kill the boy, my daughter's son, whom I gave you? , when he saw the cowherd was there, did not take the way of falsehood, lest he be caught and confuted:

O King, he said, when I took the boy, I thought and considered how to do what you wanted and not be held a murderer by your daughter or by you even though I was blameless toward you.
So I did this: I summoned this cowherd here, and gave the child to him, telling him that it was you who gave the command to kill it. And that was the truth; for such was your command. But I gave the child with the instructions that the cowherd was to lay it on a desolate mountainside and wait there and watch until it was dead; and I threatened all sorts of things if he did not accomplish this.
Then, when he had done what he was told, and the child was dead, I sent the most trusted of my eunuchs and had the body viewed and buried. This, O king, is the story, and such was the end of the boy.


 told the story straight, while , hiding the anger that he felt against him for what had been done, first repeated the story again to  exactly as he had heard it from the cowherd, then, after repeating it, ended by saying that the boy was alive and that the matter had turned out well.

For, he said, I was greatly afflicted by what had been done to this boy, and it weighed heavily on me that I was estranged from my daughter. Now, then, in this good turn of fortune, send your own son to this boy newly come, and (since I am about to sacrifice for the boy's safety to the gods to whom this honor is due) come here to dine with me.


When  heard this, he bowed and went to his home, very pleased to find that his offense had turned out for the best and that he was invited to dinner in honor of this fortunate day.
Coming in, he told his only son, a boy of about thirteen years of age, to go to ' palace and do whatever the king commanded, and in his great joy he told his wife everything that had happened.
But when ' son came,  cut his throat and tore him limb from limb, roasted some of the flesh and boiled some, and kept it ready after he had prepared it.
So when the hour for dinner came and the rest of the guests and  were present,  and the others were served dishes of lamb's meat, but  that of his own son, all but the head and hands and feet, which lay apart covered up in a wicker basket.
And when  seemed to have eaten his fill,  asked him, Did you like your meal, ? Exceedingly,  answered. Then those whose job it was brought him the head of his son and hands and feet concealed in the basket, and they stood before  and told him to open and take what he liked.

 did; he opened and saw what was left of his son: he saw this, but mastered himself and did not lose his composure.  asked him, Do you know what beast's meat you have eaten?

I know, he said, and all that the king does is pleasing. With that answer he took the remains of the meat and went home. There he meant, I suppose, after collecting everything, to bury it.


Thus  punished . But, to help him to decide about , he summoned the same  who had interpreted his dream as I have said: and when they came,  asked them how they had interpreted his dream. They answered as before, and said that the boy must have been made king had he lived and not died first.
Then  said, The boy is safe and alive, and when he was living in the country the boys of his village made him king, and he duly did all that is done by true kings: for he assigned to each individually the roles of bodyguards and sentinels and messengers and everything else, and so ruled. And what do you think is the significance of this?

If the boy is alive, said the , and has been made king without premeditation, then be confident on this score and keep an untroubled heart: he will not be made king a second time. Even in our prophecies, it is often but a small thing that has been foretold and the consequences of dreams come to nothing in the end.

I too, , said , am very much of your opinion: that the dream came true when the boy was called king, and that I have no more to fear from him. Nevertheless consider well and advise me what will be safest both for my house and for you.
The  said, O King, we too are very anxious that your sovereignty prosper: for otherwise, it passes from your nation to this boy who is a , and so we  are enslaved and held of no account by the , as we are of another blood, but while you, our countryman, are established king, we have our share of power, and great honor is shown us by you.
Thus, then, we ought by all means to watch out for you and for your sovereignty. And if at the present time we saw any danger we would declare everything to you: but now the dream has had a trifling conclusion, and we ourselves are confident and advise you to be so also. As for this boy, send him out of your sight to the  and to his parents.


Hearing this,  was glad, and calling , said, My boy, I did you wrong because of a vision I had in a dream, that meant nothing, but by your own destiny you still live; now therefore, go to the , and good luck go with you; I will send guides with you. When you get there you will find a father and mother unlike the cowherd, , and his wife.


After saying this,  sent  away. When he returned to ' house, his parents received him there, and learning who he was they welcomed him enthusiastically, for they had supposed that long ago he had been killed, and they asked him how his life had been saved.
Then he told them, and said that until now he had known nothing but been very deceived, but that on the way he had heard the whole story of his misfortune; for he had thought, he said, that ' cowherd was his father, but in his journey from the city his escort had told him the whole story.
And he had been raised, he said, by the cowherd's wife, and he was full of her praises, and in his tale he was constantly speaking of . Hearing this name, his parents circulated a story that  was suckled by a dog when exposed, thinking in this way to make the story of his salvation seem more marvellous to the .


This then was the beginning of that legend. But as  grew up to be the manliest and best loved of his peers,  courted him and sent him gifts, wishing to be avenged on ; for he saw no hope for a private man like himself of punishing , but as he saw  growing up, he tried to make him an ally, for he likened ' misfortune to his own.
Even before this the following had been done by him: since  was harsh toward the , he associated with each of the chief  and persuaded them to make  their leader and depose .
So much being ready and done,  wanted to reveal his intent to , who then lived among the . But the roads were guarded, and he had no plan for sending a message but this:

he carefully slit the belly of a hare, and then leaving it as it was without further harm he put into it a paper on which he wrote what he thought best. Then he sewed up the hare's belly, and sent it to  by the most trusted of his servants, giving him nets to carry as if he were a huntsman. The messenger was instructed to give  the hare and tell him by word of mouth to cut it open with his own hands, with no one else present.


All this was done.  took the hare and slit it and read the paper which was in it; the writing was as follows: Son of , since the gods watch over you (otherwise you would not have prospered so) avenge yourself now on , your murderer;

for thanks to his intention you are dead, while thanks to the gods, and me, you live. I expect that long ago you heard the story of what was done concerning you and how  treated me because I did not kill you but gave you to the cowherd. If, then, you will listen to me, you shall rule all the country which is now ruled by . Persuade the  to rebel, and lead their army against the ;

then you have your wish, whether I am appointed to command the army against you or some other notable man among the : for they will of themselves revolt from  and join you and try to pull him down. Seeing then that all is ready here, do as I say and do it quickly.


When  read this, he deliberated as to what was the shrewdest way to persuade the  to revolt; and what he thought to be most effective, he did:

writing what he liked on a paper, he assembled the , and then unfolded the paper and declared that in it  appointed him leader of the  armies. Now, he said in his speech, I command you, men of , to come, each provided with a sickle. This is what  said.
Now there are many tribes in : those of them that  assembled and persuaded to revolt from the  were the , the , and the . On these all the other  depend. The chief tribe is that of the ; to them belongs the clan of the , the royal house of .
The other  tribes are the , the , and the , all tillers of the soil, and the , the , the , the , all wandering herdsmen.


So when they all came with sickles as ordered,  commanded them to reclaim in one day a thorny tract of , of two and one quarter or two and one half miles each way in extent.
The  accomplished the task appointed;  then commanded them to wash themselves and come the next day; meanwhile, collecting his father's goats and sheep and oxen in one place, he slaughtered and prepared them as a feast for the  host, providing also wine and all the foods that were most suitable.
When the  came on the next day he had them sit and feast in a meadow. After dinner he asked them which they liked more: their task of yesterday or their present pastime.
They answered that the difference was great: all yesterday they had had nothing but evil, to-day nothing but good. Then, taking up their word,  laid bare his whole purpose, and said:

This is your situation, men of : obey me and you shall have these good things and ten thousand others besides with no toil and slavery; but if you will not obey me, you will have labors unnumbered like your toil of yesterday.
Now, then, do as I tell you, and win your freedom. For I think that I myself was born by a divine chance to undertake this work; and I hold you fully as good men as the  in war and in everything else. All this is true; therefore revolt from  quickly now!


The  had long been discontent that the  ruled them, and now having got a champion they were glad to win their freedom. But when  heard that  was about this business, he sent a messenger to summon him;

 told the messenger to take back word that  would see him sooner than he liked. Hearing this,  armed all his , and was distracted by Providence so that he forgot what he had done to , and appointed him to command the army.
So when the  marched out and engaged with the , those who were not in on the plan fought, while others deserted to the enemy, and most were deliberate cowards and ran.


Thus the Median army was shamefully scattered. As soon as  heard, he sent a threatening message to : Nevertheless,  shall not rejoice;

and with that he took the  who interpreted dreams, who had persuaded him to let  go free, and impaled them; then he armed the  who were left in the city, the very young and very old men.
Leading these out, and engaging the , he was beaten:  himself was taken prisoner, and lost the Median army which he led.


When  was a captive,  came and exulted over him and taunted him, and besides much other bitter mockery he recalled his banquet, when  had fed  his son's flesh, and asked  what it was like to be a slave after having been a king.
Fixing his gaze on ,  asked, Do you imagine that this, which  has done, is your work? It was I, said the other, who wrote the letter; the accomplishment of the work is rightly mine.

Then, said , you stand confessed the most foolish and most unjust man on earth; most foolish, in giving another the throne which you might have had for yourself, if the present business is indeed your doing; most unjust, in enslaving the  because of that banquet.
For if in any event another and not you had to possess the royal power, then in justice some  should have had it, not a : but now you have made the , who did you no harm, slaves instead of masters and the , who were the slaves, are now the masters of the .


Thus  was deposed from his sovereignty after a reign of thirty-five years: and the  had to bow down before the  because of ' cruelty. They had ruled all  beyond the  for one hundred and twenty-eight years, from which must be subtracted the time when the  held sway.
At a later time they repented of what they now did, and rebelled against  ; but they were defeated in battle and brought back into subjection. But now, in ' time,  and the  rose in revolt against the , and from this time ruled .
As for ,  did him no further harm, and kept him in his own house until  died.This is the story of the birth and upbringing of , and of how he became king; and afterwards, as I have already related, he subjugated  in punishment for the unprovoked wrong done him; and after this victory he became sovereign of all .


As to the customs of the , I know them to be these. It is not their custom to make and set up statues and temples and altars, but those who do such things they think foolish, because, I suppose, they have never believed the gods to be like men, as the  do;

but they call the whole circuit of heaven , and to him they sacrifice on the highest peaks of the mountains; they sacrifice also to the sun and moon and earth and fire and water and winds.
From the beginning, these are the only gods to whom they have ever sacrificed; they learned later to sacrifice to the heavenly  from the  and . She is called by the  , by the  , by the  .


And this is their method of sacrifice to the aforesaid gods: when about to sacrifice, they do not build altars or kindle fire, employ libations, or music, or fillets, or barley meal: when a man wishes to sacrifice to one of the gods, he leads a beast to an open space and then, wearing a wreath on his tiara, of myrtle usually, calls on the god.
To pray for blessings for himself alone is not lawful for the sacrificer; rather, he prays that the king and all the  be well; for he reckons himself among them. He then cuts the victim limb from limb into portions, and, after boiling the flesh, spreads the softest grass, trefoil usually, and places all of it on this.
When he has so arranged it, a  comes near and chants over it the song of the birth of the gods, as the  tradition relates it; for no sacrifice can be offered without a . Then after a little while the sacrificer carries away the flesh and uses it as he pleases.


The day which every man values most is his own birthday. On this day, he thinks it right to serve a more abundant meal than on other days: oxen or horses or camels or asses, roasted whole in ovens, are set before the rich; the poorer serve the lesser kinds of cattle.
Their courses are few, the dainties that follow many, and not all served together. This is why the  say of  that they rise from table still hungry, because not much dessert is set before them: were this too given to  (the  say) they would never stop eating.
They are very partial to wine. No one may vomit or urinate in another's presence: this is prohibited among them. Moreover, it is their custom to deliberate about the gravest matters when they are drunk;

and what they approve in their deliberations is proposed to them the next day, when they are sober, by the master of the house where they deliberate; and if, being sober, they still approve it, they act on it, but if not, they drop it. And if they have deliberated about a matter when sober, they decide upon it when they are drunk.


When one man meets another on the road, it is easy to see if the two are equals; for, if they are, they kiss each other on the lips without speaking; if the difference in rank is small, the cheek is kissed; if it is great, the humbler bows and does obeisance to the other.
They honor most of all those who live nearest them, next those who are next nearest, and so going ever onwards they assign honor by this rule: those who dwell farthest off they hold least honorable of all; for they think that they are themselves in all regards by far the best of all men, that the rest have only a proportionate claim to merit, until those who live farthest away have least merit of all.
Under the rule of the , one tribe would even govern another; the  held sway over all alike and especially over those who lived nearest to them; these ruled their neighbors, and the neighbors in turn those who came next to them, on the same scheme by which the  assign honor; for the nation kept advancing its rule and dominion.


But the  more than all men welcome foreign customs. They wear the Median dress, thinking it more beautiful than their own, and the  cuirass in war. Their luxurious practices are of all kinds, and all borrowed: the  taught them pederasty. Every  marries many lawful wives, and keeps still more concubines.


After valor in battle it is accounted noble to father the greatest number of sons: the king sends gifts yearly to him who gets most. Strength, they believe, is in numbers.
They educate their boys from five to twenty years old, and teach them only three things: riding and archery and honesty. A boy is not seen by his father before he is five years old, but lives with the women: the point of this is that, if the boy should die in the interval of his rearing, the father would suffer no grief.


This is a law which I praise; and it is a praiseworthy law, too, which does not allow the king himself to slay any one for a single offense, or any other  to do incurable harm to one of his servants for one offense. Not until an accounting shows that the offender's wrongful acts are more and greater than his services may a man give rein to his anger.
They say that no one has ever yet killed his father or mother; when such a thing has been done, it always turns out on inquest that the doer is shown to be a changeling or the fruit of adultery; for it is not to be believed (say they) that a son should kill his true parent.


Furthermore, of what they may not do, they may not speak, either. They hold lying to be the most disgraceful thing of all and next to that debt; for which they have many other reasons, but this in particular: it is inevitable (so they say) that the debtor also speak some falsehood. The citizen who has leprosy or the white sickness may not come into town or mingle with other . They say that he is so afflicted because he has sinned in some way against the sun.
Every stranger who gets such a disease, many drive out of the country; and they do the same to white doves, for the reason given. Rivers they especially revere; they will neither urinate nor spit nor wash their hands in them, nor let anyone else do so.


There is another thing that always happens among them; we have noted it although the  have not: their names, which agree with the nature of their persons and their nobility, all end in the same letter, that which the  call san, and the  sigma; you will find, if you search, that not some but all  names alike end in this letter.


So much I can say of them from my own certain knowledge. But there are other matters concerning the dead which are secretly and obscurely told: how the dead bodies of  are not buried before they have been mangled by birds or dogs.
That this is the way of the , I know for certain; for they do not conceal the practice. But this is certain, that before the  bury the body in earth they embalm it in wax. These  are as unlike the priests of  as they are unlike all other men:

for the priests consider it sacrilege to kill anything that lives, except what they sacrifice; but the  kill with their own hands every creature, except dogs and men; they kill all alike, ants and snakes, creeping and flying things, and take great pride in it. Leaving this custom to be such as it has been from the first, I return now to my former story.


As soon as the  had been subjugated by the , the  and  sent messengers to , offering to be his subjects on the same terms as those which they had under . After hearing what they proposed,  told them a story. Once, he said, there was a flute-player who saw fish in the sea and played upon his flute, thinking that they would come out on to the land.
Disappointed of his hope, he cast a net and gathered it in and took out a great multitude of fish; and seeing them leaping, You had best, he said, stop your dancing now; you would not come out and dance before, when I played to you.
The reason why  told the story to the  and  was that the , who were ready to obey him when the victory was won, had before refused when he sent a message asking them to revolt from .
So he answered them in anger. But when the message came to the  in their cities, they fortified themselves with walls, and assembled in the , all except the , with whom alone  made a treaty on the same terms as that which they had with the . The rest of the  resolved to send envoys in the name of them all to , to ask help for the .


Now these  possessed the , and of all men whom we know, they happened to found their cities in places with the loveliest of climate and seasons.
For neither to the north of them nor to the south does the land effect the same thing as in  nor to the east nor to the west, affected here by the cold and wet, there by the heat and drought.
They do not all have the same speech but four different dialects.  lies farthest south among them, and next to it come  and ; these are settlements in , and they have a common language; , , , , , , all of them in ,

have a language in common which is wholly different from the speech of the three former cities. There are yet three  cities, two of them situated on the islands of  and , and one, , on the mainland; the  and  speak alike, but the  have a language which is their own and no one else's. It is thus seen that there are four modes of speech.


Among these , the  were safe from the danger (for they had made a treaty), and the islanders among them had nothing to fear: for the  were not yet subjects of the , nor were the  themselves mariners.
But those of  were cut off from the rest of the  only in the way that I shall show. The whole  stock was then small, and the last of all its branches and the least regarded was the ; for it had no considerable city except .
Now the  and the rest would not be called , but spurned the name; even now the greater number of them seem to me to be ashamed of it; but the twelve cities aforesaid gloried in this name, and founded a holy place for themselves which they called the , and agreed among themselves to allow no other  to use it (nor in fact did any except the men of  ask to be admitted);


just as the  of what is now the country of the formerly the country of the forbid admitting any of the neighboring  to the  temple, and even barred from using it those of their own group who had broken the temple law.
For long ago, in the games in honor of , they offered certain bronze tripods to the victors; and those who won these were not to carry them away from the temple but dedicate them there to the god.
Now when a man of  called  won, he disregarded this law, and, carrying the tripod away, nailed it to the wall of his own house. For this offense the five cities, , , , and forbade the sixth cityto share in the use of the temple. Such was the penalty imposed on the .


As for the , the reason why they made twelve cities and would admit no more was in my judgment this: there were twelve divisions of them when they dwelt in the , just as there are twelve divisions of the  who drove the  out nearest to ; then  and , where is the never-failing river , from which the river in  took its name;  and , where the  fled when they were worsted in battle by the ; ; ; ; ; and , where is the great river ;  and , the only inland city of all thesethese were the twelve divisions of the , as they are now of the .


For this reason, and for no other, the  too made twelve cities; for it would be foolishness to say that these are more truly  or better born than the other ; since not the least part of them are  from , who are not  even in name, and there are mingled with them  of , , ,  renegades from their nation, , ,  of , and many other tribes;

and as for those who came from the very town-hall of  and think they are the best born of the , these did not bring wives with them to their settlements, but married  women whose parents they had put to death.
For this slaughter, these women made a custom and bound themselves by oath (and enjoined it on their daughters) that no one would sit at table with her husband or call him by his name, because the men had married them after slaying their fathers and husbands and sons. This happened at .


And as kings, some of them chose  descendants of  son of , and some  of , descendants of  son of , and some both. Yet since they set more store by the name than the rest of the , let it be granted that those of pure birth are ;

and all are  who are of  descent and keep the feast . All do keep it, except the men of  and ; these are the only  who do not keep it, and these because, they say, of a certain pretext of murder.

Those are the  cities, and these are the :  (called ), , , , , , , , , , . These are the ancient  cities, eleven in number; but one of them, , was taken away by the ; for these too were once twelve, on the mainland.

Now this is how the  lost . Some men of , the losers in civil strife and exiles from their country, had been received by them into the town. These  exiles waited for the time when the men of  were holding a festival to  outside the walls; then they shut the gates and so got the city.

When the herald had proclaimed this,  is said to have asked the  who were present who and how many in number these  were who made this declaration. When he was told, he said to the  herald, I never yet feared men who set apart a place in the middle of their city where they perjure themselves and deceive each other. They, if I keep my health, shall talk of their own misfortunes, not those of the .
He uttered this threat against all the , because they have markets and buy and sell there; for the  themselves were not used to resorting to markets at all, nor do they even have a market of any kind.
Presently, entrusting  to a  called , and instructing , a , to take charge of the gold of  and the , he himself marched away to , taking  with him, and at first taking no notice of the .
