But no sooner had  marched away from  than  made the  revolt from  and ; and he went down to the sea, where, as he had all the gold of , he hired soldiers and persuaded the men of the coast to join his undertaking. Then, marching to , he penned  in the acropolis and besieged him there.


When  heard of this on his journey, he said to , What end to this business, ? It seems that the  will never stop making trouble for me and for themselves. It occurs to me that it may be best to make slaves of them; for it seems I have acted like one who slays the father and spares the children.
So likewise I have taken with me you who were more than a father to the , and handed the city over to the  themselves; and then indeed I marvel that they revolt! So  uttered his thought; but  feared that he would destroy , and answered him thus:

O King, what you say is reasonable. But do not ever yield to anger, or destroy an ancient city that is innocent both of the former and of the present offense. For the former I am responsible, and bear the punishment on my head; while , in whose charge you left , does this present wrong; let him, then, pay the penalty.
But pardon the , and give them this command so that they not revolt or pose a danger to you: send and forbid them to possess weapons of war, and order them to wear tunics under their cloaks and knee-boots on their feet, and to teach their sons lyre-playing and song and dance and shop-keeping. And quickly, O king, you shall see them become women instead of men, so that you need not fear them, that they might revolt.


 proposed this to him, because he thought this was better for the  than to be sold as slaves; he knew that without some reasonable plea he could not change the king's mind, and feared that even if the  should escape this time they might later revolt and be destroyed by the .

 was pleased by this counsel; he relented in his anger and said he would follow ' advice. Then calling , a , he told him to give the  the commands that  advised; further, to enslave all the others who had joined the  in attacking ; and as for  himself, by all means to bring him into his presence alive.


After giving these commands on his journey, he marched away into the  country. But , learning that an army sent against him was approaching, was frightened and fled to .

 the , when he came to  with the part that he had of ' host and found ' followers no longer there, first of all compelled the  to carry out ' commands; and by his order they changed their whole way of life.
After this, he sent messengers to  demanding that  be surrendered. The  resolved to make the god at  their judge as to what course they should take; for there was an ancient place of divination there, which all the  and  used to consult; the place is in the land of , above the harbor of .


The men of , then, sent to  to inquire of the shrine what they should do in the matter of  that would be most pleasing to the gods; and the oracle replied that they must surrender  to the .
When this answer came back to them, they set about surrendering him. But while the greater part were in favor of doing this,  son of , a notable man among the citizens, stopped the men of  from doing it; for he did not believe the oracle and thought that those who had inquired of the god spoke falsely; until at last a second band of inquirers was sent to inquire concerning , among whom was .


When they came to , , speaking for all, put this question to the oracle: Lord,  the  has come to us a suppliant fleeing a violent death at the hands of the ; and they demand him of us, telling the men of  to surrender him.
But we, as much as we fear the  power, have not dared give up this suppliant of ours until it is clearly made known to us by you whether we are to do this or not. Thus  inquired; and the god again gave the same answer, that  should be surrendered to the .
With that  did as he had already decided; he went around the temple, and took away the sparrows and all the families of nesting birds that were in it. But while he was doing so, a voice (they say) came out of the inner shrine calling to , and saying, Vilest of men, how dare you do this? Will you rob my temple of those that take refuge with me?
Then  had his answer ready: Lord, he said, will you save your own suppliants, yet tell the men of  to deliver up theirs? But the god replied, Yes, I do command them, so that you may perish all the sooner for your impiety, and never again come to inquire of my oracle about giving up those that seek refuge with you.


When the  heard this answer, they sent  away to ; for they were anxious not to perish for delivering him up or to be besieged for keeping him with them.
Then  sent a message to  demanding the surrender of , and the  prepared to give him, for a price; I cannot say exactly how much it was, for the bargain was never fulfilled;

for when the  learned what the  were about, they sent a ship to  and took  away to . From there he was dragged out of the temple of  and delivered up by the ,

who received in return , which is a district in  opposite . The  thus received  and kept him guarded, so that they might show him to ;

and for a long time no one would use barley meal from this land of  in sacrifices to any god, or make sacrificial cakes of what grew there; everything that came from that country was kept away from any sacred rite.


The , then, surrendered , and afterwards  led his army against those who had helped to besiege , and he enslaved the people of , and overran the plain of the , giving it to his army to pillage and  likewise. Immediately after this he died of an illness.


After his death, , a  like , came down to succeed him in his command; this is the  who was entertained by  the king of the  at that unnatural feast, and who helped win the kingship for .
This man was now made general by . When he came to , he took the cities by means of earthworks; he would drive the men within their walls and then build earthworks against the walls and so take the cities.


 was the first  town that he attacked. These  were the earliest of the  to make long sea-voyages, and it was they who discovered the , and , and , and ,

not sailing in round freightships but in fifty-oared vessels. When they came to  they made friends with the king of the , whose name was ; he ruled  for eighty years and lived a hundred and twenty.
The  won this man's friendship to such a degree that he invited them to leave  and settle in his country wherever they liked; and then, when he could not persuade them to, and learned from them how the Median power was increasing, he gave them money to build a wall around their city.
He gave it generously: for the circuit of the wall is of not a few stades, and all this is made of great stones well fitted together.


In such a manner the ' wall was built.  marched against the city and besieged it, but he made overtures, and said that it would suffice him if the  would demolish one rampart of the wall and dedicate one house.
But the , very indignant at the thought of slavery, said they wanted to deliberate for a day, and then they would answer; but while they were deliberating,  must withdraw his army from the walls, they said.  said that he well knew what they intended to do, but that nevertheless he would allow them to deliberate.
So when  withdrew his army from the walls, the  launched their fifty-oared ships, embarked their children and women and all their movable goods, besides the statues from the temples and everything dedicated in them except bronze or stonework or painting, and then embarked themselves and set sail for ; and the  took , left thus uninhabited.


The  would have bought the islands called  from the ; but the  would not sell them, because they feared that the islands would become a market and so their own island be cut off from trade: so the  prepared to sail to , where at the command of an oracle they had built a city called  twenty years before.

 was by this time dead. While getting ready for their voyage, they first sailed to , where they destroyed the  guard to whom  had entrusted the defense of the city; and when this was done, they called down mighty curses on any one of them who should stay behind when the rest sailed.
Not only this, but they sank a mass of iron in the sea, and swore never to return to  before the iron should appear again. But while they prepared to sail to , more than half of the citizens were overcome with longing and pitiful sorrow for the city and the life of their land, and they broke their oath and sailed back to . Those of them who kept the oath put out to sea from the .


And when they came to  they lived there for five years as one community with those who had come first, and they founded temples there. But they harassed and plundered all their neighbors, as a result of which the  and  made common cause against them, and sailed to attack them with sixty ships each.
The  also manned their ships, sixty in number, and met the enemy in the sea called . They engaged and the  won, yet it was only a kind of  victory; for they lost forty of their ships, and the twenty that remained were useless, their rams twisted awry.
Then sailing to  they took their children and women and all of their possessions that their ships could hold on board, and leaving  they sailed to .


As for the crews of the disabled ships, the  and  drew lots for them, and of the  the  were allotted by far the majority and these they led out and stoned to death. But afterwards, everything from  that passed the place where the stoned  lay, whether sheep or beasts of burden or men, became distorted and crippled and palsied.
The  sent to , wanting to mend their offense; and the  priestess told them to do what the people of  do to this day: for they pay great honors to the , with religious rites and games and horse-races.
Such was the end of this part of the . Those of them who fled to  set out from there and gained possession of that city in the  country which is now called ;

they founded this because they learned from a man of  that the  whose establishment the  priestess ordained was the hero, and not the island.


Thus, then, it went with the . The  did the same things as the : when  had taken their walled city by building an earthwork, they all embarked aboard ship and sailed away for . There they founded a city, , which before this had been founded by  of ; yet he got no profit of it, but was driven out by the . This  is now honored as a hero by the  of .


These were the only  who left their native lands, unable to endure slavery. The rest of the , except the , though they faced  in battle as did the exiles, and conducted themselves well, each fighting for his own country, yet, when they were defeated and their cities taken, they remained where they were and did as they were told.
The , as I have already said, made a treaty with  himself and struck no blow. Thus  was enslaved for the second time: and when  had conquered the  of the mainland, the  of the islands, fearing the same fate, surrendered to .


When the , despite their evil plight, nonetheless assembled at the ,  of , I have learned, gave them very useful advice, and had they followed it they might have been the most prosperous of all :

for he advised them to put out to sea and sail all together to  and then found one city for all : thus, possessing the greatest island in the world and ruling others, they would be rid of slavery and have prosperity; but if they stayed in  he could see (he said) no hope of freedom for them.
This was the advice which  of  gave after the destruction of the ; and that given before the destruction by  of , a  by descent, was good too; he advised that the  have one place of deliberation, and that it be in  (for that was the center of ), and that the other cities be considered no more than demes.Thus  and  advised.


, after subjugating , made an expedition against the , , and , taking  and  with him.
Of these, the  have come to the mainland from the islands; for in the past they were islanders, called  and under the rule of , not (as far as I can learn by report) paying tribute, but manning ships for him when he needed them.
Since  had subjected a good deal of territory for himself and was victorious in war, this made the  too at that time by far the most respected of all nations.
They invented three things in which they were followed by the : it was the  who originated wearing crests on their helmets and devices on their shields, and who first made grips for their shields; until then all who used shields carried them without these grips, and guided them with leather belts which they slung round the neck and over the left shoulder.
Then, a long time afterwards, the  were driven from the islands by  and  and so came to the mainland. This is the  story about the ; but the  themselves do not subscribe to it, but believe that they are aboriginal inhabitants of the mainland and always bore the name which they bear now;

and they point to an ancient shrine of  at , to which  and , as brethren of the  (for  and , they say, were brothers of ), are admitted, but not those who spoke the same language as the  but were of another people.


I think the  are aborigines of the soil, but they say that they came from . Their speech has become like the , or the  like theirs (for I cannot clearly decide), but in their customs they diverge widely from the , as from all other men. Their chief pleasure is to assemble for drinking-bouts in groups according to their ages and friendships: men, women, and children.
Certain foreign rites of worship were established among them; but afterwards, when they were inclined otherwise, and wanted to worship only the gods of their fathers, all  men of full age put on their armor and went together as far as the boundaries of , striking the air with their spears and saying that they were casting out the alien gods.


Such are their ways. The  were from  in ancient times (for in the past none that lived on  were ).
Now there was a dispute in  about the royal power between  and , sons of ;  prevailed in this dispute and drove out  and his partisans; who, after being driven out, came to the  land in . What is now possessed by the  was in the past , and the  were then called .
For a while  ruled them, and the people were called , which was the name that they had brought with them and that is still given to the  by their neighbors; but after  son of  came from banished as well by his brother, to join  in the land of the , they came in time to be called  after .
Their customs are partly  and partly . But they have one which is their own and shared by no other men: they take their names not from their fathers but from their mothers,

and when one is asked by his neighbor who he is, he will say that he is the son of such a mother, and rehearse the mothers of his mother. Indeed, if a female citizen marries a slave, her children are considered pure-blooded; but if a male citizen, even the most prominent of them, takes an alien wife or concubine, the children are dishonored.


Neither the  nor any  who dwell in this country did any thing notable before they were all enslaved by .
Among those who inhabit it are certain , colonists from . Their country (it is called the ) lies between the sea and that part of the peninsula which belongs to , and all but a small part of the  territory is washed by the sea

(for it is bounded on the north by the gulf of , and on the south by the sea off  and ). Now while  was conquering , the  dug a trench across this little space, which is about two-thirds of a mile wide, in order that their country might be an island. So they brought it all within the entrenchment; for the frontier between the  country and the mainland is on the isthmus across which they dug.
Many of them were at this work; and seeing that the workers were injured when breaking stones more often and less naturally than usual, some in other ways, but most in the eyes, the  sent envoys to  to inquire what it was that opposed them.
Then, as they themselves say, the priestess gave them this answer in iambic verse:


At this answer from the priestess, the  stopped their digging, and when  came against them with his army they surrendered to him without resistance.


There were  dwelling inland above ; when any misfortune was approaching them or their neighbors, the priestess of  grew a long beard. This had happened to them thrice. These were the only men near  who held out for long against , and they gave him the most trouble; they fortified a hill called .


The  were at length taken, and when  led his army into the plain of , the  came out to meet him, and showed themselves courageous fighting few against many; but being beaten and driven into the city, they gathered their wives and children and goods and servants into the acropolis, and then set the whole acropolis on fire.
Then they swore great oaths to each other, and sallying out fell fighting, all the men of .
Of the  who claim now to be  the greater number, all except eighty households, are of foreign descent; these eighty families as it happened were away from the city at that time, and thus survived. So  gained , and  too in a somewhat similar manner, the  following for the most part the example of the .


, then, made havoc of lower ; in the upper country,  himself vanquished every nation, leaving none untouched. Of the greater part of these I will say nothing, but will speak only of those which gave  the most trouble and are most worthy of being described.


When  had made all the mainland submit to him, he attacked the . In  there are many other great cities, but the most famous and the strongest was , where the royal dwelling had been established after the destruction of .  was a city such as I will now describe.
It lies in a great plain, and is in shape a square, each side fifteen miles in length; thus sixty miles make the complete circuit of the city. Such is the size of the city of ; and it was planned like no other city of which we know.
Around it runs first a moat deep and wide and full of water, and then a wall eighty three feet thick and three hundred thirty three feet high. The royal measure is greater by three fingers' breadth than the common measure.


Further, I must relate where the earth was used as it was dug from the moat and how the wall was constructed. As they dug the moat, they made bricks of the earth which was carried out of the place they dug, and when they had moulded bricks enough, they baked them in ovens;

then using hot bitumen for cement and interposing layers of wattled reeds at every thirtieth course of bricks, they built first the border of the moat and then the wall itself in the same fashion.
On the top, along the edges of the wall, they built houses of a single room, facing each other, with space enough between to drive a four-horse chariot. There are a hundred gates in the circuit of the wall, all of bronze, with posts and lintels of the same.
There is another city, called , eight days' journey from , where there is a little river, also named Is, a tributary of the ; from the source of this river Is, many lumps of bitumen rise with the water; and from there the bitumen was brought for the wall of .


Thus, then, this wall was built; the city is divided into two parts; for it is cut in half by a river named , a wide, deep, and swift river, flowing from  and issuing into the .
The angles of the wall, then, on either side are built quite down to the river; here they turn, and from here a fence of baked bricks runs along each bank of the stream.
The city itself is full of houses three and four stories high; and the ways that traverse it, those that run crosswise towards the river and the rest, are all straight.
Further, at the end of each road there was a gate in the riverside fence, one gate for each alley; these gates also were of bronze, and these too opened on the river.


These walls are the city's outer armor; within them there is another encircling wall, nearly as strong as the other, but narrower.
In the middle of one division of the city stands the royal palace, surrounded by a high and strong wall; and in the middle of the other is still to this day the sacred enclosure of , a square of four hundred and forty yards each way, with gates of bronze.
In the center of this sacred enclosure a solid tower has been built, two hundred and twenty yards long and broad; a second tower rises from this and from it yet another, until at last there are eight.
The way up them mounts spirally outside the height of the towers; about halfway up is a resting place, with seats for repose, where those who ascend sit down and rest.
In the last tower there is a great shrine; and in it stands a great and well-covered couch, and a golden table nearby. But no image has been set up in the shrine, nor does any human creature lie there for the night, except one native woman, chosen from all women by the god, as the  say, who are priests of this god.


These same  say (though I do not believe them) that the god himself is accustomed to visit the shrine and rest on the couch, as in 
 of , as the  say

(for there too a woman sleeps in the temple of , and neither the  nor the  woman, it is said, has intercourse with men), and as does the prophetess of the god at  in , whenever she is appointed; for there is not always a place of divination there; but when she is appointed she is shut up in the temple during the night.


In the  temple there is another shrine below, where there is a great golden image of , sitting at a great golden table, and the footstool and the chair are also gold; the gold of the whole was said by the  to be eight hundred talents' weight.
Outside the temple is a golden altar. There is also another great altar, on which are sacrificed the full-grown of the flocks; only nurslings may be sacrificed on the golden altar, but on the greater altar the  even offer a thousand talents' weight of frankincense yearly, when they keep the festival of this god; and in the days of  there was still in this sacred enclosure a statue of solid gold twenty feet high.
I myself have not seen it, but I relate what is told by the .  son of  proposed to take this statue but dared not;  his son took it, and killed the priest who warned him not to move the statue. Such is the furniture of this temple, and there are many private offerings besides.


Now among the many rulers of this city of  (whom I shall mention in my  history) who finished the building of the walls and the temples, there were two that were women. The first of these lived five generations earlier than the second, and her name was : it was she who built dikes on the plain, a notable work; before that the whole plain used to be flooded by the river.


The second queen, whose name was , was a wiser woman than the first. She left such monuments as I shall record; and moreover, seeing that the kingdom of Media was great and restless and  itself among other cities had fallen to it, she took such precautions as she could for her protection.
First she dealt with the river , which flows through the middle of her city; this had been straight before; but by digging canals higher up she made the river so crooked that its course now passes one of the  villages three times; the village which is so approached by the  is called . And now those who travel from our sea to  must spend three days as they float down the  coming three times to the same village.
Such was this work; and she built an embankment along either shore of the river, marvellous for its greatness and height.
Then a long way above  she dug the reservoir of a lake, a little way off from the river, always digging deep enough to find water, and making the circumference a distance of fifty two miles; what was dug out of this hole, she used to embank either edge of the river;

and when she had it all dug, she brought stones and made a quay all around the lake.
Her purpose in making the river wind and turning the hole into marsh was this: that the current might be slower because of the many windings that broke its force, and that the passages to  might be crooked, and that right after them should come also the long circuit of the lake.
All this work was done in that part of the country where the passes are and the shortest road from Media, so that the  might not mix with her people and learn of her affairs.


So she made the deep river her protection; and this work led to another which she added to it. Her city was divided into two parts by the river that flowed through the middle. In the days of the former rulers, when one wanted to go from one part to the other, one had to cross in a boat; and this, I suppose, was a nuisance. But the queen also provided for this; she made another monument of her reign out of this same work when the digging of the basin of the lake was done.
She had very long blocks of stone cut; and when these were ready and the place was dug, she turned the course of the river into it, and while it was filling, the former channel now being dry, she bricked the borders of the river in the city and the descent from the gate leading down to the river with baked bricks, like those of the wall; and near the middle of the city she built a bridge with the stones that had been dug up, binding them together with iron and lead.
Each morning, she laid square-hewn logs across it, on which the  crossed; but these logs were removed at night, lest folk always be crossing over and stealing from one another.
Then, when the basin she had made for a lake was filled by the river and the bridge was finished,  brought the  back to its former channel out of the lake; thus she had served her purpose, as she thought, by making a swamp of the basin, and her citizens had a bridge made for them.


There was a trick, too, that this same queen contrived. She had a tomb made for herself and set high over the very gate of that entrance of the city which was used most, with writing engraved on the tomb, which read:

If any king of  in the future is in need of money, let him open this tomb and take as much as he likes: but let him not open it unless he is in need; for it will be the worse for him.
This tomb remained untouched until the kingship fell to . He thought it a very strange thing that he should never use this gate, or take the money when it lay there and the writing itself invited him to.
The reason he did not use the gate was that the dead body would be over his head as he passed through.
After opening the tomb, he found no money there, only the dead body, with writing which read: If you were ever satisfied with what you had and did not disgrace yourself seeking more, you would not have opened the coffins of the dead. Such a woman, it is recorded, was this queen.


, then, marched against ' son, who inherited the name of his father  and the sovereignty of . Now when the  campaigns, he marches well provided with food and flocks from home; and water from the  that flows past  is carried with him, the only river from which the king will drink.
This water of the  is boiled, and very many four-wheeled wagons drawn by mules carry it in silver vessels, following the king wherever he goes at any time.


When  reached the  on his march to , which rises in the mountains of the  and flows through the  country into another river, the , that again passes the city of  and empties into the when, I say,  tried to cross the , which was navigable there, one of his sacred white horses dashed recklessly into the river trying to get through it, but the current overwhelmed him and swept him under and away.
At this violence of the river  was very angry, and he threatened to make it so feeble that women could ever after cross it easily without wetting their knees.
After uttering this threat, he paused in his march against , and, dividing his army into two parts, drew lines planning out a hundred and eighty canals running every way from either bank of the ; then he organized his army along the lines and made them dig.
Since a great multitude was at work, it went quickly; but they spent the whole summer there before it was finished.


Then at the beginning of the following spring, when  had punished the  by dividing it among the three hundred and sixty canals, he marched against  at last. The  sallied out and awaited him; and when he came near their city in his march, they engaged him, but they were beaten and driven inside the city.
There they had stored provisions enough for very many years, because they knew already that  was not a man of no ambitition, and saw that he attacked all nations alike; so now they were indifferent to the siege; and  did not know what to do, being so long delayed and gaining no advantage.


Whether someone advised him in his difficulty, or whether he perceived for himself what to do, I do not know, but he did the following.
He posted his army at the place where the river goes into the city, and another part of it behind the city, where the river comes out of the city, and told his men to enter the city by the channel of the  when they saw it to be fordable. Having disposed them and given this command, he himself marched away with those of his army who could not fight;

and when he came to the lake,  dealt with it and with the river just as had the  queen: drawing off the river by a canal into the lake, which was a marsh, he made the stream sink until its former channel could be forded.
When this happened, the  who were posted with this objective made their way into  by the channel of the , which had now sunk to a depth of about the middle of a man's thigh.
Now if the  had known beforehand or learned what  was up to, they would have let the  enter the city and have destroyed them utterly; for then they would have shut all the gates that opened on the river and mounted the walls that ran along the river banks, and so caught their enemies in a trap.
But as it was, the  took them unawares, and because of the great size of the city (those who dwell there say) those in the outer parts of it were overcome, but the inhabitants of the middle part knew nothing of it; all this time they were dancing and celebrating a holiday which happened to fall then, until they learned the truth only too well.


And , then for the first time, was taken in this way. I shall show how great the power of  is by many other means, but particularly by this. All the land that the great King rules is parcelled out to provision him and his army, and pays tribute besides: now the territory of  feeds him for four of the twelve months in the year, the whole of the rest of  providing for the other eight.
Thus the wealth of  is one third of the entire wealth of . The governorship of this land, which the  call satrapy, is by far the most powerful of all the governorships, since the daily income of  son of , who governed this province by the king's will, was an artaba full of silver

(the artaba is a  measure, containing more than an Attic medimnus by three Attic choenixes), and besides warhorses he had eight hundred stallions in his stables, and sixteen thousand brood mares, each stallion servicing twenty mares.
Moreover he kept so great a number of  dogs that four great villages of the plain were appointed to provide food for the dogs and exempted from all other burdens. Such were the riches of the governor of .


There is little rain in . This nourishes the roots of the grain; but it is irrigation from the river that ripens the crop and brings the grain to fullness. In , the river itself rises and floods the fields; in , they are watered by hand and by swinging beams.
For the whole land of , like , is cut across by canals. The greatest of these is navigable: it runs towards where the sun rises in winter, from the  to another river, the , on which stood the city of . This land is by far the most fertile in grain which we know.
It does not even try to bear trees, fig, vine, or olive, but 's grain is so abundant there that it yields for the most part two hundred fold, and even three hundred fold when the harvest is best. The blades of the wheat and barley there are easily four fingers broad;

and for millet and sesame, I will not say to what height they grow, though it is known to me; for I am well aware that even what I have said regarding grain is wholly disbelieved by those who have never visited . They use no oil except what they make from sesame. There are palm trees there growing all over the plain, most of them yielding fruit, from which food is made and wine and honey.
The  tend these like figs, and chiefly in this respect, that they tie the fruit of the palm called male by the  to the date-bearing palm, so that the gall-fly may enter the dates and cause them to ripen, and that the fruit of the palm may not fall; for the male palms, like unripened figs, have gall-flies in their fruit.


I am going to indicate what seems to me to be the most marvellous thing in the country, next to the city itself. Their boats which ply the river and go to  are all of skins, and round.
They make these in , higher up the stream than . First they cut frames of willow, then they stretch hides over these for a covering, making as it were a hold; they neither broaden the stern nor narrow the prow, but the boat is round, like a shield. They then fill it with reeds and send it floating down the river with a cargo; and it is for the most part palm wood casks of wine that they carry down.
Two men standing upright steer the boat, each with a paddle, one drawing it to him, the other thrusting it from him. These boats are of all sizes, some small, some very large; the largest of them are of as much as five thousand talents burden. There is a live ass in each boat, or more than one in the larger.
So when they have floated down to  and disposed of their cargo, they sell the framework of the boat and all the reeds; the hides are set on the backs of asses, which are then driven back to ,

for it is not by any means possible to go upstream by water, because of the swiftness of the current; it is for this reason that they make their boats of hides and not of wood. When they have driven their asses back into , they make more boats in the same way.


Such then are their boats. For clothing, they wear a linen tunic, reaching to the feet; over this the  puts on another tunic, of wool, and wraps himself in a white mantle; he wears the shoes of his country, which are like  sandals. Their hair is worn long, and covered by caps; the whole body is perfumed.
Every man has a seal and a carved staff, and on every staff is some image, such as that of an apple or a rose or a lily or an eagle: no one carries a staff without an image.


This is the equipment of their persons. I will now speak of their established customs. The wisest of these, in our judgment, is one which I have learned by inquiry is also a custom of the  in . It is this: once a year in every village all the maidens as they attained marriageable age were collected and brought together into one place, with a crowd of men standing around.
Then a crier would display and offer them for sale one by one, first the fairest of all; and then, when she had fetched a great price, he put up for sale the next most attractive, selling all the maidens as lawful wives. Rich men of  who desired to marry would outbid each other for the fairest; the ordinary people, who desired to marry and had no use for beauty, could take the ugly ones and money besides;

for when the crier had sold all the most attractive, he would put up the one that was least beautiful, or crippled, and offer her to whoever would take her to wife for the least amount, until she fell to one who promised to accept least; the money came from the sale of the attractive ones, who thus paid the dowry of the ugly and the crippled. But a man could not give his daughter in marriage to whomever he liked, nor could one that bought a girl take her away without giving security that he would in fact make her his wife.
And if the couple could not agree, it was a law that the money be returned. Men might also come from other villages to buy if they so desired.
This, then, was their best custom; but it does not continue at this time; they have invented a new one lately so that the women not be wronged or taken to another city; since the conquest of  made them afflicted and poor, everyone of the people that lacks a livelihood prostitutes his daughters.


I come now to the next wisest of their customs: having no use for physicians, they carry the sick into the market-place; then those who have been afflicted themselves by the same illness as the sick man's, or seen others in like case, come near and advise him about his disease and comfort him, telling him by what means they have themselves recovered from it or seen others recover. No one may pass by the sick man without speaking and asking after his sickness.


The dead are embalmed in honey for burial, and their dirges are like the dirges of . Whenever a  has had intercourse with his wife, they both sit before a burnt offering of incense, and at dawn they wash themselves; they will touch no vessel before this is done. This is the custom in  also.


The foulest  custom is that which compels every woman of the land to sit in the temple of  and have intercourse with some stranger once in her life. Many women who are rich and proud and disdain to mingle with the rest, drive to the temple in covered carriages drawn by teams, and stand there with a great retinue of attendants.
But most sit down in the sacred plot of , with crowns of cord on their heads; there is a great multitude of women coming and going; passages marked by line run every way through the crowd, by which the men pass and make their choice.
Once a woman has taken her place there, she does not go away to her home before some stranger has cast money into her lap, and had intercourse with her outside the temple; but while he casts the money, he must say, I invite you in the name of  (that is the  name for ).
It does not matter what sum the money is; the woman will never refuse, for that would be a sin, the money being by this act made sacred. So she follows the first man who casts it and rejects no one. After their intercourse, having discharged her sacred duty to the goddess, she goes away to her home; and thereafter there is no bribe however great that will get her.
So then the women that are fair and tall are soon free to depart, but the uncomely have long to wait because they cannot fulfill the law; for some of them remain for three years, or four. There is a custom like this in some parts of .


These are established customs among the . Furthermore, there are three tribes in the country that eat nothing but fish, which they catch and dry in the sun; then, after throwing it into a mortar, they pound it with pestles and strain everything through linen. Then whoever desires kneads as it were a cake of it and eats it; others bake it like bread.


When  had conquered this nation, too, he wanted to subject the . These are said to be a great and powerful people dwelling towards the east and the sunrise, beyond the  and opposite the ; and some say that they are a  people.


The  is said by some to be greater and by some to be less than the . It is reported that there are many islands in it as big as , and men on them who in summer live on roots of all kinds that they dig up, and in winter on fruit that they have got from trees when it was ripe and stored for food;

and they know (it is said) of trees bearing a fruit whose effect is this: gathering in groups and kindling a fire, the people sit around it and throw the fruit into the flames; then the fumes of it as it burns make them drunk as the  are with wine, and more and more drunk as more fruit is thrown on the fire, until at last they rise up to dance and even sing. Such is said to be their way of life.
The  flows from the country of the  (as does the , which  divided into the three hundred and sixty channels) and empties itself through forty mouths, of which all except one issue into bogs and swamps, where men are said to live whose food is raw fish, and their customary dress sealskins.
The one remaining stream of the  flows in a clear channel into the .This is a sea by itself, not joined to the other sea. For that on which the  sail, and the sea beyond the pillars of , which they call , and the , are all one:


but the  is separate and by itself. Its length is what a ship rowed by oars can traverse in fifteen days, and its breadth, where it is broadest, is an eight days' journey. Along its western shore stretches the range of , which has more and higher peaks than any other range. Many and all kinds of nations dwell in the , and the most of them live on the fruits of the forest.
Here, it is said, are trees growing leaves that men crush and mix with water and use for painting figures on their clothing; these figures cannot be washed out, but last as long as the wool, as if they had been woven into it from the first. Men and women here (they say) have intercourse openly, like beasts of the flock.


This sea called  is hemmed in to the west by the : towards the east and the sunrise there stretches from its shores a boundless plain as far as the eye can see. The greater part of this wide plain is the country of the , against whom  was eager to lead his army.
For there were many weighty reasons that impelled and encouraged him to do so: first, his birth, because of which he seemed to be something more than mortal; and next, his victories in his wars: for no nation that  undertook to attack could escape from him.


Now at this time the  were ruled by a queen called , whose husband was dead.  sent a message with a pretence of wanting her for his wife, but  would have none of his advances, well understanding that he wanted not her but the kingdom of the .
So when guile was of no avail,  marched to the  and openly prepared to attack the ; he bridged the river for his army to cross, and built towers on the pontoons bridging the river.


But while he was busy at this,  sent a herald to him with this message: O king of the , stop hurrying on what you are hurrying on, for you cannot know whether the completion of this work will be for your advantage. Stop, and be king of your own country; and endure seeing us ruling those whom we rule.
But if you will not take this advice, and will do anything rather than remain at peace, then if you so greatly desire to try the strength of the , stop your present work of bridging the river, and let us withdraw three days' journey from the ; and when that is done, cross into our country.
Or if you prefer to receive us into your country, then withdraw yourself as I have said. Hearing this,  called together the leading  and laid the matter before them, asking them to advise him which he should do. They all spoke to the same end, urging him to let  and her army enter his country.


But  the , who was present, was displeased by their advice and spoke against it. O King, he said, you have before now heard from me that since  has given me to you I will turn aside to the best of my ability whatever misadventure I see threatening your house. And disaster has been my teacher.
Now, if you think that you and the army that you lead are immortal, I have no business giving you advice; but if you know that you and those whom you rule are only men, then I must first teach you this: men's fortunes are on a wheel, which in its turning does not allow the same man to prosper forever.
So, if that is the case, I am not of the same opinion about the business in hand as these other counsellors of yours. This is the danger if we agree to let the enemy enter your country: if you lose the battle, you lose your empire also, for it is plain that if the  win they will not retreat but will march against your provinces.
And if you conquer them, it is a lesser victory than if you crossed into their country and routed the  and pursued them; for I weigh your chances against theirs, and suppose that when you have beaten your adversaries you will march for the seat of ' power.
And besides what I have shown, it would be a shameful thing and not to be endured if  the son of  should yield and give ground before a woman. Now then, it occurs to me that we should cross and go forward as far as they draw back, and that then we should endeavor to overcome them by doing as I shall show.
As I understand, the  have no experience of the good things of , and have never fared well as to what is greatly desirable. Therefore, I advise you to cut up the meat of many of your sheep and goats into generous portions for these men, and to cook it and serve it as a feast in our camp, providing many bowls of unmixed wine and all kinds of food.
Then let your army withdraw to the river again, leaving behind that part of it which is of least value. For if I am not mistaken in my judgment, when the  see so many good things they will give themselves over to feasting on them; and it will be up to us then to accomplish great things.


So these opinions clashed; and  set aside his former plan and chose that of ; consequently, he told  to draw her army off, for he would cross (he said) and attack her; so she withdrew as she had promised before. Then he entrusted  to the care of his own son , to whom he would leave his sovereignty, telling  to honor  and treat him well if the crossing of the river against the  should not go well. With these instructions, he sent the two back to , and he and his army crossed the river.


After he had crossed the , he dreamed that night while sleeping in the country of the  that he saw the eldest of ' sons with wings on his shoulders, the one wing overshadowing  and the other .

 son of  was an , and  was the eldest of his sons, then about twenty years old; this  had been left behind in , not yet being of an age to go on campaign.
So when  awoke he considered his vision, and because it seemed to him to be of great importance, he sent for  and said to him privately, , I have caught your son plotting against me and my sovereignty; and I will tell you how I know this for certain.
The gods care for me and show me beforehand all that is coming. Now then, I have seen in a dream in the past night your eldest son with wings on his shoulders, overshadowing  with the one and  with the other.
From this vision, there is no way that he is not plotting against me. Therefore hurry back to , and see that when I come back after subjecting this country you bring your son before me to be questioned about this.


 said this, thinking that  was plotting against him; but in fact, heaven was showing him that he himself was to die in the land where he was and  inherit his kingdom.
So then  replied with this: O King, may there not be any  born who would plot against you! But if there is, may he perish suddenly; for you have made the  free men instead of slaves and rulers of all instead of subjects of any.
But if your vision does indeed signify that my son is planning revolution, I give him to you to treat as you like.


After having given this answer and crossed the ,  went to  to watch his son for ; and , advancing a day's journey from the , acted according to ' advice.

 and the sound portion of the  army marched back to the , leaving behind those that were useless; a third of the  forces attacked those of the army who were left behind and destroyed them despite resistance; then, when they had overcome their enemies, seeing the banquet spread they sat down and feasted, and after they had had their fill of food and wine, they fell asleep.
Then the  attacked them, killing many and taking many more alive, among whom was the son of  the queen,  by name, the leader of the .


When  heard what had happened to her army and her son, she sent a herald to  with this message:

 who can never get enough blood, do not be elated by what you have done; it is nothing to be proud of if, by the fruit of the vinewith which you  fill yourselves and rage so violently that evil words rise in a flood to your lips when the wine enters your bodiesif, by tricking him with this drug, you got the better of my son, and not by force of arms in battle.
Now, then, take a word of good advice from me: give me back my son and leave this country unpunished, even though you have savaged a third of the  army. But if you will not, then I swear to you by the sun, lord of the , that I shall give even you who can never get enough of it your fill of blood.


 dismissed this warning when it was repeated to him. But , the son of the queen , after the wine wore off and he recognized his evil plight, asked  to be freed from his bonds; and this was granted him; but as soon as he was freed and had the use of his hands, he did away with himself.


Such was the end of . , when  would not listen to her, collected all her forces and engaged him. This fight I judge to have been the fiercest ever fought by men that were not ; and indeed I have learned that this was so.
For first (it is said) they shot arrows at each other from a distance; then, when their arrows were all spent, they rushed at each other and fought with their spears and swords; and for a long time they stood fighting and neither would give ground; but at last the  got the upper hand.
The greater part of the  army was destroyed there on the spot, and  himself fell there, after having reigned for one year short of thirty years.

 filled a skin with human blood, and searched among the  dead for ' body; and when she found it, she pushed his head into the skin, and insulted the dead man in these words:

Though I am alive and have defeated you in battle, you have destroyed me, taking my son by guile; but just as I threatened, I give you your fill of blood. Many stories are told of ' death; this, that I have told, is the most credible.


These  are like the  in their dress and way of life. They are both cavalry and infantry (having some of each kind), and spearmen and archers; and it is their custom to carry battle-axes. They always use gold and bronze; all their spear-points and arrow-heads and battle-axes are bronze and the adornment of their headgear and belts and girdles is gold.
They equip their horses similarly, protecting their chests with bronze breastplates and putting gold on reins, bits, and cheekplates. But they never use iron and silver, for there is none at all in their country, but gold and bronze abound.


Now for their customs: each man marries a wife, but the wives are common to all. The  say this is a  custom; it is not, but a custom of the . There, when a man desires a woman, he hangs his quiver before her wagon, and has intercourse with her without fear.
Though they fix no certain term to life, yet when a man is very old all his family meet together and kill him, with beasts of the flock besides, then boil the flesh and feast on it.
This is held to be the happiest death; when a man dies of an illness, they do not eat him, but bury him in the earth, and lament that he did not live to be killed. They never plant seed; their fare is their livestock and the fish which they take in abundance from the .
Their drink is milk. The sun is the only god whom they worship; they sacrifice horses to him; the reasoning is that he is the swiftest of the gods, and therefore they give him the swiftest of mortal things.

title: Iliad
Odyssey
Iliad

l.#text: There were the robes, all embroidered,
The work of women of , whom godlike  himself
Brought from , crossing the broad sea,
The same voyage on which he brought back  of noble descent.
The daughter of  had such ingenious drugs,
Good ones, which she had from 's wife, , an ,

l: Whose country's fertile plains bear the most drugs,
Many mixed for good, many for harm:

l.#text: I was eager to return here, but the gods still held me in ,

l: Since I had not sacrificed entire hecatombs to them.

p.#text:
After the death of ,  inherited his throne. He was the son of  and of , the daughter of , for whom  mourned deeply when she died before him, and had all his subjects mourn also.

 was the son of this woman and of . He considered the  and  slaves inherited from his father, and prepared an expedition against , taking with him some of these  subjects besides others whom he ruled.


Now before  became king of , the  believed that they were the oldest people on earth. But ever since  became king and wished to find out which people were the oldest, they have believed that the  were older than they, and they than everybody else.

, when he was in no way able to learn by inquiry which people had first come into being, devised a plan by which he took two newborn children of the common people and gave them to a shepherd to bring up among his flocks. He gave instructions that no one was to speak a word in their hearing; they were to stay by themselves in a lonely hut, and in due time the shepherd was to bring goats and give the children their milk and do everything else necessary.

 did this, and gave these instructions, because he wanted to hear what speech would first come from the children, when they were past the age of indistinct babbling. And he had his wish; for one day, when the shepherd had done as he was told for two years, both children ran to him stretching out their hands and calling Bekos! as he opened the door and entered.
When he first heard this, he kept quiet about it; but when, coming often and paying careful attention, he kept hearing this same word, he told his master at last and brought the children into the king's presence as required.  then heard them himself, and asked to what language the word Bekos belonged; he found it to be a  word, signifying bread.
Reasoning from this, the  acknowledged that the  were older than they. This is the story which I heard from the priests of ' temple at ; the  say among many foolish things that  had the children reared by women whose tongues he had cut out.


Besides this story of the rearing of the children, I also heard other things at  in conversation with the priests of ; and I visited 
 and , too, for this very purpose, because I wished to know if the people of those places would tell me the same story as the priests at ; for the people of  are said to be the most learned of the .
Now, such stories as I heard about the gods I am not ready to relate, except their names, for I believe that all men are equally knowledgeable about them; and I shall say about them what I am constrained to say by the course of my history.


But as to human affairs, this was the account in which they all agreed: the , they said, were the first men who reckoned by years and made the year consist of twelve divisions of the seasons. They discovered this from the stars (so they said). And their reckoning is, to my mind, a juster one than that of the ; for the  add an intercalary month every other year, so that the seasons agree; but the , reckoning thirty days to each of the twelve months, add five days in every year over and above the total, and thus the completed circle of seasons is made to agree with the calendar.
Furthermore, the  (they said) first used the names of twelve gods (which the  afterwards borrowed from them); and it was they who first assigned to the several gods their altars and images and temples, and first carved figures on stone. Most of this they showed me in fact to be the case. The first human king of , they said, was .
In his time all of  except the  district was a marsh: all the country that we now see was then covered by water, north of , which is seven days' journey up the river from the sea.


And I think that their account of the country was true. For even if a man has not heard it before, he can readily see, if he has sense, that that  to which the  sail is land deposited for the , the river's giftnot only the lower country, but even the land as far as three days' voyage above the lake, which is of the same nature as the other, although the priests did not say this, too.
For this is the nature of the land of : in the first place, when you approach it from the sea and are still a day's sail from land, if you let down a sounding line you will bring up mud from a depth of eleven fathoms. This shows that the deposit from the land reaches this far.


Further, the length of the seacoast of  itself is sixty schoeni of , that is, as we judge it to be, reaching from the  to the , which is under the between these there is this length of sixty schoeni.
Men that have scant land measure by feet; those that have more, by miles; those that have much land, by parasangs; and those who have great abundance of it, by schoeni.
The parasang is three and three quarters miles, and the schoenus, which is an  measure, is twice that.


By this reckoning, then, the seaboard of  will be four hundred and fifty miles in length. Inland from the sea as far as ,  is a wide land, all flat and watery and marshy. From the sea up to  is a journey about as long as the way from the altar of the twelve gods at  to the temple of  at .
If a reckoning is made, only a little difference of length, not more than two miles, will be found between these two journeys; for the journey from  to  is two miles short of two hundred, which is the number of miles between the sea and .


Beyond and above ,  is a narrow land. For it is bounded on the one side by the mountains of , which run north to south, always running south towards the sea called the . In these mountains are the quarries that were hewn out for making the pyramids at . This way, then, the mountains run, and end in the places of which I have spoken; their greatest width from east to west, as I learned by inquiry, is a two months' journey, and their easternmost boundaries yield frankincense.
Such are these mountains. On the side of ,  is bounded by another range of rocky mountains among which are the pyramids; these are all covered with sand, and run in the same direction as those  hills that run southward.
Beyond , there is no great distancein , that is: the narrow land has a length of only fourteen days' journey up the river. Between the aforesaid mountain ranges, the land is level, and where the plain is narrowest it seemed to me that there were no more than thirty miles between the  and those that are called . Beyond this  is a wide land again. Such is the nature of this country.


From  to 
 is nine days' journey by river, and the distance is six hundred and eight miles, or eighty-one schoeni.
This, then, is a full statement of all the distances in : the seaboard is four hundred and fifty miles long; and I will now declare the distance inland from the sea to 
: it is seven hundred and sixty-five miles. And between 
 and the city called  there are two hundred and twenty-five miles.


The greater portion, then, of this country of which I have spoken was land deposited for the  as the priests told me, and I myself formed the same judgment; all that lies between the ranges of mountains above  to which I have referred seemed to me to have once been a gulf of the sea, just as the country about  and  and  and the plain of the , to compare these small things with great.
For of the rivers that brought down the stuff to make these lands, there is none worthy to be compared for greatness with even one of the mouths of the , and the  has five mouths.
There are also other rivers, not so great as the , that have had great effects; I could rehearse their names, but principal among them is the , which, flowing through  and emptying into the sea, has already made half of the  mainland.


Now in , not far from , there is a gulf extending inland from the sea called Red , whose length and width are such as I shall show:

in length, from its inner end out to the wide sea, it is a forty days' voyage for a ship rowed by oars; and in breadth, it is half a day's voyage at the widest. Every day the tides ebb and flow in it.
I believe that where  is now, there was once another such gulf; this extended from the northern sea towards , and the other, the  gulf of which I shall speak, extended from the south towards ; the ends of these gulfs penetrated into the country near each other, and but a little space of land separated them.
Now, if the  inclined to direct its current into this  gulf, why should the latter not be silted up by it inside of twenty thousand years? In fact, I expect that it would be silted up inside of ten thousand years. Is it to be doubted, then, that in the ages before my birth a gulf even much greater than this should have been silted up by a river so great and so busy?


As for , then, I credit those who say it, and myself very much believe it to be the case; for I have seen that  projects into the sea beyond the neighboring land, and shells are exposed to view on the mountains, and things are coated with salt, so that even the pyramids show it, and the only sandy mountain in  is that which is above ;

besides,  is like neither the neighboring land of  nor , not even like  (for  inhabit the seaboard of ); it is a land of black and crumbling earth, as if it were alluvial deposit carried down the river from ;

but we know that the soil of  is redder and somewhat sandy, and  and  are lands of clay and stones.


This, too, that the priests told me about , is a strong proof: when  was king, if the river rose as much as thirteen feet, it watered all of  below .  had not been dead nine hundred years when I heard this from the priests. But now, if the river does not rise at least twenty-six or twenty-five feet, the land is not flooded.
And, in my opinion, the  who inhabit the lands lower down the river than , and especially what is called the Deltaif this land of theirs rises in the same proportion and broadens likewise in extent, and the  no longer floods itwill forever after be in the same straits as they themselves once said the  would be;

for, learning that all the  land is watered by rain, but not by river water like theirs, they said that one day the  would be let down by what they counted on, and miserably starve: meaning that, if heaven send no rain for the  and afflict them with drought, the  will be overtaken by famine, for there is no other source of water for them except  alone.


And this prediction of the  about the  was true enough. But now let me show the prospect for the  themselves: if, as I have already said, the country below  (for it is this which rises) should increase in height in the same proportion as formerly, will not the  who inhabit it go hungry, as there is no rain in their country and the river will be unable to inundate their fields?
At present, of course, there are no people, either in the rest of  or in the whole world, who live from the soil with so little labor; they do not have to break the land up with the plough, or hoe, or do any other work that other men do to get a crop; the river rises of itself, waters the fields, and then sinks back again; then each man sows his field and sends swine into it to tread down the seed, and waits for the harvest; then he has the swine thresh his grain, and so garners it.


Now if we agree with the opinion of the , who say that only the Delta is , and that its seaboard reaches from the so-called  forty schoeni to the Salters' at , while inland it stretches as far as the city of , where the  divides and flows to  and , and that all the rest of  is partly  and partly if we follow this account, we can show that there was once no land for the ;

for we have seen that (as the  themselves say, and as I myself judge) the Delta is alluvial land and but lately (so to speak) came into being. Then if there was once no land for them, it was an idle notion that they were the oldest nation on earth, and they need not have made that trial to see what language the children would first speak.
I maintain, rather, that the  did not come into existence together with what the  call the Delta, but have existed since the human race came into being; and as the land grew in extent, there were many of them who stayed behind, and many who spread down over it. Be that as it may, the  district, a land of seven hundred and sixty-five miles in circumference, was in the past called .


If, then, our judgment of this is right, the  are in error concerning ; but if their opinion is right, then it is plain that they and the rest of the  cannot reckon truly, when they divide the whole earth into three parts, , , and ;

they must add to these a fourth part, the Delta of , if it belongs neither to  nor to ; for by their showing the  is not the river that separates  and ; the  divides at the apex of this Delta, so that this land must be between  and .


We leave the ' opinion aside, and our own judgment about the matter is this:  is all that country which is inhabited by , just as  and  are the countries inhabited by  and , and we know of no boundary line (rightly so called) below  and  except the borders of the .
But if we follow the belief of the , we shall consider all  commencing from the Cataracts and the city of  to be divided into two parts, and to claim both the names, the one a part of  and the other of .
For the , beginning from the Cataracts, divides  into two parts as it flows to the sea. Now, as far as the city  the  flows in one channel, but after that it parts into three.
One of these, which is called the  mouth, flows east; the second flows west, and is called the . But the direct channel of the , when the river in its downward course reaches the apex of the Delta, flows thereafter clean through the middle of the Delta into the sea; in this is seen the greatest and most famous part of its waters, and it is called the .
There are also two channels which separate themselves from the  and so flow into the sea: by name, the  and the .
The  and  mouths are not natural but excavated channels.


The response of oracle of  in fact bears witness to my opinion, that  is of such an extent as I have argued; I learned this by inquiry after my judgment was already formed about .
The men of the cities of  and , in the part of  bordering on , believing themselves to be  and not , and disliking the injunction of the religious law that forbade them to eat cows' meat, sent to  saying that they had no part of or lot with : for they lived (they said) outside the Delta and did not consent to the ways of its people, and they wished to be allowed to eat all foods.
But the god forbade them: all the land, he said, watered by the  in its course was , and all who lived lower down than the city  and drank the river's water were . Such was the oracle given to them.


When the  is in flood, it overflows not only the Delta but also the lands called  and , as far as two days' journey from either bank in places, and sometimes more than this, sometimes less. Concerning its nature, I could not learn anything either from the priests or from any others.
Yet I was anxious to learn from them why the  comes down with a rising flood for a hundred days from the summer solstice; and when this number of days is passed, sinks again with a diminishing stream, so that the river is low for the whole winter until the summer solstice again.
I was not able to get any information from any of the  regarding this, when I asked them what power the  has to be contrary in nature to all other rivers. I wished to know this, and asked; also, why no breezes blew from it as from every other river.


But some of the , wishing to be notable for cleverness, put forward three opinions about this river, two of which I would not even mention except just to show what they are.
One of them maintains that the  winds are the cause of the river being in flood, because they hinder the  from emptying into the sea. But there are many times when the  winds do not blow, yet the  does the same as before.
And further, if the  winds were the cause, then the other rivers which flow contrary to those winds should be affected like the , and even more so, since being smaller they have a weaker current. Yet there are many rivers in  and many in , and they behave nothing like the .


The second opinion is less grounded on knowledge than the previous, though it is more marvellous to the ear: according to it, the river effects what it does because it flows from Ocean, which flows around the whole world.


The third opinion is by far the most plausible, yet the most erroneous of all. It has no more truth in it than the others. According to this, the  flows from where snows melt; but it flows from  through the midst of , and comes out into .
How can it flow from snow, then, seeing that it comes from the hottest places to lands that are for the most part cooler? In fact, for a man who can reason about such things, the principal and strongest evidence that the river is unlikely to flow from snows is that the winds blowing from  and  are hot.
In the second place, the country is rainless and frostless; but after snow has fallen, it has to rain within five days ; so that if it snowed, it would rain in these lands. And thirdly, the men of the country are black because of the heat.
Moreover, kites and swallows live there all year round, and cranes come every year to these places to winter there, flying from the wintry weather of . Now, were there but the least fall of snow in this country through which the  flows and where it rises, none of these things would happen, as necessity proves.


The opinion about Ocean is grounded in obscurity and needs no disproof; for I know of no Ocean river; and I suppose that Homer or some older poet invented this name and brought it into his poetry.


If, after having condemned the opinions proposed, I must indicate what I myself think about these obscure matters, I shall say why I think the  floods in the summer. During the winter, the sun is driven by storms from his customary course and passes over the inland parts of .
For the briefest demonstration, everything has been said; for whatever country this god is nearest, or over, it is likely that that land is very thirsty for water and that the local rivers are dried up.


A lengthier demonstration goes as follows. In its passage over the inland parts of , the sun does this: as the air is always clear in that region, the land warm, and the winds cool, the sun does in its passage exactly as it would do in the summer passing through the middle of the heaven:

it draws the water to itself, and having done so, expels it away to the inland regions, and the winds catch it and scatter and dissolve it; and, as is to be expected, those that blow from that country, the south and the southwest, are the most rainy of all winds.
Yet I think that the sun never lets go of all of the water that it draws up from the  yearly, but keeps some back near itself. Then, as the winter becomes milder, the sun returns to the middle of the heaven, and after that draws from all rivers alike.
Meanwhile, the other rivers are swollen to high flood by the quantity of water that falls into them from the sky, because the country is rained on and cut into gullies; but in the summer they are low, lacking the rain and being drawn up too by the sun.
But the , being fed by no rain, and being the only river drawn up by the sun in winter, at this time falls far short of the height that it had in summer; which is but natural; for in summer all other waters too and not it alone are attracted to the sun, but in the winter it alone is afflicted.


I am convinced, therefore, that the sun is the cause of this phenomenon. The dryness of the air in these parts is also caused by the sun, in my opinion, because it burns its way through it; hence, it is always summer in the inland part of .
But were the stations of the seasons changed, so that the south wind and the summer had their station where the north wind and winter are now set, and the north wind was where the south wind is nowif this were so, the sun, when driven from mid-heaven by the winter and the north wind, would pass over the inland parts of  as it now passes over , and I think that in its passage over all  it would have the same effect on the  as it now does on the .


And as to why no breeze blows from the river, this is my opinion: it is not natural that any breeze blow from very hot places; breezes always come from that which is very cold.


Let this be, then, as it is and as it was in the beginning. But as to the sources of the , no one that conversed with me, , , or , professed to know them, except the recorder of the sacred treasures of  in the  city of .
I thought he was joking when he said that he had exact knowledge, but this was his story. Between the city of  in the  and , there are two hills with sharp peaks, one called  and the other .
The springs of the , which are bottomless, rise between these hills; half the water flows north towards , and the other half south towards .
He said that  king of  had put to the test whether the springs are bottomless: for he had a rope of many thousand fathoms' length woven and let down into the spring, but he could not reach to the bottom.
This recorder, then, if he spoke the truth, showed, I think, that there are strong eddies and an upward flow of water, such that with the stream rushing against the hills the sounding-line when let down cannot reach bottom.


I was unable to learn anything from anyone else, but this much further I did learn by the most extensive investigation that I could make, going as far as the city of  to look myself, and beyond that by question and hearsay.
Beyond , as one travels inland, the land rises. Here one must pass with the boat roped on both sides as men harness an ox; and if the rope breaks, the boat will be carried away by the strength of the current.
This part of the river is a four days' journey by boat, and the  here is twisty just as the ; a distance of twelve schoeni must be passed in the foregoing manner. After that, you come to a level plain, where there is an island in the , called .
The country above  now begins to be inhabited by : half the people of the island are , and half . Near the island is a great lake, on whose shores live nomadic . After crossing this, you come to the stream of the , which empties into this lake.
Then you disembark and journey along the river bank for forty days; for there are sharp projecting rocks in the  and many reefs, through which no boat can pass.
Having traversed this part in forty days as I have said, you take boat again and so travel for twelve days until you come to a great city called , which is said to be the capital of all .
The people of the place worship no other gods but  and ; these they greatly honor, and they have a place of divination sacred to ; they send out armies whenever and wherever this god through his oracle commands them.


From this city you make a journey by water equal in distance to that by which you came from  to the capital city of , and you come to the land of the . These  are called , which translates, in , as those who stand on the left hand of the king.
These once revolted and joined themselves to the , two hundred and forty thousand  of fighting age. The reason was as follows. In the reign of , there were watchposts at  facing , at  of  facing  and , and at  facing .
And still in my time the  hold these posts as they were held in the days of ; there are  guards at  and at . Now the  had been on guard for three years, and no one came to relieve them; so, organizing and making common cause, they revolted from  and went to .

 heard of it and pursued them; and when he overtook them, he asked them in a long speech not to desert their children and wives and the gods of their fathers. Then one of them, the story goes, pointed to his genitals and said that wherever that was, they would have wives and children.
So they came to , and gave themselves up to the king of the country; who, to make them a gift in return, told them to dispossess certain  with whom he was feuding, and occupy their land. These  then learned  customs and have become milder-mannered by intermixture with the .


To a distance of four months' travel by land and water, then, there is knowledge of the , besides the part of it that is in . So many months, as reckoning shows, are found to be spent by one going from  to the country of the Deserters. The river flows from the west and the sun's setting. Beyond this, no one has clear information to declare; for all that country is desolate because of the heat.


But I heard this from some men of , who told me that they had gone to the oracle of , and conversed there with  king of the , and that from other subjects the conversation turned to the , how no one knows the source of it. Then  told them that once he had been visited by some .
These are a  people, inhabiting the country of the  and a little way to the east of the .
When these  were asked on their arrival if they brought any news concerning the  desert, they told  that some sons of their leading men, proud and violent youths, when they came to manhood, besides planning other wild adventures, had chosen by lot five of their company to visit the deserts of  and see whether they could see any farther than those who had seen the farthest.
It must be known that the whole northern seacoast of , from  as far as the promontory of , which is the end of , is inhabited throughout its length by , many tribes of them, except the part held by  and ; the region of  that is above the sea and the inhabitants of the coast is infested by wild beasts; and farther inland than the wild-beast country everything is sand, waterless and desolate.
When the young men left their companions, being well supplied with water and provisions, they journeyed first through the inhabited country, and after passing this they came to the region of wild beasts.
After this, they travelled over the desert, towards the west, and crossed a wide sandy region, until after many days they saw trees growing in a plain; when they came to these and were picking the fruit of the trees, they were met by little men of less than common stature, who took them and led them away. The  did not know these men's language nor did the escort know the language of the .
The men led them across great marshes, after crossing which they came to a city where all the people were of a stature like that of the guides, and black. A great river ran past this city, from the west towards the rising sun; crocodiles could be seen in it.


This is enough of the story told by  the ; except he said that the  returned, as the men of  told me, and that the people to whose country they came were all wizards;

as to the river that ran past the city,  guessed it to be the ; and reason proves as much. For the  flows from , right through the middle of it; and as I guess, reasoning about things unknown from visible signs, it rises proportionally as far away as does the .
For the  flows from the land of the  and the city of  through the very middle of ; now the  live beyond the Pillars of , being neighbors of the , who are the westernmost of all the peoples inhabiting .
The , then, flows clean across  and ends its course in the , at , which is inhabited by  colonists.


The , since it flows through inhabited country, is known from many reports; but no one can speak of the source of the ; for , though which it runs, is uninhabited and desert. Regarding its course, I have related everything that I could learn by inquiry; and it issues into . Now  lies about opposite to the mountainous part of ;
