and they say that afterwards the girl strangled herself for grief, and that he buried her in this cow, but that her mother cut off the hands of the attendants who had betrayed the daughter to her father, and that now their statues are in the same condition as the living women were.
But this I believe to be a silly story, especially about the hands of the figures. For in fact we ourselves saw that the hands have fallen off through age, and were lying at their feet even in my day.


As for the cow, it is covered with a purple robe, only the head and neck exposed, encrusted with a very thick layer of gold. Between the horns is the golden figure of the sun's orb.
It does not stand, but kneels; it is as big as a live cow of great size. This image is carried out of the chamber once every year, whenever the  mourn the god whose name I omit in speaking of these matters:

then the cow is brought out into the light; for they say that before she died she asked her father, , that she see the sun once a year.


After what happened to his daughter, the following happened next to this king: an oracle came to him from the city of , announcing that he had just six years to live and was to die in the seventh.
The king took this badly, and sent back to the oracle a message of reproach, blaming the god that his father and his uncle, though they had shut up the temples, and disregarded the gods, and destroyed men, had lived for a long time, but that he who was pious was going to die so soon.
But a second oracle came announcing that for this very reason his life was hastening to a close: he had done what was contrary to fate;  should have been afflicted for a hundred and fifty years, and the two kings before him knew this, but not he.
Hearing this,  knew that his doom was fixed. Therefore, he had many lamps made, and would light these at nightfall and drink and enjoy himself, not letting up day or night, roaming to the marsh country and the groves and wherever he heard of the likeliest places of pleasure.
This was his recourse, so that by turning night into day he might make his six years into twelve and so prove the oracle false.


This king, too, left a pyramid, but far smaller than his father's, each side twenty feet short of three hundred feet long, square at the base, and as much as half its height of  stone. Some  say that it was built by , the courtesan, but they are wrong;

indeed, it is clear to me that they say this without even knowing who  was (otherwise, they would never have credited her with the building of a pyramid on which what I may call an uncountable sum of money was spent), or that  flourished in the reign of , not of ;

for very many years later than these kings who left the pyramids came , who was  by birth, and a slave of  son of  the , and a fellow-slave of  the story-writer. For he was owned by , too, as the following made crystal clear:

when the , obeying an oracle, issued many proclamations summoning anyone who wanted it to accept compensation for the killing of , no one accepted it except the son of 's son, another ; hence , too, was 's.


 came to  to work, brought by  of , but upon her arrival was freed for a lot of money by  of , son of  and brother of  the poetess.
Thus  lived as a free woman in , where, as she was very alluring, she acquired a lot of moneysufficient for such a , so to speak, but not for such a pyramid.
Seeing that to this day anyone who likes can calculate what one tenth of her worth was, she cannot be credited with great wealth. For  desired to leave a memorial of herself in , by having something made which no one else had thought of or dedicated in a temple and presenting this at  to preserve her memory;

so she spent one tenth of her substance on the manufacture of a great number of iron beef spits, as many as the tenth would pay for, and sent them to ; these lie in a heap to this day, behind the altar set up by the  and in front of the shrine itself.
The courtesans of  seem to be peculiarly alluring, for the woman of whom this story is told became so famous that every  knew the name of , and later on a certain  was the theme of song throughout , although less celebrated than the other.

, after giving  her freedom, returned to . He is bitterly attacked by  in one of her poems. This is enough about .


After , the priests said,  became king of . He built the eastern outer court of ' temple; this is by far the finest and grandest of all the courts, for while all have carved figures and innumerable felicities of architecture, this court has far more than any.
As not much money was in circulation during this king's reign, they told me, a law was made for the  allowing a man to borrow on the security of his father's corpse; and the law also provided that the lender become master of the entire burial-vault of the borrower, and that the penalty for one giving this security, should he fail to repay the loan, was that he was not to be buried at his death either in that tomb of his fathers or in any other, nor was he to bury any relative of his there.
Furthermore, in his desire to excel all who ruled  before him, this king left a pyramid of brick to commemorate his name, on which is this writing, cut on a stone:

Do not think me less than pyramids of stone; for I excel them as much as  does other gods; for they stuck a pole down into a marsh and collected what mud clung to the pole, made bricks of it, and thus built me. These were the acts of .


After him reigned a blind man called , of the town of that name. In his reign  was invaded by  king of  and a great army of .
The blind man fled to the marshes, and the  ruled  for fifty years, during which he distinguished himself for the following:

he would never put to death any  wrongdoer but sentenced all, according to the severity of their offenses, to raise embankments in their native towns. Thus the towns came to stand yet higher than before;

for after first being built on embankments made by the excavators of the canals in the reign of , they were yet further raised in the reign of the .
Of the towns in  that were raised, in my opinion,  is especially prominent, where there is also a temple of , a building most worthy of note. Other temples are greater and more costly, but none more pleasing to the eye than this.  is, in the  language, .


Her temple is of this description: except for the entrance, it stands on an island; for two channels approach it from the  without mixing with one another, running as far as the entryway of the temple, the one and the other flowing around it, each a hundred feet wide and shaded by trees.
The outer court is sixty feet high, adorned with notable figures ten feet high. The whole circumference of the city commands a view down into the temple in its midst; for the city's level has been raised, but that of the temple has been left as it was from the first, so that it can be seen into from above.
A stone wall, cut with figures, runs around it; within is a grove of very tall trees growing around a great shrine where the image of the goddess is; the temple is a square, each side measuring an eighth of a mile.
A road, paved with stone, about three eighths of a mile long leads to the entrance, running eastward through the marketplace, towards the temple of ; this road is about four hundred feet wide, and bordered by trees reaching to heaven. Such is this temple.


Now the departure of the  (they said) came about in this way. After seeing in a dream one who stood over him and urged him to gather together all the Priests in  and cut them in half, he fled from the country.
Seeing this vision, he said, he supposed it to be a manifestation sent to him by the gods, so that he might commit sacrilege and so be punished by gods or men; he would not (he said) do so, but otherwise, for the time foretold for his rule over  was now fulfilled, after which he was to depart:

for when he was still in , the oracles that are consulted by the people of that country told him that he was fated to reign fifty years over . Seeing that this time was now completed and that he was troubled by what he saw in his dream,  departed from  of his own volition.


When the  left , the blind man (it is said) was king once more, returning from the marshes where he had lived for fifty years on an island that he built of ashes and earth; for the  who were to bring him food without the 's knowledge were instructed by the king to bring ashes whenever they came, to add to their gift.
This island was never discovered before the time of ; all the kings before him sought it in vain for more than seven hundred years. The name of it is , and it is over a mile long and of an equal breadth.


The next king was the priest of  whose name was . He despised and had no regard for the warrior , thinking he would never need them; besides otherwise dishonoring them, he took away the chosen lands which had been given to them, twelve fields to each man, in the reign of former kings.
So when presently king  came against , with a great force of  and , the warrior  would not march against him.
The priest, in this quandary, went into the temple shrine and there before the god's image bitterly lamented over what he expected to suffer. Sleep came on him while he was lamenting, and it seemed to him the god stood over him and told him to take heart, that he would come to no harm encountering the power of : I shall send you champions, said the god.
So he trusted the vision, and together with those  who would follow him camped at , where the road comes into ; and none of the warriors would go with him, but only merchants and craftsmen and traders.
Their enemies came there, too, and during the night were overrun by a horde of field mice that gnawed quivers and bows and the handles of shields, with the result that many were killed fleeing unarmed the next day.
And to this day a stone statue of the  king stands in ' temple, with a mouse in his hand, and an inscription to this effect: Look at me, and believe.


Thus far went the record given by the  and their priests; and they showed me that the time from the first king to that priest of , who was the last, covered three hundred and forty-one generations, and that in this time this also had been the number of their kings, and of their high priests.
Now three hundred generations are ten thousand years, three generations being equal to a hundred. And over and above the three hundred, the remaining forty-one cover thirteen hundred and forty years.
Thus the whole period is eleven thousand three hundred and forty years; in all of which time (they said) they had had no king who was a god in human form, nor had there been any such either before or after those years among the rest of the kings of .
Four times in this period (so they told me) the sun rose contrary to experience; twice he came up where he now goes down, and twice went down where he now comes up; yet  at these times underwent no change, either in the produce of the river and the land, or in the matter of sickness and death.


 the historian was once at 
, where he made a genealogy for himself that had him descended from a god in the sixteenth generation. But the priests of  did with him as they also did with me (who had not traced my own lineage).
They brought me into the great inner court of the temple and showed me wooden figures there which they counted to the total they had already given, for every high priest sets up a statue of himself there during his lifetime;

pointing to these and counting, the priests showed me that each succeeded his father; they went through the whole line of figures, back to the earliest from that of the man who had most recently died.
Thus, when  had traced his descent and claimed that his sixteenth forefather was a god, the priests too traced a line of descent according to the method of their counting; for they would not be persuaded by him that a man could be descended from a god; they traced descent through the whole line of three hundred and forty-five figures, not connecting it with any ancestral god or hero, but declaring each figure to be a Piromis the son of a Piromis; in , one who is in all respects a good man.


Thus they showed that all those whose statues stood there had been good men, but quite unlike gods.
Before these men, they said, the rulers of  were gods, but none had been contemporary with the human priests. Of these gods one or another had in succession been supreme; the last of them to rule the country was ' son , whom the  call ; he deposed , and was the last divine king of .  is, in the  language, .


Among the , , , and Pan are held to be the youngest of the gods. But in , Pan is the most ancient of these and is one of the eight gods who are said to be the earliest of all;  belongs to the second dynasty (that of the so-called twelve gods); and  to the third, which came after the twelve.
How many years there were between  and the reign of , I have already shown; Pan is said to be earlier still; the years between  and  are the fewest, and they are reckoned by the  at fifteen thousand.
The  claim to be sure of all this, since they have reckoned the years and chronicled them in writing.
Now the  who was called the son of , daughter of , was about sixteen hundred years before my time, and  son of  about nine hundred years; and Pan the son of  (for according to the   and  were the parents of Pan) was about eight hundred years before me, and thus of a later date than the  war.


With regard to these two, Pan and , one may follow whatever story one thinks most credible; but I give my own opinion concerning them here. Had  son of  and Pan son of  appeared in  and lived there to old age, like  the son of , it might have been said that they too (like ) were but men, named after the older Pan and , the gods of antiquity;

but as it is, the  story has it that no sooner was  born than  sewed him up in his thigh and carried him away to  in  beyond ; and as for Pan, the  do not know what became of him after his birth. It is therefore plain to me that the  learned the names of these two gods later than the names of all the others, and trace the birth of both to the time when they gained the knowledge.


So far I have recorded what the  themselves say. I shall now relate what is recorded alike by  and foreigners, and shall add something of what I myself have seen.

After the reign of the priest of  the  were made free. But they could never live without a king, so they divided  into twelve districts and set up twelve kings.
These kings intermarried, and agreed to be close friends, no one deposing another or seeking to possess more than another.
The reason for this agreement, which they scrupulously kept, was this: no sooner were they established in their districts than an oracle was given them that whichever of them poured a libation from a bronze vessel in the temple of  (where, as in all the temples, they used to assemble) would be king of all .


Moreover, they decided to preserve the memory of their names by a common memorial, and so they made a labyrinth a little way beyond  and near the place called the . I have seen it myself, and indeed words cannot describe it;

if one were to collect the walls and evidence of other efforts of the , the sum would not amount to the labor and cost of this labyrinth. And yet the temple at  and the one on  are noteworthy.
Though the pyramids beggar description and each one of them is a match for many great monuments built by , this maze surpasses even the pyramids.
It has twelve roofed courts with doors facing each other: six face north and six south, in two continuous lines, all within one outer wall. There are also double sets of chambers, three thousand altogether, fifteen hundred above and the same number under ground.
We ourselves viewed those that are above ground, and speak of what we have seen, but we learned through conversation about the underground chambers;
the  caretakers would by no means show them, as they were, they said, the burial vaults of the kings who first built this labyrinth, and of the sacred crocodiles.
Thus we can only speak from hearsay of the lower chambers; the upper we saw for ourselves, and they are creations greater than human. The exits of the chambers and the mazy passages hither and thither through the courts were an unending marvel to us as we passed from court to apartment and from apartment to colonnade, from colonnades again to more chambers and then into yet more courts.
Over all this is a roof, made of stone like the walls, and the walls are covered with cut figures, and every court is set around with pillars of white stone very precisely fitted together. Near the corner where the labyrinth ends stands a pyramid two hundred and forty feet high, on which great figures are cut. A passage to this has been made underground.


Such is this labyrinth; and still more marvellous is , on which it stands. This lake has a circumference of four hundred and fifty miles, or sixty schoeni: as much as the whole seaboard of . Its length is from north to south; the deepest part has a depth of fifty fathoms.
That it has been dug out and made by men's hands the lake shows for itself; for almost in the middle of it stand two pyramids, so built that fifty fathoms of each are below and fifty above the water; atop each is a colossal stone figure seated on a throne.
Thus these pyramids are a hundred fathoms high; and a hundred fathoms equal a furlong of six hundred feet, the fathom measuring six feet or four cubits, the foot four spans and the cubit six spans.
The water of the lake is not natural (for the country here is exceedingly arid) but brought by a channel from the ; six months it flows into the lake, and six back into the river.
For the six months that it flows out of the lake, the daily take of fish brings a silver talent into the royal treasury, and twenty minae for each day of the flow into the lake.


Furthermore, the natives said that this lake drains underground into the , and extends under the mountains that are above , having the inland country on its west.
When I could not see anywhere the earth taken from the digging of this lake, since this was curious to me, I asked those who live nearest the lake where the stuff was that had been dug out. They told me where it had been carried, and I readily believed them, for I had heard of a similar thing happening in the  city of .

 king of  had great wealth, which he kept in an underground treasury. Some thieves plotted to carry it off; they surveyed their course and dug an underground way from their own house to the palace, carrying the earth taken out of the passage dug by night to the , which runs past , until at last they accomplished their end.
This, I was told, had happened when the  was dug, except that the work went on not by night but by day. The  bore the earth dug out by them to the , to be caught and scattered (as was to be expected) by the river. Thus is this lake said to have been dug.


Now the twelve kings were just, and in time came to sacrifice in ' temple. On the last day of the feast, as they were about to pour libations, the high priest brought out the golden vessels which they commonly used for this; but he counted wrongly and had only eleven for the twelve.
So the last in line, , as he had no vessel, took off his bronze helmet and held it out and poured the libation with it. All the kings were accustomed to wear helmets, and were then helmeted;

it was not in guile, then, that  held out his headgear; but the rest perceived what  had done, and remembered the oracle that promised the sovereignty of all  to whoever poured a libation from a vessel of bronze; therefore, though they considered  not deserving of death (for they examined him and found that he had acted without intent), they decided to strip him of most of his power and to chase him away into the marshes, and that he was not to concern himself with the rest of .


This  had formerly been in exile in , where he had fled from  the , who killed his father ; then, when the  departed because of what he saw in a dream, the  of the district of  brought him back from .

 was king for the second time when he found himself driven away into the marshes by the eleven kings because of the helmet.
Believing, therefore, that he had been abused by them, he meant to be avenged on those who had expelled him. He sent to inquire in the town of , where the most infallible oracle in  is; the oracle answered that he would have vengeance when he saw men of bronze coming from the sea.

 did not in the least believe that men of bronze would come to aid him. But after a short time,  and , voyaging for plunder, were forced to put in on the coast of , where they disembarked in their armor of bronze; and an  came into the marsh country and brought news to  (for he had never before seen armored men) that men of bronze had come from the sea and were foraging in the plain.

 saw in this the fulfillment of the oracle; he made friends with the  and , and promised them great rewards if they would join him and, having won them over, deposed the eleven kings with these allies and those  who volunteered.


Having made himself master of all , he made the southern outer court of ' temple at , and built facing this a court for , where  is kept and fed whenever he appears; this court has an inner colonnade all around it and many cut figures; the roof is held up by great statues twenty feet high for pillars.  in  is .


To the  and  who had helped him,  gave places to live in called , opposite each other on either side of the ; and besides this, he paid them all that he had promised.
Moreover, he put  boys in their hands to be taught , and from these, who learned the language, are descended the present-day  interpreters.
The  and  lived for a long time in these places, which are near the sea, on the arm of the  called the , a little way below the town of . Long afterwards, king  removed them and settled them at  to be his guard against the .
It is a result of our communication with these settlers in  (the first of foreign speech to settle in that country) that we  have exact knowledge of the history of  from the reign of  onwards.
There still remained in my day, in the places out of which the  and  were turned, the winches for their ships and the ruins of their houses. This is how  got .


I have often mentioned the  oracle, and shall give an account of this, as it deserves. This oracle is sacred to , and is situated in a great city by the  of the , on the way up from the sea.

 is the name of the city where this oracle is; I have already mentioned it. In  there is a temple of  and . The shrine of  where the oracle is, is itself very great, and its outer court is sixty feet high.
But what caused me the most wonder among the things apparent there I shall mention. In this precinct is the shrine of , the height and length of whose walls is all made of a single stone slab; each wall has an equal length and height; namely, seventy feet. Another slab makes the surface of the roof, the cornice of which is seven feet broad.


Thus, then, the shrine is the most marvellous of all the things that I saw in this temple; but of things of second rank, the most wondrous is the island called .
This lies in a deep and wide lake near the temple at , and the  say that it floats. I never saw it float, or move at all, and I thought it a marvellous tale, that an island should truly float.
However that may be, there is a great shrine of  on it, and three altars stand there; many palm trees grow on the island, and other trees too, some yielding fruit and some not.
This is the story that the  tell to explain why the island moves: that on this island that did not move before, , one of the eight gods who first came to be, who was living at  where this oracle of hers is, taking charge of  from , hid him for safety in this island which is now said to float, when  came hunting through the world, keen to find the son of .

 and  were (they say) children of  and , and  was made their nurse and preserver; in ,  is ,  ,  .
It was from this legend and no other that  son of  took a notion which is in no poet before him: that  was the daughter of . For this reason the island was made to float. So they say.


 ruled  for fifty-three years, twenty-nine of which he spent before , a great city in , besieging it until he took it.  held out against a siege longer than any city of which we know.


 had a son, , who became king of . It was he who began building the canal into the , which was finished by  the . This is four days' voyage in length, and it was dug wide enough for two triremes to move in it rowed abreast.
It is fed by the , and is carried from a little above  by the  town of ; it issues into the . Digging began in the part of the  plain nearest to ; the mountains that extend to  (the mountains where the stone quarries are) come close to this plain;

the canal is led along the foothills of these mountains in a long reach from west to east; passing then into a ravine, it bears southward out of the hill country towards the .
Now the shortest and most direct passage from the northern to the southern or  is from the  promontory, the boundary between  and , to the , and this is a distance of one hundred and twenty five miles, neither more nor less;

this is the most direct route, but the canal is far longer, inasmuch as it is more crooked. In ' reign, a hundred and twenty thousand  died digging it.  stopped work, stayed by a prophetic utterance that he was toiling beforehand for the barbarian. The  call all men of other languages barbarians.


, then, stopped work on the canal and engaged in preparations for war; some of his ships of war were built on the northern sea, and some in the , by the  coast: the winches for landing these can still be seen.
He used these ships when needed, and with his land army met and defeated the  at , taking the great  city of  after the battle.
He sent to  of  and dedicated there to  the garments in which he won these victories. Then he died after a reign of sixteen years, and his son  reigned in his place.


While this  was king of , he was visited by ambassadors from , the  boasting that they had arranged the  games with all the justice and fairness in the world, and claiming that even the , although the wisest of all men, could not do better.
When the  came to  and announced why they had come,  assembled the  reputed to be wisest. These assembled and learned all that the  were to do regarding the games; after explaining this, the  said that they had come to learn whether the  could discover any juster way.
The  deliberated, and then asked the  if their own citizens took part in the contests. The  answered that they did: all  from  or elsewhere might contend.
Then the  said that in establishing this rule they fell short of complete fairness: For there is no way that you will not favor your own townsfolk in the contest and wrong the stranger; if you wish in fact to make just rules and have come to  for that reason, you should admit only strangers to the contest, and not . Such was the counsel of the  to the .


 reigned over  for only six years; he invaded , and immediately thereafter died, and  the son of  reigned in his place.
He was more fortunate than any former king (except his great-grandfather ) during his rule of twenty-five years, during which he sent an army against  and fought at sea with the king of .
But when it was fated that evil should overtake him, the cause of it was something that I will now deal with briefly, and at greater length in the  part of this history.

 sent a great force against  and suffered a great defeat. The  blamed him for this and rebelled against him; for they thought that  had knowingly sent his men to their doom, so that after their perishing in this way he might be the more secure in his rule over the rest of the . Bitterly angered by this, those who returned home and the friends of the slain openly revolted.


Hearing of this,  sent  to dissuade them. When  came up with the , he exhorted them to desist; but as he spoke an  came behind him and put a helmet on his head, saying it was the token of royalty.
And  showed that this was not displeasing to him, for after being made king by the rebel  he prepared to march against .
When  heard of it, he sent against  an esteemed  named , one of his own court, instructing him to take the rebel alive and bring him into his presence. When  came and summoned ,  (who was on horseback) rose up and farted, telling the messenger to take that back to .
But when in spite of this  insisted that  obey the king's summons and go to him,  answered that he had long been preparing to do just that, and  would find him above reproach, for he would present himself, and bring others.
Hearing this,  could not mistake ; he saw his preparations and hastened to depart, the more quickly to make known to the king what was going on. When  saw him return without , he did not stop to reflect, but in his rage and fury had ' ears and nose cut off.
The rest of the , who were until now ' friends, seeing this outrage done to the man who was most prominent among them, changed sides without delay and offered themselves to .


Learning of this, too,  armed his guard and marched against the ; he had a bodyguard of  and , thirty thousand of them, and his royal palace was in the city of , a great and marvellous palace.

' men marched against the , and so did ' men against the foreigners. So they both came to  and were going to make trial of one another.


The  are divided into seven classes: priests, warriors, cowherds, swineherds, merchants, interpreters, and pilots. There are this many classes, each named after its occupation.
The warriors are divided into  and , and they belong to the following districts (for all divisions in  are made according to districts).


The  are from the districts of , , , and , the island called , and half of from all of these; their number, at its greatest, attained to a hundred and sixty thousand. None of these has learned any common trade; they are free to follow the profession of arms alone.


The  are from the districts of 
, , , , , , , , , , ,  (this last is in an island opposite the city of )

from all of these; their number, at its greatest, attained to two hundred and fifty thousand men. These too may practise no trade but war, which is their hereditary calling.


Now whether this, too, the  have learned from the , I cannot confidently judge. I know that in  and  and  and  and nearly all foreign countries, those who learn trades are held in less esteem than the rest of the people, and those who have least to do with artisans' work, especially men who are free to practise the art of war, are highly honored.
This much is certain: that this opinion, which is held by all  and particularly by the , is of foreign origin. It is in  that artisans are held in least contempt.


The warriors were the only , except the priests, who had special privileges: for each of them an untaxed plot of twelve acres was set apart. This acre is a square of a hundred  cubits each way, the  cubit being equal to the .
These lands were set apart for all; it was never the same men who cultivated them, but each in turn. A thousand  and as many  were the king's annual bodyguard. These men, besides their lands, each received a daily provision of five minae's weight of roast grain, two minae of beef, and four cups of wine. These were the gifts received by each bodyguard.


When  with his guards and  with the whole force of  came to the town of , they engaged; and though the foreigners fought well, they were vastly outnumbered, and therefore were beaten.

, they say, supposed that not even a god could depose him from his throne, so firmly did he think he was established; and now, defeated in battle and taken captive, he was brought to , to the royal dwelling which belonged to him once but now belonged to .
There, he was kept alive for a while in the palace and well treated by . But presently the  complained that there was no justice in keeping alive one who was their own and their king's bitterest enemy; whereupon  gave  up to them, and they strangled him and then buried him in the burial-place of his fathers.
This is in the temple of , very near to the sanctuary, on the left of the entrance. The people of  buried within the temple precinct all kings who were natives of their district.
The tomb of  is farther from the sanctuary than the tomb of  and his ancestors; yet it, too, is within the temple court; it is a great colonnade of stone, richly adorned, the pillars made in the form of palm trees. In this colonnade are two portals, and the place where the coffin lies is within their doors.


There is also at  the burial-place of one whose name I think it impious to mention in speaking of such a matter; it is in the temple of , behind and close to the length of the wall of the shrine.
Moreover, great stone obelisks stand in the precinct; and there is a lake nearby, adorned with a stone margin and made in a complete circle; it is, as it seemed to me, the size of the lake at  which they call the .


On this lake they enact by night the story of the god's sufferings, a rite which the  call the Mysteries. I could say more about this, for I know the truth, but let me preserve a discreet silence.
Let me preserve a discreet silence, too, concerning that rite of  which the  call  , except as much of it as I am not forbidden to mention.
The daughters of  were those who brought this rite out of  and taught it to the  women; afterwards, when the people of the  were driven out by the , it was lost, except in so far as it was preserved by the , the  people which was not driven out but left in its home.


After  was deposed,  became king; he was from a town called  in the district of .
Now at first he was scorned and held in low regard by the  on the ground that he was a common man and of no high family; but presently he won them over by being shrewd and not arrogant.
He had among his countless treasures a golden washbowl, in which he and all those who ate with him were accustomed to clean their feet. This he broke in pieces and out of it made a god's image, which he set in a most conspicuous spot in the city; and the  came frequently to this image and held it in great reverence.
When  learned what the townsfolk were doing, he called the  together and told them that the image had been made out of the washbowl, in which  had once vomited and urinated and cleaned their feet, but which now they greatly revered.

Now then, he said, I have fared like the washbowl, since if before I was a common man, still, I am your king now. And he told them to honor and show respect for him.


The following was how he scheduled his affairs: in the morning, until the the hour when the marketplace filled, he readily conducted whatever business was brought to him; the rest of the day, he drank and joked at the expense of his companions and was idle and playful.
But this displeased his friends, who admonished him thus: O King, you do not conduct yourself well by indulging too much in vulgarity. You, a celebrated man, ought to conduct your business throughout the day, sitting on a celebrated throne; and thus the  would know that they are governed by a great man, and you would be better spoken of; as it is, what you do is by no means kingly.
But he answered them like this: Men that have bows string them when they must use them, and unstring them when they have used them; were bows kept strung forever, they would break, and so could not be used when needed.
Such, too, is the nature of man. Were one to be always at serious work and not permit oneself a bit of relaxation, he would go mad or idiotic before he knew it; I am well aware of that, and give each of the two its turn. Such was his answer to his friends.


It is said that even when  was a private man he was fond of drinking and joking and was not at all a sober man; and that when his drinking and pleasure-seeking cost him the bare necessities, he would go around stealing. Then when he contradicted those who said that he had their possessions, they would bring him to whatever place of divination was nearby, and sometimes the oracles declared him guilty and sometimes they acquitted him.
When he became king, he did not take care of the shrines of the gods who had acquitted him of theft, or give them anything for maintenance, or make it his practice to sacrifice there, for he knew them to be worthless and their oracles false; but he took scrupulous care of the gods who had declared his guilt, considering them to be gods in very deed and their oracles infallible.


 made a marvellous outer court for the temple of  at , far surpassing all in its height and size, and in the size and quality of the stone blocks; moreover, he set up huge images and vast man-headed sphinxes, and brought enormous blocks of stone besides for the building.
Some of these he brought from the stone quarries of ; the largest came from the city of , twenty days' journey distant by river from .
But what I admire most of his works is this: he brought from  a shrine made of one single block of stone; its transport took three years and two thousand men had the carriage of it, all of them pilots. This chamber is thirty-five feet long, twenty-three feet wide, thirteen feet high.
These are the external dimensions of the chamber which is made of one block; its internal dimensions are: thirty-one feet long, twenty feet wide, eight feet high. It stands at the entrance of the temple;

it was not dragged within (so they say) because while it was being drawn the chief builder complained aloud of the great expense of time and his loathing of the work, and  taking this to heart would not let it be drawn further. Some also say that a man, one of those who heaved up the shrine, was crushed by it, and therefore it was not dragged within.


Furthermore,  dedicated, besides monuments of marvellous size in all the other temples of note, the huge image that lies supine before ' temple at ; this image is seventy-five feet in length; there stand on the same base, on either side of the great image, two huge statues hewn from the same block, each of them twenty feet high.
There is at  another stone figure of like size, supine as is the figure at . It was , too, who built the great and most marvellous temple of  at .


It is said that in the reign of   attained to its greatest prosperity, in respect of what the river did for the land and the land for its people: and that the number of inhabited cities in the country was twenty thousand.
It was  also who made the law that every  declare his means of livelihood to the ruler of his district annually, and that omitting to do so or to prove that one had a legitimate livelihood be punishable with death.  the  got this law from  and established it among his people; may they always have it, for it is a perfect law.


 became a philhellene, and besides other services which he did for some of the , he gave those who came to  the city of  to live in; and to those who travelled to the country without wanting to settle there, he gave lands where they might set up altars and make holy places for their gods.
Of these the greatest and most famous and most visited precinct is that which is called the , founded jointly by the  cities of , , , and , the  cities of , , , and Phaselis, and one  city, .
It is to these that the precinct belongs, and these are the cities that furnish overseers of the trading port; if any other cities advance claims, they claim what does not belong to them. The  made a precinct of their own, sacred to ; and so did the  for  and the  for .


 was in the past the only trading port in . Whoever came to any other mouth of the  had to swear that he had not come intentionally, and had then to take his ship and sail to the ; or if he could not sail against contrary winds, he had to carry his cargo in barges around the Delta until he came to . In such esteem was  held.


When the  paid three hundred talents to have the temple that now stands at  finished (as that which was formerly there burnt down by accident), it was the ' lot to pay a fourth of the cost.
They went about from city to city collecting gifts, and got most from ; for  gave them a thousand talents' weight of astringent earth, and the  settlers in  twenty minae.


 made friends and allies of the people of . And he decided to marry from there, either because he had his heart set on a  wife, or for the sake of the ' friendship;

in any case, he married a certain , said by some to be the daughter of , of  by others, and by others again of , an esteemed citizen of the place. But whenever  lay with her, he became unable to have intercourse, though he managed with every other woman;

and when this happened repeatedly,  said to the woman called , Woman, you have cast a spell on me, and there is no way that you shall avoid perishing the most wretchedly of all women.
So , when the king did not relent at all although she denied it, vowed in her heart to  that, if  could have intercourse with her that night, since that would remedy the problem, she would send a statue to  to her. And after the prayer, immediately,  did have intercourse with her. And whenever  came to her thereafter, he had intercourse, and he was very fond of her after this.

 paid her vow to the goddess; she had an image made and sent it to , where it stood safe until my time, facing outside the city. , when he had conquered  and learned who  was, sent her away to  unharmed.


Moreover,  dedicated offerings in . He gave to  a gilt image of  and a painted picture of himself; to  of , two stone images and a marvellous linen breast-plate; and to  in , two wooden statues of himself that were still standing in my time behind the doors in the great shrine.
The offerings in  were dedicated because of the friendship between  and , son of ; what he gave to  was not out of friendship for anyone, but because the temple of  in  is said to have been founded by the daughters of , when they landed there in their flight from the sons of . Such were ' offerings. Moreover, he was the first conqueror of , which he made tributary to himself.

p.#text:
' son  was leading an army of his subjects,  and  among them, against this  for the following reason.  had sent a herald to  asking  for his daughter; he asked on the advice of an , who advised it out of resentment against , that out of all the  physicians  had dragged him away from his wife and children and sent him up to  when  sent to  asking for the best eye-doctor in .
Out of resentment, the  by his advice induced  to ask  for his daughter, so that  would either be wretched if he gave her, or hated by  if he did not. , intimidated by the power of  and frightened, could neither give his daughter nor refuse her; for he knew well that  was not going to take her as his wife but as his concubine.
After considering the matter, he did as follows. There was a daughter of the former king , all that was left of that family, quite tall and pretty, and her name was ; this girl  adorned with clothes and gold and sent to  as his own daughter.
But after a time, as he embraced her addressing her as the daughter of , the girl said to him, O King, you do not understand how you have been made a fool of by , who dressed me in finery and sent me to you as his own daughter, when I am in fact the daughter of , the ruler  revolted from with the  and killed.
This speech and this crime that occurred turned ' son , furiously angry, against . So the  say.


But the , who say that  was the son of this daughter of , claim him as one of theirs; they say that it was  who asked  for his daughter, and not .
But what they say is false. They are certainly not unaware (for if any understand the customs of the  the  do) firstly, that it is not their custom for illegitimate offspring to rule when there are legitimate offspring; and secondly, that  was the son of , the daughter of , who was an , and not of the  woman. But they falsify the story, pretending to be related to the house of . That is the truth of the matter.


The following story, incredible to me, is also told: that one of the  women who came to visit ' wives, and saw the tall and attractive children who stood by , expressed her admiration in extravagant terms. Then , ' wife, said,

Although I am the mother of such children,  dishonors me and honors his new woman from . So she spoke in her bitterness against ; and , the eldest of her sons, said,

Then, mother, when I am grown up, I will turn all  upside down. When he said this, he was about ten years old, and the women were amazed; but he kept it in mind, and it was thus that when he grew up and became king, he made the campaign against .


It so happened, too, that something else occurred contributing to this campaign. There was among ' mercenaries a man who was a  by birth, a clever man and a good soldier, whose name was .
This  had some grudge against , and fled from  aboard ship, hoping to talk to . Since he was a man much admired among the mercenaries and had an exact knowledge of all  matters,  was anxious to catch him, and sent a trireme with his most trusted eunuch to pursue him. This eunuch caught him in  but never brought him back to , for  was too clever for him.
He made his guards drunk and so escaped to . There he found  prepared to set out against , but in doubt as to his march, how he should cross the waterless desert; so  showed him what was ' condition and how he should march; as to this, he advised  to send and ask the king of the  for a safe passage.


Now the only apparent way of entry into  is this. The road runs from  as far as the borders of the city of , which belongs to the so-called  of .
From  (which, as I judge, is a city not much smaller than ) to the city of  the seaports belong to the ; then they are  again from  as far as the  marsh, beside which the  promontory stretches seawards;

from this  marsh, where  is supposed to have been hidden, the country is . Now between  and the  and the  marsh there lies a wide territory for as much as three days' journey, terribly arid.


I am going to mention something now which few of those who sail to  know. Earthen jars full of wine are brought into  twice a year from all  and  besides: yet one might safely say there is not a single empty wine jar anywhere in the country.
What then (one may ask) becomes of them? I shall explain this too. Each governor of a district must gather in all the earthen pots from his own township and take them to , and the people of  must fill them with water and carry them to those arid lands of ; so the earthen pottery that is brought to  and unloaded or emptied there is carried to  to join the stock that has already been taken there.


Now as soon as the  took possession of , they became the caretakers of the entryway into it, having it provisioned with water in the way I have described.
But at this time there was as yet no ready supply of water; and so , hearing what was said by the stranger from , sent messengers to the  and asked and obtained safe conduct, giving to him and receiving from him pledges.


There are no men who respect pledges more than the . This is how they give them: a man stands between the two pledging parties, and with a sharp stone cuts the palms of their hands, near the thumb; then he takes a piece of wood from the cloak of each and smears with their blood seven stones that lie between them, meanwhile calling on  and the Heavenly ;

after this is done, the one who has given his pledge commends the stranger (or his countryman if the other be one) to his friends, and his friends hold themselves bound to honor the pledge.
They believe in no other gods except  and the Heavenly ; and they say that they wear their hair as  does his, cutting it round the head and shaving the temples. They call , ; and , .


When, then, the  had made the pledge to the messengers who had come from , he devised the following expedient: he filled camel-skins with water and loaded all his camels with these; then he drove them into the waterless land and there awaited ' army.
This is the most credible of the stories told; but I must relate the less credible tale also, since they tell it. There is a great river in  called , emptying into the sea called Red.
From this river (it is said) the king of the  brought water by an aqueduct made of sewn oxhides and other hides and extensive enough to reach to the dry country; and he had great tanks dug in that country to try to receive and keep the water.
It is a twelve days' journey from the river to that desert. By three aqueducts (they say) he brought the water to three different places.


, son of , was encamped by the mouth of the  called , awaiting .
For when  marched against , he found  no longer alive; he had died after reigning forty-four years, during which he had suffered no great misfortune; and being dead he was embalmed and laid in the burial-place built for him in the temple.
While his son  was king of , the people saw an extraordinary thing, namely, rain at 
 of , where, as the  themselves say, there had never been rain before, nor since to my lifetime; for indeed there is no rain at all in the upper parts of ; but at that time a drizzle of rain fell at 
.


When the  had crossed the waterless country and encamped near the  intending to engage them, the  mercenaries,  and , devised a plan to punish , angered at him for leading a foreign army into .

 had left sons in ; these they brought to the camp, into their father's sight, and set a great bowl between the two armies; then they brought the sons one by one and cut their throats over the bowl.
When all the sons had been slaughtered, they poured wine and water into the bowl, and the mercenaries drank this and then gave battle. The fighting was fierce, and many of both armies fell; but at last the  were routed.


I saw a strange thing on the site of the battle, of which the people of the country had told me. The bones of those killed on either side in this fight lying scattered separately (for the  bones lay in one place and the  in another, where the armies had first separately stood), the skulls of the  are so brittle that if you throw no more than a pebble it will pierce them, but the  skulls are so strong that a blow of a stone will hardly crack them.
And this, the people said (which for my own part I readily believed), is the explanation of it: the  shave their heads from childhood, and the bone thickens by exposure to the sun.
This also is the reason why they do not grow bald; for nowhere can one see so few bald heads as in .
Their skulls then are strong for this reason; while the  skulls are weak because they cover their heads throughout their lives with the felt hats (called tiaras) which they wear. Such is the truth of the matter. I saw too the skulls of those  at  who were killed with ' son  by  the , and they were like the others.


After their rout in the battle the  fled in disorder; and when they had been overtaken in ,  sent a  herald up the river aboard a  boat to invite the  to an accord.
But when they saw the boat coming to , they sallied out all together from their walls, destroyed the boat, dismembered the crew (like butchers) and carried them within the walls.
So the  were besieged, and after a long while surrendered; but the neighboring , frightened by what had happened in , surrendered without a fight, laying tribute on themselves and sending gifts; and so too did the people of  and , frightened like the .

 received in all kindness the gifts of the ; but he seized what came from  and, displeased, I think, because it was so littlefor the  had sent five hundred silver minaecast it with his own hands among his army.


On the tenth day after the surrender of the walled city of ,  took  king of , who had reigned for six months, and confined him in the outer part of the city with other , to insult him; having confined him there, he tried ' spirit, as I shall show.
He dressed the daughter of the king as a slave and sent her out with a pitcher to fetch water, together with other girls from the families of the leading men, dressed like the daughter of the king.
So when the girls went out before their fathers' eyes crying and lamenting, all the rest answered with cries and weeping, seeing their children abused; but , having seen with his own eyes and learned all, bowed himself to the ground.
After the water-carriers had passed by,  next made ' son go out before him with two thousand  of the same age, all with ropes bound round their necks and bridle-bits in their mouths;

they were led out to be punished for those  who had perished with their boat at ; for such was the judgment of the royal judges, that every man's death be paid for by the deaths of ten noble .
When  saw them passing and perceived that his son was being led out to die, and all the  who sat with him wept and showed their affliction, he did as he had done at the sight of his daughter.
After these too had gone out, it happened that there was one of his companions, a man past his prime, who had lost all his possessions, and had only what a poor man might have, and begged of the army; this man now went out before  son of  and the  confined in the outer part of the city. When  saw him, he broke into loud weeping, striking his head and calling on his companion by name.
Now there were men set to watch , who told  all that he did as each went forth. Wondering at what the king did,  made this inquiry of him by a messenger:

,  wants to know why, seeing your daughter abused and your son going to his death, you did not cry out or weep, yet you showed such feeling for the beggar, who (as  learns from others) is not one of your kindred? So the messenger inquired.  answered:

Son of , my private grief was too great for weeping; but the unhappiness of my companion deserves tearsa man fallen from abundance and prosperity to beggary come to the threshold of old age. When the messenger reported this,  and his court, it is said, thought the answer good.
And, the  say,  wept (for it happened that he too had come with  to ) and the  that were there wept;  himself felt some pity, and he ordered that ' son be spared from those that were to be executed, and that  himself be brought in from the outer part of the city and brought before him.


Those that went for him found that the son was no longer alive, but had been the first to be slaughtered; but they brought  up and led him to ; and there he lived, and no violence was done him for the rest of his life.
And if he had known how to mind his own business, he would have regained  to govern; for the  are inclined to honor kings' sons; even though kings revolt from them, they give back to their sons the sovereign power.
There are many instances showing that it is their custom so to do, and notably the giving back of his father's sovereign power to  son of , and also to  son of ; yet none ever did the  more harm than  and .
But as it was,  plotted evil and got his reward; for he was caught raising a revolt among the ; and when  heard of it,  drank bull's blood and died. Such was his end.


From   went to the city Sais, anxious to do exactly what he did do. Entering the house of , he had the body of  carried outside from its place of burial; and when this had been done, he gave orders to scourge it and pull out the hair and pierce it with goads, and to desecrate it in every way.
When they were weary of doing this (for the body, being embalmed, remained whole and did not fall to pieces),  gave orders to burn it, a sacrilegious command; for the  hold fire to be a god;

therefore neither nation thinks it right to burn the dead, the  for the reason given, as they say it is wrong to give the dead body of a man to a god; while the  believe fire to be a living beast that devours all that it catches, and when sated with its meal dies together with that on which it feeds.
Now it is by no means their custom to give the dead to beasts; and this is why they embalm the corpse, that it may not lie and feed worms. Thus what  commanded was contrary to the custom of both peoples.
The  say, however, that it was not  to whom this was done, but another  of the same age as , whom the  abused thinking that they were abusing .
For their story is that  learned from an oracle what was to be done to him after his death, and so to escape this fate buried this dead man, the one that was scourged, near the door inside his own vault, and ordered his son that he himself should be laid in the farthest corner of the vault.
I think that these commands of , regarding the burial-place and the man, were never given at all, and that the  believe in them in vain.


After this  planned three expeditions, against the , against the , and against the long-lived , who inhabit that part of  that is on the southern sea.
He decided after consideration to send his fleet against the  and a part of his land army against the ; to  he would first send spies, to see what truth there was in the story of a Table of the Sun in that country, and to spy out all else besides, under the pretext of bringing gifts for the  king.


Now the Table of the Sun is said to be something of this kind: there is a meadow outside the city, filled with the boiled flesh of all four-footed things; here during the night the men of authority among the townsmen are careful to set out the meat, and all day whoever wishes comes and feasts on it. These meats, say the people of the country, are ever produced by the earth of itself. Such is the story of the Sun's Table.


When  determined to send the spies, he sent for those  from the city of  who understood the  language.
While they were fetching them, he ordered his fleet to sail against . But the  said they would not do it; for they were bound, they said, by strong oaths, and if they sailed against their own progeny they would be doing an impious thing; and the  being unwilling, the rest were inadequate fighters.
Thus the  escaped being enslaved by the ; for  would not use force with the , seeing that they had willingly surrendered to the , and the whole fleet drew its strength from them. The  too had come of their own accord to aid the  against .


When the  arrived from  at ' summons, he sent them to , with orders what to say, and bearing as gifts a red cloak and a twisted gold necklace and bracelets and an alabaster box of incense and an earthenware jar of palm wine. These , to whom  sent them, are said to be the tallest and most handsome of all men.
Their way of choosing kings is different from that of all others, as (it is said) are all their laws; they consider that man worthy to be their king whom they judge to be tallest and to have strength proportional to his stature.


When the  arrived among these men, they gave the gifts to their king and said: , the king of the , wishing to become your friend and ally, sent us with orders to address ourselves to you; and he offers you as gifts these things which he enjoys using himself.
But the , perceiving that they had come as spies, spoke thus to them: It is not because he values my friendship that the  sends you with gifts, nor do you speak the truth (for you have come to spy on my realm), nor is that man just; for were he just, he would not have coveted a land other than his own, nor would he try to lead into slavery men by whom he has not been injured. Now, give him this bow, and this message:

The King of the  advises the King of the  to bring overwhelming odds to attack the long-lived  when the  can draw a bow of this length as easily as I do; but until then, to thank the gods who do not incite the sons of the  to add other land to their own.


So speaking he unstrung the bow and gave it to the men who had come. Then, taking the red cloak, he asked what it was and how it was made; and when the  told him the truth about the color and the process of dyeing, he said that both the men and their garments were full of deceit.
Next he inquired about the twisted gold necklace and the bracelets; and when the  told him how they were made, the king smiled, and, thinking them to be fetters, said: We have stronger chains than these.
Thirdly he inquired about the incense; and when they described making and applying it, he made the same reply as about the cloak. But when he came to the wine and asked about its making, he was vastly pleased with the drink, and asked further what food their king ate, and what was the greatest age to which a  lived.
They told him their king ate bread, showing him how wheat grew; and said that the full age to which a man might hope to live was eighty years. Then, said the , it was no wonder that they lived so few years, if they ate dung; they would not even have been able to live that many unless they were refreshed by the drinksignifying to the  the winefor in this, he said, the  excelled the .


The  then in turn asking of the  length of life and diet, he said that most of them attained to a hundred and twenty years, and some even to more; their food was boiled meat and their drink milk.
The spies showed wonder at the tale of years; whereupon he led them, it is said, to a spring, by washing in which they grew sleeker, as though it were of oil; and it smelled of violets.
So light, the spies said, was this water, that nothing would float on it, neither wood nor anything lighter than wood, but all sank to the bottom. If this water is truly such as they say, it is likely that their constant use of it makes the people long-lived.
When they left the spring, the king led them to a prison where all the men were bound with fetters of gold. Among these  there is nothing so scarce and so precious as bronze. Then, having seen the prison, they saw what is called the Table of the Sun.

Last after this they viewed the  coffins; these are said to be made of alabaster, as I shall describe:

they cause the dead body to shrink, either as the  do or in some other way, then cover it with gypsum and paint it all as far as possible in the likeness of the living man;

then they set it within a hollow pillar of alabaster, which they dig in abundance from the ground, and it is easily worked; the body can be seen in the pillar through the alabaster, no evil stench nor anything unpleasant proceeding from it, and showing clearly all its parts, as if it were the man himself.
The nearest of kin keep the pillar in their house for a year, giving it of the first-fruits and offering it sacrifices; after which they bring the pillars out and set them round about the city.


Having seen everything, the spies departed again. When they reported all this,  was angry, and marched at once against the , neither giving directions for any provision of food nor considering that he was about to lead his army to the ends of the earth;

being not in his right mind but mad, however, he marched at once on hearing from the , ordering the  who were with him to await him where they were, and taking with him all his land army.
When he came in his march to 
, he detached about fifty thousand men from his army, and directed them to enslave the  and burn the oracle of ; and he himself went on towards  with the rest of his host.
But before his army had accomplished the fifth part of their journey they had come to an end of all there was in the way of provision, and after the food was gone, they ate the beasts of burden until there was none of these left either.
Now had , when he perceived this, changed his mind and led his army back again, he would have been a wise man at last after his first fault; but as it was, he went ever forward, taking account of nothing.
While his soldiers could get anything from the earth, they kept themselves alive by eating grass; but when they came to the sandy desert, some did a terrible thing, taking by lot one man out of ten and eating him.
Hearing this,  feared their becoming cannibals, and so gave up his expedition against the  and marched back to 
, with the loss of many of his army; from 
 he came down to , and sent the  to sail away.


So fared the expedition against . As for those who were sent to march against the , they set out and journeyed from 
 with guides; and it is known that they came to the city of Oasis, inhabited by  said to be of the  tribe, seven days' march from 
 across sandy desert; this place is called, in the  language, .
Thus far, it is said, the army came; after that, except for the  themselves and those who heard from them, no man can say anything of them; for they neither reached the  nor returned back.
But this is what the  themselves say: when the  were crossing the sand from Oasis to attack them, and were about midway between their country and Oasis, while they were breakfasting a great and violent south wind arose, which buried them in the masses of sand which it bore; and so they disappeared from sight. Such is the  tale about this army.


When  was back at , there appeared in  that  whom the  call ; at whose epiphany the  put on their best clothing and held a festival.
Seeing the  so doing,  was fully persuaded that these signs of joy were for his misfortunes, and summoned the rulers of ; when they came before him, he asked them why the  behaved so at the moment he returned with so many of his army lost, though they had done nothing like it when he was before at .
The rulers told him that a god, wont to appear after long intervals of time, had now appeared to them; and that all  rejoiced and made holiday whenever he so appeared. At this  said that they lied, and he punished them with death for their lie.


Having put them to death, he next summoned the priests before him. When they gave him the same account, he said that if a tame god had come to the  he would know it; and with no more words he bade the priests bring . So they went to fetch and bring him.
This , or , is a calf born of a cow that can never conceive again. By what the  say, the cow is made pregnant by a light from heaven, and thereafter gives birth to .
The marks of this calf called  are these: he is black, and has on his forehead a three-cornered white spot, and the likeness of an eagle on his back; the hairs of the tail are double, and there is a knot under the tongue.


When the priests led  in, for he was all but maddrew his dagger and, meaning to stab the calf in the belly, stuck the thigh; then laughing he said to the priests:

Simpletons, are these your gods, creatures of flesh and blood that can feel weapons of iron? That is a god worthy of the . But for you, you shall suffer for making me your laughing-stock. So saying he bade those, whose business it was, to scourge the priests well, and to kill any other  whom they found holiday-making.
So the  festival ended, and the priests were punished, and  lay in the temple and died of the wound in the thigh. When he was dead of the wound, the priests buried him without ' knowledge.


But , the  say, owing to this wrongful act immediately went mad, although even before he had not been sensible. His first evil act was to destroy his full brother , whom he had sent away from  to  out of jealousy, because  alone could draw the bow brought from the  by the  as far as two fingerbreadths, but no other  could draw it.

 having gone to ,  saw in a dream a vision, in which it seemed to him that a messenger came from  and told him that  sitting on the royal throne touched heaven with his head.
Fearing therefore for himself, lest his brother might slay him and so be king, he sent , the most trusted of his , to  to kill him.  went up to  and killed ; some say that he took  out hunting, others that he brought him to the Red Sea and there drowned him.


This, they say, was the first of ' evil acts; next, he destroyed his full sister, who had come with him to , and whom he had taken to wife.
He married her in this way (for before this, it had by no means been customary for  to marry their sisters):  was infatuated with one of his sisters and when he wanted to marry her, because his intention was contrary to usage, he summoned the royal judges and inquired whether there were any law enjoining one, that so desired, to marry his sister.
These royal judges are men chosen out from the  to function until they die or are detected in some injustice; it is they who decide suits in  and interpret the laws of the land; all matters are referred to them.
These then replied to  with an answer which was both just and prudent, namely, that they could find no law enjoining a brother to marry his sister; but that they had found a law permitting the King of  to do whatever he liked.
Thus, although they feared  they did not break the law, and, to save themselves from death for keeping it, they found another law abetting one who wished to marry sisters.
So  married the object of his desire; yet not long afterwards he took another sister as well. It was the younger of these who had come with him to , and whom he now killed.


There are two tales of her death, as there are of the death of . The  say that  had set a lion cub to fight a puppy, and that this woman was watching too; and that as the puppy was losing, its brother broke its leash and came to help, and the two dogs together got the better of the cub.

, they say, was pleased with the sight, but the woman wept as she sat by.  perceiving it asked why she wept, and she said that when she saw the puppy help its brother she had wept, recalling  and knowing that there would be no avenger for him.
For saying this, according to the  story, she was killed by . But the  tale is that as the two sat at table the woman took a lettuce and plucked off the leaves, then asked her husband whether he preferred the look of it with or without leaves. With the leaves, he said; whereupon she answered:

Yet you have stripped ' house as bare as this lettuce. Angered at this, they say, he sprang upon her, who was great with child, and she miscarried and died of the hurt he gave her.


Such were ' mad acts to his own household, whether they were done because of  or grew from some of the many troubles that are wont to beset men; for indeed he is said to have been afflicted from his birth with that grievous disease which some call sacred. It is not unlikely then that when his body was grievously afflicted his mind too should be diseased.


I will now relate his mad dealings with the rest of . He said, as they report, to whom he held in particular honor, who brought him all his messages, whose son held the very honorable office of ' cup-bearerthus, I say, he spoke to :

What manner of man, , do the  think me to be, and how do they speak of me? Sire, said , for all else they greatly praise you, but they say that you love wine too well.
So he reported of the . The king angrily replied: If the  now say that it is my fondness for wine that drives me to frenzy and madness, then it would seem that their former saying also was a lie.
For it is said that before this, while some  and  were sitting with him,  asked what manner of man they thought him to be in comparison with  his father; and they answered,  was the better man; for he had all of ' possessions and had won  and the sea besides.
So said the ; but , who was present, and was dissatisfied with their judgment, spoke thus to : To me, son of , you do not seem to be the equal of your father; for you have as yet no son such as he left after him in you. This pleased , and he praised ' judgment.


Remembering this, then, he said to  in his anger: Judge then if the  speak the truth, or rather are themselves out of their minds when they speak of me so.
Yonder stands your son in the porch; now if I shoot and pierce his heart, that will prove the  to be wrong; if I miss, then say that they are right and that I am out of my senses.
So saying, he strung his bow and hit the boy, and gave orders to open the fallen body and examine the wound: and the arrow being found in the heart,  laughed in great glee and said to the boy's father:

It is plain, , that I am in my right mind and the  mad; now tell me: what man in the world did you ever see that shot so true to the mark? , it is said, replied (for he saw that  was mad, and he feared for his own life), Master, I think that not even the god himself could shoot so true.
Thus did  then; at another time he took twelve , equal to the noblest in the land, convicted them of some minor offense, and buried them alive up to the neck.


For these acts  the  thought fit to take him to task, and addressed him thus: Sire, do not sacrifice everything to youth and temper, but restrain and control yourself; prudence is a good thing, forethought is wise. But you kill men of your own country whom you have convicted of some minor offense, and you kill boys.
If you do so often, beware lest the  revolt from you. As for me, your father  earnestly begged me to counsel you and to give you such advice as I think to be good.  gave him this counsel out of goodwill; but  answered:

It is very well that you should even dare to counsel me; you, who governed your own country so well, and gave fine advice to my fathertelling him, when the  were willing to cross over into our lands, to pass the  and attack them; thus you worked your own ruin by misgoverning your country and ', who trusted you. But you shall regret it; I have long waited for an occasion to deal with you.
With that  took his bow to shoot him dead; but  leapt up and ran out; and , being unable to shoot him, ordered his attendants to catch and kill him.
They, knowing ' mood, hid ; intending to reveal him and receive gifts for saving his life, if  should repent and ask for , but if he should not repent nor wish  back, then to kill the .
Not long after this  did wish  back, and the attendants, understanding this, told him that  was alive still.  said that he was glad of it; but that they, who had saved , should not escape with impunity, but be killed; and this was done.


 committed many such mad acts against the  and his allies; he stayed at , and there opened ancient coffins and examined the dead bodies.
Thus too he entered the temple of  and jeered at the image there. This image of  is most like the  , which the  carry on the prows of their triremes. I will describe it for anyone who has not seen these figures: it is the likeness of a dwarf.
Also he entered the temple of the , into which no one may enter save the priest; the images here he even burnt, with bitter mockery. These also are like the images of , and are said to be his sons.


I hold it then in every way proved that  was quite insane; or he would never have set himself to deride religion and custom. For if it were proposed to all nations to choose which seemed best of all customs, each, after examination, would place its own first; so well is each convinced that its own are by far the best.
It is not therefore to be supposed that anyone, except a madman, would turn such things to ridicule. I will give this one proof among many from which it may be inferred that all men hold this belief about their customs.
When  was king, he summoned the  who were with him and asked them for what price they would eat their fathers' dead bodies. They answered that there was no price for which they would do it.
Then  summoned those  who are called , who eat their parents, and asked them (the  being present and understanding through interpreters what was said) what would make them willing to burn their fathers at death. The  cried aloud, that he should not speak of so horrid an act. So firmly rooted are these beliefs; and it is, I think, rightly said in 's poem that custom is lord of all.

While  was attacking , the  too were making war upon  and upon ' son , who had revolted and won .
And first, dividing the city into three parts, he gave a share in the government to his brothers  and ; but presently he put one of them to death, banished the younger, , and so made himself lord of all ; then he made a treaty with  king of , sending to him and receiving from him gifts.
Very soon after this,  grew to such power that he was famous in  and all other  lands; for all his military affairs succeeded. He had a hundred fifty-oared ships, and a thousand archers.
And he pillaged every place, indiscriminately; for he said that he would get more thanks if he gave a friend back what he had taken than if he never took it at all. He had taken many of the islands, and many of the mainland cities. Among others, he conquered the ; they had brought all their force to aid the , and  defeated them in a sea-fight; it was they who, being his captives, dug all the trench around the acropolis of .


Now  was somehow aware of ' great good fortune; and as this continued to increase greatly, he wrote this letter and sent it to :  addresses  as follows.
It is pleasant to learn that a friend and ally is doing well. But I do not like these great successes of yours; for I know the gods, how jealous they are, and I desire somehow that both I and those for whom I care succeed in some affairs, fail in others, and thus pass life faring differently by turns, rather than succeed at everything.
For from all I have heard I know of no man whom continual good fortune did not bring in the end to evil, and utter destruction. Therefore if you will be ruled by me do this regarding your successes:

consider what you hold most precious and what you will be sorriest to lose, and cast it away so that it shall never again be seen among men; then, if after this the successes that come to you are not mixed with mischances, strive to mend the matter as I have counselled you.


Reading this, and perceiving that ' advice was good,  considered which of his treasures it would most grieve his soul to lose, and came to this conclusion: he wore a seal set in gold, an emerald, crafted by  son of  of ;

being resolved to cast this away, he embarked in a fifty-oared ship with its crew, and told them to put out to sea; and when he was far from the island, he took off the seal-ring in sight of all that were on the ship and cast it into the sea. This done, he sailed back and went to his house, where he grieved for the loss.


But on the fifth or sixth day from this it happened that a fisherman, who had taken a fine and great fish, and desired to make a gift of it to , brought it to the door and said that he wished to see . This being granted, he gave the fish, saying:

O King, when I caught this fish, I thought best not to take it to market, although I am a man who lives by his hands, but it seemed to me worthy of you and your greatness; and so I bring and offer it to you.  was pleased with what the fisherman said; You have done very well, he answered, and I give you double thanks, for your words and for the gift; and I invite you to dine with me.
Proud of this honor, the fisherman went home; but the servants, cutting up the fish, found in its belly ' seal-ring.
As soon as they saw and seized it, they brought it with joy to , and giving the ring to him told him how it had been found.  saw the hand of heaven in this matter; he wrote a letter and sent it to , telling all that he had done, and what had happened to him.


When  had read ' letter, he perceived that no man could save another from his destiny, and that , being so continually fortunate that he even found what he cast away, must come to an evil end.
So he sent a herald to  to renounce his friendship, determined that when some great and terrible mischance overtook  he himself might not have to sadden his heart for a friend.
