It was against this ever-victorious  that the  now made war, invited by the  who afterwards founded  in .  had without the knowledge of his subjects sent a herald to , son of , then raising an army against , inviting  to send to  too and request men from him.
At this message  very readily sent to , asking  to send a fleet to aid him against .  chose those men whom he most suspected of planning a rebellion against him, and sent them in forty triremes, directing  not to send the men back.


Some say that these  who were sent never came to , but that when they had sailed as far as  discussed the matter among themselves and decided to sail no further; others say that they did come to  and there escaped from the guard that was set over them.
But as they sailed back to , ' ships met and engaged them; and the returning  were victorious and landed on the island, but were there beaten in a land battle, and so sailed to .
There are those who say that the  from  defeated ; but to my thinking this is untrue; for they need not have invited the  if in fact they had been able to master  by themselves. Besides, it is not even reasonable to suppose that he, who had a great army of hired soldiers and bowmen of his own, was beaten by a few men like the returning .

 took the children and wives of the townsmen who were subject to him and shut them up in the boathouses, with intent to burn them and the boathouses too if their men should desert to the returned .


When the  who were expelled by  came to , they came before the ruling men and made a long speech to show the greatness of their need. But the  at their first sitting answered that they had forgotten the beginning of the speech and could not understand its end.
After this the  came a second time with a sack, and said nothing but this: The sack wants flour. To this the  replied that they were over-wordy with the sack; but they did resolve to help them.


The  then equipped and sent an army to , returning a favor, as the  say, because they first sent a fleet to help the  against ; but the  say that they sent this army less to aid the  in their need than to avenge the robbery of the bowl which they had been carrying to  and the breastplate which  King of  had sent them as a gift.
This breastplate had been stolen by the  in the year before they took the bowl; it was of linen, decked with gold and cotton embroidery, and embroidered with many figures;

but what makes it worthy of wonder is that each thread of the breastplate, fine as each is, is made up of three hundred and sixty strands, each plainly seen. It is the exact counterpart of that one which  dedicated to  in .


The  also enthusiastically helped to further the expedition against . For an outrage had been done them by the  a generation before this expedition, about the time of the robbery of the bowl.

 son of  sent to  at  three hundred boys, sons of notable men in , to be made eunuchs. The  who brought the boys put in at ; and when the  heard why the boys were brought, first they instructed them to take sanctuary in the temple of ,

then they would not allow the suppliants to be dragged from the temple; and when the  tried to starve the boys out, the  held a festival which they still celebrate in the same fashion; throughout the time that the boys were seeking asylum, they held nightly dances of young men and women to which it was made a custom to bring cakes of sesame and honey, so that the  boys might snatch these and have food.
This continued to be done until the  guards left their charge and departed; then the  took the boys back to .


If after the death of , the  had been friendly towards the , they would not have taken part in the expedition against  for this reason. But as it was, ever since the island was colonized, they have been at odds with each other, despite their kinship.
For these reasons then the  bore a grudge against the . chose the sons of the notable  and sent them to  to be made eunuchs as an act of vengeance; for the  had first begun the quarrel by committing a terrible crime against him.


For after killing his own wife ,  suffered yet another calamity on top of what he had already suffered. He had two sons by , one seventeen and one eighteen years old.
Their mother's father, , the sovereign of , sent for the boys and treated them affectionately, as was natural, seeing that they were his own daughter's sons. When they left him, he said as he sent them forth:

Do you know, boys, who killed your mother? The elder of them paid no attention to these words; but the younger, whose name was , was struck with such horror when he heard them that when he came to  he would not speak to his father, his mother's murderer, nor would he answer him when addressed nor reply to his questions. At last  was so angry that he drove the boy from his house.


Having driven this one away, he asked the elder son what their grandfather had said to them. The boy told him that  had treated them kindly, but did not mention what he had said at parting; for he had paid no attention.  said that by no means could  not have dropped some hint, and interrogated him persistently;

until the boy remembered, and told him. And , comprehending, and wishing to show no weakness, sent a message to those with whom his banished son was living and forbade them to keep him.
So when the boy, driven out, would go to another house, he would be driven from this also, since  threatened all who received him and ordered them to shut him out; so when driven forth, he would go to some other house of his friends, and they, although he was the son of , and although they were afraid, nonetheless took him in.


In the end  made a proclamation, that whoever sheltered the boy in his house or spoke to him, would owe a fine to , and he set the amount.
In view of this proclamation no one wished to address or receive the boy into his house; and besides, the boy himself did not think it right to attempt what was forbidden, but accepting it slept in the open.
On the fourth day, when  saw him starved and unwashed, he took pity on him, and his anger being softened, he came near and said: My son, which is preferableto follow your present way of life, or by being well-disposed toward your father to inherit my power and the goods which I now possess?
Though my son and a prince of prosperous , you prefer the life of a vagrant, by opposing and being angry with me with whom you least ought to be. For if something has happened as a result of which you have a suspicion about me, it has happened to my disadvantage and I bear the brunt of it, inasmuch as I am the cause.
But bearing in mind how much better it is to be envied than to be pitied, and at the same time what sort of thing it is to be angry with your parents and with those that are stronger than you, come back to the house.
With these words  tried to move his son, but he said nothing else to his father, only told him that because he had conversed with him he owed the fine to . When  saw that his son's stubbornness could not be got around or overcome, he sent him away out of his sight in a ship to ; for  too was subject to him.
And when he had sent him away, he sent an army against  his father-in-law, since he was most to blame for his present troubles; and he took , captured , and imprisoned him.


As time went on, , now grown past his prime and aware that he could no longer oversee and direct all his affairs, sent to  inviting  to be sovereign; for he saw no hope in his eldest son, who seemed to him to be slow-witted.

 did not dignify the invitation with a reply. Then , pressing the young man, sent to him (as the next best way) his daughter, the boy's sister, thinking that he would listen to her.
She came and said, Child, would you want the power to fall to others, and our father's house destroyed, rather than to return and have it yourself? Come home and stop punishing yourself.
Pride is an unhappy possession. Do not cure evil by evil. Many place the more becoming thing before the just; and many pursuing their mother's business have lost their father's. Power is a slippery thing; many want it, and our father is now old and past his prime; do not lose what is yours to others.
So she spoke communicating their father's inducements. But he answered that he would never come to  as long as he knew his father was alive.
When she brought this answer back,  sent a third messenger, through whom he proposed that he should go to , and that the boy should return to  and be the heir of his power.
The son consented to this;  got ready to go to  and  to go to ; but when the  learned of all these matters, they put the young man to death so that  would not come to their country. It was for this that  desired vengeance on the .


The  then came with a great army, and besieged . They advanced to the wall and entered the tower that stands by the seaside in the outer part of the city; but then  himself attacked them with a great force and drove them out.
The mercenaries and many of the  themselves sallied out near the upper tower on the ridge of the hill and withstood the  advance for a little while; then they fled back, with the  pursuing and destroying them.


Had all the  there that day been like  and ,  would have been taken. These two alone entered the fortress along with the fleeing crowd of , and were cut off and killed in the city of .
I myself have met in his native town of  another  son of , and grandson of the  mentioned above, who honored the  more than any other of his guest-friends, and told me that his father had borne the name  because he was the son of that  who was killed fighting bravely at . The reason that he honored the , he said, was that they had given his grandfather a public funeral.

So when the  had besieged  for forty days with no success, they went away to the .
There is a foolish tale abroad that  bribed them to depart by making and giving them a great number of gilded lead coins, as a native currency. This was the first expedition to  made by  of .


When the  were about to abandon them, the  who had brought an army against  sailed away too, and went to ;

for they were in need of money; and the  were at this time very prosperous and the richest of the islanders, because of the gold and silver mines on the island. They were so wealthy that the treasure dedicated by them at , which is as rich as any there, was made from a tenth of their income; and they divided among themselves each year's income.
Now when they were putting together the treasure they inquired of the oracle if their present prosperity was likely to last long; whereupon the priestess gave them this answer:



At this time the market-place and town-hall of  were adorned with  marble.

They could not understand this oracle either when it was spoken or at the time of the ' coming. As soon as the  put in at , they sent ambassadors to the town in one of their ships;

now in ancient times all ships were painted with vermilion; and this was what was meant by the warning given by the priestess to the , to beware a wooden force and a red herald.
The messengers, then, demanded from the  a loan of ten talents; when the  refused them, the  set about ravaging their lands.
Hearing this the  came out at once to drive them off, but they were defeated in battle, and many of them were cut off from their town by the ; who presently exacted from them a hundred talents.


Then the  took from the men of , instead of money, the island  which is near to the , and gave it to men of  for safekeeping; they themselves settled at  in , though their voyage had been made with no such intent, but rather to drive  out of the island.
Here they stayed and prospered for five years; indeed, the temples now at  and the shrine of  are the ' work;

but in the sixth year  and  came and defeated them in a sea-fight and made slaves of them; moreover they cut off the ships' prows, that were shaped like boars' heads, and dedicated them in the temple of  in .
The  did this out of a grudge against the ; for previously the , in the days when  was king of , sailing in force against , had hurt the  and been hurt by them. This was the cause.


I have written at such length of the , because the three greatest works of all the  were engineered by them. The first of these is the tunnel with a mouth at either end driven through the base of a hill nine hundred feet high;

the whole tunnel is forty-two hundred feet long, eight feet high and eight feet wide; and throughout the whole of its length there runs a channel thirty feet deep and three feet wide, through which the water coming from an abundant spring is carried by pipes to the city of .
The designer of this work was  son of , a . This is one of the three works; the second is a breakwater in the sea enclosing the harbor, sunk one hundred and twenty feet, and more than twelve hundred feet in length.
The third  work is the temple, which is the greatest of all the temples of which we know; its first builder was  son of , a . It is for this cause that I have expounded at more than ordinary length of .


Now after , son of , had lost his mind, while he was still in , two  brothers rebelled against him. One of them had been left by  as steward of his house; this man now revolted from him, perceiving that the death of  was kept secret, and that few knew of it, most believing him to be still alive.
Therefore he plotted to gain the royal power: he had a brother, his partner, as I said, in rebellion; this brother was in appearance very like ' son , whom , his brother, had killed; nor was he like him in appearance only, but he bore the same name too, .

 the  persuaded this man that he would manage everything for him; he brought his brother and set him on the royal throne; then he sent heralds to all parts, one of whom was to go to  and proclaim to the army that henceforth they must obey not  but , the son of .


So this proclamation was made everywhere. The herald appointed to go to , finding  and his army at  in , came out before them all and proclaimed the message given him by the .
When  heard what the herald said, he supposed that it was the truth, and that , when sent to kill , had not done it but had played  false; and he said, fixing his eyes on , Is it thus, , that you carried out my instructions?

No, said , this is not true, sire, that your brother  has rebelled against you; he cannot have any quarrel with you, small or great; I myself did as you instructed, and I buried him with my own hands.
If then the dead can rise, you may expect to see  the  rise up against you; but if things are as usual, assuredly no harm to you will arise from . Now then this is my opinion, that we pursue this herald and interrogate him, to learn from whom he comes with his proclamation that we must obey  as our king.


 liked ' advice; the herald was pursued at once and brought; and when he came,  put this question to him: Fellow, you say that your message is from ' son ; tell me this now, and you may go away unpunished: was it  who appeared to you and gave you this charge, or was it one of his servants?

Since  marched to , answered the herald, I have never seen  the son of ; the  whom  made overseer of his house gave me the message, saying that it was the will of , son of , that I should make it known to you.
So spoke the herald, telling the whole truth; and  said, , having done what you were told like a good man you are free of blame; but who can this  be who rebels against me and usurps the name of ?

 replied, I think, sire, that I understand what has been done here; the rebels are the ,  whom you left steward of your house, and his brother .


The truth of the words and of a dream struck  the moment he heard the name ; for he had dreamt that a message had come to him that  sitting on the royal throne touched heaven with his head;

and perceiving that he had killed his brother without cause, he wept bitterly for . Having wept, and grieved by all his misfortune, he sprang upon his horse, with intent to march at once to  against the .
As he sprang upon his horse, the cap fell off the sheath of his sword, and the naked blade pierced his thigh, wounding him in the same place where he had once wounded the  god ; and believing the wound to be mortal,  asked what was the name of the town where he was.
They told him it was . Now a prophecy had before this come to him from , that he would end his life at ;  supposed this to signify that he would die in old age at the Median , his capital city; but as the event proved, the oracle prophesied his death at  of .
So when he now inquired and learned the name of the town, the shock of his wound, and of the misfortune that came to him from the , brought him to his senses; he understood the prophecy and said: Here  son of  is to die.


At this time he said no more. But about twenty days later, he sent for the most prominent of the  that were about him, and thus addressed them: , I have to make known to you something which I kept most strictly concealed.
When I was in  I had a dream, which I wish I had not had; it seemed to me that a messenger came from home to tell me that  sitting on the royal throne touched heaven with his head.
Then I feared that my brother would take away my sovereignty from me, and I acted with more haste than wisdom; for it is not in the power of human nature to run away from what is to be; but I, blind as I was, sent  to  to kill . When that great wrong was done I lived without fear, for I never thought that when  was removed another man might rise against me.
But I mistook altogether what was to be; I have killed my brother when there was no need, and I have lost my kingdom none the less; for it was the   that the divinity forewarned in the dream would revolt.
Now he has been done for by me, and I would have you believe that  ' son no longer lives; the  rule the kingdom, the one that I left caretaker of my house, and his brother . So then, the man is dead of an unholy destiny at the hands of his relations who ought to have been my avenger for the disgrace I have suffered from the ;

and as he is no longer alive, necessity constrains me to charge you, men of , in his place, with the last desire of my life. In the name of the gods of my royal house I charge all of you, but chiefly those  that are here, not to let the sovereignty fall again into Median hands; if they have it after getting it by trickery, take it back through trickery of your own; if they have got it away by force, then by force all the stronger get it back.
And if you do this, may your land bring forth fruit, and your women and your flocks and herds be blessed with offspring, remaining free for all time; but if you do not get the kingdom back or attempt to get it back, then I pray things turn out the opposite for you, and on top of this, that every  meet an end such as mine. With that  wept bitterly for all that had happened to him.


When the  saw their king weep, they all tore the clothing which they wore and wailed loud and long.
But when after this the bone rotted and the thigh rapidly putrefied, it carried off  son of , who had reigned in all seven years and five months, but was altogether childless, without male or female issue.
To the  who were present it was quite incredible that the  were masters of the kingdom; they believed that ' intent was to deceive them with his story of ' death, so that all  might be embroiled in a war against him.


So they believed that it was ' son  who had been made king. For  stoutly denied that he had killed , since now that  was dead, it was not safe for him to say that he had slain the son of  with his own hands.

 being dead, the , pretending to be the  of like name, ' son, reigned without fear for the seven months by which  had fallen short of reigning eight years.
In this time he benefitted all his subjects to such an extent that after his death all the  except the  wished him back; for he sent to every nation he ruled and proclaimed an exemption for three years from military service and from tribute.


Such was his proclamation at the beginning of his reign; but in the eighth month he was exposed in the following manner. There was one , son of , as well-born and rich a man as any .
This  was the first to guess that the  was not ' son  and who, in fact, he was; the reason was, that he never left the acropolis nor summoned any notable  into his presence. And having formed this suspicion  did as follows:

 had taken his daughter, whose name was ; this same girl the  had now and he lived with her and with all ' other wives.  sent to this daughter, asking at what man's side she lay, with , ' son, or with some other?
She sent back a message that she did not know; for (she said) she had never seen ' son , nor did she know who her bedfellow was. Then  sent a second message, to this effect: If you do not know ' son  yourself, then find out from  who it is that she and you are living with; for surely she knows her own brother.
To this his daughter replied: I cannot communicate with , nor can I see any other of the women of the household; for no sooner had this man, whoever he is, made himself king, than he sent us to live apart, each in her own appointed place.


When  heard that, he saw more clearly how the matter stood; and he sent her this third message:

Daughter, your noble birth obliges you to run any risk that your father commands you to face. If this man is not  son of  but who I think he is, then he must not get away with sleeping with you and sitting on the throne of , but be punished.
Now, then, when he lies with you and you see that he is sleeping, feel his ears; if he has ears, rest assured that you are living with  son of ; but if he has none, it is  the .

 answered by messenger that she would run a very great risk by so doing; for if it should turn out that he had no ears, and she were caught feeling for them, he would surely kill her; nevertheless she would do it.
So she promised to do this for her father.  son of  during his reign cut off the ears of this   for some grave reason.
So , daughter of , performed her promise to her father. When it was her turn to go to the  (for their wives go in sequence to the ), she came to his bed and felt for the ' ears while he slumbered deeply; and having with no great difficulty assured herself that he had no ears, she sent and told this to her father as soon as it was morning.


 then took aside two  of the highest rank whom he thought worthiest of trust,  and , and told them the whole story. These, it would seem, had themselves suspected that it was so; and now they readily believed what  revealed to them.
They resolved that each should take into his confidence that  whom he most trusted;  brought in ,  brought , and  .
When they were six, , whose father, , was a subordinate governor of the , arrived at . When he came, then, the six  resolved to include  too.


The seven then met and gave each other tokens of good faith and spoke together; and when it was ' turn to declare his mind, he spoke as follows:

I thought that I alone knew that it was the  who was king and that  son of  was dead; and it was for this reason that I made haste to come, that I might effect the ' death; but since it turns out that you know too and not only I, I think that we should act at once and not put it off.

 replied, son of , you have a good father and seem likely yourself to be in no way inferior to your father; do not hurry this undertaking without thinking, but take it up more prudently; there must be more of us to try it.
To this  answered: You gentlemen who are here, if you do as  says, know that you will die horribly; for someone will inform the , looking to enrich himself alone.
You ought to have done it by yourselves; but since you decided to confide in others and have included me, let us either act today or else understand that if the present day passes, nobody else will betray you before I do, for I shall myself betray you to the .

To this  replied, seeing ' vehemence, Since you force us to hurry and will tolerate no delay, tell us now yourself how we shall pass into the palace and attack them. For you know yourself, I suppose, if not because you have seen them then you have heard, that guards are stationed all around; how shall we go past the guards?

, answered , there are many things that cannot be described in words, but in deed; and there are other things that can be described in words, but nothing illustrious comes of them. You know well that the guards who are set are easy to go by.
There is no one who will not allow us to pass, from respect or from fear, because of who we are; and further, I have myself the best pretext for entering, for I shall say that I have just arrived from  and have a message for the king from my father.
When it is necessary to lie, lie. For we want the same thing, liars and those who tell the truth; some lie to win credence and advantage by lies, while others tell the truth in order to obtain some advantage by the truth and to be more trusted; thus we approach the same ends by different means.
If the hope of advantage were taken away, the truth-teller would be as ready to lie as the liar to tell the truth. Now if any of the watchmen willingly let us pass, it will be better for him later. But if any tries to withstand us, let us note him as an enemy, and so thrust ourselves in and begin our work.


Then  said, Friends, when shall we have a better chance to win back the kingship, or, if we cannot, to die, since we who are  are ruled by a , a , and he a man that has no ears?
Those of you that were with  at his death-bed of course remember the curse which he pronounced as he died on the  if they should not try to get back the kingship, although we did not believe  then, but thought that he spoke to deceive us.
Now therefore my vote is that we follow ' plan, and not quit this council to do anything else but attack the  at once. So spoke ; and they all consented to what he said.


While they were making these plans, by coincidence the following happened. The  had resolved after consideration to make a friend of , because he had been wronged by  (who had killed his son with an arrow) and because he alone knew of the death of ' son , having himself been the slayer; but besides this, because he was in great repute among the .
For these reasons they summoned him and tried to make him a friend, having bound him by tokens of good faith and oaths to keep to himself and betray to no one their deception of the , and promising to give him all things in great abundance.
When  agreed to do this, since the  importuned him, the  made this second proposal to him, that they should call an assembly of all the  before the palace wall, and he should go up on to a tower and declare that it was  son of  and no other who was king of .
They gave him this charge, because they thought him to be the man most trusted by the , and because he had often asserted that ' son  was alive, and had denied the murder.


When  said that he was ready to do this too, the  summoned the  together, and brought him up on to a tower and bade him speak. Then, deliberately forgetting all the 's instructions, he traced the lineage of  from  downwards; when he came at last to the name of , he recounted all the good which that king had done to ,

and after he had narrated this, he revealed the truth, saying that he had concealed it before, as it had not been safe for him to tell what had happened, but at the present time necessity forced him to reveal it: and he said that he himself, forced by , had killed  son of , and that the  were in power.
Then, invoking a terrible curse on the  if they did not win back the throne and take vengeance on the , he threw himself headlong down from the tower; so , a man who was always well thought of, perished in this way.


The seven , when they had decided to attack the  at once and not delay, prayed to the gods and set forth, knowing nothing of what had happened to .
But when they had gone half way they learned what had happened to . Then they argued there, standing beside the road, ' party demanding that they delay and not attack while events were in flux, and ' party that they go directly and do what they had decided and not put it off.
While they were arguing, they saw seven pairs of hawks chase and slash and tear to bits two pairs of vultures. And seeing this all seven consented to ' opinion, and went on to the palace, encouraged by the birds.


When they came to the gate, it turned out as  had expected; the guards, out of respect for the leading men in  and never suspecting that there would be trouble from them, allowed them to pass, who enjoyed divine guidance, and no one asked any questions.
And when they came to the court, they met the eunuchs that carry messages, who asked the seven why they had come; and while they were questioning these, they were threatening the watchmen for letting them pass, and restraining the seven who wanted to go on.
These gave each other the word, drew their knives, and stabbing the eunuchs who barred their way, went forward at a run to the men's apartment.


Both the  were within, deliberating about the consequences of ' act. Seeing the eunuchs in confusion and hearing their cries they both sprang up: and when they realized what was happening they turned to defending themselves.
One rushed to take down a bow, the other went for a spear. Then the fighting started. The one that had caught up the bow found it was no use to him, as the antagonists were close and jostling one another; but the other defended himself with his spear, wounding  in the thigh and  in the eye;  lost his eye from the wound but was not killed.
So one of the  wounded these; the other, as the bow was no use to him, fled into a chamber adjoining the men's apartment and would have shut its door.
Two of the seven flung into the room with him,  and ; as  and the  wrestled together,  stood helpless in the darkness, afraid of stabbing .

, seeing  stand helpless, asked why he did not lend a hand; and he said, Because I am afraid for you, that I might stab you. And  answered, Stick your sword even if it goes through us both. So  complying stabbed with his knife and somehow stuck the .


When they had killed the  and cut off their heads, they left their wounded there because of their infirmity and for the sake of guarding the acropolis, while five of them carrying the 's heads ran outside with much shouting and commotion, calling all  to aid, telling what they had done and showing the heads; at the same time they killed every  that came in their way.
The , when they learned what had been done by the seven and how the  had tricked them, resolved to follow the example set, and drew their daggers and killed all the  they could find; and if nightfall had not stopped them they would not have left one  alive.
This day is the greatest holy day that all  alike keep; they celebrate a great festival on it, which they call the Massacre of the ; while the festival lasts no  may go outdoors, but during this day the  remain in their houses.


After the tumult quieted down, and five days passed, the rebels against the  held a council on the whole state of affairs, at which sentiments were uttered which to some  seem incredible, but there is no doubt that they were spoken.

 was for turning the government over to the  people: It seems to me, he said, that there can no longer be a single sovereign over us, for that is not pleasant or good. You saw the insolence of , how far it went, and you had your share of the insolence of the .
How can monarchy be a fit thing, when the ruler can do what he wants with impunity? Give this power to the best man on earth, and it would stir him to unaccustomed thoughts. Insolence is created in him by the good things to hand, while from birth envy is rooted in man.
Acquiring the two he possesses complete evil; for being satiated he does many reckless things, some from insolence, some from envy. And yet an absolute ruler ought to be free of envy, having all good things; but he becomes the opposite of this towards his citizens; he envies the best who thrive and live, and is pleased by the worst of his fellows; and he is the best confidant of slander.
Of all men he is the most inconsistent; for if you admire him modestly he is angry that you do not give him excessive attention, but if one gives him excessive attention he is angry because one is a flatter. But I have yet worse to say of him than that; he upsets the ancestral ways and rapes women and kills indiscriminately.
But the rule of the multitude has in the first place the loveliest name of all, equality, and does in the second place none of the things that a monarch does. It determines offices by lot, and holds power accountable, and conducts all deliberating publicly. Therefore I give my opinion that we make an end of monarchy and exalt the multitude, for all things are possible for the majority.


Such was the judgment of : but  urged that they resort to an oligarchy. I agree, said he, with all that  says against the rule of one; but when he tells you to give the power to the multitude, his judgment strays from the best. Nothing is more foolish and violent than a useless mob;

for men fleeing the insolence of a tyrant to fall victim to the insolence of the unguided populace is by no means to be tolerated. Whatever the one does, he does with knowledge, but for the other knowledge is impossible; how can they have knowledge who have not learned or seen for themselves what is best, but always rush headlong and drive blindly onward, like a river in flood?
Let those like democracy who wish ill to ; but let us choose a group of the best men and invest these with the power. For we ourselves shall be among them, and among the best men it is likely that there will be the best counsels.


Such was the judgment of .  was the third to express his opinion. It seems to me, he said, that  speaks well concerning democracy but not concerning oligarchy. For if the three are proposed and all are at their best for the sake of argument, the best democracy and oligarchy and monarchy, I hold that monarchy is by far the most excellent.
One could describe nothing better than the rule of the one best man; using the best judgment, he will govern the multitude with perfect wisdom, and best conceal plans made for the defeat of enemies.
But in an oligarchy, the desire of many to do the state good service often produces bitter hate among them; for because each one wishes to be first and to make his opinions prevail, violent hate is the outcome, from which comes faction and from faction killing, and from killing it reverts to monarchy, and by this is shown how much better monarchy is.
Then again, when the people rule it is impossible that wickedness will not occur; and when wickedness towards the state occurs, hatred does not result among the wicked, but strong alliances; for those that want to do the state harm conspire to do it together. This goes on until one of the people rises to stop such men. He therefore becomes the people's idol, and being their idol is made their monarch; and thus he also proves that monarchy is best.
But (to conclude the whole matter in one word) tell me, where did freedom come from for us and who gave it, from the people or an oligarchy or a single ruler? I believe, therefore, that we who were liberated through one man should maintain such a government, and, besides this, that we should not alter our ancestral ways that are good; that would not be better.


Having to choose between these three options, four of the seven men preferred the last. Then , whose proposal to give the  equality was defeated, spoke thus among them all:

Fellow partisans, it is plain that one of us must be made king (whether by lot, or entrusted with the office by the choice of the , or in some other way), but I shall not compete with you; I desire neither to rule nor to be ruled; but if I waive my claim to be king, I make this condition, that neither I nor any of my descendants shall be subject to any one of you.
To these terms the six others agreed;  took no part in the contest but stood aside; and to this day his house (and no other in ) remains free, and is ruled only so far as it is willing to be, so long as it does not transgress  law.


The rest of the seven then considered what was the fairest way of making a king; and they decided that if another of the seven than  should gain the royal power, that  and his descendants should receive a yearly gift of Median clothing and everything else that the  hold most valuable. The reason for this decision was that it was he who had first planned the matter and assembled the conspirators.
For , then, they choose this particular honor; but with regard to all of them they decreed that any one of the seven should, if he wished, enter the king's palace unannounced, except when the king was sleeping with a woman; and that the king should be forbidden to take a wife except from the households of the conspirators.
As for the making of a king, they decided that he should be elected whose horse, after they were all in their saddles in the suburb of the city, should first be heard to neigh at sunrise.


Now  had a clever groom, whose name was . When the council broke up,  said to him: , we have resolved to do as follows about the kingship: he shall be elected whose horse, after we are all mounted on our horses in the suburb of the city, neighs first at sunrise. Now if you have any cunning, figure out how we and no one else can win this prize.

Master,  answered, if this is to determine whether you become king or not, be confident for this reason and have an easy mind, for no one else shall be king before you, such are the tricks I have. Then, said , if you have any trick such as you say, use it and don't put it off, for tomorrow is the day of decision.
When  heard that, he did as follows. At nightfall he brought one of the mares which ' horse particularly favored, and tethered her in the suburb of the city; then bringing ' horse, he repeatedly led him near the horse, bumping against the mare, and at last let the horse mount.


At dawn of day the six came on horseback as they had agreed. As they rode out through the suburb and came to the place where the mare had been tethered in the past night, ' horse trotted forward and whinnied;

and as he so did there came lightning and thunder out of a clear sky. These signs given to  were thought to be foreordained and made his election perfect; his companions leapt from their horses and bowed to him.


Some say that this was ' plan; but there is another story in  besides this: that he rubbed this mare's vulva with his hand, which he then kept inside his clothing until the six were about to let go their horses at sunrise, when he took his hand out and held it to the nostrils of ' horse, which at once snorted and whinnied.


So  son of  was made king, and the whole of , which  first and  after him had conquered, was subject to him, except the ; these did not yield as of slaves to the , but were united to them by friendship, having given  passage into , which the  could not enter without the consent of the .

 took wives from the noblest houses of , marrying ' daughters  and ;  had been a wife of her brother  and afterwards of the ;  was a virgin.
He also married a daughter of ' son , whose name was , and the daughter of  who had discovered the truth about the ; and everything was full of his power. First he made and set up a carved stone, upon which was cut the figure of a horseman, with this inscription:  son of , aided by the excellence of his horse (here followed the horse's name) and of  his groom, got possession of the kingdom of .


Having done these things in , he divided his dominions into twenty provinces, which they call satrapies; and having divided his dominions and appointed governors, he instructed each people to pay him tribute, consolidating neighboring peoples and distributing outlying peoples among different provinces, passing over those adjoining.
I will now show how he divided his provinces and the tributes which were paid him yearly. Those that paid in silver were required to render the weight of a  talent; those that paid in gold, of a  talent; the  talent being equal to seventy-eight  minae.
In the reigns of  and  after him there was no fixed tribute, but payment was made in gifts. It is because of this fixing of tribute, and other similar ordinances, that the  called  the merchant,  the master, and  the father; for  made petty profit out of everything,  was harsh and arrogant,  was merciful and always worked for their well-being.


The ,  of , , , , , and , on whom  laid one joint tribute, paid a revenue of four hundred talents of silver. This was established as his first province. The , , , , and  paid five hundred talents; this was the second province.
The third comprised the  on the right of the entrance of the straits, the ,  of , , , and ; these paid three hundred and sixty talents of tribute.
The fourth province was . This rendered three hundred and sixty white horses, one for each day in the year, and five hundred talents of silver. A hundred and forty of these were expended on the horsemen who were the guard of ; the three hundred and sixty that remained were paid to .


The fifth province was the country (except the part belonging to the , which paid no tribute) between , a city founded on the  and  border by  son of , and ; this paid three hundred and fifty talents; in this province was all , and the part of  called , and .
The sixth province was  and the neighboring parts of , and  and , all of which were included in the province of . From here came seven hundred talents, besides the income in silver from the fish of the ;

besides that silver and the assessment of grain that was given also, seven hundred talents were paid; for a hundred and twenty thousand bushels of grain were also assigned to the  quartered at the  of  and their allies.
The , , , and  paid together a hundred and seventy talents; this was the seventh province; the eighth was  and the rest of the  country, paying three hundred talents.


From  and the rest of  came to  a thousand talents of silver and five hundred castrated boys; this was the ninth province;  and the rest of Media, with the  and , paid four hundred and fifty talents, and was the tenth province.
The eleventh comprised the , , , and , paying jointly two hundred;


The twelfth, the  as far as the land of the ; these paid three hundred and sixty. The thirteenth, the  country and  and the lands adjoining as far as the ; these paid four hundred.
The fourteenth province was made up of the , , , , , and the inhabitants of those islands of the southern sea on which the king settles the so-called displaced people; these together paid a tribute of six hundred talents.
The  and  were the fifteenth, paying two hundred and fifty. The , , , and  were the sixteenth, paying three hundred.


The  and  of , the seventeenth, paid four hundred; the , , and  were the eighteenth, and two hundred talents were the appointed tribute.
The , , , , and Mares, the nineteenth province, were ordered to pay three hundred. The  made up the twentieth province. These are more in number than any nation of which we know, and they paid a greater tribute than any other province, namely three hundred and sixty talents of gold dust.


Now if these  silver talents be calculated in  money, the sum is seen to be nine thousand eight hundred and eighty  talents:

and the gold coin being thirteen times the value of the silver, the gold-dust is found to be worth four thousand six hundred and eighty  talents. Therefore it is seen by adding all together that  collected a yearly tribute of fourteen thousand five hundred and sixty talents; I take no account of figures less than ten.


This was ' revenue from  and a few parts of . But as time went on he drew tribute also from the islands and the dwellers in , as far as .
The tribute is stored by the king in this fashion: he melts it down and pours it into earthen vessels; when the vessel is full he breaks the earthenware away, and when he needs money coins as much as serves his purpose.


These were the governments and appointments of tribute. The  country is the only one which I have not recorded as tributary; for the  live free from all taxes.
As for those on whom no tribute was laid, but who rendered gifts instead, they were, firstly, the  nearest to , whom  conquered in his march towards the long-lived ; and also those who dwell about the holy , where  is the god of their festivals. These  and their neighbors use the same seed as the , and they live underground.
These together brought every other year and still bring a gift of two choenixes of unrefined gold, two hundred blocks of ebony, five  boys, and twenty great elephants' tusks.
Gifts were also required of the  and their neighbors as far as the  (which is as far as the  rule reaches, the country north of the  paying no regard to the ); these were rendered every four years and are still rendered, namely, a hundred boys and as many maids.
The  rendered a thousand talents' weight of frankincense yearly. Such were the gifts of these peoples to the king, besides the tribute.


All this abundance of gold, from which the  send the aforementioned gold-dust to the king, they obtain in the following way.
To the east of the  country is sand. Of all the people of  whom we know - even those about whom something is said with precision - the  dwell nearest to the dawn and the rising sun; for on the eastern side of  all is desolate because of the sand.
There are many  nations, none speaking the same language; some of them are nomads, some not; some dwell in the river marshes and live on raw fish, which they catch from reed boats. Each boat is made of one joint of reed.
These  wear clothes of bullrushes; they mow and cut these from the river, then weave them crosswise like a mat, and wear them like a breastplate.


Other , to the east of these, are nomads and eat raw flesh; they are called . It is said to be their custom that when anyone of their fellows, whether man or woman, is sick, a man's closest friends kill him, saying that if wasted by disease he will be lost to them as meat; though he denies that he is sick, they will not believe him, but kill and eat him.
When a woman is sick, she is put to death like the men by the women who are her close acquaintances. As for one that has come to old age, they sacrifice him and feast on his flesh; but not many reach this reckoning, for before that everyone who falls ill they kill.


There are other , again, who kill no living creature, nor plant anything, nor are accustomed to have houses; they eat grass, and they have a grain growing naturally from the earth in its husk, about the size of a millet-seed, which they gather with the husk and boil and eat. When any one of them falls sick, he goes into the desert and lies there, and no one notices whether he is sick or dies.


These  whom I have described have intercourse openly like cattle; they are all black-skinned, like the .
Their semen too, which they ejaculate into the women, is not white like other men's, but black like their skin, and resembles in this respect that of the . These  dwell far away from the  southwards, and were not subjects of .


Other  dwell near the town of  and the  country, north of the rest of ; these live like the ; they are of all  the most warlike, and it is they who are sent for the gold; for in these parts all is desolate because of the sand.
In this sandy desert are ants, not as big as dogs but bigger than foxes; the  king has some of these, which have been caught there. These ants live underground, digging out the sand in the same way as the ants in , to which they are very similar in shape, and the sand which they carry from the holes is full of gold.
It is for this sand that the  set forth into the desert. They harness three camels apiece, males on either side sharing the drawing, and a female in the middle: the man himself rides on the female, that when harnessed has been taken away from as young an offspring as may be. Their camels are as swift as horses, and much better able to bear burdens besides.


I do not describe the camel's appearance to , for they know it; but I shall tell them something that they do not know concerning it: the hindlegs of the camel have four thighbones and four knee-joints; its genitals are turned towards the tail between the hindlegs.


Thus and with teams so harnessed the  ride after the gold, being careful to be engaged in taking it when the heat is greatest; for the ants are then out of sight underground.
Now in these parts the sun is hottest in the morning, not at midday as elsewhere, but from sunrise to the hour of market-closing. Through these hours it is much hotter than in  at noon, so that men are said to sprinkle themselves with water at this time.
At midday the sun's heat is nearly the same in  as elsewhere. As it goes to afternoon, the sun of  has the power of the morning sun in other lands; as day declines it becomes ever cooler, until at sunset it is exceedingly cold.


So when the  come to the place with their sacks, they fill these with the sand and drive back as fast as possible; for the ants at once scent them out, the  say, and give chase. They say nothing is equal to them for speed, so that unless the  have a headstart while the ants were gathering, not one of them would get away.
They cut loose the male trace-camels, which are slower than the females, as they begin to lag, one at a time; the mares never tire, for they remember the young that they have left. Such is the tale. Most of the gold (say the ) is got in this way by the ; they dig some from mines in their country, too, but it is less abundant.


The most outlying nations of the world have somehow drawn the finest things as their lot, exactly as  has drawn the possession of far the best seasons.
As I have lately said,  lies at the world's most distant eastern limit; and in  all living creatures four-footed and flying are much bigger than those of other lands, except the horses, which are smaller than the Median horses called ; moreover, the gold there, whether dug from the earth or brought down by rivers or got as I have described, is very abundant.
There, too, wool more beautiful and excellent than the wool of sheep grows on wild trees; these trees supply the  with clothing.


Again,  is the most distant to the south of all inhabited countries: and this is the only country which produces frankincense and myrrh and casia and cinnamon and gum-mastich. All these except myrrh are difficult for the  to get.
They gather frankincense by burning that storax which  carry to ; they burn this and so get the frankincense; for the spice-bearing trees are guarded by small winged snakes of varied color, many around each tree; these are the snakes that attack . Nothing except the smoke of storax will drive them away from the trees.


The  also say that the whole country would be full of these snakes if the same thing did not occur among them that I believe occurs among vipers.
Somehow the forethought of God (just as is reasonable) being wise has made all creatures prolific that are timid and edible, so that they do not become extinct through being eaten, whereas few young are born to hardy and vexatious creatures.
On the one hand, because the hare is hunted by every beast and bird and man, therefore it is quite prolific; alone of all creatures it conceives during pregnancy; some of the unborn young are hairy, some still naked, some are still forming in the womb while others are just conceived.
On the one hand there is this sort of thing, but on the other hand the lioness, that is so powerful and so bold, once in her life bears one cub; for in the act of bearing she casts her uterus out with her cub. The explanation of this is that when the cub first begins to stir in the mother, its claws, much sharper than those of any other creature, tear the uterus, and the more it grows the more it scratches and tears, so that when the hour of birth is near seldom is any of the uterus left intact.


So too if the vipers and the winged serpents of  were born in the natural manner of serpents life would be impossible for men; but as it is, when they copulate, while the male is in the act of procreation and as soon as he has ejaculated his seed, the female seizes him by the neck, and does not let go until she has bitten through.
The male dies in the way described, but the female suffers in return for the male the following punishment: avenging their father, the young while they are still within the womb gnaw at their mother and eating through her bowels thus make their way out.
Other snakes, that do no harm to men, lay eggs and hatch out a vast number of young. The  winged serpents do indeed seem to be numerous; but that is because (although there are vipers in every land) these are all in  and are found nowhere else.


The  get frankincense in the foregoing way, and casia in the following way: when they go after it they bind oxhides and other skins all over their bodies and faces except for the eyes. Casia grows in a shallow lake; around this and in it live winged creatures, very like bats, that squeak similarly and make a fierce resistance; these have to be kept away from the eyes in order to take the casia.


As for cinnamon, they gather it in an even stranger way. Where it comes from and what land produces it they cannot say, except that it is reported, reasonably enough, to grow in the places where  was reared.
There are great birds, it is said, that take these dry sticks which we have learned from the  to call cinnamon and carry them off to nests stuck with mud to precipitous cliffs, where man has no means of approach.
The  solution to this is to cut dead oxen and asses and other beasts of burden into the largest possible pieces, then to set these near the eyries and withdraw far off. The birds then fly down (it is said) and carry the pieces of the beasts up to their nests, while these, not being able to bear the weight, break and fall down the mountain side, and then the  come and gather them up. Thus is cinnamon said to be gathered, and so to come from  to other lands.


But ledanon, which the  call ladanon, is produced yet more strangely than this. For it is the most fragrant thing produced in the most malodorous; for it is found in he-goats' beards, forming in them like gum among timber. This is used in the manufacture of many perfumes; there is nothing that the  burn so often as incense.


Enough of marvels, and yet the land of  gives off a scent as sweet as if divine. They have besides two marvellous kinds of sheep, found nowhere else. One of these has tails no less than nine feet long. Were the sheep to trail these after them they would suffer by the chafing of the tails on the ground;

but every shepherd there knows enough of carpentry to make little carts which they fix under the tails, binding the tail of each sheep on its own cart. The other kind of sheep has a tail a full three feet broad.


Where south inclines westwards, the part of the world stretching farthest towards the sunset is ; this produces gold in abundance, and huge elephants, and all sorts of wild trees, and ebony, and the tallest and handsomest and longest-lived people.


These then are the most distant lands in  and . But concerning those in  that are the farthest away towards evening, I cannot speak with assurance; for I do not believe that there is a river called by foreigners  issuing into the northern sea, where our amber is said to come from, nor do I have any knowledge of , where our tin is brought from.
The very name  betrays itself as not a foreign but a  name, invented by some poet; nor for all my diligence have I been able to learn from one who has seen it that there is a sea beyond . All we know is that our tin and amber come from the most distant parts.


But in the north of  there is by far the most gold. In this matter again I cannot say with assurance how the gold is produced, but it is said that one-eyed men called  steal it from griffins.
But I do not believe this, that there are one-eyed men who have a nature otherwise the same as other men.
The most outlying lands, though, as they enclose and wholly surround all the rest of the world, are likely to have those things which we think the finest and the rarest.


There is a plain in  shut in on all sides by mountains through which there are five passes. This plain was once the ', being at the boundaries of the , the , , , and , but since the  have held power it has been the king's.
Now from the encircling mountains flows a great river whose name is the Aces. Its stream divides into five channels and formerly watered the lands of the above-mentioned peoples, going to each through a different pass, but since the beginning of the  rule

the king has blocked the mountain passes, and closed each passage with a gate; with the water barred from outlet, the plain within the mountains becomes a lake, seeing that the river pours into it and finds no way out.
Those therefore who before were accustomed to use the water endure great hardship in not being able to use it; for during the winter, god rains for them just as for the rest of mankind, but in the summer they are in need of the water for their sown millet and sesame.
So whenever no water is given to them, they come into  with their women, and cry and howl before the door of the king's palace, until the king commands that the river-gate should be opened for those whose need is greatest;

then, when this land has drunk its fill of water, that gate is shut, and the king has another opened for those of the rest who most require it. I know by hearsay that he gets a lot of money, over and above the tribute, for opening the gates. So much for these matters.


Of the seven men who revolted against the , one, , got his death through his own violence immediately after the rebellion. He wanted to enter the palace and speak with the king; and in fact the law was, that the rebels against the  could come into the king's presence unannounced, if the king were not having intercourse with one of his wives.

, as one of the seven, claimed his right to enter unannounced; but the gatekeeper and the messenger forbade him, telling him that the king was having intercourse with one of his wives.  thought that they were lying; drawing his scimitar he cut off their noses and ears, then strung these on his horse's bridle and hung it around the men's necks, and so let them go.


They showed themselves to the king and told him why they had been treated so. , fearing that the six had done this by common consent, sent for each and asked his opinion, whether they approved what had been done;

and being assured that they had no part in it, he seized  with his sons and all his householdfor he strongly suspected that the man was plotting a rebellion with his kinsmenand imprisoned them with the intention of putting them to death.
Then ' wife began coming to the palace gates, weeping and lamenting; and by continuing to do this same thing she persuaded  to pity her; and he sent a messenger to tell her, Woman,  will allow one of your imprisoned relatives to survive, whomever you prefer of them all.
After considering she answered, If indeed the king gives me the life of one, I chose from them all my brother.

 was astonished when he heard her answer, and sent someone who asked her: Woman, the king asks you with what in mind you abandon your husband and your children and choose to save the life of your brother, who is less close to you than your children and less dear than your husband?

O King, she answered, I may have another husband, if a god is willing, and other children, if I lose these; but since my father and mother are no longer living, there is no way that I can have another brother; I said what I did with that in mind.

 thought that the woman answered well, and for her sake he released the one for whom she had asked, and the eldest of her sons as well; he put to death all the rest. Thus immediately perished one of the seven.


While  was still ill, the following events occurred. The governor of  appointed by  was , a . This man had an impious desire; for although he had not been injured or spoken badly of by  of , and had in fact never even seen him before, he desired to seize and kill him, for the following reason, most people say.
As  and another  whose name was , governor of the province at , sat at the king's doors, they fell from talking to quarreling; and as they compared their achievements  said to ,

You are not to be reckoned a man; the island of  lies close to your province, yet you have not added it to the king's dominionan island so easy to conquer that some native of it revolted against his rulers with fifteen hoplites, and is now lord of it.
Some say that , angered by this reproach, did not so much desire to punish the source of it as to destroy  utterly, the occasion of the reproach.


A few people, however, say that when  sent a herald to  with some request (it is not said what this was), the herald found  lying in the men's apartments, in the company of  of ;

and, whether on purpose to show contempt for , or by mere chance, when ' herald entered and addressed him, , then lying with his face to the wall, never turned or answered him.


These are the two reasons alleged for ' death; believe whichever you like. But the consequence was that , then at  which is above the river , sent  son of , a , with a message to , having learned ' intention;

for  was the first of the  whom we know to aim at the mastery of the sea, leaving out of account  of  and any others who before him may have ruled the sea; of what may be called the human race  was the first, and he had great hope of ruling  and the Islands.
Learning then that he had this intention,  sent him this message:  addresses  as follows: I find that you aim at great things, but that you have not sufficient money for your purpose. Do then as I direct, and you will succeed yourself and will save me.  aims at my death; of this I have clear intelligence.
Now if you will transport me and my money, you may take some yourself and let me keep the rest; thus you shall have wealth enough to rule all . If you mistrust what I tell you about the money, send someone who is most trusted by you and I will prove it to him.


Hearing this,  was pleased and willing; and since he had a great desire for money he first sent one of his townsmen, , son of , to have a look; this man was his scribe; it was he who not long afterwards dedicated in the  all the splendid furnishings of the men's apartment in ' house.
When  heard that an inspection was imminent, he filled eight chests with stones, leaving only a very shallow space at the top; then he laid gold on top of the stones, locked the chests, and kept them ready.  came and saw, and brought word back to his master.


 then prepared to visit , despite the strong dissuasion of his diviners and friends, and a vision seen by his daughter in a dream; she dreamt that she saw her father in the air overhead being washed by  and anointed by ;

after this vision she used all means to persuade him not to go on this journey to ; even as he went to his fifty-oared ship she prophesied evil for him. When  threatened her that if he came back safe, she would long remain unmarried, she answered with a prayer that his threat might be fulfilled: for she would rather, she said, long remain unmarried than lose her father.


But  would listen to no advice. He sailed to meet , with a great retinue of followers, among whom was , son of , a man of  and the most skillful physician of his time.
But no sooner had  come to  than he was horribly murdered in a way unworthy of him and of his aims; for, except for the sovereigns of , no sovereign of  race is fit to be compared with  for magnificence.
Having killed him in some way not fit to be told,  then crucified him; as for those who had accompanied him, he let the  go, telling them to thank him that they were free; those who were not , or were servants of ' followers, he kept for slaves.
And  hanging in the air fulfilled his daughter's vision in every detail; for he was washed by  when it rained, and he was anointed by  as he exuded sweat from his body.


This was the end of ' string of successes as  king of  had forewarned him. But not long after, atonement for  overtook . After the death of  and the rule of the ,  stayed in , where he did not help the  in any way to regain the power taken from them by the ,

but, to the contrary, in this confusion killed two prominent , , the governor from , who had taunted him about , and ' son ; and on top of many other violent acts, he set an ambush down the road after a messenger from  came with a message which displeased him and killed that messenger on his homeward journey, and concealed the man's body and horse.


So when  became king, he wanted to punish  for all his wrongdoing, and especially for killing  and his son. But he thought it best not to send an army openly against the satrap, seeing that everything was still in confusion and he was still new to the royal power; moreover he heard that  was very powerful, having a guard of a thousand  spearmen and being governor of the  and  and  province.
He had recourse, then, to the following expedient: having summoned an assembly of the most prominent , he addressed them as follows: , which of you will promise to do this for me, not with force and numbers, but by cunning? Where there is need for cunning, force has no business.
So then, which of you would either bring me  alive or kill him? For he has done the  no good, but much harm; he has destroyed two of us,  and his son, and is killing my messengers that are sent to recall him, displaying an insolence that is not to be borne. So, then, before he does the  some still greater harm, he has to be punished by us with death.


 asked this and thirty men promised, each wanting to do it himself.  told them not argue but draw lots; they did, and the lot fell to , son of .

, having drawn the lot, did as follows: he had many letters written concerning many things and put the seal of  on them, and then went with them to .
When he got there and came into ' presence, he took out each letter in turn and gave it to one of the royal scribes to read (all of the governors of the King have scribes);  gave the letters to test the spearmen, whether they would consent to revolt against .
Seeing that they were greatly affected by the rolls and yet more by what was written in them, he gave another, in which were these words: !  forbids you to be ' guard. Hearing this, they lowered their spears for him.
When  saw that they obeyed the letter so far, he was encouraged and gave the last roll to the scribe, in which was written:  instructs the  in  to kill . Hearing this the spearmen drew their scimitars and killed him at once. Thus atonement for  the  overtook  the .


' slaves and other possessions were brought to . Not long after this, it happened that  twisted his foot in dismounting from his horse while hunting

so violently that the ball of the ankle joint was dislocated from its socket.  called in the best physicians of , whom he had until now kept near his person. But by violently twisting the foot they made the injury worse;

and for seven days and nights the king could not sleep because of the pain. On the eighth day, when he was doing poorly, someone who had heard in  of the skill of  of  told  of him; and he told them to bring him as quickly as possible. When they found him among the slaves of , where he was forgotten, they brought him along, dragging his chains and dressed in rags.


 asked him when he was brought in if he were trained in medicine. He refused to admit it, for he was afraid that if he revealed himself he would be cut off from  for good.
It was clear to , however, that he was trained in deceit, and he ordered those who had brought him to bring along scourges and goads. Then he confessed, saying that his training was not exact, but that he had associated with a physician and had a passing acquaintance with medicine.
But when  turned the case over to him and  applied  remedies and used gentleness instead of the ' violence, he enabled him to sleep and in a short time had him well, although  had had no hope of regaining the use of his foot.
After this,  rewarded him with a gift of two pairs of golden fetters. Is it your purpose,  asked, to double my pains for making you well? Pleased by the retort,  sent him to his own wives. The eunuchs who conducted him told the women that this was the man who had given the king his life back.
Each of them took a bowl and dipped it in a chest full of gold, so richly rewarding  that the servant accompanying him, whose name was , collected a very great sum of gold by picking up the staters that fell from the bowls.


Now this is how  had come from  to live with : he was oppressed by a harsh-tempered father at ; since he could not stand him, he left him and went to . Within the first year after settling there, he excelled the rest of the physicians, although he had no equipment nor any medical implements.
In his second year the  paid him a talent to be their public physician; in the third year the  hired him for a hundred minae, and  in the fourth year for two talents. Thus he came to , and not least because of this man the physicians of  were well-respected 

for at this time the best physicians in  countries were those of , and next to them those of . About the same time the  had the name of being the best musicians.


So now because he had healed  at   had a very grand house and ate at the king's table; he had everything, except permission to return to the .
When the  physicians who until now had attended the king were about to be impaled for being less skilful than a ,  interceded with the king for them and saved them; and he saved an  seer, too, who had been a retainer of ' and was forgotten among the slaves.  was a man of considerable influence with the King.


A short time after this, something else occurred; there was a swelling on the breast of , the daughter of  and wife of , which broke and spread further. As long as it was small, she hid it out of shame and told no one; but when it got bad, she sent for  and showed it to him.
He said he would cure her, but made her swear that she would repay him by granting whatever he asked of her, and said that he would ask nothing shameful.


And after he treated her and did cure her,  addressed  in their chamber as she had been instructed by : O King, although you have so much power you are idle, acquiring no additional people or power for the .
The right thing for a man who is both young and the master of great wealth is to be seen aggrandizing himself, so that the  know too that they are ruled by a man. On two counts it is in your interest to do this, both so that the  know that their leader is a man, and so that they be occupied by war and not have time to plot against you.
You should show some industry now, while you are still young: for sense grows with the growing body, but grows old too with the aging body and loses its edge for all purposes.
She said this as instructed, but he replied with this: Woman, what you have said is exactly what I had in mind to do. For I have planned to make a bridge from this continent to the other continent and lead an army against the ; and this will be done in a short time.

Look,  said, let the  go for the present; you shall have them whenever you like; I tell you, march against . I have heard of  and  and Attic and  women, and would like to have them as servants. You have a man who is fitter than any other to instruct and guide you in everything concerning : I mean the physician who healed your foot.

 answered, Woman, since you think that we should make an attempt on  first, it seems to me to be best that we first send  spies with the man whom you mention, who shall tell us everything that they learn and observe; and then when I am fully informed I shall rouse myself against them.


He said this, and no sooner said than did it. For the next day at dawn he summoned fifteen prominent , and instructed them to go with  and sail along the coast of ; telling them, too, by all means to bring the physician back and not let him escape.
Having given these instructions to them, he then sent for , and asked of him that when he had shown and made clear all of  to the , he would come back; and he told him to take all his movable goods to give to his father and siblings, saying that he would give him many times as much in return and would send with him a ship with a cargo of all good things.

, I think, made this promise without a treacherous intent, but  was afraid that  was testing him; therefore he was in no hurry to accept all that was offered, but answered that he would leave his own possessions where they were, so as to have them when he returned; the ship which  promised him to carry the gifts for his siblings, he said he would accept. Having given the same instructions to  too,  sent them all to the coast.


They came down to the city of  in , and there chartered two triremes, as well as a great galley laden with all good things; and when everything was ready they set sail for , where they surveyed and mapped the coasts to which they came; until having viewed the greater and most famous parts they reached  in .
There , king of the , out of sympathy for , took the steering gear off the Median ships and put the  under a guard, calling them spies. While they were in this plight,  made his way to ; and  did not set the  free and give them back what he had taken from their ships until the physician was in his own country.


The  sailed from  and pursued  to , where they found him in the marketplace and tried to seize him.
Some , who feared the  power, would have given him up; but others resisted and beat the  with their sticks. Men of , watch what you do, said the ; you are harboring an escaped slave of the King's.
How do you think  will like this insolence? What good will it do you if he gets away from us? What city will we attack first here? Which will we try to enslave first?
But the men of  paid no attention to them; so the  lost  and the galley with which they had come, and sailed back for , making no attempt to visit and learn of the further parts of  now that their guide was taken from them.
But  gave them a message as they were setting sail; they should tell , he said, that  was engaged to the daughter of . For  held the name of  the wrestler in great honor; and, to my thinking,  sought this match and paid a great sum for it to show  that he was a man of influence in his own country as well as in .


The  then put out from ; but their ships were wrecked on the coast of , and they were made slaves in the country until , an exile from , released and restored them to , who was ready to give him whatever he wanted in return.

 chose to be restored to  and told the story of his misfortune; but, so as not to be the occasion of agitating , if on his account a great expedition sailed against , he said that it was enough that the  alone be his escort; for he supposed that the  would be the readier to receive him back as the  were their friends.

 kept his word, and sent a messenger to the men of , telling them to take  back to . They obeyed ; but they could not persuade the , and were not able to apply force.
This is what happened, and these  were the first who came from  into , and they came to view the country for this reason.


After this,  conquered , the greatest of all city states,  or barbarian, the reason for his conquest being this: when , son of , invaded , many  came with the army, some to trade, as was natural, and some to see the country itself; among them was , son of , who was ' brother and in exile from .
This  had a stroke of good luck. He was in the market at  wearing a red cloak, when , at that time one of ' guard and as yet a man of no great importance, saw him, and coveting the cloak came and tried to buy it.
When  saw ' eagerness, by good luck he said, I will not sell this for any money, but I give it to you free if you must have it so much. Extolling this,  accepted the garment.


 supposed that he had lost his cloak out of foolish good nature. But in time  died, the seven rebelled against the , and  of the seven came to the throne;  then learned that the successor to the royal power was the man to whom he had given the garment in ; so he went up to  and sat in the king's antechamber, saying that he was one of ' benefactors.
When the doorkeeper brought word of this to the king,  asked But to what  benefactor can I owe thanks? In the little time since I have been king hardly one of that nation has come to us, and I have, I may say, no use for any . Nevertheless bring him in, so that I may know what he means.
The doorkeeper brought  in and the interpreters asked him as he stood there who he was and what he had done to call himself the king's benefactor. Then  told the story of the cloak, and said that it was he who had given it.

Most generous man, said , it was you who gave me a present when I had as yet no power; and if it was a small one, I was none the less grateful then than I am now when I get a big one. In return, I give you gold and silver in abundance so you may never be sorry that you did  son of  good.

 answered, Do not give me gold, O king, or silver, but , my country, which our slave has now that my brother  has been killed by ; give me this without killing or enslaving.


Having heard this,  sent an army and , one of the seven, to command it, instructing him to do whatever  asked. So  went down to the coast and got his army ready.


Now  was ruled by , son of , who had authority delegated by . He wanted to be the justest of men, but that was impossible.
For when he learned of ' death, first he set up an altar to  the Liberator and marked out around it that sacred enclosure which is still to be seen in the suburb of the city; when this had been done, he called an assembly of all the citizens, and addressed them thus:

To me, as you know, have come ' scepter and all of his power, and it is in my power now to rule you. But I, so far as it lies in me, shall not do myself what I blame in my neighbor. I always disliked it that  or any other man should lord it over men like himself.  has fulfilled his destiny, and inviting you to share his power I proclaim equality.
Only I claim for my own privilege that six talents of ' wealth be set apart for my use, and that I and my descendants keep the priesthood of  the Liberator, whose temple I have founded, and now I give you freedom.
Such was ' promise to the . But one of them arose and answered: But you are not even fit to rule us, low-born and vermin, but you had better give an account of the monies that you have handled.


This was the speech of , a man of consequence among the citizens. But , realizing that if he let go of the sovereignty someone else would make himself sovereign instead, resolved not to let it go. Withdrawing into the acropolis, he sent for the citizens individually as if he would give an account of the money; then he seized and bound them.
So they were imprisoned, and afterwards  fell sick. His brother  thought him likely to die, and, so that he might the more easily make himself master of , he put all the prisoners to death. They had, it would seem, no desire to be free.
