So when the  brought  back to , no one raised a hand against them, but  and those of his faction offered to evacuate the island under a flag of truce;  agreed to this, and after the treaty was made, the  of highest rank sat down on seats facing the acropolis.


Now  the sovereign had a crazy brother named , who lay bound in the dungeon for some offense; this man heard what was going on, and by peering through the dungeon window saw the  sitting there peaceably;

whereupon he cried with a loud voice that he wanted to talk to . His brother, hearing him, had  loosed and brought before him. No sooner had he been brought than he attempted with reviling and abuse to persuade  to attack the . Although I am your brother, you coward, he said, and did no wrong deserving of prison, you have bound and imprisoned me; but when you see the  throwing you out of house and home, you have no courage to avenge yourself, though you could so easily beat them?
If you are yourself afraid of them, give me your foreign guards, and I will punish them for coming here; as for you, I will give you safe conduct out of the island.


This was what  said; and  took his advice, to my thinking not because he was so foolish as to suppose that he would be strong enough to defeat the king, but because he did not want  to recover  safe and sound with no trouble.
He wanted therefore by provoking the  to weaken  as much as he could before surrendering it, for he was well aware that if the  were hurt they would be furiously angry with the . Besides, he knew that he could get himself safely off the island whenever he liked, having built a secret passage leading from the acropolis to the sea.

 then set sail from ; but  armed all the guards, opened the acropolis' gates, and attacked the . These supposed that a full agreement had been made, and were taken unawares; the guard fell upon them and killed the  of highest rank, those who were carried in litters.
They were engaged in this when the rest of the  force came up in reinforcement, and, hard-pressed, the guards retreated into the acropolis.


The  captain , seeing how big a loss the  had suffered, deliberately forgot the command given him at his departure by  not to kill or enslave any  but to deliver the island intact to ; and he commanded his army to kill everyone they took, men and boys alike.
Then, while some of the  laid siege to the acropolis, the rest killed everyone they met, inside the temples and outside the temples alike.


 sailed to , escaping from ; and after he arrived there and brought up the possessions with which he had left his country, it became his habit to make a display of silver and gold drinking cups; while his servants were cleaning these, he would converse with the king of ,  son of , and would bring him to his house. As  marvelled greatly at the cups whenever he saw them,  would tell him to take as many as he liked.

 made this offer two or three times;  showed his great integrity in that he would not accept; but realizing that there were others in  from whom  would get help by offering them the cups, he went to the ephors and told them it would be best for  if this  stranger quit the country, lest he persuade  himself or some other  to do evil. The ephors listened to his advice and banished  by proclamation.


As for , the  swept it clear and turned it over uninhabited to . But afterwards , the  general, helped to settle the land, prompted by a dream and a disease that he contracted in his genitals.


While the fleet was away at , the  revolted. They had made very good preparation; for during the reign of the , and the rebellion of the seven, they had taken advantage of the time and the confusion to provision themselves against the siege; and (I cannot tell how) this went undetected.
At last they revolted openly and did this:sending away all the mothers, each chose one woman, whomever he liked of his domestics, as a bread-maker; as for the rest, they gathered them together and strangled them so they would not consume their bread.


When  heard of this, he collected all his forces and led them against , and he marched up to the town and laid siege to it; but the  thought nothing of the siege. They came up on to the ramparts of the wall and taunted  and his army with gesture and word, and one of them uttered this mot:

Why loiter there, , and not go away? You will take us when mules give birth. One of the  said this, by no means expecting that a mule would give birth.


A year and seven months passed, and  and his whole army were bitter because they could not take . Yet  had used every trick and every device against it. He tried the stratagem by which  took it, and every other stratagem and device, yet with no success; for the  kept a vigilant watch, and he could not take them.


But in the twentieth month of the siege a marvellous thing befell , son of that  who was one of the seven destroyers of the : one of his food-carrying mules gave birth.  would not believe the news; but when he saw the foal for himself, he told those who had seen it to tell no one;

then reflecting he recalled the 's word at the beginning of the siegethat the city would be taken when mules gave birthand having this utterance in mind he conceived that  might be taken; for the hand of heaven, he supposed, was in the man's word and the birth from his own mule.


As soon as he thought that it was 's fate to fall, he came and inquired of  if taking  were very important to him; and when he was assured that it was, he then cast about for a plan by which the city's fall would be accomplished by him alone; for good service among the  is very much esteemed, and rewarded by high preferment.
He could think of no other way to bring the city down than to mutilate himself and then desert to the ; so, making light of it, he mutilated himself beyond repair, and after cutting off his nose and ears and cropping his hair as a disfigurement and scourging himself, he came before .


The king reacted very violently to seeing a man so well-respected mutilated, and springing from the throne he uttered a cry and asked  who it was who had mutilated him and why.

There is no man, he said, except you, who has enough power to do this to me, and no one but I myself did this, O King, because I felt it terribly that  were laughing at .

 answered, Unfeeling man, you give a pretty name to an ugly act if you say that it was on account of those besieged that you did for yourself past cure. Why, you poor fool, will the enemy surrender sooner because you mutilated yourself? How could you not have been out of your mind to disfigure yourself?

Had I told you, said , what I intended to do, you would not have let me; but now I have done it on my own. Now, then, if you do your part we shall take . I shall desert to the city as I am, and I shall say to them that I suffered this at your hands; and I think that I shall persuade them, and thus gain a command.
Now, on the tenth day after I enter the city, take a thousand men from the part of your army about which you will least care if it is lost, and post them before the gate called the gate of ; on the seventh day after that, post two thousand more before the gate called the gate of the ; and when twenty days are past after that seventh, lead out four thousand more and post them before the  gate, as they call it; allow neither these, nor the others that go before them, to carry any weapons except daggers; leave them these.
But immediately after the twentieth day command the rest of your army to assault the whole circuit of the walls, and post the  before the gate of  and the gate called . For I think that once I have done conspicuous things the  will give me, among other things, the keys of their gates; then it will depend on me and on the  to do what is necessary.


Having given these instructions, he went to the gates, turning and looking back as though he were in fact a deserter. When the watch posted on the towers saw him, they ran down, and opening half the gate a little asked him who he was and why he came; he told them that he was  and was deserting to them.
When they heard this, the gatekeepers brought him before the general assembly of the , where he made a pitiful sight, saying that he had suffered at the hands of  what he had suffered at his own because he had advised the king to lead his army away, since they could find no way to take the city.

Now, he said in his speech to them, I come as a great boon to you, men of , and as a great bane to  and to his army and to the ; for he shall not get away with having mutilated me so; and I know all the issues of his plans. This was what he said.


When the  saw the most well-respected man in  without his nose and ears and all lurid with blood from the scourging, they were quite convinced that he was telling them the truth and came as their ally, and were ready to give him all that he asked; and he asked for a command.
When he got this from them, he did exactly as he had arranged with . On the tenth day he led out the  army, surrounded and slaughtered the thousand whom he had instructed  to put in the field first.
Seeing that he produced works equal to his words, the  were overjoyed and ready to serve him in every way. When the agreed number of days was past, he led out once more a chosen body of , and slaughtered the two thousand men of ' army.
When the  saw this work too, the praise of  was on everyone's lips. The agreed number of days once again passing, he led out his men to the place he had named, where he surrounded the four thousand and slaughtered them. And when he had done this,  was the one man for : he was made the commander of their armies and guard of the walls.


So when  assaulted the whole circuit of the walls, according to the agreed plan, then ' treason was fully revealed. For while the townsmen were on the wall defending it against ' assault, he opened the gates called  and , and let the  inside the walls.
Those  who saw what he did fled to the temple of that  whom they call ; those who had not seen it remained in position, until they too discovered how they had been betrayed.


Thus  was taken a second time, and when  was master of the , he destroyed their walls and tore away all their gates, neither of which  had done at the first taking of ; moreover he impaled about three thousand men that were prominent among them; as for the rest, he gave them back their city to live in.
Further, as the , fearing for their food, had strangled their own women, as I described above,  provided wives to give them a posterity by appointing that each of the neighboring nations should send a certain number of women to ; the sum of the women thus collected was fifty thousand: these were the mothers of those who now inhabit the city.


There never was in ' judgment any  before or after who did better service than , except , with whom no  could compare himself. Many times  is said to have declared that he would rather  were free of disfigurement than have twenty  on top of the one he had.
He honored him very much; every year he sent him such gifts as the  hold most precious, and let him govern  all his life with no tribute to pay, giving him many other things besides. This  was the father of , who was general of an army in  against the  and their allies; and ' son was that  who deserted from the  to .

The aegis is the conventional buckler of . Probably the conservatism of religious art retained for the warrior goddess the goatskin buckler which was one of the earliest forms of human armor.

Asphodel is a long-stalked plant. The name has acquired picturesque associations; but Homer's asphodel meadow is in the unhappy realm of the dead, and is intended clearly to indicate a place of rank weeds.

quote.#text:
For the lifetimes of four  and four , eight generations of men,  grants to your house the kingship of ; more than this he advises you not even to try.

But you, return to your country and live there in peace. But if you find the oven full of amphora, do not bake the amphora, but let them go unscathed. And if you bake them in the oven, do not go into the tidal place; for if you do, then you shall be killed yourself, and also the bull that is fairest of the herd.

p.#text:
After taking ,  himself marched against the . For since  was bursting with men and vast revenues were coming in,  desired to punish the  for the wrong they had begun when they invaded Media first and defeated those who opposed them in battle.
For the , as I have said before, ruled upper  for twenty-eight years; they invaded  in their pursuit of the , and ended the power of the , who were the rulers of  before the  came.
But when the  had been away from their homes for twenty-eight years and returned to their country after so long an absence, as much trouble as their Median war awaited them. They found themselves opposed by a great force; for the  women, when their husbands were away for so long, turned to their slaves.


Now the  blind all their slaves, because of the milk they drink; and this is how they get it: taking tubes of bone very much like flutes, they insert these into the genitalia of the mares and blow into them, some blowing while others milk. According to them, their reason for doing this is that blowing makes the mare's veins swell and her udder drop.
When done milking, they pour the milk into deep wooden buckets, and make their slaves stand around the buckets and shake the milk; they draw off what stands on the surface and value this most; what lies at the bottom is less valued. This is why the  blind all prisoners whom they take: for they do not cultivate the soil, but are nomads.


So it came about that a younger generation grew up, born of these slaves and the women; and when the youths learned of their parentage, they came out to fight the  returning from Media.
First they barred the way to their country by digging a wide trench from the  to the broadest part of the ; and then, when the  tried to force a passage, they camped opposite them and engaged them in battle.
There were many fights, and the  could gain no advantage; at last one of them said, Men of , look at what we are doing! We are fighting our own slaves; they kill us, and we grow fewer; we kill them, and shall have fewer slaves.
Now, then, my opinion is that we should drop our spears and bows, and meet them with horsewhips in our hands. As long as they see us armed, they imagine that they are our equals and the sons of our equals; let them see us with whips and no weapons, and they will perceive that they are our slaves; and taking this to heart they will not face our attack.


The  heard this and acted on it; and their enemies, stunned by what they saw, did not think of fighting, but fled. Thus, the  ruled  and were driven out again by the , and returned to their own country in such a way. Desiring to punish them for what they had done,  assembled an army against them.


The  say that their nation is the youngest in the world, and that it came into being in this way. A man whose name was  appeared in this country, which was then desolate. They say that his parents were  and a daughter of the  (I do not believe the story, but it is told).
Such was ' lineage; and he had three sons: , , and , youngest of the three.
In the time of their rule (the story goes) certain implementsnamely, a plough, a yoke, a sword, and a flask, all of goldfell down from the sky into . The eldest of them, seeing these, approached them meaning to take them; but the gold began to burn as he neared, and he stopped.
Then the second approached, and the gold did as before. When these two had been driven back by the burning gold, the youngest brother approached and the burning stopped, and he took the gold to his own house. In view of this, the elder brothers agreed to give all the royal power to the youngest.


, it is said, was the father of the  clan called ; , the second brother, of those called  and ; the youngest, who was king, of those called .
All these together bear the name of , after their king;  is the name given them by . This, then, is the ' account of their origin,


and they say that neither more nor less than a thousand years in all passed from the time of their first king  to the entry of  into their country. The kings guard this sacred gold very closely, and every year offer solemn sacrifices of propitiation to it.
Whoever falls asleep at this festival in the open air, having the sacred gold with him, is said by the  not to live out the year; for which reason (they say) as much land as he can ride round in one day is given to him. Because of the great size of the country, the lordships that  established for his sons were three, one of which, where they keep the gold, was the greatest.
Above and north of the neighbors of their country no one (they say) can see or travel further, because of showers of feathers; for earth and sky are full of feathers, and these hinder sight.


This is what the  say about themselves and the country north of them. But the story told by the  who live in  is as follows. , driving the cattle of , came to this land, which was then desolate, but is now inhabited by the .

 lived west of the , settled in the island called by the  , on the shore of Ocean near , outside the pillars of . As for Ocean, the  say that it flows around the whole world from where the sun rises, but they cannot prove that this is so.

 came from there to the country now called , where, encountering wintry and frosty weather, he drew his lion's skin over him and fell asleep, and while he slept his mares, which were grazing yoked to the chariot, were spirited away by divine fortune.


When  awoke, he searched for them, visiting every part of the country, until at last he came to the land called the Woodland, and there he found in a cave a creature of double form that was half maiden and half serpent; above the buttocks she was a woman, below them a snake.
When he saw her he was astonished, and asked her if she had seen his mares straying; she said that she had them, and would not return them to him before he had intercourse with her;  did, in hope of this reward.
But though he was anxious to take the horses and go, she delayed returning them, so that she might have  with her for as long as possible; at last she gave them back, telling him, These mares came, and I kept them safe here for you, and you have paid me for keeping them, for I have three sons by you.
Now tell me what I am to do when they are grown up: shall I keep them here (since I am queen of this country), or shall I send them away to you? Thus she inquired, and then (it is said)  answered:

When you see the boys are grown up, do as follows and you will do rightly: whichever of them you see bending this bow and wearing this belt so, make him an inhabitant of this land; but whoever falls short of these accomplishments that I require, send him away out of the country. Do so and you shall yourself have comfort, and my will shall be done.


So he drew one of his bows (for until then  always carried two), and showed her the belt, and gave her the bow and the belt, that had a golden vessel on the end of its clasp; and, having given them, he departed. But when the sons born to her were grown men, she gave them names, calling one of them  and the next  and the youngest Scythes; furthermore, remembering the instructions, she did as she was told.
Two of her sons,  and , were cast out by their mother and left the country, unable to fulfill the requirements set; but Scythes, the youngest, fulfilled them and so stayed in the land.

 son of  comes the whole line of the kings of ; and it is because of the vessel that the  carry vessels on their belts to this day. This alone his mother did for Scythes. This is what the  dwellers in  say.


There is yet another story, to which account I myself especially incline. It is to this effect. The nomadic  inhabiting , when hard pressed in war by the , fled across the  river to the  country (for the country which the  now inhabit is said to have belonged to the  before),

and the , at the advance of the , deliberated as men threatened by a great force should. Opinions were divided; both were strongly held, but that of the princes was the more honorable; for the people believed that their part was to withdraw and that there was no need to risk their lives for the dust of the earth; but the princes were for fighting to defend their country against the attackers.
Neither side could persuade the other, neither the people the princes nor the princes the people; the one party planned to depart without fighting and leave the country to their enemies, but the princes were determined to lie dead in their own country and not to flee with the people, for they considered how happy their situation had been and what ills were likely to come upon them if they fled from their native land.
Having made up their minds, the princes separated into two equal bands and fought with each other until they were all killed by each other's hands; then the  people buried them by the , where their tombs are still to be seen, and having buried them left the land; and the  came and took possession of the country left empty.


And to this day there are  walls in , and a  ferry, and there is a country  and a strait named .
Furthermore, it is evident that the  in their flight from the  into  also made a colony on the peninsula where the  city of  has since been founded; and it is clear that the  pursued them and invaded Media, missing their way;

for the  always fled along the coast, and the  pursued with the  on their right until they came into the Median land, turning inland on their way. That is the other story current among  and foreigners alike.


There is also a story related in a poem by  son of , a man of . This , possessed by , visited the ; beyond these (he said) live the one-eyed , beyond whom are the griffins that guard gold, and beyond these again the , whose territory reaches to the sea.
Except for the , all these nations (and first the ) are always at war with their neighbors; the  were pushed from their lands by the , and the  by the , and the , living by the southern sea, were hard pressed by the  and left their country. Thus ' story does not agree with the  account about this country.


Where  who wrote this came from, I have already said; I will tell the story that I heard about him at  and . It is said that this , who was as well-born as any of his townsfolk, went into a fuller's shop at  and there died; the owner shut his shop and went away to tell the dead man's relatives,

and the report of ' death being spread about in the city was disputed by a man of , who had come from the town of , and said that he had met  going toward  and spoken with him. While he argued vehemently, the relatives of the dead man came to the fuller's shop with all that was necessary for burial;

but when the place was opened, there was no  there, dead or alive. But in the seventh year after that,  appeared at  and made that poem which the  now call the , after which he vanished once again.


Such is the tale told in these two towns. But this, I know, happened to the  in , two hundred and forty years after the second disappearance of , as reckoning made at  and  shows me:

, so the  say, appeared in their country and told them to set up an altar to , and set beside it a statue bearing the name of  the ; for, he said,  had come to their country alone of all  lands, and hethe man who was now , but then when he followed the god had been a crowhad come with him.
After saying this, he vanished. The , so they say, sent to  and asked the god what the vision of the man could mean; and the  priestess told them to obey the vision, saying that their fortune would be better.
They did as instructed. And now there stands beside the image of  a statue bearing the name of ; a grove of bay-trees surrounds it; the image is set in the marketplace. Let it suffice that I have said this much about .


As for the land of which my history has begun to speak, no one exactly knows what lies north of it; for I can find out from no one who claims to know as an eyewitness. For even , whom I recently mentionedeven he did not claim to have gone beyond the , even though a poet; but he spoke by hearsay of what lay north, saying that the  had told him.
But all that we have been able to learn for certain by report of the farthest lands shall be told.


North of the port of the , which lies midway along the coast of , the first inhabitants are the , who are ; and beyond them another tribe called ; these and the , though in other ways they live like the , plant and eat grain, onions, garlic, lentils, and millet.
Above the  live  farmers, who plant grain not to eat but to sell; north of these, the ; north of the , the land is uninhabited so far as we know.


These are the tribes by the , west of the . But on the other side of the , the tribe nearest to the sea is the tribe of the Woodlands; and north of these live  farmers, whom the  colonists on the  (who call themselves ) call .
These farming  inhabit a land stretching east a three days' journey to a river called , and north as far as an eleven days' voyage up the ; and north of these the land is desolate for a long way;

after the desolation is the country of the , who are a nation apart and by no means ; and beyond them is true desolation, where no nation of men lives, as far as we know.


But to the east of these farming , across the , you are in the land of nomadic , who plant nothing, nor plough; and all these lands except the Woodlands are bare of trees. These nomads inhabit a country to the east that stretches fourteen days' journey to the .


Across the  are those lands called Royal, where the best and most numerous of the  are, who consider all other  their slaves; their territory stretches south to the  land, and east to the trench that was dug by the sons of the blind men, and to the port called  on the ; and part of it stretches to the  river.
North of the Royal  live the , who are of another and not a  stock; and beyond the  the land is all marshes and uninhabited by men, so far as we know.


Across the  it is no longer ; the first of the districts belongs to the , whose country begins at the inner end of the  and stretches fifteen days' journey north, and is quite bare of both wild and cultivated trees. Above these in the second district, the  inhabit a country thickly overgrown with trees of all kinds.


North of the  the land is uninhabited for seven days' journey; after this desolation, and somewhat more toward the east wind, live the , a numerous and a separate nation, who live by hunting.
Adjoining these and in the same country live the people called ; these also live by hunting, in the way that I will describe. The hunter climbs a tree, and sits there concealed; for trees grow thickly all over the land; and each man has his horse at hand, trained to flatten on its belly for the sake of lowness, and his dog; and when he sees the quarry from the tree, he shoots with the bow and mounts his horse and pursues it, and the dog follows close behind.
Beyond these and somewhat to the east live  again, who revolted from the Royal  and came to this country.


As for the countryside of these , all the land mentioned up to this point is level and its soil deep; but thereafter it is stony and rough.
After a long journey through this rough country, there are men inhabiting the foothills of high mountains, who are said to be bald from birth (male and female alike) and snub-nosed and with long beards; they speak their own language, and wear  clothing, and their food comes from trees.
The tree by which they live is called ; it is about the size of a fig-tree, and bears a fruit as big as a bean, with a stone in it. When this fruit is ripe, they strain it through cloth, and a thick black liquid comes from it, which they call aschu; they lick this up or drink it mixed with milk, and from the thickest lees of it they make cakes, and eat them.
They have few cattle, for the pasture in their land is not good. They each live under a tree, covering it in winter with a white felt cloth, but using no felt in summer.
These people are wronged by no man, for they are said to be sacred; nor have they any weapon of war. They judge the quarrels between their neighbors; furthermore, whatever banished man has taken refuge with them is wronged by no one. They are called .


Now as far as the land of these bald men, we have full knowledge of the country and the nations on the near side of them; for some of the  make their way to them, from whom it is easy to get knowledge, and from some of the , too, from the  port and the other ports of ; such  as visit them transact their business with seven interpreters and in seven languages.


As far as these men this country is known, then, but what lies north of the bald men no one can say with exact knowledge; for high and impassable mountains bar the way, and no one crosses them. These bald men say (although I do not believe them) that the mountains are inhabited by men with goats' feet, and that beyond these are men who sleep for six months of the twelve. This I cannot accept as true at all.
But the country east of the bald-heads is known for certain to be inhabited by the ; however, of what lies north either of the bald-heads or the  we have no knowledge, except what comes from the report of these latter.


It is said to be the custom of the  that, whenever a man's father dies, all the nearest of kin bring beasts of the flock and, having killed these and cut up the flesh, they also cut up the dead father of their host, and set out all the flesh mixed together for a feast.
As for his head, they strip it bare and clean and gild it, and keep it for a sacred relic, to which they offer solemn sacrifice yearly. Every son does this for his father, just like the  in their festivals in honor of the dead. In other respects, these are said to be a law-abiding people, too, and the women to have equal power with the men.


Of these too, then, we have knowledge; but as for what is north of them, it is from the  that the tale comes of the one-eyed men and the griffins that guard gold; this is told by the , who have heard it from them; and we have taken it as true from the , and call these people by the  name, ; for in the  tongue arima is one, and spou is the eye.


All the aforesaid country is exceedingly cold: for eight months of every year there is unbearable frost, and during these you do not make mud by pouring out water but by lighting a fire; the sea freezes, as does all the ; and the  living on this side of the trench lead armies over the ice, and drive their wagons across to the land of the .
So it is winter for eight months, and cold in that country for the four that remain. Here, there is a different sort of winter than the winters in other lands: for in the season for rain scarcely any falls, but all summer it rains unceasingly;

and when there are thunderstorms in other lands, here there are none, but in summer there are plenty of them; if there is a thunderstorm in winter they are apt to wonder at it as at a portent. And so, too, if there is an earthquake summer or winter, it is considered a portent in .
Horses have the endurance to bear the  winter; mules and asses cannot bear it at all; and yet in other lands, while asses and mules can endure frost, horses that stand in it are frostbitten.


And in my opinion it is for this reason that the hornless kind of cattle grow no horns in . A verse of Homer in the  attests to my opinion:
in which it is correctly observed that in hot countries the horns grow quickly, whereas in very cold countries beasts hardly grow horns, or not at all.


In , then, this happens because of the cold. But I think it strange (for it was always the way of my history to investigate excurses) that in the whole of  no mules can be conceived although the country is not cold, nor is there any evident cause. The  themselves say that it is because of a curse that mules cannot be conceived among them;

but whenever the season is at hand for the mares to conceive, they drive them into the countries of their neighbors, and then send the asses after them, until the mares are pregnant, and then they drive them home again.


But regarding the feathers of which the  say that the air is full, so thickly that no one can see or traverse the land beyond, I have this opinion. North of that country snow falls continually, though less in summer than in winter, as is to be expected.
Whoever has seen snow falling thickly near him knows himself my meaning; for snow is like feathers; and because of the winter, which is as I have said, the regions to the north of this continent are uninhabited. I think therefore that in this story of feathers the  and their neighbors only speak of snow figuratively. So, then, I have spoken of those parts that are said to be most distant.


Concerning the  people, neither the  nor any other inhabitants of these lands tell us anything, except perhaps the . And, I think, even they say nothing; for if they did, then the , too, would have told, just as they tell of the one-eyed men. But  speaks of , and Homer too in his poem , if that is truly the work of Homer.


But the  say much more about them than any others do. They say that offerings wrapped in straw are brought from the  to ; when these have passed , each nation in turn receives them from its neighbors until they are carried to the , which is the most westerly limit of their journey;

from there, they are brought on to the south, the people of  being the first  to receive them. From  they come down to the  gulf, and are carried across to , and one city sends them on to another until they come to ; after this,  is left out of their journey, for  carry them to , and  to .
Thus (they say) these offerings come to . But on the first journey, the  sent two maidens bearing the offerings, to whom the  give the names  and , and five men of their people with them as escort for safe conduct, those who are now called  and greatly honored at .
But when those whom they sent never returned, they took it amiss that they should be condemned always to be sending people and not getting them back, and so they carry the offerings, wrapped in straw, to their borders, and tell their neighbors to send them on from their own country to the next;

and the offerings, it is said, come by this conveyance to . I can say of my own knowledge that there is a custom like these offerings; namely, that when the  and  women sacrifice to the Royal , they have straw with them while they sacrifice.


I know that they do this. The  girls and boys cut their hair in honor of these  maidens, who died at ; the girls before their marriage cut off a tress and lay it on the tomb, wound around a spindle

(this tomb is at the foot of an olive-tree, on the left hand of the entrance of the temple of ); the  boys twine some of their hair around a green stalk, and lay it on the tomb likewise.


In this way, then, these maidens are honored by the inhabitants of . These same  relate that two virgins,  and , came from the  by way of the aforesaid peoples to  earlier than  and ;

these latter came to bring to  the tribute which they had agreed to pay for easing child-bearing; but  and , they say, came with the gods themselves, and received honors of their own from the .
For the women collected gifts for them, calling upon their names in the hymn made for them by  of ; it was from  that the islanders and  learned to sing hymns to  and , calling upon their names and collecting gifts (this , after coming from , also made the other and ancient hymns that are sung at ).
Furthermore, they say that when the thighbones are burnt in sacrifice on the altar, the ashes are all cast on the burial-place of  and , behind the temple of , looking east, nearest the refectory of the people of .


I have said this much of the , and let it suffice; for I do not tell the story of that , alleged to be a , who carried the arrow over the whole world, fasting all the while. But if there are men beyond the north wind, then there are others beyond the south.
And I laugh to see how many have before now drawn maps of the world, not one of them reasonably; for they draw the world as round as if fashioned by compasses, encircled by the , and  and  of a like extent. For myself, I will in a few words indicate the extent of the two, and how each should be drawn.


The land where the  live extends to the southern sea which is called Red; beyond these to the north are the , and beyond the  the , and beyond the  the , whose country extends to the northern sea into which the  flows; so these four nations live between the one sea and the other.


But west of this region two peninsulas stretch out from it into the sea, which I will now describe.
On the north side one of the peninsulas begins at the  and stretches seaward along the  and the , as far as  in the ; on the south side, the same peninsula has a seacoast beginning at the  that is near , and stretching seaward as far as the  headland. On this peninsula live thirty nations.


This is the first peninsula. But the second, beginning with , stretches to the , and is  land; and next, the neighboring land of ; and after , ; this peninsula ends (not truly but only by common consent) at the , to which  brought a canal from the .
Now from the  country to  there is a wide and vast tract of land; and from  this peninsula runs beside our sea by way of the  and , which is at the end of it; in this peninsula there are just three nations.


So much for the parts of  west of the . But what is beyond the , and , and , and , east and toward the rising sun, this is bounded on the one hand by the , and to the north by the  and the , which flows toward the sun's rising.
As far as ,  is an inhabited land; but thereafter, all to the east is desolation, nor can anyone say what kind of land is there.


Such is , and such its extent. But  is on this second peninsula; for  comes next after . The  part of this peninsula is narrow; for from our sea to the  it is a distance of a hundred and twenty-five miles; that is, a thousand stades; but after this narrow part, the peninsula which is called  is very broad.


I wonder, then, at those who have mapped out and divided the world into , , and ; for the difference between them is great, seeing that in length  stretches along both the others together, and it appears to me to be wider beyond all comparison.
For  shows clearly that it is bounded by the sea, except where it borders on .  king of  first discovered this and made it known. When he had finished digging the canal which leads from the  to the , he sent  in ships, instructing them to sail on their return voyage past the Pillars of  until they came into the northern sea and so to .
So the  set out from the  and sailed the southern sea; whenever autumn came they would put in and plant the land in whatever part of  they had reached, and there await the harvest;

then, having gathered the crop, they sailed on, so that after two years had passed, it was in the third that they rounded the pillars of  and came to . There they said (what some may believe, though I do not) that in sailing around  they had the sun on their right hand.


Thus was the first knowledge of  gained. The next story is that of the : for as for  son of , an , he did not sail around , although he was sent for that purpose; but he feared the length and loneliness of the voyage and so returned without accomplishing the task laid upon him by his mother.
For he had raped the virgin daughter of  son of ; and when on this charge he was to be impaled by , ' mother, who was ' sister, interceded for his life, saying that she would impose a heavier punishment on him than ;

for he would be compelled to sail around , until he completed his voyage and came to the .  agreed to this, and  went to  where he received a ship and a crew from the , and sailed past the Pillars of .
Having sailed out beyond them, and rounded the  promontory called , he sailed south; but when he had been many months sailing over the sea, and always more before him, he turned back and made sail for .
Coming to  from there, he related in his narrative that, when he was farthest distant, he sailed by a country of little men, who wore palm-leaf clothing; these, whenever he and his men put in to land with their ship, left their towns and fled to the hills; he and his men did no harm when they landed, and took nothing from the people except cattle.
As to his not sailing completely around , the reason (he said) was that the ship could move no farther, but was stopped. But  did not believe that  spoke the truth, and, as the task appointed was unfulfilled, he impaled him, punishing him on the charge first brought against him.
This  had a eunuch, who as soon as he heard of his master's death escaped to , with a great hoard of wealth, of which a man of  got possession. I know the man's name but deliberately omit it.


But as to , most of it was discovered by . There is a river, , second of all rivers in the production of crocodiles. , desiring to know where this  empties into the sea, sent ships manned by , a man of , and others whose word he trusted;

these set out from the city of  and the  country, and sailed down the river toward the east and the sunrise until they came to the sea; and voyaging over the sea west, they came in the thirtieth month to that place from which the  king sent the above-mentioned  to sail around .
After this circumnavigation,  subjugated the  and made use of this sea. Thus it was discovered that , except the parts toward the rising sun, was in other respects like .


But it is plain that none have obtained knowledge of 's eastern or northern regions, so as to be able say if it is bounded by seas; its length is known to be enough to stretch along both  and .
I cannot guess for what reason the earth, which is one, has three names, all women's, and why the boundary lines set for it are the  and the  (though some say that the  and the  are boundaries); and I cannot learn the names of those who divided the world, or where they got the names which they used.
For  is said by most  to be named after a native woman of that name, and  after the wife of ; yet the  claim a share in the latter name, saying that  was not named after ' wife , but after , the son of , who was the son of Manes, and that from him the  clan at  also takes its name.
But as for , no men have any knowledge whether it is bounded by seas or not, or where it got its name, nor is it clear who gave the name, unless we say that the land took its name from the  , having been (it would seem) before then nameless like the rest.
But it is plain that this woman was of  birth, and never came to this land which the  now call , but only from  to  and from  to . Thus much I have said of these matters, and let it suffice; we will use the names established by custom.


Nowhere are men so ignorant as in the lands by the   (excluding the  nation) into which  led his army. For we cannot show that any nation within the region of the  has any cleverness, nor do we know of (overlooking the  nation and ) any notable man born there.
But the  race has made the cleverest discovery that we know in what is the most important of all human affairs; I do not praise the  in all respects, but in this, the most important: that they have contrived that no one who attacks them can escape, and no one can catch them if they do not want to be found.
For when men have no established cities or forts, but are all nomads and mounted archers, not living by tilling the soil but by raising cattle and carrying their dwellings on wagons, how can they not be invincible and unapproachable?


They have made this discovery in a land that suits their purpose and has rivers that are their allies; for their country is flat and grassy and well-watered, and rivers run through it not very many fewer in number than the canals of .
As many of them as are famous and can be entered from the sea, I shall name. There is the , which has five mouths, and the , and , and , and , and , and , and . Their courses are as I shall indicate.


The , the greatest of all rivers which we know, flows with the same volume in summer and winter; it is most westerly  of all, and the greatest because other rivers are its tributaries.
Those that make it great, five flowing through the  country, are these: the river called by   and by  , and besides this the , the , the , and the .
The first-named of these rivers is a great stream flowing east and uniting its waters with the ; the second, the , is more westerly and smaller; the , , and  flow between these two and pour their waters into the .


These are the native-born  rivers that help to swell it; but the , which commingles with the , flows from the . The , , and , three other great rivers that pour into it, flow north from the heights of . The , the , and the  flow into the  from the country of the  in ; the , which cuts through the middle of , from the  and the mountain range of .
The  flows north from  into the Triballic plain and the , and the  into the , which receives these two great rivers into itself. The  and another river called  also flow northward, from the country north of the , to flow into it;

for the  traverses the whole of , rising among the , who are the most westerly dwellers in , except for the , and flowing thus clean across  it issues forth along the borders of .


With these rivers aforesaid, and many others, too, as its tributaries, the  becomes the greatest river of all, while river for river the  surpasses it in volume, since that owes its volume of water to no tributary river or spring.
But the  is always the same height in summer and winter, the reason for which, I think, is this. In winter it is of its customary size, or only a little greater than is natural to it, for in that country in winter there is very little rain, but snow everywhere.
In the summer, the abundant snow that has fallen in winter melts and pours from all sides into the ; so this snow-melt pours into the river and helps to swell it and much violent rain besides, as the summer is the season of rain.
And in proportion as the sun draws to itself more water in summer than in winter, the water that commingles with the  is many times more abundant in summer than it is in winter; these opposites keep the balance true, so that the volume of the river appears always the same.


One of the rivers of the , then, is the . The next is the ; this comes from the north, flowing at first out of a great lake, which is the boundary between the  and the  countries; at the mouth of the river there is a settlement of , who are called .


The third river is the ; this comes from , flowing out of a great lake, around which wild, white horses graze. This lake is truly called the mother of the .
Here, then, the  rises; for five days' journey its waters are shallow and still sweet; after that for four days' journey seaward it is amazingly bitter,

for a spring runs into it so bitter that although its volume is small its admixture taints the , one of the few great rivers of the world. This spring is on the border between the farming  and the ; the name of it and of the place where it rises is in Scythian ; in the  tongue, .
The  and the  draw near together in the ' country; after that they flow apart, the intervening space growing wider.


The fourth is the . This is the next greatest after the , and the most productive, in our judgment, not only of the  but of all rivers, except the  , with which no other river can be compared.
But of the rest, the  is the most productive; it provides the finest and best-nurturing pasture lands for beasts, and the fish in it are beyond all in their excellence and abundance. Its water is most sweet to drink, flowing with a clear current, whereas the other rivers are turbid. There is excellent soil on its banks, and very rich grass where the land is not planted;

and self-formed crusts of salt abound at its mouth; it provides great spineless fish, called sturgeons, for salting, and many other wonderful things besides.
Its course is from the north, and it is known as far as the  land; that is, for forty days' voyage; beyond that, no one can say through what nations it flows; but it is plain that it flows through desolate country to the land of the farming , who live beside it for a ten days' voyage.
This is the only river, besides the , whose source I cannot identify; nor, I think, can any . When the  comes near the sea, the  mingles with it, running into the same marsh;

the land between these rivers, where the land projects like a ship's beak, is called ' promontory; a temple of  stands there. The settlement of the  is beyond the temple, on the .


This is the produce of these rivers, and after these there is a fifth river called ; this also flows from the north out of a lake, and the land between it and the  is inhabited by the farming ; it flows into the woodland country, after passing which it mingles with the .


The sixth is the , which rises from a lake, and flowing through the midst of the nomadic  flows out near the city of , bordering on its right the Woodland and the region called the .


The seventh river, the , separates from the  at about the place which is the end of our knowledge of that river; at this place it separates, and has the same name as the place itself, ; then in its course to the sea it divides the country of the  and the country of the Royal , and empties into the .


The eighth is the  river; in its upper course, this begins by flowing out of a great lake, and enters a yet greater lake called the , which divides the Royal  from the ; another river, called , is a tributary of this .


These are the rivers of note with which the  are provided. For rearing cattle, the grass growing in  is the most productive of bile of all pastures which we know; that this is so can be judged by opening up the bodies of the cattle.


The most important things are thus provided them. It remains now to show the customs which are established among them. The only gods whom they propitiate are these:  in particular, and secondly  and Earth, whom they believe to be the wife of ; after these, , and the Heavenly , and , and . All the  worship these as gods; the  called Royal sacrifice to  also.
In the  tongue,  is called ;  (in my judgment most correctly so called) ; Earth is ;  ; the Heavenly  ;  . It is their practice to make images and altars and shrines for , but for no other god.


In all their sacred rites they follow the same method of sacrifice; this is how it is offered. The victim stands with its forefeet shackled together; the sacrificer stands behind the beast, and throws it down by pulling the end of the rope;

as the victim falls, he invokes whatever god it is to whom he sacrifices. Then, throwing a noose around the beast's neck, he thrusts in a stick and twists it and so strangles the victim, lighting no fire nor offering the first-fruits, nor pouring any libation; and having strangled and skinned the beast, he sets about cooking it.


Now as the  land is quite bare of wood, this is how they contrive to cook the meat. When they have skinned the victims, they strip the meat from the bones and throw it into the cauldrons of the country, if they have them: these are most like  bowls, except that they are much bigger; they throw the meat into these, then, and cook it by lighting a fire beneath with the bones of the victims. But if they have no cauldron, then they put all the meat into the victims' stomachs, adding water, and make a fire of the bones beneath,

which burn nicely; the stomachs easily hold the meat when it is stripped from the bones; thus a steer serves to cook itself, and every other victim does likewise. When the flesh is cooked, the sacrificer takes the first-fruits of the flesh and the entrails and casts them before him. They use all grazing animals for sacrifice, but mainly horses.


This is their way of sacrificing to other gods and these are the beasts offered; but their sacrifices to  are of this sort. Every district in each of the governments has a structure sacred to ; namely, a pile of bundles of sticks three eighths of a mile wide and long, but of a lesser height, on the top of which there is a flattened four-sided surface; three of its sides are sheer, but the fourth can be ascended.
Every year a hundred and fifty wagon-loads of sticks are heaped upon this; for the storms of winter always make it sink down. On this sacred pile an ancient scimitar of iron is set for each people: their image of . They bring yearly sacrifice of sheep and goats and horses to this scimitar, offering to these symbols even more than they do to the other gods.
Of enemies that they take alive, they sacrifice one man in every hundred, not as they sacrifice sheep and goats, but differently. They pour wine on the men's heads and cut their throats over a bowl; then they carry the blood up on to the pile of sticks and pour it on the scimitar.
They carry the blood up above, but down below by the sacred pile they cut off all the slain men's right arms and hands and throw these into the air, and depart when they have sacrificed the rest of the victims; the arm lies where it has fallen, and the body apart from it.


These then are their established rites of sacrifice; but these  make no offerings of swine; nor are they willing for the most part to rear them in their country.


As to war, these are their customs. A  drinks the blood of the first man whom he has taken down. He carries the heads of all whom he has slain in the battle to his king; for if he brings a head, he receives a share of the booty taken, but not otherwise.
He scalps the head by making a cut around it by the ears, then grasping the scalp and shaking the head off. Then he scrapes out the flesh with the rib of a steer, and kneads the skin with his hands, and having made it supple he keeps it for a hand towel, fastening it to the bridle of the horse which he himself rides, and taking pride in it; for he who has most scalps for hand towels is judged the best man.
Many  even make garments to wear out of these scalps, sewing them together like coats of skin. Many too take off the skin, nails and all, from their dead enemies' right hands, and make coverings for their quivers;the human skin was, as it turned out, thick and shining, the brightest and whitest skin of all, one might say.
Many flay the skin from the whole body, too, and carry it about on horseback stretched on a wooden frame.


The heads themselves, not all of them but those of their bitterest enemies, they treat this way. Each saws off all the part beneath the eyebrows, and cleans the rest. If he is a poor man, then he covers the outside with a piece of raw hide, and so makes use of it; but if he is rich, he covers the head with the raw hide, and gilds the inside of it and uses it for a drinking-cup.
Such a cup a man also makes out of the head of his own kinsman with whom he has been feuding, and whom he has defeated in single combat before the king; and if guests whom he honors visit him he will serve them with these heads, and show how the dead were his kinsfolk who fought him and were beaten by him; this they call manly valor.


Furthermore, once a year each governor of a province brews a bowl of wine in his own province, which those  who have slain enemies drink; those who have not achieved this do not taste this wine but sit apart dishonored; and this they consider a very great disgrace; but as many as have slain not one but many enemies have two cups apiece and drink out of both.


There are many diviners among the , who divine by means of many wi!low wands as I will show. They bring great bundles of wands, which they lay on the ground and unfasten, and utter their divinations as they lay the rods down one by one; and while still speaking, they gather up the rods once more and place them together again;

this manner of divination is hereditary among them. The , who are hermaphrodites, say that  gave them the art of divination, which they practise by means of lime-tree bark. They cut this bark into three portions, and prophesy while they braid and unbraid these in their fingers.


Whenever the king of the  falls ill, he sends for the three most reputable diviners, who prophesy in the aforesaid way; and they generally tell him that such and such a man (naming whoever it may be of the people) has sworn falsely by the king's hearth;

for when the  will swear their mightiest oath, it is by the king's hearth that they are accustomed to swear. Immediately, the man whom they allege to have sworn falsely is seized and brought in, and when he comes the diviners accuse him, saying that their divination shows him to have sworn falsely by the king's hearth, and that this is the cause of the king's sickness; and the man vehemently denies that he has sworn falsely.
When he denies it, the king sends for twice as many diviners: and if they too, consulting their art, prove him guilty of perjury, then he is instantly beheaded, and his goods are divided among the first diviners;

but if the later diviners acquit him, then other diviners come, and yet again others. If the greater number of them acquit the man, it is decreed that the first diviners themselves be put to death.


And this is how they die. Men yoke oxen to a wagon laden with sticks and tie the diviners up in these, fettering their legs and binding their hands behind them and gagging them; then they set fire to the sticks and drive the oxen away, stampeding them.
Often the oxen are burnt to death with the diviners, and often the yoke-pole of their wagon is burnt through and the oxen escape with a scorching. They burn their diviners for other reasons, too, in the way described, calling them false prophets.
When the king puts them to death, he does not leave the sons alive either, but kills all the males of the family; the females he does not harm.


As for giving sworn pledges to those who are to receive them, this is the  way: they take blood from the parties to the agreement by making a little cut in the body with an awl or a knife, and pour it mixed with wine into a big earthenware bowl, into which they then dip a scimitar and arrows and an axe and a javelin; and when this is done those swearing the agreement, and the most honorable of their followers, drink the blood after solemn curses.


The burial-places of the kings are in the land of the , which is the end of the navigation of the . Whenever their king has died, the  dig a great four-cornered pit in the ground there; when this is ready, they take up the dead manhis body enclosed in wax, his belly cut open and cleaned and filled with cut marsh-plants and frankincense, and parsley and anise seed, and sewn up againand transport him on a wagon to another tribe.
Then those who receive the dead man on his arrival do the same as do the Royal : that is, they cut off a part of their ears, shave their heads, make cuts around their arms, tear their foreheads and noses, and pierce their left hands with arrows.
From there, the escorts transport the king's body on the wagon to another of the tribes that they rule, and those to whom they have already come follow them; and having carried the dead man to all in turn, they are at the place of burial, in the country of the , the farthest distant tribe of all under their rule.
Then, having laid the body on a couch in the tomb, they plant spears on each side of the body and lay wooden planks across them, which they then roof over with braided osiers; in the open space which is left in the tomb they bury one of the king's concubines, his cupbearer, his cook, his groom, his squire, and his messenger, after strangling them, besides horses, and first-fruits of everything else, and golden cups; for the  do not use silver or bronze.
Having done this, they all build a great barrow of earth, vying eagerly with one another to make this as great as possible.


After a year has past, they next do as follows. They take the most trusted of the rest of the king's servants (and these are native-born , for only those whom he tells to do so serve the king, and none of the  have servants bought by money)

and strangle fifty of these and fifty of their best horses and empty and clean the bellies of them all, fill them with chaff, and sew them up again.
Then they fasten half of a wheel to two posts, the hollow upward, and the other half to another pair of posts, until many posts thus prepared are planted in the ground, and, after driving thick stakes lengthways through the horses' bodies to their necks, they place the horses up on the wheels

so that the wheel in front supports the horse's forequarters and the wheel behind takes the weight of the belly by the hindquarters, and the forelegs and hindlegs hang free; and putting bridles and bits in the horses' mouths, they stretch the bridles to the front and fasten them with pegs.
Then they take each one of the fifty strangled young men and mount him on the horse; their way of doing it is to drive an upright stake through each body passing up alongside the spine to the neck leaving enough of the stake projecting below to be fixed in a hole made in the other stake, which passes through the horse. So having set horsemen of this fashion around the tomb, they ride away.


This is the way they bury their kings. All other , when they die, are laid in wagons and carried about among their friends by their nearest of kin; each receives them and entertains the retinue hospitably, setting before the dead man about as much of the fare as he serves to the rest. All but the kings are carried about like this for forty days and then buried.
After the burial the  cleanse themselves as follows: they anoint and wash their heads and, for their bodies, set up three poles leaning together to a point and cover these over with wool mats; then, in the space so enclosed to the best of their ability, they make a pit in the center beneath the poles and the mats and throw red-hot stones into it.


They have hemp growing in their country, very like flax, except that the hemp is much thicker and taller. This grows both of itself and also by their cultivation, and the  even make garments of it which are very like linen; no one, unless he were an expert in hemp, could determine whether they were hempen or linen; whoever has never seen hemp before will think the garment linen.


The  then take the seed of this hemp and, crawling in under the mats, throw it on the red-hot stones, where it smoulders and sends forth such fumes that no  vapor-bath could surpass it.
The  howl in their joy at the vapor-bath. This serves them instead of bathing, for they never wash their bodies with water.
But their women pound cypress and cedar and frankincense wood on a rough stone, adding water also, and with the thick stuff thus pounded they anoint their bodies and faces, as a result of which not only does a fragrant scent come from them, but when on the second day they take off the ointment, their skin becomes clear and shining.


But as regards foreign customs, the  (like others) very much shun practising those of any other country, and particularly of , as was proved in the case of  and also of .
For when  was coming back to the  country after having seen much of the world in his travels and given many examples of his wisdom, he sailed through the  and put in at ;

where, finding the  celebrating the feast of the Mother of the Gods with great ceremony, he vowed to this same Mother that if he returned to his own country safe and sound he would sacrifice to her as he saw the  doing, and establish a nightly rite of worship.
So when he came to , he hid himself in the country called Woodland (which is beside the Race of , and is all overgrown with every kind of timber); hidden there,  celebrated the goddess' ritual with exactness, carrying a small drum and hanging images about himself.
Then some  saw him doing this and told the king, ; who, coming to the place himself and seeing  performing these rites, shot an arrow at him and killed him. And now the , if they are asked about , say they have no knowledge of him; this is because he left his country for  and followed the customs of strangers.
But according to what I heard from , the deputy for ,  was an uncle of  king of , and he was the son of , son of , son of . Now if  was truly of this family, then let him know he was slain by his own brother; for  was the son of , and it was  who killed .


It is true that I have heard another story told by the ; namely, that  had been sent by the king of  and had been a student of the ways of , and after his return told the king who sent him that all  were keen for every kind of learning, except the ; but that these were the only  who spoke and listened with discretion.
But this is a tale pointlessly invented by the  themselves; and be this as it may, the man was put to death as I have said.


This, then, was how  fared, owing to his foreign ways and consorting with ; and a great many years afterward, , son of , suffered a like fate.  was one of the sons born to , king of ; but his mother was of , and not native-born; and she taught him to speak and read .
As time passed,  was treacherously killed by , king of the , and  inherited the kingship and his father's wife, a  woman whose name was , and she bore  a son, .
So  was king of ; but he was in no way content with the  way of life, and was much more inclined to  ways, from the upbringing that he had received. So this is what he would do: he would lead the  army to the city of the  (who say that they are ), and when he arrived there would leave his army in the suburb of the city,

while he himself, entering within the walls and shutting the gates, would take off his  apparel and put on  dress; and in it he would go among the townsfolk unattended by spearmen or any others (who would guard the gates, lest any  see him wearing this apparel), and in every way follow the  manner of life, and worship the gods according to  usage.
When he had spent a month or more like this, he would put on  dress and leave the city. He did this often; and he built a house in , and married a wife of the people of the country and brought her there.


But when things had to turn out badly for him, they did so for this reason: he conceived a desire to be initiated into the rites of the ; and when he was about to begin the sacred mysteries, he saw the greatest vision.
He had in the city of the  a spacious house, grand and costly (the same house I just mentioned), all surrounded by sphinxes and griffins worked in white marble; this house was struck by a thunderbolt. And though the house burnt to the ground,  none the less performed the rite to the end.
Now the  reproach the  for this Bacchic revelling, saying that it is not reasonable to set up a god who leads men to madness.
So when  had been initiated into the Bacchic rite, some one of the  scoffed at the : You laugh at us, , because we play the Bacchant and the god possesses us; but now this deity has possessed your own king, so that he plays the Bacchant and is maddened by the god. If you will not believe me, follow me now and I will show him to you.
The leading men among the  followed him, and the  brought them up secretly onto a tower; from which, when  passed by with his company of worshippers, they saw him playing the Bacchant; thinking it a great misfortune, they left the city and told the whole army what they had seen.


After this  rode off to his own place; but the  rebelled against him, setting up his brother , son of the daughter of , for their king.

, learning what had happened concerning him and the reason why it had happened, fled into ; and when  heard this he led his army there. But when he was beside the , the  barred his way; and when the armies were about to engage,  sent this message to :

Why should we try each other's strength? You are my sister's son, and you have my brother with you; give him back to me, and I will give up your  to you; and let us not endanger our armies.
Such was the offer  sent to him; for ' brother had fled from him and was with . The  agreed to this, and took his brother , giving up his own uncle to .

 then took his brother and carried him away, but  beheaded  on the spot. This is how closely the  guard their customs, and these are the penalties they inflict on those who add foreign customs to their own.


How numerous the  are, I was not able to learn exactly, and the accounts that I heard did not tally, some saying that they are very numerous, and some that they are few, so far as they are true .
But this much they let me see for myself: there is a region between the  and  rivers, whose name is ; this is the land that I mentioned when I said that there is a spring of salt water in it, whose water makes the  unfit to drink.
In this region is a bronze vessel, as much as six times greater than the cauldron dedicated by  son of  at the entrance of the .
For anyone who has not yet seen the latter, I will make my meaning plain: the  bronze vessel easily contains five thousand four hundred gallons, and it is of six fingers' thickness. This vessel (so the people of the country said) was made out of arrowheads.
For their king, whose name was , desiring to know the census of the , commanded every  to bring him the point from an arrow, threatening death to all who did not.
So a vast number of arrow-heads was brought, and he decided to make and leave a memorial out of them; and he made of these this bronze vessel, and set it up in this country . This much I heard about the number of the .


As for marvels, there are none in the land, except that it has by far the greatest and the most numerous rivers in the world; and over and above the rivers and the great extent of the plains there is one most marvellous thing for me to mention: they show a footprint of  by the  stamped on rock, like the mark of a man's foot, but forty inches in length. Having described this, I will now return to the story which I began to tell.


While  was making preparations against the , and sending messengers to direct some to furnish infantry and some to furnish ships, and others again to bridge the , , son of  and ' brother, by no means wanted him to make an expedition against the , telling him how hard that people were to deal with.
But when, for all his good advice, he could not deter the king,  ceased to advise, and , all his preparations made, led his army from .


Then the  , who had three sons, all with the army, asked  that one be left behind. You are my friend, said the king, and your request is reasonable; I will leave all your sons.

 was very happy, supposing his sons released from service; but  told those whose job it was to execute all of ' sons. So their throats were cut, and they were left there.


But , when he came to that place in his march from  where the  was bridged in the territory of , went aboard ship and sailed to the  (as they are called), which the  say formerly moved; there, he sat on a headland and viewed the , a marvellous sight.
For it is the most wonderful sea of all. Its length is eleven thousand one hundred stades, and its breadth three thousand three hundred stades at the place where it is widest.
The channel at the entrance of this sea is four stades across; the narrow neck of the channel, called , across which the bridge was thrown, is about one hundred and twenty stades long. The  reaches as far as to the ;

and the  is five hundred stades wide and one thousand four hundred long; its outlet is the , which is no wider than seven stades and four hundred long. The  empties into a gulf of the sea which we call .


These measurements have been made in this way: a ship will generally accomplish seventy thousand orguiae  in a long day's voyage, and sixty thousand by night.
This being granted, seeing that from the ' mouth to the  (which is the greatest length of the sea) it is a voyage of nine days and eight nights, the length of it will be one million one hundred and ten thousand orguiai, which make eleven thousand stades.
From the  region to  on the  (the greatest width of the ) it is a voyage of three days and two nights; that is, of three hundred and thirty thousand orguiai, or three thousand three hundred stades.
Thus have I measured the  and the  and , and they are as I have said. Furthermore, a lake is seen issuing into the  and not much smaller than the sea itself; it is called the , and the mother of the .


After having viewed the ,  sailed back to the bridge, whose architect was  of ; and when he had viewed the  also, he set up two pillars of white marble by it, engraving on the one in  and on the other in  characters the names of all the nations that were in his army: all the nations subject to him. The full census of these, over and above the fleet, was seven hundred thousand men, including horsemen, and the number of ships assembled was six hundred.
These pillars were afterward carried by the  into their city and there used to build the altar of  , except for one column covered with  writing that was left beside the temple of  at . Now if my reckoning is correct, the place where king  bridged the  was midway between  and the temple at the entrance of the sea.


After this, being pleased with his bridge of boats,  made a gift of ten of everything to  the , the architect of it;  took the first-fruits of these and had a picture made with them, showing the whole bridge of the , and  sitting aloft on his throne and his army crossing; he set this up in the temple of , with this inscription:



This memorialized the builder of the bridge.


, after rewarding , crossed over to ; he had told the  to sail into the  as far as the , and when they got to the , to wait there for him, bridging the river meanwhile; for the fleet was led by  and  and men of the .
So the fleet passed between the  and sailed straight for the  and, after a two days' voyage up the river from the sea, set about bridging the narrow channel of the river where its various mouths separate.
But , passing over the  on the floating bridge of ships, journeyed through  to the sources of the , where he camped for three days.


The  is said by those living on it to be the best river of all for purposes of healing, especially for healing mange in men and horses. Its springs are thirty-eight in number, some cold and some hot, all flowing from the same rock.
There are two roads to the place, one from the town of  near , one from  on the ; each is a two days' journey. This  is a tributary of the , and that of the , and that of the , which empties into the sea near the city of .


Having come to this river and camped there, then,  was pleased with the sight of it, and set up yet another pillar there, cut with this inscription:

From the headwaters of the river  flows the best and finest water of all; and to them came, leading an army against the , the best and finest man of all,  son of , king of  and all the continent. Such was the inscription.


From there,  set out and came to another river called , which flows through the country of the ; and having reached this river, he pointed out a spot to the army, and told every man to lay one stone as he passed in this spot that he pointed out. After his army did this, he led it away, leaving behind there great piles of stones.


But before he came to the , he first took the , who pretend to be immortal. The  of  and of the country above the towns of  and , who are called  and , surrendered without a fight to ; but the  resisted stubbornly, and were enslaved at once, the bravest and most just  of all.


Their belief in their immortality is as follows: they believe that they do not die, but that one who perishes goes to the deity , or , as some of them call him.
Once every five years they choose one of their people by lot and send him as a messenger to , with instructions to report their needs; and this is how they send him: three lances are held by designated men; others seize the messenger to  by his hands and feet, and swing and toss him up on to the spear-points.
If he is killed by the toss, they believe that the god regards them with favor; but if he is not killed, they blame the messenger himself, considering him a bad man, and send another messenger in place of him. It is while the man still lives that they give him the message.
Furthermore, when there is thunder and lightning these same  shoot arrows skyward as a threat to the god, believing in no other god but their own.


I understand from the  who live beside the  and , that this  was a man who was once a slave in , his master being  son of ;

then, after being freed and gaining great wealth, he returned to his own country. Now the  were a poor and backward people, but this  knew  ways and a more advanced way of life than the ; for he had consorted with , and moreover with one of the greatest  teachers, ;

therefore he made a hall, where he entertained and fed the leaders among his countrymen, and taught them that neither he nor his guests nor any of their descendants would ever die, but that they would go to a place where they would live forever and have all good things.
While he was doing as I have said and teaching this doctrine, he was meanwhile making an underground chamber. When this was finished, he vanished from the sight of the , and went down into the underground chamber, where he lived for three years,

while the  wished him back and mourned him for dead; then in the fourth year he appeared to the , and thus they came to believe what  had told them. Such is the  story about him.


Now I neither disbelieve nor entirely believe the tale about  and his underground chamber; but I think that he lived many years before ;

and as to whether there was a man called  or this is some deity native to the , let the question be dismissed.


Such were the ways of the , who were subdued by the  and followed their army. When  and the land army with him had come to the , and all had crossed, he had the  break the bridge and follow him in his march across the mainland, together with the men of the fleet.
So the  were preparing to break the bridge and do ' bidding; but Ces son of , the general of the , after first asking if  were willing to listen to advice from one who wanted to give it, said,

Since, O King, you are about to march against a country where you will not find tilled lands or inhabited cities, let this bridge stay where it is, leaving those who made it to guard it.
Thus, if we find the  and do what we want, we have a way of return; and even if we do not find them, at least our way back is safe; for my fear has never been that we shall be overcome by the  in the field, but rather that we may not be able to find them, and so go astray to our harm.
Now it may perhaps be said that I say this for my own sake, because I want to remain behind; but it is not so; I only declare publicly the opinion that I think best for you, and I will follow you and do not want to be left here.

 was very pleased with this advice, and he answered Ces thus: My friend from , do not fail to show yourself to me when I return to my house safe, so that I may make you a good return for your good advice.


After saying this, he tied sixty knots in a thong, and summoning the  sovereigns to an audience said to them:

Gentlemen of , I take back the decision which I delivered before about the bridge; now, take this thong and do as follows.
