Begin to reckon from the day when you see me march away against the , and untie one knot each day: and if the days marked by the knots have all passed and I have not returned, embark for your own homes.
But until then, since the plan is changed, guard the bridge, making every effort to keep and watch it. You will please me very much if you do this. Having said this,  hastened to march further.


 runs farther out into the sea than ; and  begins where a bay is formed in its coast, and the mouth of the , facing southeast, is in that country.
Now I am going to describe the coast of the true  from the , and give its measurements. The ancient  land begins at the  and faces south and the south wind, as far as the city called .
Beyond this place, the country fronting the same sea is hilly and projects into the ; it is inhabited by the  nation as far as what is called the ; and this ends in the eastern sea.
For the sea to the south and the sea to the east are two of the four boundary lines of , just as seas are boundaries of ; and the  inhabit a part of  like , as though some other people, not Attic, were to inhabit the heights of  from  to the town of , if  jutted farther out into the sea.
I mean, so to speak, to compare small things with great. Such a land is the  country. But those who have not sailed along that part of  may understand from this other analogy: it is as though in  some other people, not , were to live on the promontory within a line drawn from the harbor of  to . I am speaking of these two countries, but there are many others of a similar kind that  resembles.


Beyond the  country the  begin, living north of the  and beside the eastern sea, west of the  and the , as far as the  river, which empties into the end of that lake.
Now it has been seen that on its northern and inland side, running from the ,  is bounded first by the , next by the , next by the , and last by the .


, then, is a four-sided country, two of whose sides are coastline, the frontiers running inland and those that are by the sea making it a perfect square;

for it is a ten days' journey from the  to the , and the same from the  to the ; and it is a twenty days' journey from the sea inland to the country of the  who live north of .
Now, as I reckon a day's journey at two hundred stades, the cross-measurement of  would be a distance of five hundred miles, and the line drawn straight up inland the same. Such then is the extent of this land.


Convinced that they alone were not able to repel ' army in open warfare, the  sent messengers to their neighbors, whose kings had already gathered and were deliberating on the presumption that a great army was marching against them.
The assembled kings were those of the , , , , , , , and .


Among these, the  have the following customs: all ship-wrecked men, and any  whom they capture in their sea-raids, they sacrifice to the Virgin goddess as I will describe: after the first rites of sacrifice, they strike the victim on the head with a club;

according to some, they then place the head on a pole and throw the body off the cliff on which their temple stands; others agree as to the head, but say that the body is buried, not thrown off the cliff. The  themselves say that this deity to whom they sacrifice is 's daughter .
As for enemies whom they defeat, each cuts his enemy's head off and carries it away to his house, where he places it on a tall pole and stands it high above the dwelling, above the smoke-vent for the most part. These heads, they say, are set up to guard the whole house. The  live by plundering and war.


The  are the most refined of men and especially given to wearing gold. Their intercourse with women is promiscuous, so that they may be consanguine with one another and, all being relations, not harbor jealousy or animosity toward one another. In the rest of their customs they are like the .


The  follow  customs; but one generation before the advent of ' army, they happened to be driven from their country by snakes; for their land produced great numbers of these, and still more came down on them out of the desolation on the north, until at last the  were so afflicted that they left their own country and lived among the . It may be that these people are wizards;

for the , and the  settled in , say that once a year every one of the  becomes a wolf for a few days and changes back again to his former shape. Those who tell this tale do not convince me; but they tell it nonetheless, and swear to its truth.


The  are the most savage of all men in their way of life; they know no justice and obey no law. They are nomads, wearing a costume like the , but speaking a language of their own; of all these, they are the only people that eat men.


The  all wear black clothing, from which they get their name; their customs are .


The  are a great and populous nation; the eyes of them all are very bright, and they are ruddy. They have a city built of wood, called . The wall of it is three and three quarters miles in length on each side of the city; this wall is high and all of wood; and their houses are wooden, and their temples;

for there are temples of  gods among them, furnished in  style with images and altars and shrines of wood; and they honor  every two years with festivals and revelry. For the  are by their origin , who left their trading ports to settle among the ; and they speak a language half  and half . But the  do not speak the same language as the , nor is their manner of life the same.


The  are indigenous; they are nomads, and the only people in these parts that eat fir-cones; the  are farmers, eating grain and cultivating gardens; they are altogether unlike the  in form and in coloring. Yet the  call the  too ; but this is wrong.
Their whole country is thickly wooded with every kind of tree; in the depth of the forest there is a great, wide lake and a marsh surrounded by reeds; otter is trapped in it, and beaver, besides certain square-faced creatures whose skins are used to trim mantles, and their testicles are used by the people to heal sicknesses of the womb.


About the , the story is as follows. When the  were at war with the  (whom the  call , a name signifying in our tongue killers of men, for in  a man is oior and to kill is pata), the story runs that after their victory on the  they sailed away carrying in three ships as many  as they had been able to take alive; and out at sea the  attacked the crews and killed them.
But they knew nothing about ships, or how to use rudder or sail or oar; and with the men dead, they were at the mercy of waves and winds, until they came to the Cliffs by the ; this place is in the country of the free . The  landed there, and set out on their journey to the inhabited country, and seizing the first troop of horses they met, they mounted them and raided the  lands.


The  could not understand the business; for they did not recognize the women's speech or their dress or their nation, but wondered where they had come from, and imagined them to be men all of the same age; and they met the  in battle. The result of the fight was that the  got possession of the dead, and so came to learn that their foes were women.
Therefore, after deliberation they resolved by no means to slay them as before, but to send their youngest men to them, of a number corresponding (as they guessed) to the number of the women. They directed these youths to camp near the  and to imitate all that they did; if the women pursued them, not to fight, but to flee; and when the pursuit stopped, to return and camp near them. This was the plan of the , for they desired that children be born of the women. The young men who were sent did as they were directed.


When the  perceived that the youths meant them no harm, they let them be; but every day the two camps drew nearer to each other. Now the young men, like the , had nothing but their arms and their horses, and lived as did the women, by hunting and plunder.


At midday the  would scatter and go apart from each other singly or in pairs, roaming apart for greater comfort. The  noticed this and did likewise; and as the women wandered alone, a young man laid hold of one of them, and the woman did not resist but let him do his will;

and since they did not understand each other's speech and she could not speak to him, she signed with her hand that he should come the next day to the same place and bring another youth with him (showing by signs that there should be two), and she would bring another woman with her.
The youth went away and told his comrades; and the next day he came himself with another to the place, where he found the  and another with her awaiting them. When the rest of the young men learned of this, they had intercourse with the rest of the .


Presently they joined their camps and lived together, each man having for his wife the woman with whom he had had intercourse at first. Now the men could not learn the women's language, but the women mastered the speech of the men;

and when they understood each other, the men said to the , We have parents and possessions; therefore, let us no longer live as we do, but return to our people and be with them; and we will still have you, and no others, for our wives. To this the women replied:

We could not live with your women; for we and they do not have the same customs. We shoot the bow and throw the javelin and ride, but have never learned women's work; and your women do none of the things of which we speak, but stay in their wagons and do women's work, and do not go out hunting or anywhere else.
So we could never agree with them. If you want to keep us for wives and to have the name of fair men, go to your parents and let them give you the allotted share of their possessions, and after that let us go and live by ourselves. The young men agreed and did this.


So when they had been given the allotted share of possessions that fell to them, and returned to the , the women said to them:

We are worried and frightened how we are to live in this country after depriving you of your fathers and doing a lot of harm to your land.
Since you propose to have us for wives, do this with us: come, let us leave this country and live across the  river.


To this too the youths agreed; and crossing the , they went a three days' journey east from the river, and a three days' journey north from ; and when they came to the region in which they now live, they settled there.
Ever since then the women of the  have followed their ancient ways; they ride out hunting, with their men or without them; they go to war, and dress the same as the men.


The language of the  is , but not spoken in its ancient purity, since the  never learned it correctly. In regard to marriage, it is the custom that no maiden weds until she has killed a man of the enemy; and some of them grow old and die unmarried, because they cannot fulfill the law.


The kings of the aforesaid nations having gathered, then, the  messengers came and laid everything before them, explaining how the , now that the whole of the other continent was subject to him, had crossed over to their continent by a bridge thrown across the neck of the , and how having crossed it and subjugated the  he was now bridging the , so as to make that whole region subject to him like the others.

By no means stand aside and let us be destroyed, they said; rather, let us unite and oppose this invader. If you will not, then we shall either be driven out of our country or stay and make terms.
For what is to become of us if you will not help us? And afterward it will not be easy for you, either; for the  has come to attack you no less than us, and when he has subjugated us he will not be content to leave you alone.
We will give you a convincing proof of what we say: if indeed the  were marching against us alone, wanting vengeance for our former enslavement of his country, he ought to leave others alone and make straight for us, and would show everyone that  and no other country was his goal.
But as it is, from the day he crossed over to this continent, he has been taming all that come in his way, and he holds in subjection not only the rest of , but also our neighbors the .


After the  had made this speech, the kings who had come from the nations deliberated, and their opinions were divided. The kings of the  and the  and the  were of one mind and promised to help the ; but the kings of the  and  and  and  and  gave this answer to the messengers:

Had it not been you who wronged the  first and began the war, what you now ask would seem to us right, and we would listen and act together with you.
But as it is, you invaded their land without us and ruled the  for as long as god granted; and the , urged on by the same god, are only repaying you in kind.
But we did these men no wrong at that former time, nor do we intend now to wrong them first; but if the  comes against our land too and begins the wrong-doing, then we will not accept it, either; but until we see that, we shall keep to ourselves. For in our judgment the  have not come for us but for those who were the agents of wrong.


When this answer was brought back to the , they determined not to meet their enemy in the open field, since they could not get the allies that they sought, but rather to fall back driving off their herds, choking the wells and springs on their way and destroying the grass from the earth; and they divided themselves into two companies.
It was their decision that to one of their divisions, which  ruled, the  be added; if the  marched that way, this group was to retire before him and fall back toward the  river, by the , and if the  turned to go back, then they were to pursue and attack him. This was one of the divisions of the royal people, and it was appointed to follow this course;

their two other divisions, namely, the greater whose ruler was , and the third whose king was , were to unite, and taking with them also the  and , to draw off like the others at the  approach, always keeping one day's march ahead of the enemy, avoiding a confrontation and doing what had been determined.
First, then, they were to retreat in a straight line toward the countries which refused their alliance, so as to involve these, too, in the war; for if they did not of their own accord support the war against the , they must be involved against their will; and after that, the division was to turn back to its own country, and attack the enemy, if in deliberation they thought this best.


Determined on this plan, the  sent an advance guard of their best horsemen to meet ' army. As for the wagons in which their children and wives lived, all these they sent forward, with instructions to drive always northward; and they sent all their flocks with the wagons, keeping none back except what was required for their food.


After this convoy was first sent on its way, the advance guard of the  found the  about a three days' march distant from the ; and having found them they camped a day's march ahead of the enemy and set about scorching the earth of all living things.
When the  saw the  cavalry appear, they marched on its track, the horsemen always withdrawing before them; and then, making for the one  division, the  held on in pursuit toward the east and the  river;

when the horsemen crossed this, the  crossed also, and pursued until they had marched through the land of the  to the land of the .


As long as the  were traversing the  and  territory there was nothing for them to harm, as the land was dry and barren. But when they entered the country of the , they found themselves before the wooden-walled town; the  had abandoned it and left nothing in it, and the  burnt the town.
Then going forward still on the horsemen's track, they passed through this country into desolation, which is inhabited by no one; it lies to the north of the  and its breadth is a seven days' march.
Beyond this desolation live the ; four great rivers flow from their country through the land of the , and issue into the lake called the ; their names are , , , .


When  came into the desolate country, he halted in his pursuit and camped on the , where he built eight great forts, the ruins of which were standing even in my lifetime, all at an equal distance of about seven miles from one another.
While he was occupied with these, the  whom he was pursuing doubled north and turned back into . Then, when they had altogether vanished and were no longer within the ' sight,  left those forts only half finished, and he too doubled about and marched west, thinking that those  were the whole army, and that they were fleeing toward the west.


But when he came by forced marches into , he met the two divisions of the , and pursued them, who always kept a day's march away from him;

and because  would not stop pursuing them, the , according to the plan they had made, fell back before him to the countries of those who had refused their alliance, to the land of the  first.
The  and  burst into their land, agitating them; and from there, the  led the  into the country of the , agitating them too; from there, they drew off into the country of the  and, agitating them also, fled to the .
But the , seeing their neighbors fleeing panic-stricken at the ' approach, before the  could break into their land sent a herald to forbid them to set foot across their borders, warning the  that if they tried to break through they would have to fight with the  first.
With this warning, the  mustered on their borders, intending to stop the invaders. When the  and the  broke into their lands, the  and  and  put up no resistance, but forgot their threats and fled panic-stricken north into the desolate country.
But warned off by the , the  made no second attempt on that country, but led the  from the lands of the  into .


As this went on for a long time and did not stop,  sent a horseman to  the  king, with this message: You crazy man, why do you always run, when you can do otherwise? If you believe yourself strong enough to withstand my power, stand and fight and stop running; but if you know you are the weaker, then stop running like this and come to terms with your master, bringing gifts of earth and water.


 the  king replied: It is like this with me, : I never ran from any man before out of fear, and I am not running from you now; I am not doing any differently now than I am used to doing in time of peace, too.
As to why I do not fight with you at once, I will tell you why. We  have no towns or cultivated land, out of fear for which, that the one might be taken or the other wasted, we would engage you sooner in battle. But if all you want is to come to that quickly, we have the graves of our fathers.
Come on, find these and try to destroy them: you shall know then whether we will fight you for the graves or whether we will not fight. Until then, unless we have reason, we will not engage with you.
As to fighting, enough; as to masters, I acknowledge  my forefather and  queen of the  only. As for you, instead of gifts of earth and water I shall send such as ought to come to you; and for your boast that you are my master, I say Weep! Such is the proverbial  speech.


So the herald went to carry this message to ; but the  kings were filled with anger when they heard the word slavery.
They then sent the division of the  to which the  were attached, and which was led by , to speak with those  guarding the bridge over the ; as for those of the  who remained behind, it was decided that they should no longer decoy the , but attack them whenever they were foraging for provision. So they watched for the time when ' men were foraging, and did as they had planned.
The  horse always routed the  horse, and when the  cavalry would fall back in flight on their infantry, the infantry would come up to their aid; and the , once they had driven in the horse, turned back for fear of the infantry. The  attacked in this fashion by night as well as by day.


Very strange to say, what aided the  and thwarted the  in their attacks on ' army was the braying of the asses and the appearance of the mules.
For, as I have before indicated,  produces no asses or mules; and there is not in most of  an ass or a mule, because of the cold. Therefore the asses frightened the  horses when they brayed loudly;

and often, when they were in the act of charging the , the horses would shy in fear if they heard the asses bray or would stand still with ears erect, never having heard a noise like it or seen a like creature.


The  thus gained very little in the war, for when the  saw that the  were shaken, they formed a plan to have them remain longer in  and, remaining, be distressed by lack of necessities: they would leave some of their flocks behind with the shepherds, moving away themselves to another place; and the  would come and take the sheep, and be encouraged by this achievement.


After such a thing had happened several times,  was finally at a loss; and when they perceived this, the  kings sent a herald to  with the gift of a bird, a mouse, a frog, and five arrows.
The  asked the bearer of these gifts what they meant; but he said that he had only been told to give the gifts and then leave at once; he told the  to figure out what the presents meant themselves, if they were smart enough.


When they heard this, the  deliberated. ' judgment was that the  were surrendering themselves and their earth and their water to him; for he reasoned that a mouse is a creature found in the earth and eating the same produce as men, and a frog is a creature of the water and a bird particularly like a horse; and the arrows signified that the  surrendered their fighting power.
This was the opinion declared by ; but the opinion of , one of the seven who had slain the , was contrary to it. He reasoned that the meaning of the gifts was,

Unless you become birds, , and fly up into the sky, or mice and hide in the earth, or frogs and leap into the lakes, you will be shot by these arrows and never return home.


The  reasoned thus about the gifts. But when the first division of the  came to the bridgethe division that had first been appointed to stand on guard by the  and had now been sent to the  to speak with the they said,

, we have come to bring you freedom, if you will only listen to us. We understand that  has directed you to guard the bridge for sixty days only, and if he does not come within that time, then to go away to your homes.
Now then, do what will leave you guiltless in his eyes as in ours: stay here for the time appointed; and after that, leave. So the  promised to do this, and the  made their way back with all haste.


But after sending the gifts to , the  who had remained there came out with foot and horse and offered battle to the . But when the  ranks were set in order, a rabbit ran out between the armies; and every  that saw it gave chase. So there was confusion and shouting among the ;  asked about the clamor among the enemy; and when he heard that they were chasing a rabbit, he said to those with whom he was accustomed to speak,

These men hold us in deep contempt; and I think now that ' opinion of the  gifts was true. Since, then, my own judgment agrees with his, we need to consider carefully how we shall return safely. To this  said : O King, I understood almost by reason alone how difficult it would be to deal with these ; but when I came here, I understood even better, watching them toying with us.
Now then, my advice is that at nightfall we kindle our campfires in the usual way, deceive those in our army who are least fit to endure hardship, and tether all our asses here, and ourselves depart, before the  can march straight to the  to break up the bridge, or the  take some action by which we may well be ruined.


This was ' advice, and at nightfall  followed it. He left the men who were worn out, and those whose loss mattered least to him, there in the camp, and all the asses, too, tethered.
His reasons for leaving the asses, and the infirm among his soldiers, were the following: the asses, so that they would bray; the men, who were left because of their infirmity, he pretended were to guard the camp while he attacked the  with the fit part of his army.
Giving this order to those who were left behind, and lighting campfires,  made all haste to reach the . When the asses found themselves deserted by the multitude, they brayed the louder for it; and the  heard them and assumed that the  were in the place.


But when it was day, the men left behind perceived that  had betrayed them, and they held out their hands to the  and explained the circumstances; they, when they heard this, assembled their power in haste, the two divisions of their horde and the one division that was with the  and  and , and made straight for the  in pursuit of the .
And as the  army was for the most part infantry and did not know the roads (which were not marked), while the  were horsemen and knew the short cuts, they went wide of each other, and the  reached the bridge long before the .
There, perceiving that the  had not yet come, they said to the , who were in their ships, , the days have exceeded the number, and you are wrong to be here still.
Since it was fear that kept you here, now break the bridge in haste and go, free and happy men, thanking the gods and the . The one that was your master we shall impress in such a way that he will never lead an army against anyone again.


Then the  held a council.  the , general and sovereign of the  of the , advised that they do as the  said and set  free.
But  of  advised the opposite. He said, It is owing to  that each of us is sovereign of his city; if ' power is overthrown, we shall no longer be able to rule, I in  or any of you elsewhere; for all the cities will choose democracy rather than despotism.
When  explained this, all of them at once inclined to his view, although they had first sided with .

for  had coined money out of gold refined to an extreme purity, and , then ruling , made a similar silver coinage; and now there is no silver money so pure as is the . But when  heard that  was doing so, he put him to death, not on this charge but as a rebel.

Now, concerning the lands inhabited by , the  are the people that live nearest to ; they follow  customs for the most part, but dress like other . Their women wear twisted bronze ornaments on both legs; their hair is long; each catches her own lice, then bites and throws them away.
They are the only  that do this, and who show the king all virgins that are to be married; the king then takes the virginity of whichever of these pleases him. These  extend from  to the harbor called .


Next to them are the , who inhabit the country to the west as far as the island of ; in between lies the island of , which the  colonized, and on the mainland is the harbor called , and the  which was a settlement of the . Here the country of silphium begins,

which reaches from the island of  to the entrance of the . This people is like the others in its customs.


The next people west of the  are the , who live inland of , not coming down to the coast, for that is  territory. These drive four-horse chariots to a greater extent than any other ; it is their practice to imitate most of the  customs.


Next west of the  are the , dwelling inland of , and touching the coast at . About the middle of the land of the  lives the little tribe of the , whose territory comes down to the sea at , a town in the  country; their customs are the same as those of the dwellers inland of .


Next west of these  is the populous country of the , who in summer leave their flocks by the sea and go up to the land called  to gather dates from the palm-trees that grow there in great abundance and all bear fruit. They hunt locusts, which they dry in the sun, and after grinding sprinkle them into milk and drink it.
It is their custom for every man to have many wives; their intercourse with women is promiscuous, as among the ; a staff is placed before the dwelling, and then they have intercourse. When a man of the  weds, on the first night the bride must by custom lie with each of the whole company in turn; and each man after intercourse gives her whatever gift he has brought from his house.
As for their manner of swearing and divination, they lay their hands on the graves of the men reputed to have been the most just and good among them, and by these men they swear; their practice of divination is to go to the tombs of their ancestors, where after making prayers they lie down to sleep, and take for oracles whatever dreams come to them.
They give and receive pledges by each drinking from the hand of the other party; and if they have nothing liquid, they take the dust of the earth and lick it up.


On the borders of the  is the country of the , who perished in this way: the force of the south wind dried up their water-tanks, and all their country, lying in the region of the , was waterless. After deliberating together, they marched south (I tell the story as it is told by the ), and when they came into the sandy desert, a strong south wind buried them. So they perished utterly, and the  have their country.


Inland of these to the south, the  live in wild beast country. They shun the sight and fellowship of men, and have no weapons of war, nor know how to defend themselves.


These live inland of the ; the neighboring seaboard to the west is the country of the , who shave their hair to a crest, leaving that on the top of their heads to grow and shaving clean off what is on either side; in war they carry shields made of ostrich skins.
The  empties into their sea through their country from a hill called the Hill of the Graces. This hill is thickly wooded, while the rest of  of which I have spoken is bare of trees; it is twenty-five miles from the sea.


Next to these  are the , where every woman wears many leather anklets, because (so it is said) she puts on an anklet for every man with whom she has had intercourse; and she who wears the most is reputed to be the best, because she has been loved by the most men.


There is a headland jutting out into the sea from the land of the ; on it live the , whose only fare is the lotus. The lotus fruit is the size of a mastich-berry: it has a sweet taste like the fruit of a date-palm; the  not only eat it, but make wine of it.


Next to these along the coast are the , who also use the lotus, but less than the aforesaid people. Their country reaches to a great river called the , which empties into the great , in which is an island called . It is said that the  were told by an oracle to plant a settlement on this island.


The following story is also told: it is said that , when the  had been built at the foot of , put aboard besides a hecatomb a bronze tripod, and set out to sail around the , to go to .
But when he was off , a north wind caught and carried him away to ; and before he saw land, he came into the shallows of the . There, while he could find no way out yet,  (the story goes) appeared to him and told  to give him the tripod, promising to show the sailors the channel and send them on their way unharmed.

 did, and  then showed them the channel out of the shallows and set the tripod in his own temple; but first he prophesied over it, declaring the whole matter to 's comrades: namely, that should any descendant of the 's crew take away the tripod, then a hundred  cities would be founded on the shores of the . Hearing this (it is said) the  people of the country hid the tripod.


Next to these  are the ; these and the , separated by the , live on the shores of the . The  wear their hair long behind, the  in front.
They celebrate a yearly festival of , where their maidens are separated into two bands and fight each other with stones and sticks, thus (they say) honoring in the way of their ancestors that native goddess whom we call . Maidens who die of their wounds are called false virgins.
Before the girls are set fighting, the whole people choose the fairest maid, and arm her with a  helmet and  panoply, to be then mounted on a chariot and drawn all along the lake shore.
With what armor they equipped their maidens before  came to live near them, I cannot say; but I suppose the armor was ; for I maintain that the  took their shield and helmet from .
As for , they say that she was daughter of  and the , and that, being for some reason angry at her father, she gave herself to , who made her his own daughter. Such is their tale. The intercourse of men and women there is promiscuous; they do not cohabit but have intercourse like cattle.
When a woman's child is well grown, the men assemble within three months and the child is adjudged to be that man's whom it is most like.


I have now described all the nomadic  who live on the coast. Farther inland than these is that  country which is haunted by wild beasts, and beyond this wild beasts' haunt runs a ridge of sand that stretches from 
 of  to the Pillars of .
At intervals of about ten days' journey along this ridge there are masses of great lumps of salt in hills; on the top of every hill, a fountain of cold sweet water shoots up from the midst of the salt; men live around it who are farthest away toward the desert and inland from the wild beasts' country. The first on the journey from 
, ten days distant from there, are the , who follow the worship of the  of 
; for, as I have said before, the image of  at 
 has the head of a ram.
They have another spring of water besides, which is warm at dawn, and colder at market-time, and very cold at noon;

and it is then that they water their gardens; as the day declines, the coldness abates, until at sunset the water grows warm. It becomes ever hotter and hotter until midnight, and then it boils and bubbles; after midnight it becomes ever cooler until dawn. This spring is called the Spring of the Sun.


At a distance of ten days' journey again from the  along the sandy ridge, there is a hill of salt like that of the , and springs of water, where men live; this place is called ; it is to this that the  come to gather palm-fruit.


After ten days' journey again from  there is yet another hill of salt and springs of water and many fruit-bearing palms, as at the other places; men live there called , an exceedingly great nation, who sow in earth which they have laid on the salt.
The shortest way to the ' country is from here, thirty days' journey distant. Among the  are the cattle that go backward as they graze, the reason being that their horns curve forward;

therefore, not being able to go forward, since the horns would stick in the ground, they walk backward grazing. Otherwise, they are like other cattle, except that their hide is thicker and harder to the touch.
These  go in their four-horse chariots chasing the cave-dwelling : for the  cave-dwellers are swifter of foot than any men of whom tales are brought to us. They live on snakes and lizards and such-like creeping things. Their speech is like no other in the world: it is like the squeaking of bats.


Another ten days' journey from the  there is again a salt hill and water, where men live called . These are the only men whom we know who have no names; for the whole people are called , but no man has a name of his own.
When the sun is high, they curse and very foully revile him, because his burning heat afflicts their people and their land.
After another ten days' journey there is again a hill of salt, and water, and men living there. Near to this salt is a mountain called Atlas, whose shape is slender and conical; and it is said to be so high that its heights cannot be seen, for clouds are always on them winter and summer. The people of the country call it the pillar of heaven.
These men get their name, which is , from this mountain. It is said that they eat no living creature, and see no dreams in their sleep.


I know and can tell the names of all the peoples that live on the ridge as far as the , but no farther than that. But I know this, that the ridge reaches as far as the Pillars of  and beyond them.
There is a mine of salt on it every ten days' journey, and men live there. Their houses are all built of blocks of the salt; for these are parts of  where no rain falls; for the walls, being of salt, could not stand firm if there were rain.
The salt there is both white and purple. Beyond this ridge, the southern and inland parts of  are desolate and waterless: there are no wild beasts, no rain, no forests; this region is wholly without moisture.


Thus from  to the , the  are nomads that eat meat and drink milk; for the same reason as the  too profess, they will not touch the flesh of cows; and they rear no swine.
The women of , too, consider it wrong to eat cows' flesh, because of the  of ; and they even honor her with fasts and festivals; and the  women refuse to eat swine too, as well as cows.


Thus it is with this region. But west of the  the  are not nomads; they do not follow the same customs, or treat their children as the nomads do.
For the practice of many  nomads (I cannot say absolutely whether it is the practice of all) is to take their children when four years old, and to burn the veins of their scalps or sometimes of their temples with grease of sheep's wool, so that the children may never afterward be afflicted by phlegm draining from the head.
They say that this makes their children quite healthy. In fact, the  are the healthiest of all men whom we know; whether it is because of this practice, I cannot say absolutely; but they certainly are healthy. When the children smart from the pain of the burning, the  have found a remedy; they soothe them by applications of goats' urine. This is what the  themselves say.


The nomads' way of sacrificing is to cut a piece from the victim's ear for first-fruits and throw it over the house; then they wring the victim's neck. They sacrifice to no gods except the sun and moon; that is, this is the practice of the whole nation; but the dwellers by the  sacrifice to  chiefly, and next to  and .


It would seem that the robe and aegis of the images of  were copied by the  from the  women; for except that  women dress in leather, and that the tassels of their goatskin cloaks are not snakes but thongs of hide, in everything else their equipment is the same.
And in fact, the very name betrays that the attire of the statues of  has come from ; for  women wear the hairless tasselled aegea over their dress, colored with madder, and the  have changed the name of these aegeae into their aegides.
Furthermore, in my opinion the ceremonial chant first originated in : for the women of that country chant very tunefully. And it is from the  that the  have learned to drive four-horse chariots.


The dead are buried by the nomads in  fashion, except by the . They bury their dead sitting, being careful to make the dying man sit when he releases his spirit, and not die lying supine. Their dwellings are constructed of asphodel stalks twined about reeds; they can be carried here and there. Such are the  customs.


West of the  and next to the  begins the country of  who cultivate the soil and possess houses; they are called ; they wear their hair long on the right side of their heads and shave the left, and they paint their bodies with vermilion.
These claim descent from the men who came from . Their country, and the rest of the western part of , is much fuller of wild beasts and more wooded than the country of the nomads.
For the eastern region of , which the nomads inhabit, is low-lying and sandy as far as the ; but the land west of this, where the farmers live, is exceedingly mountainous and wooded and full of wild beasts.
In that country are the huge snakes and the lions, and the elephants and bears and asps, the horned asses, the dog-headed and the headless men that have their eyes in their chests, as the  say, and the wild men and women, besides many other creatures not fabulous.


But in the nomads' country there are none of these; but there are others, white-rumped antelopes, gazelles, hartebeest, asses, not the horned asses, but those that are called undrinking (for indeed they never drink), the oryx, whose horns are made the horns of the lyre (this is a beast the size of a bull),

foxes, hyenas, porcupines, wild rams, the dictys, jackals, panthers, the borys, land crocodiles sixty inches long, very like lizards, and ostriches and little one-horned serpents; all these beasts besides those that are elsewhere too, except deer and wild boar; of these two kinds there are none at all in .
There are in this country three kinds of mice, the two-footed, the zegeries (this is a  word, meaning in our language hills), and the bristly-haired, as they are called. There are also weasels found in the silphium, very like to the weasels of . So many are the wild creatures of the nomads' country, as far as by our utmost enquiry we have been able to learn.


Next to the  of  are the , whose women drive their chariots to war.


Next to these are the , where much honey is made by bees, and much more yet (so it is said) by craftsmen. It is certain that they all paint themselves with vermilion and eat apes, with which their mountains swarm.


Off their coast (the  say) lies an island called , twenty-five miles long and narrow across, accessible from the mainland; it is full of olives and vines.
It is said that there is a lake on this island from which the maidens of the country draw gold-dust out of the mud on feathers smeared with pitch. I do not know whether this is true; I just write what is said. But all things are possible; for I myself saw pitch drawn from the water of a pool in .
The pools there are numerous; the greatest of them is seventy feet long and broad, and twelve feet deep. Into this they drop a pole with a myrtle branch fastened to its end, and bring up pitch on the myrtle, smelling like asphalt, and for the rest better than the pitch of . Then they pour it into a pit that they have dug near the pool; and when a fair amount is collected there, they fill their vessels from the pit.
Whatever falls into the pool is carried under the ground and appears again in the sea, which is about a half a mile distant from the pool. So, then, the story that comes from the island lying off the  coast is like the truth, too.


Another story is told by the . There is a place in , they say, where men live beyond the Pillars of ; they come here and unload their cargo; then, having laid it in order along the beach, they go aboard their ships and light a smoking fire. The people of the country see the smoke, and, coming to the sea, they lay down gold to pay for the cargo, and withdraw from the wares.
Then the  disembark and examine the gold; if it seems to them a fair price for their cargo, they take it and go away; but if not, they go back aboard and wait, and the people come back and add more gold until the sailors are satisfied.
In this transaction, it is said, neither party defrauds the other: the  do not touch the gold until it equals the value of their cargo, nor do the people touch the cargo until the sailors have taken the gold.


These are all the  whom we can name, and the majority of their kings cared nothing for the king of the  at the time of which I write, nor do they care for him now.
I have this much further to say of this country: four nations and no more, as far as we know, inhabit it, two of which are aboriginal and two not; the  in the north and the  in the south of  are aboriginal; the  and  are later settlers.


In my opinion, there is in no part of  any great excellence for which it should be compared to  or , except in the region which is called by the same name as its river, .
But this region is a match for the most fertile farmland in the world, nor is it at all like to the rest of . For the soil is black and well-watered by springs, and has no fear of drought, nor is it harmed by drinking excessive showers (there is rain in this part of ). Its yield of grain is of the same measure as in the land of .
The land inhabited by the  is also good; it yields at the most a hundredfold; but the land of the  region yields three hundredfold.


The country of , which is the highest part of the  that the nomads inhabit, has the marvellous advantage of three harvest seasons. The fruits of the earth are ripe for reaping and picking on the coast first; when these have been gathered, the middle region above the coast, which they call the Hills, is ripe for gathering;

and no sooner has this yield of the middle country been gathered than the highest-lying crops are mellow and ripe, so that the latest fruits of the earth are coming in when the earliest are already spent by way of food and drink. Thus the  have a harvest lasting eight months. Enough of these matters, then.


Now when the  that  sent from  to avenge  came to , they laid siege to the city, demanding the surrender of those who were guilty of the murder of : but the , whose whole people were accessory to the deed, would not yield.
The  besieged  for nine months, digging underground passages leading to the walls, and making violent assaults. As for the tunnels, a blacksmith discovered them by the means of a bronze shield, and this is how he found them: carrying the shield around the inner side of the walls, he struck it against the ground of the city;

all the other places which he struck returned a dull sound; but where there were tunnels, the bronze of the shield rang clear. Here the  made a counter-tunnel and killed those  who were digging underground. Thus the tunnels were discovered, and the assaults were repelled by the townsfolk.


When much time had been spent and many on both sides (not less of the  than of their enemies) slain,  the general of the foot soldiers devised a plot, knowing that  could not be taken by force but might be taken by guile: he dug by night a wide trench and laid frail planks across it, which he then covered over with a layer of earth level with the ground about it.
Then when day came, he invited the  to confer with him, and they readily consented; at last all agreed to conditions of peace. This was done thus: standing on the hidden trench, they gave and accepted a sworn assurance that their treaty would hold good while the ground where they stood was unchanged; the  promised to pay a due sum to the king, and the  to do the  no harm.
When the sworn agreement was made, the townsfolk, trusting in it and opening all their gates, themselves came out of the city, and let all their enemies who so desired enter within the walls. But the  broke down the hidden bridge and ran into the city. They broke down the bridge that they had made, so that they might keep the oath which they had sworn to the : namely, that this treaty would hold good for as long as the ground remained as it was; but if they broke the bridge the treaty held good no longer.


When they were delivered to her by the ,  took the most guilty of the  and set them impaled around the top of the wall; the breasts of their women she cut off and planted around the wall in like manner.
As for the rest of the , she told the  to take them as their booty, except those who were of the house of  and not accessory to the murder: to these she turned over the city.


The  thus enslaved the rest of the , and went home. When they appeared before the city of , the  let them pass through their city, so that a certain oracle might be fulfilled.
As the army was passing through,  the admiral of the fleet was for taking the city, but  the general of the land army would not consent, saying that he had been sent against  and no other  city; at last they passed through  and camped on the hill of ; there they regretted not having taken the city, and tried to enter it again, but the  would not let them.
Then, although no one attacked them, panic seized the , and they fled to a place seven miles distant and camped there; and while they were there, a messenger from  came to the camp asking them to return. The  asked and received from the  provisions for their march, after which they left to go to ;

but then they fell into the hands of the , who killed the laggards and stragglers of the army for the sake of their garments and possessions; until at last they came to .


This  force advanced as far as  in  and no farther. As for the  whom they had taken for slaves, they carried them from  into banishment and brought them to the king, and  gave them a town of  to live in. They gave this town the name , and it remained an inhabited place in  until my own lifetime.


But  did not end well, either. For as soon as she had revenged herself on the  and returned to , she met an awful death. For while still alive she teemed with maggots: thus does over-brutal human revenge invite retribution from the gods. That of , daughter of , against the  was revenge of this nature and this brutality.

p.#text:
Those  whom  had left in  under the command of , finding the  unwilling to be ' subjects, subdued them before any others of the people of the . These  had already been roughly handled by the .
For the oracle of the god ordered the  from the  to march against , and if the , who were encamped opposite them, should call to them, crying out their name, then to attack them. If, however, there were no such call, they were not to attack. The  acted accordingly. When the  set up camp in front of their city, the armies then challenged each other to a threefold duel, in which man was matched against man, horse against horse, and dog against dog.
The  were victorious in two of the combats and raised the cry of Paean in their joy. The  reasoned that this was what the oracle had spoken of and must have said to each other, This is surely the fulfillment of the prophecy; now it is time for us to act. Accordingly, the  set upon the  and won a great victory, leaving few of their enemies alive.


This, then, is what the  had previously suffered at the hands of the . Now they fought like brave men for their liberty, but  and the  overcame them by weight of numbers.
When  had been taken,  marched his army through , subduing to the king's will every city and every people of that region. For this, the conquest of , was the charge given him by .


The  are the biggest nation in the world, next to the . If they were under one ruler, or united, they would, in my judgment, be invincible and the strongest nation on earth. Since, however, there is no way or means to bring this about, they are weak.
The  have many names, each tribe according to its region, but they are very similar in all their customs, save the , the , and those who dwell above the .


As for the , who claim to be immortal, I have already given an account of their practices. The , who in all else conform to the customs of other , do as I will show at the times of birth and death.
When a child is born, the kinsmen sit around it and lament all the ills that it must endure from its birth onward, recounting all the sorrows of men. The dead, however, they bury with celebration and gladness, asserting that he is rid of so many ills and has achieved a state of complete blessedness.


Those who dwell above the  have yet other practices. Each man has many wives, and at his death there is both great rivalry among his wives and eager contention on their friends' part to prove which wife was best loved by her husband. She to whom the honor is adjudged is praised by men and women alike and then slain over the tomb by her nearest of kin. After the slaying she is buried with the husband. The rest of the wives are greatly displeased by this, believing themselves to be deeply dishonored.


Among the rest of the , it is the custom to sell their children for export and to take no care of their maidens, allowing them to have intercourse with any man they wish. Their wives, however, they strictly guard, and buy them for a price from the parents.
To be tattooed is a sign of noble birth, while to bear no such marks is for the baser sort. The idler is most honored, the tiller of the soil most scorned; he is held in highest honor who lives by war and robbery.


These are most notable of their usages. They worship no gods but , , and . Their princes, however, unlike the rest of their countrymen, worship  above all gods and swear only by him, claiming him for their ancestor.


The wealthy have the following funeral practices. First they lay out the dead for three days, and after killing all kinds of victims and making lamentation, they feast. After that they do away with the body either by fire or else by burial in the earth, and when they have built a barrow, they initiate all kinds of contests, in which the greatest prizes are offered for the hardest type of single combat. Such are the  funeral rites.


As for the region which lies north of this country, none can tell with certainty what men dwell there, but what lies beyond the  is a desolate and infinitely large tract of land. I can learn of no men dwelling beyond the  save certain that are called  and wear Median dress.
Their horses are said to be covered all over with shaggy hair five fingers' breadth long, and to be small, blunt-nosed, and unable to bear men on their backs, but very swift when yoked to chariots. It is for this reason that driving chariots is the usage of the country. These men's borders, it is said, reach almost as far as the  on the .
They call themselves colonists from Media. How this has come about I myself cannot understand, but all is possible in the long passage of time. However that may be, we know that the  who dwell inland of  use the word sigynnae for hucksters, and the  use it for spears.


According to the , all the land beyond the  is full of bees, and that by reason of these none can travel there. This, to my mind, is not a credible tale, for those creatures are ill able to bear cold. It appears to me rather that it is by reason of the cold that the northern lands are not inhabited. Such, then, are the stories about this region. Whatever the truth may be,  made its coastal area subject to the .


As soon as  had crossed the  and come to , he remembered the good service done him by  of  and the counsel of  the , and after sending for them to come to , he offered them a choice of whatever they wanted.

, seeing that he was tyrant of , desired no further sovereignty than that, but asked for  in the  land so that he might build a city there. This, then, was ' choice, but , inasmuch as he was no tyrant but a plain citizen, asked that he might be made tyrant of .


When the wishes of each had been granted, they made their way to the places of their choice, but , as it fell out, saw a sight which put it in his mind to bid  take the  and take them from their homes out of  into . There were two ,  and , who themselves desired to be rulers of their countrymen. When  had crossed into , they came to , bringing with them their sister, a tall and beautiful woman.

 took note of the woman as she passed by him, for what she did was not in the manner of the  or  or any of the peoples of . Having taken note of this, he sent some of his guards, bidding them watch what the woman would do with the horse.

But those near the  and the country of the  and the  and the  and the  itself were never subdued at all by . He did in fact try to take the lake-dwellers and did so in the following manner. There is set in the midst of the lake a platform made fast on tall piles, to which one bridge gives a narrow passage from the land.
In olden times all the people working together set the piles which support the platform there, but they later developed another method of setting them. The men bring the piles from a mountain called , and every man plants three for each of the three women that he weds.
Each man has both a hut on the platform and a trap-door in the platform leading down into the lake. They make a cord fast to the feet of their little children out of fear that they will fall into the water.
They give fish as fodder to their horses and beasts of burden, and there is such an abundance of fish that a man can open his trap-door, let down an empty basket by a line into the lake, and draw it up after a short time full of fish. There are two kinds of these, some called paprakes, some tilones.

, now feeling compelled to do so, bade the women sit beside them. When the women had done as they were bidden, the , flushed as they were with excess of wine, at once laid hands on the women's breasts, and one or another tried to kiss them.


This  saw, but held his peace despite his anger because he greatly feared the . If you want me to leave, to that I consent.


When  made this request and had gone his way,  said to the , Sirs, you have full freedom to deal with these women, and may have intercourse with all or any of them.

Be aware that in so doing we are giving you all the honor that you deserve, and tell your king who sent you how his  viceroy of  has received you hospitably, providing food and bedfellows.

, bringing with him the , came to the , and after crossing it from there, he came to .  the  was by this time fortifying the place which he hadasked of  as his reward for guarding the bridge, a place called  by the river .  discovered what he was doing, and upon his arrival at  with the , he said to ,

The  fought well and defended themselves, till at last they were brought to evil plight, and the  set as governor over those that were left of them  the brother of  who had been king of .

After only a short period of time without evils, trouble began once more to come on the , and this from  and .  surpassed all the other islands in prosperity, and at about the same time , at the height of her fortunes, was the glory of . The  reconciled them in the following manner. Their best men came to , and seeing the  households sadly wasted, they said that they desired to go about the country. After travelling over the whole country and finding only a few such men, they assembled the people immediately upon their return to the city and appointed as rulers of the state those whose lands they had found well tilled. This they did in the belief that these men were likely to take as good care of public affairs as they had of their own, and they ordained that the rest of the  who had been at feud should obey these men.


It was in this way that the  made peace in , but now these cities began to bring trouble upon . Certain men of substance who had been banished by the common people, went in exile to .
Now it chanced that the deputy ruling  was  son of , son-in-law and cousin of that  son of  whom  kept with him at .  was tyrant of  but was at  when the , who had been his guests and friends, arrived.

I myself do not have the authority to give you such power as will restore you against the will of the  who hold your city, for I know that the  have eight thousand men that bear shields, and many ships of war. Nevertheless, I will do everything I can to realize your request.

 came to  and told  that  was indeed an island of no great size, but that it was otherwise a beautiful and noble island lying near . Furthermore it had a store of wealth and slaves. Therefore send an army against that country, he said,  and bring back the men who have been banished from there.

, however, said, But you, what have you to do with these matters? Did not  send you to obey me and to sail wherever I bid you? Why are you so meddlesome? This response on the part of  enraged , who, went night fell, sent men in a boat to  to tell the  of the trouble in store for them.

 The , then, made all preparations to face the onset of war. When their enemies had brought their ships over from  to , it was a fortified city that they attacked, and for four months they besieged it.

 had no way of fulfilling his promise to , and he was hard-pressed by demands for the costs of the force. Furthermore he feared what might come of the failure of the army and ' displeasure against him. It was likely, he thought, that his lordship of  would be taken away from him.

, who had been sent for this very purpose, craftily seized  of  son of ;  of  son of ;  son of , to whom  gave ;  of , son of ; and many others besides. Then  revolted openly, devising all he could to harm .

At ,  the son of , who had been king, was now no longer alive but was dead, and  son of  held the royal power. This he had won not by manly merit but by right of birth.  had as his wife his own sister's daughter, and although he was content with her, no children were born to him.

After no long time the second wife gave birth to . She, then, gave the  an heir to the royal power, and as luck would have it, the first wife, who had been barren before, conceived at that very time.

 He mustered the remnant of his army and took , the colony from , and aided in freeing the people of  from their monarch .  of , son of , was among those who followed  and were slain with him. He had been betrothed to the daughter of  of  but was banished from .  For his physical beauty he received from the  honors accorded to no one else. They built a hero's shrine by his grave and offer him sacrifices of propitiation.


Such, then, was the manner of ' death. Had he endured ' rule and stayed at  he would have been king of , for  reigned no long time, and died leaving no son but one only daughter, whose name was .


It was in the reign of  that  the tyrant of  came to . When he had an audience with the king, as the  report, he brought with him a bronze tablet on which the map of all the earth was engraved, and all the sea and all the rivers.
Having been admitted to converse with ,  spoke thus to him: Do not wonder, , that I have been so eager to come here, for our present situation is such that the sons of the  are slaves and not free men, which is shameful and grievous particularly to ourselves but also, of all others, to you, inasmuch as you are the leaders of .
Now, therefore, we entreat you by the gods of  to save your  kinsmen from slavery. This is a thing which you can easily achieve, for the strangers are not valiant men while your valor in war is preeminent. As for their manner of fighting, they carry bows and short spears, and they go to battle with trousers on their legs and turbans on their heads.
Accordingly, they are easy to overcome. Furthermore, the inhabitants of that continent have more good things than all other men together, gold first but also silver, bronze, colored cloth, beasts of burden, and slaves. All this you can have to your heart's desire.
The lands in which they dwell lie next to each other, as I shall show: next to the  are the , who inhabit a good land and have great store of silver. (This he said pointing to the map of the earth which he had brought engraved on the tablet.) The yearly tribute which they pay to the king is five hundred talents. Next to the , are the , another people rich in flocks, and after the , the , whose country I show you.
Adjoining these you see the  land, in which, on the , lies that  where the great king lives and where the storehouses of his wealth are located. Take that city, and you need not fear to challenge  for riches.
You should suspend your war, then, for strips of land of no great worthfor that fight with with , who are matched in strength with you, and  and , men who have nothing in the way of gold or silver (for which things many are spurred by zeal to fight and die). Yet when you can readily be masters of all , will you refuse to attempt it?
Thus spoke , and  replied: , my guest, wait till the third day for my answer.


At that time, then, they got so far. When, on the day appointed for the answer, they came to the place upon which they had agreed,  asked  how many days' journey it was from the  to the king.
Till now,  had been cunning and fooled the  well, but here he made a false step. If he desired to take the  away into  he should never have told the truth, but he did tell it, and said that it was a three months' journey inland.
At that,  cut short ' account of the prospective journey. He then bade his  guest depart from  before sunset, for never, he said, would the  listen to the plan, if  desired to lead them a three months' journey from the sea.


 went to his house after this exchange, but  took a suppliant's garb and followed him there. Upon entering, he used a suppliant's right to beg  to listen to him. He first asked  to send away the child, his daughter , who was standing by him. She was his only child, and was about eight or nine years of age.  bade him say whatever he wanted and not let the child's presence hinder him.
Then  began to promise  from ten talents upwards, if he would grant his request. When  refused,  offered him ever more and more. When he finally promised fifty talents the child cried out, Father, the stranger will corrupt you, unless you leave him and go away.

 was pleased with the child's counsel and went into another room while  departed from , finding no further occasion for telling of the journey inland to the king's palace.


Now the nature of this road is as I will show. All along it are the king's road stations and very good resting places, and the whole of it passes through country that is inhabited and safe. Its course through  and  is of the length of twenty stages, and ninety-four and a half parasangs.
Next after  it comes to the river , where there is both a defile which must be passed before the river can be crossed and a great fortress to guard it. After the passage into , the road in that land as far as the borders of  is of twenty-eight stages and one hundred and four parasangs. On this frontier you must ride through two defiles and pass two fortresses.
Ride past these, and you will have a journey through  of three stages and fifteen and a half parasangs. The boundary of  and  is a navigable river, the name of which is the . In  there are fifteen resting-stages and fifty-six and a half parasangs. Here too there is a fortress. From  the road enters the  land, in which there are thirty-four stages and one hundred and thirty-seven parasangs.
Through this land flow four navigable rivers which must be passed by ferries, first the , then a second and a third of the same name, yet not the same stream nor flowing from the same source. The first-mentioned of them flows from the  and the second from the .
The fourth river is called , that  which  parted once into three hundred and sixty channels.
When this country is passed, the road is in the  land, where there are eleven stages and forty-two and a half parasangs, as far as yet another navigable river, the , on the banks of which stands the city of .


Thus the sum total of stages is one hundred and eleven. So many resting-stages, then, are there in the journey up from  to . If I have accurately counted the parasangs of the royal road, and the parasang is of thirty furlongs' length, which assuredly it is, then between  and the king's abode called  there are thirteen thousand and five hundred furlongs, the number of parasangs being four hundred and fifty. If each day's journey is one hundred and fifty furlongs, then the sum of days spent is ninety, neither more nor less.


 of  accordingly spoke the truth to  the  when he said that the journey inland was three months long. If anyone should desire a more exact measurement, I will give him that too, for the journey from  to  must be added to the rest.

 So, then, from the  to , which is the city called , it is a journey of fourteen thousand and forty stages, for there are five hundred and forty furlongs from  to . The three months' journey is accordingly made longer by three days.

, which had been great before, now grew even greater when her tyrants had been removed. The two principal holders of power were  an , who was reputed to have bribed the  priestess, and  son of , a man of a notable house but his lineage I cannot say. His kinsfolk, at any rate, sacrifice to  of .

, who was on the losing side, devised a counter-plot, and invited the aid of , who had been his friend since the besieging of the . It was even said of  that he regularly went to see ' wife.

These men, then, were bound and put to death. After that, the  sent to bring back  and the seven hundred households banished by . Then, desiring to make an alliance with the , they despatched envoys to , for they knew that they had provoked the  and  to war.

, however, fully aware that the  had done him wrong in word and deed, mustered an army from the whole of the . He did not declare the purpose for which he mustered it, namely to avenge himself on the  people and set up , who had come with him out of the acropolis, as tyrant.

When this force then had been ingloriously scattered, the  first marched against the  to punish them. The  came to the  to help the  and as soon as the  saw these allies, they resolved to attack the  before the .
