Horse-breeders was the name given to the men of substance among the . They fettered as many of these as they took alive and kept them imprisoned with the captive . In time, however, they set them free, each for an assessed ransom of two minae. The fetters in which the prisoners had been bound they hung up in the acropolis, where they could still be seen in my time hanging from walls which the ' fire had charred, opposite the temple which faces west.

 Moreover, they made a dedication of a tenth part of the ransom, and this money was used for the making of a four-horse chariot which stands on the left hand of the entrance into the outer porch of the acropolis and bears this inscription:




So the  grew in power and proved, not in one respect only but in all, that equality is a good thing. Evidence for this is the fact that while they were under tyrannical rulers, the  were no better in war than any of their neighbors, yet once they got rid of their tyrants, they were by far the best of all. This, then, shows that while they were oppressed, they were, as men working for a master, cowardly, but when they were freed, each one was eager to achieve for himself.


This, then, is the course of action which the  took, and the , desiring vengeance on , afterwards appealed to  for advice. The  priestess said that the  themselves would not be able to obtain the vengeance they wanted and that they should lay the matter before the many-voiced and entreat their nearest.
Upon the return of the envoys, an assembly was called and the oracle put before it. When the  heard that they must entreat their nearest, they said, If this is so, our nearest neighbors are the men of  and  and . These are always our comrades in battle and zealously wage our wars. What need, then, is there to entreat them? Perhaps this is the meaning of the oracle.


They reasoned in this way, till at last one understood, and said: I think that I perceive what the oracle is trying to tell us.  and , it is said, were daughters of  and sisters. The god's answer is, I think, that we should ask the  to be our avengers.

 Seeing that there seemed to be no better opinion before them than this, they sent straightaway to entreat the  and invite their aid, since this was the oracle's bidding, and the  were their nearest. These replied to their demand that they were sending the Sons of  in aid.


The  took the field on the strength of their alliance with that family but were soundly beaten by the . Thereupon they sent a second message to , giving back the sons of  and asking for some men instead.
The , who were enjoying great prosperity and remembered their old feud with , accordingly made war on the  at the entreaty of the  without sending a herald.
While the  were busy with the , they descended on  in ships of war, and ravaged  and many other seaboard townships. By so doing they dealt the  a very shrewd blow.


This was the beginning of the ' long-standing debt of enmity against the . The ' land bore no produce. For this reason they inquired at  concerning this calamity, and the priestess bade them set up images of  and , saying that if they so did their luck would be better. The  then asked in addition whether they should make the images of bronze or of stone, and the priestess bade them do neither, but make them of the wood of the cultivated olive.
So the men of  asked the  to permit them to cut down some olive trees, supposing the olives there to be the holiest. Indeed it is said that at that time there were no olives anywhere save at .
The  consented to give the trees, if the  would pay yearly sacred dues to , the city's goddess, and to . The  agreed to this condition, and their request was granted. When they set up images made of these olive trees, their land brought forth fruit, and they fulfilled their agreement with the .


Now at this time, as before it, the  were in all matters still subject to the  and even crossed to  for the hearing of their own private lawsuits. From this time, however, they began to build ships, and stubbornly revolted from the .
In the course of this struggle, they did the  much damage and stole their images of  and . These they took away and set them up in the middle of their own country at a place called , about twenty furlongs distant from their city.
Having set them up in this place they sought their favor with sacrifices and female choruses in the satirical and abusive mode. Ten men were appointed providers of a chorus for each of the deities, and the choruses aimed their raillery not at any men but at the women of the country. The  too had the same rites, and they have certain secret rites as well.


When these images were stolen, the  ceased from fulfilling their agreement with the . Then the  sent an angry message to the  who pleaded in turn that they were doing no wrong. For as long, they said, as we had the images in our country, we fulfilled our agreement. Now that we are deprived of them, it is not just that we should still be paying. Ask your dues of the men of , who have the images.

 The  therefore sent to  and demanded that the images be restored, but the  answered that they had nothing to do with the .


The  report that after making this demand, they despatched one trireme with certain of their citizens who, coming in the name of the whole people to , attempted to tear the images, as being made of Attic wood, from their bases so that they might carry them away.
When they could not obtain possession of them in this manner, they tied cords around the images with which they could be dragged. While they were attempting to drag them off, they were overtaken both by a thunderstorm and an earthquake. This drove the trireme's crew to such utter madness that they began to slay each other as if they were enemies. At last only one of all was left, who returned by himself to .


This is the  version of the matter, but the  say that the  came not in one ship only, for they could easily have kept off a single ship, or several, for that matter, even if they had no navy themselves. The truth was, they said, that the  descended upon their coasts with many ships and that they yielded to them without making a fight of it at sea.
They are not able to determine clearly whether it was because they admitted to being weaker at sea-fighting that they yielded, or because they were planning what they then actually did.
When, as the  say, no man came out to fight with them, the  disembarked from their ships and turned their attention to the images. Unable to drag them from the bases, they fastened cords on them and dragged them until they boththis I cannot believe, but another mightfell on their knees. Both have remained in this position ever since.
This is what the  did, but the  say that they discovered that the  were about to make war upon them and therefore assured themselves of help from the . So when the  disembarked on the land of , the  came to aid the , crossing over from  to the island secretly. They then fell upon the  unaware and cut them off from their ships. It was at this moment that the thunderstorm and earthquake came upon them


This, then, is the story told by the  and , and the  too acknowledge that only one man of their number returned safely to .
The , however, say that he escaped after they had destroyed the rest of the  force, while the  claim that the whole thing was to be attributed to divine power. This one man did not survive but perished in the following manner. It would seem that he made his way to  and told of the mishap. When the wives of the men who had gone to attack  heard this, they were very angry that he alone should be safe. They gathered round him and stabbed him with the brooch-pins of their garments, each asking him where her husband was.
This is how this man met his end, and the  found the action of their women to be more dreadful than their own misfortune. They could find, it is said, no other way to punish the women than changing their dress to the  fashion. Until then the  women had worn  dress, which is very like the . It was changed, therefore, to the linen tunic, so that they might have no brooch-pins to use.


The truth of the matter, however, is that this form of dress is not in its origin , but , for in ancient times all women in  wore the costume now known as .
As for the  and , this was the reason of their passing a law in both their countries that brooch-pins should be made half as long as they used to be and that brooches should be the principal things offered by women in the shrines of these two goddesses. Furthermore, nothing else Attic should be brought to the temple, not even pottery, and from that time on only drinking vessels made in the country should be used.


Ever since that day even to my time the women of  and  wore brooch-pins longer than before, by reason of the feud with the . The enmity of the  against the  began as I have told, and now at the ' call the  came readily to the aid of the , remembering the matter of the images.
While the  were laying waste to the seaboard of , the  were setting out to march against them, but an oracle from  came to them bidding them to restrain themselves for thirty years after the wrongdoing of the , and in the thirty-first to mark out a precinct for  and begin the war with . In this way their purpose would prosper. If, however, they sent an army against their enemies straightaway, they would indeed subdue them in the end but would in the meantime both suffer and do many things.
When the  heard this reported to them, they marked out for  that precinct which is now set in their marketplace, but they could not stomach the order that they must hold their hand for thirty years, seeing that the  had dealt them a foul blow.


As they were making ready for vengeance, a matter which took its rise in  hindered them, for when the  learned of the plot of the  with the  priestess and of her plot against themselves and the , they were very angry for two reasons, namely that they had driven their own guests and friends from the country they dwelt in, and that the  showed them no gratitude for their doing so.
Furthermore, they were spurred on by the oracles which foretold that many deeds of enmity would be perpetrated against them by the . Previously they had had no knowledge of these oracles but now  brought them to , and the  learned their contents. It was from the  acropolis that  took the oracles, which had been in the possession of the  earlier. When they were exiled, they left them in the temple from where they were retrieved by .


Now the , when they regained the oracles and saw the  increasing in power and in no way inclined to obey them, realized that if the  remained free, they would be equal in power with themselves, but that if they were held down under tyranny, they would be weak and ready to serve a master. Perceiving all this, they sent to bring ' son  from  on the , the 's place of refuge.
When  arrived, the  sent for envoys from the rest of their allies and spoke to them as follows: Sirs, our allies, we do acknowledge that we have acted wrongly, for, led astray by lying divinations, we drove from their native land men who were our close friends and promised to make  subject to us. Then we handed that city over to a thankless people which had no sooner lifted up its head in the freedom which we gave it, than it insolently cast out us and our king. Now it has bred such a spirit of pride and is growing so much in power, that its neighbors in  and  have really noticed it, and others too will soon recognize their error.
Since we erred in doing what we did, we will now attempt with your aid to avenge ourselves on them. It is on this account and no other that we have sent for , whom you see, and have brought you from your cities, namely that uniting our counsels and our power, we may bring him to  and restore that which we took away.


These were the words of the , but their words were ill-received by the greater part of their allies. The rest then keeping silence, , a , said,


In truth heaven will be beneath the earth and the earth aloft above the heaven, and men will dwell in the sea and fishes where men dwelt before, now that you, , are destroying the rule of equals and making ready to bring back tyranny into the cities, tyranny, a thing more unrighteous and bloodthirsty than anything else on this earth.
If indeed it seems to you to be a good thing that the cities be ruled by tyrants, set up a tyrant among yourselves first and then seek to set up such for the rest. As it is, however, you, who have never made trial of tyrants and take the greatest precautions that none will arise at , deal wrongfully with your allies. If you had such experience of that thing as we have, you would be more prudent advisers concerning it than you are now.

The  state was ordered in such manner as I will show.There was an oligarchy, and this group of men, called the , held sway in the city, marrying and giving in marriage among themselves. Now , one of these men, had a crippled daughter, whose name was . Since none of the  would marry her, she was wedded to  son of , of the township of , a  by lineage and of the posterity of .
When no sons were born to him by this wife or any other, he set out to  to enquire concerning the matter of acquiring offspring. As soon as he entered, the  priestess spoke these verses to him: 


This oracle which was given to  was in some way made known to the . The earlier oracle sent to  had not been understood by them, despite the fact that its meaning was the same as the meaning of the oracle of , and it read as follows: 




This earlier prophecy had been unintelligible to the , but as soon as they heard the one which was given to , they understood it at once, recognizing its similarity with the oracle of . Now understanding both oracles, they kept quiet but resolved to do away with the offspring of . Then, as soon as his wife had given birth, they sent ten men of their clan to the township where  dwelt to kill the child.
These men came to  and passing into 's courtyard, asked for the child. , knowing nothing of the purpose of their coming and thinking that they wished to see the baby out of affection for its father, brought it and placed it into the hands of one of them. Now they had planned on their way that the first of them who received the child should dash it to the ground.
When, however,  brought and handed over the child, by divine chance it smiled at the man who took it. This he saw, and compassion prevented him from killing it. Filled with pity, he handed it to a second, and this man again to a third.In fact it passed from hand to hand to each of the ten, for none would make an end of it.
They then gave the child back to its mother, and after going out, they stood before the door reproaching and upbraiding one another, but chiefly him who had first received it since he had not acted in accordance with their agreement. Finally they resolved to go in again and all have a hand in the killing.

Fate, however, had decreed that 's offspring should be the source of ills for , for , standing close to this door, heard all this. Fearing that they would change their minds and that they would take and actually kill the child, she took it away and hid it where she thought it would be hardest to find, in a chest, for she knew that if they returned and set about searching they would seek in every placewhich in fact they did.
They came and searched, but when they did not find it, they resolved to go off and say to those who had sent them that they had carried out their orders. They then went away and said this.


's son, however, grew up, and because of his escape from that danger, he was called , after the chest. When he had reached manhood and was seeking a divination, an oracle of double meaning was given him at . Putting faith in this, he made an attempt on  and won it.

Such was the oracle. , however, when he had gained the tyranny, conducted himself in this way: many of the  he drove into exile, many he deprived of their wealth, and by far the most he had killed.

After a reign of thirty years, he died in the height of prosperity, and was succeeded by his son . Now  was to begin with milder than his father, but after he had held converse by messenger with  the tyrant of , he became much more bloodthirsty than .
He had sent a herald to  and inquired in what way he would best and most safely govern his city.  led the man who had come from  outside the town, and entered into a sown field. As he walked through the corn, continually asking why the messenger had come to him from , he kept cutting off all the tallest ears of wheat which he could see, and throwing them away, until he had destroyed the best and richest part of the crop.
Then, after passing through the place and speaking no word of counsel, he sent the herald away. When the herald returned to ,  desired to hear what counsel he brought, but the man said that  had given him none. The herald added that it was a strange man to whom he had been sent, a madman and a destroyer of his own possessions, telling  what he had seen  do.


, however, understood what had been done, and perceived that  had counselled him to slay those of his townsmen who were outstanding in influence or ability; with that he began to deal with his citizens in an evil manner. Whatever act of slaughter or banishment  had left undone, that  brought to accomplishment. In a single day he stripped all the women of  naked, because of his own wife .

 had sent messengers to the Oracle of the Dead on the river  in  to enquire concerning a deposit that a friend had left, but , in an apparition, said that she would tell him nothing, nor reveal where the deposit lay, for she was cold and naked. The garments, she said, with which  had buried with her had never been burnt, and were of no use to her. Then, as evidence for her husband that she spoke the truth, she added that  had put his loaves into a cold oven.
When this message was brought back to  (for he had had intercourse with the dead body of  and knew her token for true), immediately after the message he made a proclamation that all the  women should come out into the temple of . They then came out as to a festival, wearing their most beautiful garments, and  set his guards there and stripped them all alike, ladies and serving-women, and heaped all the clothes in a pit, where, as he prayed to , he burnt them.
When he had done this and sent a second message, the ghost of  told him where the deposit of the friend had been laid. This, then, , is the nature of tyranny, and such are its deeds.
We  marvelled greatly when we saw that you were sending for , and now we marvel yet more at your words to us. We entreat you earnestly in the name of the gods of  not to establish tyranny in the cities, but if you do not cease from so doing and unrighteously attempt to bring  back, be assured that you are proceeding without the ' consent.


These were the words of , the envoy from , and  answered, calling the same gods as  had invoked to witness, that the  would be the first to wish the  back, when the time appointed should come for them to be vexed by the .

 made this answer, inasmuch as he had more exact knowledge of the oracles than any man, but the rest of the allies, who had till now kept silence, spoke out when they heard the free speech of  and sided with the opinion of the , entreating the  not to harm a  city.


His plan, then, came to nothing, and  was forced to depart.  king of the  offered him , and the  , but he would have neither. He withdrew to , which  had taken at the spear's point from the  and where he then established as tyrant , his own bastard son by an  woman. , however, could not keep what  had given him without fighting,

for there was constant war over a long period of time between the  at  and the  at . The  were demanding the place back, and the , bringing proof to show that the  had no more part or lot in the land of  than they themselves and all the other  who had aided  to avenge the rape of , would not consent.


Among the various incidents of this war, one in particular is worth mention; In the course of a battle in which the  had the upper hand,  the poet took to flight and escaped, but his armor was taken by the  and hung up in the temple of  at .

 wrote a poem about this and sent it to . In it he relates his own misfortune to his friend . As for the  and , however, peace was made between them by  son of , to whose arbitration they committed the matter, and the terms of peace were that each party should keep what it had.


It was in this way, then, that  came to be under  rule, but , having come from  into , left no stone unturned, maligning the  to , and doing all he could to bring  into subjection to himself and .
While  was engaged in these activities, the  heard of it and sent messengers to , warning the  not to believe banished . , however, bade them receive  back, if they wanted to be safe.When his words were brought back to the , they would not consent to them, and since they would not consent, it was resolved that they should be openly at war with .


It was when the  had made their decision and were already on bad terms with , that  the , driven from  by  the , came to , since that city was more powerful than any of the rest. Coming before the people,  spoke to the same effect as at , of the good things of , and how the  carried neither shield nor spear in war and could easily be overcome.
This he said adding that the  were settlers from , whom it was only right to save seeing that they themselves were a very powerful people. There was nothing which he did not promise in the earnestness of his entreaty, till at last he prevailed upon them. It seems, then, that it is easier to deceive many than one, for he could not deceive  of , one single man, but thirty thousand  he could.
The , now persuaded, voted to send twenty ships to aid the , appointing for their admiral , a citizen of  who had an unblemished reputation. These ships were the beginning of troubles for both  and foreigners.


 sailed before the rest, and when he came to , he devised a plan from which no advantage was to accrue to the  (nor indeed was that the purpose of his plan, but rather to vex king ). He sent a man into , to the  who had been led captive from the  by , and now dwelt in a  territory and village by themselves. When the man came to the , he spoke as follows:

Men of , I have been sent by , tyrant of , to show you the way to deliverance, if you are disposed to obey. All  is now in revolt against the king, and it is possible for you to win your own way back safely to your own land, but afterwards we will take care of you.
The  were very glad when they heard that, and although some of them remained where they were for fear of danger, the rest took their children and women and fled to the sea. After arriving there, the  crossed over to .
They were already in , when a great host of  horsemen came after them in pursuit. Unable to overtake them, the  sent to , commanding the  to go back. The  would not consent to this, but were brought from  by the  to  and carried by the  to , from where they made their way by land to .


The  came with their twenty ships as well as five triremes of the  who came to the war to please not the  but the  themselves, thereby repaying their debt (for the  had once been the allies of the  in the war against , when the  came to aid the  against the  and ). When these, then, and the rest of the allies had arrived,  planned a march against .
He himself did not go with the army but remained at , and appointed others to be generals of the , namely his own brother  and another citizen named .


When the  had come to  with this force, they left their ships at  in the  territory and marched inland with a great host, taking  to guide them on their way. They made their way along the river , and after crossing the , they came to  and captured it without any resistance. They took all of it except the citadel, which was held by  himself with a great force of men.


They were prevented from plundering the city by the fact that most of the houses in  were made of reeds, and those made of brick had roofs of reeds. Accordingly, when one of these was seton fire by a soldier, the flames spread from house to house all over the whole city.
While the city was burning, the  and all the  who were in the citadel, being hemmed in on every side since the fire was consuming the outer parts and having no exit from the city, came thronging into the marketplace and to the river , which flows through the marketplace carrying down gold dust from  and issues into the river , which in turn issues into the sea. They assembled in the marketplace by this  and were forced to defend themselves there.
When the  saw some of their enemies defending themselves and a great multitude of others approaching, they were afraid and withdrew to the mountain called , from where they departed to their ships at nightfall.


In the fire at , a temple of , the goddess of that country, was burnt, and the  afterwards made this their pretext for burning the temples of . At this time, the  of the provinces this side of the , on hearing of these matters, gathered together and came to aid the .
It chanced that they found the  no longer at , but following on their tracks, they caught them at . There the  stood arrayed to meet them, but were utterly routed in the battle.
The  put to the sword many men of renown including  the general of the  who had won crowns as victor in the games and been greatly praised by  of . Those of the  who escaped from the battle fled, each to his city.


This, then is how they fared in their fighting. Presently, however, the  wholly separated themselves from the  and refused to aid them, although  sent messages of earnest entreaty. Despite the fact that they had been deprived of their  allies, the  fervently continued their war against the king (for they remained committed by what they had done to ).
They sailed to the  and made  and all the other cities of that region subject to themselves. Then sailing out from the  they gained to their cause the greater part of , for even , which till then had not wanted to be their ally, now joined itself to them after the burning of .


The  did likewise of their own free will, all save the people of , for these too revolted from the  in such manner as I will show. There was a certain , a younger brother of  king of the , son of , whose father was , and grandson of .
This man had often before advised  to revolt from , and now when he heard that the  too had revolted, he was insistent in striving to move him. When, however, he could not persuade , he and his faction waited till his brother had gone out of the city of , and shut him out of the gates.

, after having lost his city, took refuge with the , and , now king of , persuaded all  to revolt with him, all save the , who would not consent. He accordingly stationed his forces in front of their city and besieged it.


, then, besieged . When it was reported to  that  had been taken and burnt by the  and  and that  the  had been leader of the conspiracy for the making of this plan, he at first, it is said, took no account of the  since he was sure that they would not go unpunished for their rebellion.  did, however, ask who the  were, and after receiving the answer, he called for his bow. This he took and, placing an arrow on it, and shot it into the sky, praying as he sent it aloft,

O , grant me vengeance on the . Then he ordered one of his servants to say to him three times whenever dinner was set before him, Master, remember the .


After giving this order, he called before him  the , whom  had kept with him for a long time now, and said, I hear, , that the viceregent whom you put in charge of  has done me wrong. He has brought men from the mainland overseas, and persuaded certain who shall yet pay me the penalty for their deedsto follow them and has robbed me of .
Now then, I ask you, do you think that this state of affairs is good? How did such things come to pass without any advice from your side? See to it that you do not have cause to blame yourself hereafter.
To this  answered: My lord, what is this you saythat I and none other should devise a plan as a result of which any harm, great or small, was likely to come to you? What desire or feeling of deprivation would prompt me to do such a thing? All that you have is mine, and I am regarded worthy of hearing all your deliberations.
If my vicegerent is indeed doing what you say, be assured that he has acted of his own accord. For myself, I cannot even go so far as to believe the report that the  and my vicegerent are doing you some dreadful wrong. If, however,it is true that they are engaged in such activities and what you, O king, have heard has a basis in fact, then you can see how unwisely you acted when you forced me to leave the coast.
It would seem, then, that as soon as I was out of sight, the  did exactly what their hearts had long been set on. If I had been in  no city would have stirred. Now send me off to  right away, so that I may restore that country to peace and deliver into your hands that vicegerent of  who has devised all this.

 Then, when I have done this to your satisfaction, I swear by the gods of your royal house that I will not take off the tunic I am wearing on my arrival in  until I have made , the largest of the islands, tributary to you.


With these words  successfully deceived  who gave his consent and let him go, charging  to appear before him at  when he had achieved what he promised.


Now while the message concerning  was making its way to the king, and , having done as I said with his bow, held converse with  and permitted him to go to the sea, the following events took place. When  of  was besieging the , news was brought him that , a , was thought to be coming to  with a great  host.
Upon hearing this,  sent heralds all through  to summon the people, and the , after no long deliberation, came with a great force. So the  were in  when the , crossing from , marched to  by land, and the  were sailing around the headland which is called the keys of .


In this turn of affairs, the tyrants of  called together the generals of the , and said to them: , we  offer you the choice of engaging either the  or the .
If you want to draw up your army on land and try your strength against the , then it is time for you to disembark and array yourselves on land and for us to embark in your ships to contend with the . If, however, you desire rather to engage the , do so, but whichever you choose, see to it that  and  become free.
To this the  answered, We were sent by the common voice of  to guard the seas, not to deliver our ships to men of  and encounter the  on land. We will attempt then to bear ourselves bravely in the task which was given us. It is for you to prove yourselves valiant men, remembering what you suffered when you were enslaved by the Medians.


This was the ' response, and when the  army afterwards arrived on the plain of , the  kings ordered their battle line. They drew up the best of the  and  against the , leaving the remaining  to face the rest of the enemy's army.  placed himself opposite , the  general.


Now the horse which  rode was trained to fight with infantrymen by rearing up. Hearing this,  said to his attendant, a  of great renown in war and a valiant man ,

I learn that ' horse rears up and kicks and bites to death whomever he encounters. In light of this decide and tell me straightway which you will watch and strike down,  himself or his horse.
To this his henchman answered, My King, ready am I to do either or both, whatever you desire. Nevertheless, I will tell you what I think is in your best interest.
To my mind, a king and general should be met in battle by a king and general (For if you lay low a man who is a general, you have achieved a great feat. Failing that, if he lays you low, as I pray he may not, it is but half the misfortune to be slain by a noble enemy). For us servants it is fitting that we fight with servants like ourselves and with that horse. Do not fear his tricks, for I promise that he will never again do battle with any man.


This, then, was his response, and immediately afterwards war broke out on land and sea. The  in their ships, displaying surpassing excellence that day, overcame the , and it was the  who were most brave. On land, when the armies met, they charged and fought.
As for the two generals,  rode against  who as he had agreed with his attendant, dealt  a blow as he bore down upon him. When the horse struck his hooves on ' shield, the  shore away the horse's legs with a stroke of his curved sword.


It was in this way that  the  general, together with his horse, fell. While the rest were still fighting,  the ruler of , allegedly an  settlement, played the traitor with great company of men under him. The war-chariots of the  immediately followed their lead, and the  accordingly gained the upper hand over the .
So the army was routed, and many were slain, among them , son of , who had contrived the  revolt, as well as the king of the ,  son of , that  whom  of , when he came to , extolled in a poem above all other tyrants.


As for , the  cut off his head and brought it to , where they hung it above their gates, because he had besieged their city. When this head became hollow, a swarm of bees entered it and filled it with their honeycomb.
In consequence of this the , who had inquired concerning the matter, received an oracle which stated that they should take the head down and bury it, and offer yearly sacrifice to  as to a hero. If they did this, things would go better for them.


This the  did, and have done to this day. When, however, the  engaged in the sea-battle off  learned that ' cause was lost and that the cities of , with the exception of  which the  had handed over to their former king , were besieged, they sailed off to  without delay.

 was the  city which withstood siege longest; the  took it in the fifth month by digging a mine under its walls.


So the , after winning freedom for a year, were enslaved once more. , , and , all of them  generals and married to daughters of , pursued those  who had marched to , and drove them to their ships. After this victory they divided the cities among themselves and sacked them.


 made for the cities of the  and took , , , , and , each in a single day. Then as he marched from  against , news came to him that the  had made common cause with the  and revolted from the . For this reason he turned aside from the  and marched his army to .


It so happened that news of this was brought to the  before ' coming, and when the  heard, they mustered at the place called the  by the river  which flows from the region of  and issues into the .
When they had gathered together, many plans were laid before them, the best of which, in my judgment, was that of  of , the son of  and husband of the daughter of , king of . He proposed that the  should cross the  and fight with the river at their back, so that being unable to flee and compelled to stand their ground they might prove themselves even braver than nature made them.
This opinion, however, did not prevail, and it was decided instead that the  and not the  should have the  at their back, the intent being that if the  were overcome in the battle and put to flight, they would not escape but be hurled into the river.


Presently, when the  had come and had crossed the , they and the  joined battle by the river . The  fought obstinately and for a long time, but at the last they were overcome by the odds. Of the , as many as two thousand men fell, and of the  ten thousand.
Those of them who escaped were driven into the precinct of  of Armies at , a large and a holy grove of plane-trees. (The  are the only people whom we know who offer sacrifices to  by this name.) When they had been driven there, they deliberated how best to save themselves, whether it would be better for them to surrender to the  or to depart from .


While they took counsel, the  and their allies came to their aid, whereupon the  put aside their former plans, and prepared to wage a new war over again. They met the  attack and suffered a heavier defeat in the battle than the first; many of their whole army fell, but the  were hardest stricken.


The , however, rallied and fought again after this disaster, for learning that the  had set forth to march against their cities, they beset the road with an ambush at . The  fell into this by night and perished, they and their generals,  and  and . With these fell also , son of . The leader of this ambush was  of , son of .


This, then, is how these  perished. , who had been one of those who went in pursuit of the  who marched on , now turned towards the , and there took  in .
When he had taken this place and heard that  had left the  and was marching towards , he left the  and led his army to the , making himself master of all the  who dwell in the territory of , and of the , a remnant of the ancient . While he was conquering these nations, however,  himself died of a sickness in the .


This is how he met his end, and , viceroy of , and , the third general, were appointed to lead the army against  and the  territory on its borders. They took  in , and  in .


 the , as he clearly demonstrated, was a man of little courage, for after he had disturbed  and thrown all into utter confusion, he, perceiving what he had done, began to deliberate flight. Moreover, it seemed to him to be impossible to overcome .
While the cities were being taken, he accordingly called his fellow-rebels together and took counsel with them, saying that it was best for them to have some place of refuge in case they should be thrown out of . He also asked them whether he should lead them from there to a settlement in , or  in , which  had received as a gift from  and fortified.


 the historian, son of , was of the opinion that they should set forth to neither of these places, but that  should build a fortress in the island of  and reside there, if he were driven from . Afterwards, with this as a base, he could return to .


Such was the advice of , but  himself thought it best to depart for . He accordingly entrusted  to , a citizen of repute, and himself sailed to  with any that would follow him and then took possession of the place to which he had come.

 After this he was put to the sword by the , he and his army, as he was besieging a town, even though the  were ready to depart from it under treaty.
