p.#text:
This was the end of , after he had brought about the  revolt. , the tyrant of , arrived in  after he was let go by . When he came there from , , the governor of , asked him for what reason he supposed the  had rebelled;  said that he did not know and marvelled at what had happened, pretending to have no knowledge of the present troubles.
But  saw that he dissembled and, knowing the exact story of the revolt, said: I will tell you, , the truth of this business: it was you who stitched this shoe, and  who put it on.


Thus spoke  regarding the revolt.  was frightened by ' understanding of the matter and fled the next night to the sea, for he had deceived  by promising to subdue , the greatest of the islands, while secretly intending to make himself leader of the  in their war against .
Crossing over to , he was taken and bound by the , because they judged him to have been sent by  to make trouble for them. But when they learned the whole story of his hostility to the king, they set him free.


Then  was asked by the  why he had so zealously ordered  to revolt from the king and done the  such great harm. He did not at all reveal the true reason to them, telling them instead that king  had planned to remove the  and settle them in , and the  in ; for this reason, he said, he had sent the order. The king had made no such plan, but  wanted to frighten the .


Then , using , a man of , as messenger, sent letters to the  at , because they had previously talked with him about revolt. But  did not give the letters to the men to whom he was sent, and went and delivered them to  instead.

, learning all that was afoot, bade  carry ' letters to those for whom he was bringing them, and give him those which the  sent in answer to . Thus these men became known, and then  put many  to death.


So troubles arose in . Since he failed in this hope, the  brought  back to  at his own request. But the  were glad enough to be rid of  himself, and they had no wish to receive another tyrant into their country now that they had tasted freedom.
When  tried to force his way into  by night, he was wounded in the thigh by a . Since he was thrust out from his own city, he went back to ; when he could not persuade the  to give him ships, he then crossed over to  and persuaded the  to give him ships.
They manned eight triremes, and sailed with  to ; there they encamped, and seized all the ships that were sailing out of the , except when the crews consented to serve .


Such were the doings of  and the . Against  itself a great fleet and army were expected, for the  generals had joined their power together and made one army, which they led against , taking less account of the other fortresses. Of the fleet, the  were the most eager to fight, and there came with them to the war the newly subdued , and the  and .


These were coming to attack  and the rest of . When the  learned of it, they sent deputies to take counsel for them in the .  When they came to that place and consulted, they resolved not to collect a land army to meet the , but to leave the  to defend their walls themselves, and to man their fleet to the last ship and gather as quickly as possible at  to fight for  at sea. This  is a small island lying off the city of .


The  then came there with their ships manned, and with them the  who dwell in . This was their order of battle: The  themselves had the eastern wing, bringing eighty ships; next to them were the  with twelve ships, and the  with three; next to the  were the  with seventeen ships; next to these the  with a hundred; near these in the line were the , bringing eight ships, and the  with three, and next to these the  with seventy; last of all in the line were the , holding the western wing with sixty ships.
The total number of all these together was three hundred and fifty-three triremes.


These were the  ships; the ships of the foreigners were six hundred. When these, too, reached the  shore, and all their land power was present, the  generals, learning the number of the  ships, feared they would be too weak to overcome the . If they did not have mastery of the sea, they would not be able to take , and would be in danger of some evil treatment by .
With this in mind, they gathered the tyrants of the  who had been deposed from their governments by  of  and had fled to the , and who now were with the army that was led against . They gathered as many of these men as were with them and said to them:

Men of , let each one of you now show that he has done good service to the king's house; let each one of you try to separate your own countrymen from the rest of the allied power.  Set this promise before them: they will suffer no harm for their rebellion, neither their temples nor their houses will be burnt, nor will they in any way be treated more violently than before.
But if they will not do so and are set on fighting, then utter a threat that will restrain them: if they are defeated in battle, they will be enslaved; we will make eunuchs of their boys, and carry their maidens captive to , and hand over their land to others.


So they spoke; the  tyrants sent their messages by night, each to his own countrymen. But the  to whom these messages came were stubborn and would have no part of the treachery, each thinking that the  made this offer to them alone. This happened immediately after the  arrived at .


Then the  who had gathered at  held assemblies; among those whom I suppose to have addressed them was , the  general, who spoke thus:

Our affairs, men of , stand on the edge of a razor, whether to be free men or slaves, and runaway slaves at that. If you now consent to endure hardships, you will have toil for the present time, but it will be in your power to overcome your enemies and gain freedom; but if you will be weak and disorderly, I see nothing that can save you from paying the penalty to the king for your rebellion.
Believe me and entrust yourselves to me; I promise you that (if the gods deal fairly with us) either our enemies shall not meet us in battle, or if they do they shall be utterly vanquished.


When the  heard this, they put themselves in ' hands. He then each day put out to sea with ships in column, using the rowers to pierce each other's line of ships, and arming the fighting men on board; for the rest of the day he kept the fleet at anchor; all day he made the  work.
For seven days they obeyed him and did his bidding; but on the next day, untried as they were in such labor and worn out by hard work and by the sun, the  began to say each to other:

Against what god have we sinned that we have to fulfill this task? We have lost our minds and launched out into folly, committing ourselves into the hands of this  braggart, who brings but three ships; and having got us he afflicts us with afflictions incurable. Many of us have fallen sick already, and many are likely to suffer the same thing; instead of these ills, it would be better for us to suffer anything, and endure this coming slavery, whatever it will be, rather than be oppressed by that which is now upon us. Come, let us obey him no longer!
So they spoke, and from then on no man would obey. As if they were an army, they raised tents on the island where they stayed in the shade, and they were unwilling to embark upon their ships or to continue their exercises.


When the generals of the  learned what the  were doing, they recalled that message which  son of  had already sent them at the ' bidding, entreating them to desert the  alliance; seeing great disorder on the  side, they consented to the message; moreover, it seemed impossible to them to overcome the king's power, and they were well assured that if they overcame ' present fleet, another one five times as large would come.
Therefore, as soon as they saw the  refusing to be useful, they took up that for a pretext, considering it advantageous to save their own temples and houses. This , from whom they received the message, was the son of  son of , and had been tyrant of  until he was deposed from his rule by  of , just like the other  tyrants.


Now when the  fleet came sailing against them, the  put out to sea against them with their ships in column. When they drew near and met each other in battle, which of the  were brave men or cowards then in that sea-fight I cannot exactly say; for they all blame each other.
The  are said, according to their agreement with , to have raised their sails and gone off to , leaving their post, all except eleven ships.
The captains of these stood their ground and fought, disobeying their admirals. For this deed the  people granted that their names and patronymics should be engraved on a pillar as brave men; this pillar now stands in their market-place. But the , seeing their neighbors fleeing, did the same as the ; and most of the  did likewise.


The most roughly handled of those that stood their ground in the sea-fight were the , since they refused to be cowards and achieved deeds of renown. They brought a hundred ships to the fleet, as was mentioned above, and on each ship were forty picked men of their citizens.
Seeing themselves betrayed by the greater part of their allies, they did not think it right to act like the worst among them; with only a few allies to aid them they fought on and broke the enemy's line, until they had taken many ships but lost most of their own.


The  escaped to their own country with their remaining ships, but the crews of the  ships that were damaged and disabled were pursued and took refuge in . There the men beached and left their ships, and made their way across the mainland.
But when the  entered the lands of  on their march, they came by night while the women were celebrating the ; then the , never having heard the story of the  and seeing an army invading their country, were fully persuaded that these were robbers come after their women; so they mustered all their force and killed the .


So these men met with such a fate. As for  the , when he saw that the  cause was lost, he sailed away with the three enemy ships that he had captured; but not to , now that he knew well that it would be enslaved with the rest of ; he right away sailed straight to  instead, sunk some merchant ships, took a lot of money, and sailed to ; from this base he set himself up as a pirate, robbing  and , but no .


When the  had conquered the  by sea, they laid siege to  by sea and land, mining the walls and using every device against it, until they utterly captured it in the sixth year after the revolt of . They enslaved the city, and thus the calamity agreed with the oracle concerning .


When the  inquired at  about the safety of their city, a common response was given, one part regarding the  themselves, but there was an additional response for the .
I will mention the part concerning the  when I come to that part of my history; this was the prophecy given to the  in their absence:


All this now came upon the , since most of their men were slain by the , who wore long hair, and their women and children were accounted as slaves, and the temple at  with its shrine and place of divination was plundered and burnt. Of the wealth that was in this temple I have often spoken elsewhere in my history.


After that, the captive  were brought to .  did them no further harm, settling them by the sea called Red, in the city of , by which the river  flows as it issues into the sea. Of the  land the  themselves held what was nearest to the city, and the plain, giving the hill country into the possession of  from .


Now when the  suffered all this at the hands of the , the  (who had lost their city and dwelt in  and ) did not give them equal return for what they had done. When  was taken by the , all the people of , young and old, shaved their heads and made great public lamentation; no cities which we know were ever so closely joined in friendship as these.
The  acted very differently. The  made clear their deep grief for the taking of  in many ways, but especially in this: when  wrote a play entitled The Fall of  and produced it, the whole theater fell to weeping; they fined  a thousand drachmas for bringing to mind a calamity that affected them so personally, and forbade the performance of that play forever.


 then was left empty of . The men of property among the  were displeased by the dealings of their generals with the , so after the sea-fight they took counsel immediately and resolved that before  the tyrant came to their country they would sail to a colony, rather than remain and be slaves of the  and .
The people of  in  about this time sent messengers to  inviting the  to the , desiring there to found an  city. This , as it is called, is in , in that part which looks towards . At this invitation, the  alone of the , with those  who had escaped, set forth.


In their journey a thing happened to them such as I will show. As they voyaged to , the  came to the country of the   at a time when the people of  and their king (whose name was Scythes) were besieging a  town desiring to take it.
Learning this,  the tyrant of , being then in a feud with the , joined forces with the  and persuaded them to leave off their voyage to the  and seize  while it was deserted by its men.
The  consented and seized ; when they learned that their city was taken, the  came to deliver it, calling to their aid  the tyrant of , who was their ally.
But , when he came bringing his army to aid them, put Scythes the monarch of  and his brother  in chains for losing the city, and sent them away to the city of . He betrayed the rest of the  to the , with whom he had made an agreement and exchanged oaths.
The price which the  agreed to give him was that  should take for his share half of the movable goods and slaves in the city, and all that was in the country.
Most of the  were kept in chains as slaves by  himself; he gave three hundred chief men to the  to be put to death, but the  did not do so.


Scythes the monarch of  escaped from  to , and from there he came to  and went up country to king .  considered him the most honest man of all who had come up to him from ;

 for he returned by the king's permission to  and from  back again to , until in old age he ended his life in  in great wealth. Without trouble the  planted themselves in that most excellent city of , after they had escaped from the .


After the fight at sea for , the  at the ' bidding brought  son of  back to , for the high worth of his service to them and for his great achievements. Because of the desertion of their ships in the sea-fight, the  were the only rebel people whose city and temples were not burnt.
After  was captured, the  at once gained possession of . Some of the towns submitted voluntarily; others were brought over by force.


All this happened so.  the  was at , seizing the  merchant ships as they sailed out of the , when he had news of the business of . Leaving all matters concerning the  in charge of  of , son of , he himself sailed with the  to  and, when the  guardships would not receive him, fought in the Hollows of  (as they are called).
Many of their crews he killed; the rest of the people of the country, since they were crippled by the sea-fight, were mastered by  with his , setting out from  in .


It is common for some sign to be given when great ills threaten cities or nations; for before all this plain signs had been sent to the .
Of a band of a hundred youths whom they had sent to  only two returned, ninety-eight being caught and carried off by pestilence; moreover, at about this same time, a little before the sea-fight, the roof fell in on boys learning their letters: of one hundred and twenty of them one alone escaped.
These signs a god showed to them; then the sea-fight broke upon them and beat the city to its knees; on top of the sea-fight came  and the . Since the  were in such a bad state, he easily subdued them.


Then  brought a great force of  and  against . While he was besieging  a message came that the  were putting out to sea from  to attack the rest of . When he learned this, he left  unsacked, and hastened instead with all his army to .
From there, since his army suffered from hunger, he crossed over to reap from  the corn there and the  corn of the  plain. Now it chanced that in that region was , a , with no small force under him; when  landed,  met him in battle and took  himself alive and killed most of his army.


 was taken prisoner in this way: the  fought with the  at  in the country of ; the armies fought for a long time, until the  cavalry charged and fell upon the . So this was the accomplishment of the cavalry; when the  were routed, , supposing that the king would not put him to death for his present transgression, did what showed that he loved his life too well.
He was overtaken in his flight by a , and when he was caught and about to be stabbed, he cried out in the  language and revealed himself to be  the .


Now if he had been taken prisoner and brought to king , he would have suffered no harm (to my thinking) and the king would have forgiven his guilt; but as it was, when  was brought to , both because of what he had done, and for fear that he might escape and again win power at the court, , governor of , and , who had captured him, impaled his body on the spot, and sent his head embalmed to king  at .
When  learned of this, he blamed those who had done it because they had not brought  before him alive, and he commanded that the head should be washed and buried with due ceremony, as of a man who had done great good to  himself and to .


Thus it fared with . The  fleet wintered at , and putting out to sea in the next year easily subdued the islands that lie off the mainland,  and  and . Whenever they took an island, the foreigners would (net) the people.
This is the manner of their doing it: the men link hands and make a line reaching from the northern sea to the southern, and then advance over the whole island hunting the people down. They also captured the  cities of the mainland in the same way, but not by netting the people; for that was not possible.


Then the  generals were not false to the threats they had made against the  when they were encamped opposite them. When they had gained mastery over the cities, they chose out the most handsome boys and castrated them, making them eunuchs instead of men, and they carried the fairest maidens away to the king; they did all this, and they burnt the cities with their temples. Thus three times had the  been enslaved, first by the  and now twice in a row by the .


Then the fleet departed from  and captured everything which lies to the left of one sailing up the ; the right side had been subdued by the  themselves from the mainland. These are the regions of  that belong to the : the , in which there are many cities; , and the forts that lie towards , and  and .
The  and the  beyond them did not even wait for the attack of the , but left their own land and fled away into the , and there settled in the city of . The  burnt the aforementioned places and turned against  and ; after giving these also to the flames they sailed back to the  to finish off the remaining cities, as many as they had not destroyed at their former landing.
But they did not sail against  at all; the  had already made themselves the king's subjects before the  expedition, by an agreement with the governor at ,  son of .


The  subdued all the cities in the  except .  son of  son of  was tyrant there.  son of  had gained the rule earlier in the following manner: the  held possession of this . They were crushed in war by the , so they sent their kings to  to inquire about the war.
The  answered that they should bring to their land as founder the first man who offered them hospitality after they left the sacred precinct. But as the  passed through  and , going along the , no one invited them, so they turned toward .


At that time in ,  held all power, but  son of  also had great influence. His household was rich enough to maintain a four-horse chariot, and he traced his earliest descent to  and , though his later ancestry was .  son of  was the first of that house to be an .

 was sitting on his porch when he saw the  go by with their foreign clothing and spears, so he called out to them, and when they came over, he invited them in for lodging and hospitality. They accepted, and after he entertained them, they revealed the whole story of the oracle to him and asked him to obey the god.
He was persuaded as soon as he heard their speech, for he was tired of ' rule and wanted to be away from it. He immediately set out for  to ask the oracle if he should do what the  asked of him.


The  also bade him do so. Then  son of , previously an  victor in the four-horse chariot, recruited any  who wanted to take part in the expedition, sailed off with the , and took possession of their land. Those who brought him appointed him tyrant.
His first act was to wall off the isthmus of the  from the city of  across to , so that the  would not be able to harm them by invading their land. The isthmus is thirty-six stadia across, and to the south of the isthmus the  is four hundred and twenty stadia in length.


After  had pushed away the  by walling off the neck of the , he made war first on the people of , but the  laid an ambush and took him prisoner. However,  stood high in the opinion of  the , and when  heard what had happened, he sent to the  and commanded them to release . If they did not do so, he threatened to cut them down like a pine tree.
The  went astray in their counsels as to what the utterance meant which  had threatened them with, saying he would devastate them like a pine tree, until at last one of the elders understood and said what it was: the pine is the only tree that once cut down never sends out any shoots; it is utterly destroyed. So out of fear of  the  released  and let him go.


So he escaped by the intervention of , but he later died childless and left his rule and possessions to , the son of his half-brother . Since his death, the people of the  offer sacrifices to him as their founder in the customary manner, instituting a contest of horse races and gymnastics. No one from  is allowed to compete.
But in the war against the   too met his end and died childless; he was struck on the head with an axe in the town-hall by a man who pretended to be a deserter but in truth was an enemy and a man of violence.


 met his end in this way. The sons of  sent , son of  and brother of the dead , in a trireme to the  to take control of the country; they had already treated him well at , feigning that they had not been accessory to the death of  his father, which I will relate in another place.
Reaching the ,  kept himself within his house, professing thus to honor the memory of his brother . When the people of the  learned this, their ruling men gathered together from all the cities on every side, and came together in a group to show fellow-feeling with his mourning; but he put them in bonds. So  made himself master of the ; there he maintained a guard of five hundred men, and married  the daughter of , king of .


But not long after this  son of  had come to the , greater difficulties than the present afflictions overtook him. He had been driven from the country three years before this by the . The nomadic , provoked by , gathered themselves together and rode as far as the .

 did not await their attack and fled from the , until the  departed and the  brought him back again. All this had happened three years before the matters that now engaged him.


But now, learning that the  were in , he sailed away to  with five triremes loaded with the possessions that he had nearby. He set out from  and crossed the , and as he was sailing along the  the  fell upon him with their ships.

 himself escaped with four of his ships to , but the fifth was pursued and overtaken by the . It happened that the captain of this ship was , the eldest son of  by another wife, not the daughter of  the .
The  took this man captive with his ship; and when they heard that he was ' son, they brought him up to the king, thinking that this would be a very favorable service, because  had declared his opinion among the  that they should obey the  in their demand to break the bridge of boats and sail away to their homes.
But when the  brought ' son  before him,  did him no harm but much good, giving him a house and possessions and a  wife, who bore him children who were reckoned as .  made his way from  to .


In this year the  caused no further trouble for the , and at this same time certain things happened which greatly benefited the .  governor of  summoned ambassadors from the cities and compelled the  to make agreements among themselves that they would abide by the law and not rob and plunder each other.
He compelled them to do this, and he measured their lands by parasangs, which is the  name for a distance of thirty stadia, and ordered that each people should according to this measurement pay a tribute which has remained fixed as assessed by  ever since that time up to this day; the sum appointed was about the same as that which they had rendered before. This then kept them peaceable.


But at the beginning of spring the other generals were deposed by the king from their offices, and  son of , a man young in years and recently married to ' daughter , came down to the coast at the head of a very great army and fleet.
When  reached  at the head of this army, he himself embarked on shipboard and sailed with the rest of his ships, while other captains led the land army to the .
When  arrived in  in his voyage along the coast of , he did a thing which I here set down for the wonder of those  who will not believe  to have declared his opinion among the Seven that democracy was best for :  deposed all the  tyrants and set up democracies in their cities.
He did this and hurried to the . When a great multitude of ships and a great army were assembled, the  crossed the  on shipboard and marched through , with  and  as their goal.


This was the stated end of their expedition, but they intended to subdue as many of the  cities as they could. Their fleet subdued the , who did not so much as lift up their hands against it; their land army added the  to the slaves that they had already, for all the nations nearer to them than  had been made subject to the  before this.
Crossing over from  they travelled near the land as far as , and putting out from there they tried to round . But a great and irresistible north wind fell upon them as they sailed past and dealt very roughly with them, driving many of their ships upon .
It is said that about three hundred ships were lost, and more than twenty thousand men. Since the coasts of  abound in wild beasts, some men were carried off by beasts and so perished; others were dashed against the rocks; those who could not swim perished because of that, and still others by the cold.


Thus it fared with the fleet; as for  and his land army, while they were encamped in , the  of  attacked them by night and killed many of them, wounding  himself. But not even these could escape being enslaved by the ;  did not depart from those lands before he had subjugated them.
After conquering them, he led his army away homewards, since the  had dealt a heavy blow to his army and  an even heavier blow to his fleet. This expedition after an inglorious adventure returned back to .


In the next year after this,  first sent a message bidding the , who were falsely reported by their neighbors to be planning rebellion, to destroy their walls and bring their ships to .
Since they had been besieged by  of  and had great revenues, the  had used their wealth to build ships of war and surround themselves with stronger walls.
Their revenue came from the mainland and from the mines. About eighty talents on average came in from the gold-mines of the , and less from the mines of  itself, yet so much that the , paying no tax on their crops, drew a yearly revenue from the mainland and the mines of two hundred talents on average, and three hundred when the revenue was greatest.


I myself have seen these mines; by far the most marvellous were those that were found by the  who with  colonized this island, which is now called after that .
These  mines are between the place called  and  in , opposite ; they are in a great hill that has been dug up in the searching. So much for that. The  at the king's command destroyed their walls and brought all their ships to .


Then  attempted to learn whether the  intended to wage war against him or to surrender themselves. He sent heralds this way and that throughout , bidding them demand a gift of earth and water for the king.
He despatched some to , and he sent others to his own tributary cities of the coast, commanding that ships of war and transports for horses be built.


So the cities set about these preparations. The heralds who went to  received what the king's proclamation demanded from many of those dwelling on the mainland and from all the islanders to whom they came with the demand. Among the islanders who gave earth and water to  were the .
The  immediately came down upon them for doing this, for they supposed the  to have given the gift out of enmity for , so they might join with the  in attacking the . Gladly laying hold of this pretext, they went to  and there accused the  of acting to betray .


Regarding this accusation,  son of , king of , crossed over to  intending to arrest the most culpable of its people.
But when he attempted to make the arrests, the  opposed him, especially  son of , who told him he would not take away any  with impunity, for he had no authority from the  for what he was doing; instead he had been bribed by the ; otherwise he would have come to make the arrests with the other king. He said this because of a letter from .
Driven from ,  asked  his name; and when  told him what it was,  said to him, Now is the time to put bronze on your horns, , for great calamity will confront you.


All this time  son of  remained at  and spread evil reports of . This  was also king of , but of the inferior house; not indeed inferior in any other regard (for they have a common ancestor), but the house of  has in some sort the greater honor by right of primogeniture.


The  say (but no poet agrees) that it was  son of  son of  son of , and not his sons, who led them to that land which they now possess.
After no long time ' wife, whose name was , bore him offspring; they say she was daughter of  son of  son of  son of ; she bore him twins;  lived to see the children, then died of a sickness.
The  of that day planned to follow their custom and make the eldest of the children king. But the children were identical in all respects, so the  did not know which to choose; when they could not judge between them, or perhaps even before this, they asked the mother.
She said she knew no better than the  which was the elder; she knew perfectly well, but she said this because she desired that by some means both might be made kings. The  were at a loss, so they sent to  to inquire how they should deal with the matter.
The priestess bade them make both children kings but give greater honor to the elder. When the priestess gave this response, the  knew no better than before how to discover the elder child, and a man of , whose name was , gave them advice:

he advised them to watch the mother and see which of the children she washed and fed before the other; if she was seen to do this always in the same order, they would then have all that they sought and desired to discover; but if she changed her practice haphazardly, then it would be manifest to the  that she know no more than they did, and they must have recourse to some other means.
Then the  did as the  advised; as they watched the mother of ' children, they found her always preferring the elder when she fed and washed them, since she did not know why she was being watched. So they took the child that was preferred by its mother and brought it up at public expense as the first-born; and they called it , and the other .
They say that when these two brothers grew to manhood, they feuded with each other as long as they lived, and their descendants continued to do likewise.


The  are the only  who tell this story. But in what I write I follow the  report, and hold that the  correctly recount these kings of the  as far back as  son of they make no mention of the god and prove these kings to be ; for by that time they had come to be classified as .
I said as far back as , and I took the matter no further than that, because no one is named as the mortal father of , as  is named father of . So I used correct reasoning when I said that the  record is correct as far back as ; farther back than that, if the king's ancestors in each generation, from  daughter of  upward, be reckoned, then the leaders of the  will be shown to be true-born .


Thus have I traced their lineage according to the  story; but the  tale is that  himself was an , and became a , which his forebears had not been; the  say that the ancestors of  had no bond of kinship with , and they indeed were, as the  say, .


Enough of these matters. Why and for what achievements these men, being , won the kingship of the  has been told by others, so I will let it go, and will make mention of matters which others have not touched.


These privileges the  have given to their kings: two priesthoods, of  called  and of  of Heaven; they wage war against whatever land they wish, and no  can hinder them in this on peril of being put under a curse; when the armies go forth the kings go out first and return last; one hundred chosen men guard them in their campaigns; they sacrifice as many sheep and goats as they wish at the start of their expeditions, and take the hides and backs of all sacrificed beasts.


Such are their rights in war; in peace the powers given them are as follows: at all public sacrifices the kings first sit down to the banquet and are first served, each of them receiving a portion double of what is given to the rest of the company; they make the first libations, and the hides of the sacrificed beasts are theirs.
At each new moon and each seventh day of the first part of the month, a full-grown victim for 's temple, a bushel of barley-meal, and a  quart of wine are given to each from the public store, and chief seats are set apart for them at the games.
It is their right to appoint whatever citizens they wish to be protectors of foreigners; and they each choose two . (The  are the ambassadors to  and eat with the kings at the public expense.)  If the kings do not come to the public dinner, two choenixes of barley-meal and half a pint of wine are sent to their houses, but when they come, they receive a double share of everything; and the same honor shall be theirs when they are invited by private citizens to dinner.
They keep all oracles that are given, though the  also know them. The kings alone judge cases concerning the rightful possessor of an unwedded heiress, if her father has not betrothed her, and cases concerning public roads.
If a man desires to adopt a son, it is done in the presence of the kings. They sit with the twenty-eight elders in council; if they do not come, the elders most closely related to them hold the king's privilege, giving two votes over and above the third which is their own.


The kings are granted these rights from the  commonwealth while they live; when they die, their rights are as follows: Horsemen proclaim their death in all parts of , and in the city women go about beating on cauldrons. When this happens, two free persons from each house, a man and a woman, are required to wear mourning, or incur heavy penalties if they fail to do so.
The  have the same custom at the deaths of their kings as the foreigners in ; most foreigners use the same custom at their kings' deaths. When a king of the  dies, a fixed number of their subject neighbors must come to the funeral from all , besides the .
When these and the helots and the  themselves have assembled in one place to the number of many thousands, together with the women, they zealously beat their foreheads and make long and loud lamentation, calling that king that is most recently dead the best of all their kings. Whenever a king dies in war, they make an image of him and carry it out on a well-spread bier. For ten days after the burial there are no assemblies or elections, and they mourn during these days.


The  also resemble the  in this: when one king is dead and another takes his office, this successor releases from debt any  who owes a debt to the king or to the commonwealth. Among the  the king at the beginning of his reign forgives all cities their arrears of tribute.


The  resemble the  in that their heralds and flute-players and cooks inherit the craft from their fathers, a flute-player's son being a flute-player, and a cook's son a cook, and a herald's son a herald; no others usurp their places, making themselves heralds by loudness of voice; they ply their craft by right of birth. Such is the way of these matters.


While  was in  working for the common good of ,  slandered him, not out of care for the , but out of jealousy and envy. Once  returned home from , he planned to remove  from his kingship, using the following affair as a pretext against him: , king of , had married twice but had no children.
He did not admit that he himself was responsible, so he married a third time. This is how it came about: he had among the  a friend to whom he was especially attached. This man's wife was by far the most beautiful woman in , but she who was now most beautiful had once been the ugliest.
Her nurse considered her inferior looks and how she was of wealthy people yet unattractive, and, seeing how the parents felt her appearance to be a great misfortune, she contrived to carry the child every day to the sacred precinct of , which is in the place called , beyond the sacred precinct of . Every time the nurse carried the child there, she set her beside the image and beseeched the goddess to release the child from her ugliness.
Once as she was leaving the sacred precinct, it is said that a woman appeared to her and asked her what she was carrying in her arms. The nurse said she was carrying a child and the woman bade her show it to her, but she refused, saying that the parents had forbidden her to show it to anyone. But the woman strongly bade her show it to her,

and when the nurse saw how important it was to her, she showed her the child. The woman stroked the child's head and said that she would be the most beautiful woman in all . From that day her looks changed, and when she reached the time for marriage,  son of  married her. This man was 's friend.


So love for this woman pricked , and he contrived as follows: He promised to give to his comrade any one thing out of all he owned, whatever  might choose, and he bade his comrade make him the same promise.  had no fear about his wife, seeing that  was already married, so he agreed and they took oaths on these terms.

 gave  whatever it was that he chose out of all his treasures, and then, seeking equal recompense from him, tried to take the wife of his comrade.  said that he had agreed to anything but that, but he was forced by his oath and by the deceitful trick to let his wife be taken.


In this way  married his third wife, after divorcing the second one. But his new wife gave birth to  too soon, before ten lunar months had passed.
When one of his servants announced to him as he sat in council with the ephors that he had a son, , knowing the time of the marriage, counted up the months on his fingers and swore on oath, It's not mine. The ephors heard this but did not make anything of it. When the boy grew up,  regretted having said that, for he firmly believed  to be his own son.
He named him  because before his birth all the  populace had prayed that , the man most highly esteemed out of all the kings of , might have a son. Thus he was named , which means answer to the people's prayer.


Time passed and  died, so  held the kingship. But it seems that these matters had to become known and cause  to lose his kingship. He had already fallen out with  when he had brought the army back from , and now they were even more at odds when  crossed over after the  who were Medizing.


 wanted revenge, so he made a deal with  son of  son of , of the same family as . The deal was that  would go with  against the  if he became king.

 had already become strongly hostile to  for the following reason:  was betrothed to , daughter of , but  plotted and robbed him of his marriage, stealing  and marrying her first.
From this affair  was hostile toward , so at ' instigation he took an oath against him, saying that he was not king of the  by right, since he was not 's son. After making this oath, he prosecuted him, recalling that utterance which  had made when the servant told him he had a son, and he counted up the months and swore that it was not his.
Taking his stand on this remark,  declared that  was not 's son and that he was not rightly king of , bringing as witnesses the ephors who had been sitting beside  and heard him say this.


Disputes arose over it, so the  resolved to ask the oracle at  if  was the son of .
At ' instigation this was revealed to the . He had won over a man of great influence among the ,  son of , and  persuaded the priestess, , to say what  wanted her to.
When the ambassadors asked if  was the son of , the  gave judgment that he was not. All this came to light later;  was exiled from , and  was deposed from her position.


So it was concerning ' loss of the kingship, and from  he went into exile among the  because of the following reproach: after he was deposed from the kingship, he was elected to office.
When it was the time of the , , now king in his place, saw him in the audience and, as a joke and an insult, sent a messenger to him to ask what it was like to hold office after being king.
He was grieved by the question and said that he had experience of both, while  did not, and that this question would be the beginning for  of either immense evil or immense good fortune. He said this, covered his head, left the theater, and went home, where he immediately made preparations and sacrificed an ox to . Then he summoned his mother.


When she came in, he put some of the entrails in her hands and entreated her, saying, Mother, appealing to  of the household and to all the other gods, I beseech you to tell me the truth. Who is my father? Tell me truly.

 said in the disputes that you were already pregnant by your former husband when you came to . Others say more foolishly that you approached to one of the servants, the ass-keeper, and that I am his son.
I adjure you by the gods to speak what is true. If you have done anything of what they say, you are not the only one; you are in company with many women. There is much talk at  that  did not have child-bearing seed in him, or his former wives would have given him children.


Thus he spoke. His mother answered, My son, since you adjure me by entreaties to speak the truth, I will speak out to you all that is true. On the third night after  brought me to his house, a phantom resembling him came to me. It came and lay with me and then put on me the garlands which it had.
It went away, and when  came in later and saw me with the garlands, he asked who gave them to me. I said he did, but he denied it. I swore an oath that just a little while before he had come in and lain with me and given me the garlands, and I said it was not good of him to deny it.
When he saw me swearing, he perceived that this was some divine affair. For the garlands had clearly come from the hero's precinct which is established at the courtyard doors, which they call the precinct of , and the seers responded that this was the same hero who had come to me. Thus, my son, you have all you want to know.
Either you are from this hero and  the hero is your father, or  is, for I conceived you that night. As for how your enemies chiefly attack you, saying that  himself, when your birth was announced, denied in front of a large audience that you were his because the ten months had not yet been completed, he spoke an idle word, out of ignorance of such things.
Some women give birth after nine months or seven months; not all complete the ten months. I gave birth to you, my son, after seven months. A little later  himself recognized that he had blurted out that speech because of foolishness. Do not believe other stories about your manner of birth. You have heard the whole truth. May the wife of  himself, and the wives of the others who say these things, give birth to children fathered by ass-keepers.


Thus his mother spoke. After learning what he desired,  took provisions and travelled to , pretending that he was going to  to inquire of the oracle. But the  suspected that he planned to escape and went in pursuit.

 somehow went across to  from  before them; the  crossed over after him and laid hands on him, carrying off his servants. But the  refused to give him up, and later he crossed from there to  and went to king , who received him in grand style and gave him lands and cities.
So  reached  through such chances, a man who had gained much renown in  by his many achievements and his wisdom, and by conferring on the state the victory in a chariot-race he had won at ; he was the only king of  who did this.


 son of  succeeded to the kingship after  was deposed. A son was born to him, , called by some of the  . This  never became king of , for he died before , leaving his son .
After the loss of ,  married a second wife, , sister of  and daughter of ; by her he had no male offspring, but a daughter, , to whom  son of  was married by .


But  also did not come to old age in ; he was punished for his dealings with  as I will show. He led a  army to , and when he could have subdued all the country he took a great bribe.
After being caught in the act of hoarding a sleeve full of silver there in the camp, he was brought before a court and banished from , and his house was destroyed. He went into exile at  and died in that country.


This happened long afterwards. When ' dealings with  came off successfully, he immediately took  with him and went to punish the , with whom he was terribly angry because of their insulting behavior.
When the  saw that both kings had come after them, they now deemed it best to offer no further resistance; the kings chose ten men of  who were most honored for wealth and lineage, among them  son of  and  son of , the two most powerful men in ; they carried them to  and gave them into the keeping of the , the bitterest foes of the .


Later ' treacherous plot against  became known; he was seized with fear of the  and secretly fled to . From there he came to  and stirred up disorder, uniting the  against ; among his methods of binding them by oath to follow him wherever he led was his zeal to bring the chief men of  to the city of  and make them swear by the water of the .
Near this city is said to be the  water of the , and this is its nature: it is a stream of small appearance, dropping from a cliff into a pool; a wall of stones runs round the pool. , where this spring rises, is a city of  near .


When the  learned that  was doing this, they took fright and brought him back to  to rule on the same terms as before.  had already been not entirely in his right mind, and on his return from exile a mad sickness fell upon him: any  that he happened to meet he would hit in the face with his staff.
For doing this, and because he was out of his mind, his relatives bound him in the stocks. When he was in the stocks and saw that his guard was left alone, he demanded a dagger; the guard at first refused to give it, but  threatened what he would do to him when he was freed, until the guard, who was a helot, was frightened by the threats and gave him the dagger.

 took the weapon and set about slashing himself from his shins upwards; from the shin to the thigh he cut his flesh lengthways, then from the thigh to the hip and the sides, until he reached the belly, and cut it into strips; thus he died, as most of the  say, because he persuaded the  priestess to tell the tale of . The  alone say it was because he invaded  and laid waste the precinct of the gods. The  say it was because when  had taken refuge after the battle in their temple of  he brought them out and cut them down, then paid no heed to the sacred grove and set it on fire.


As  was seeking divination at , the oracle responded that he would take . When he came with  to the river , which is said to flow from the  lake (this lake issues into a cleft out of sight and reappears at , and from that place onwards the stream is called by the  )when  came to this river he offered sacrifices to it.
The omens were in no way favorable for his crossing, so he said that he honored the  for not betraying its countrymen, but even so the  would not go unscathed. Then he withdrew and led his army seaward to , where he sacrificed a bull to the sea and carried his men on shipboard to the region of  and to .


The  heard of this and came to the coast to do battle with him. When they had come near  and were at the place called , they encamped opposite the , leaving only a little space between the armies. There the  had no fear of fair fighting, but rather of being captured by a trick.
This was the affair referred to by that oracle which the  priestess gave to the  and  in common, which ran thus:


All these things coming together spread fear among the . Therefore they resolved to defend themselves by making use of the enemies' herald, and they performed their resolve in this way: whenever the  herald signalled anything to the , the  did the same thing.


When  saw that the  did whatever was signalled by his herald, he commanded that when the herald cried the signal for breakfast, they should then put on their armor and attack the .
The  performed this command, and when they assaulted the  they caught them at breakfast in obedience to the herald's signal; they killed many of them, and far more fled for refuge into the grove of , which the  encamped around and guarded.


Then ' plan was this: He had with him some deserters from whom he learned the names, then he sent a herald calling by name the  that were shut up in the sacred precinct and inviting them to come out, saying that he had their ransom. (Among the  there is a fixed ransom of two minae to be paid for every prisoner.) So  invited about fifty  to come out one after another and murdered them.
Somehow the rest of the men in the temple precinct did not know this was happening, for the grove was thick and those inside could not see how those outside were faring, until one of them climbed a tree and saw what was being done. Thereafter they would not come out at the herald's call.


Then  bade all the helots pile wood about the grove; they obeyed, and he burnt the grove. When the fire was now burning, he asked of one of the deserters to what god the grove belonged; the man said it was of . When he heard that, he groaned aloud, , god of oracles, you have gravely deceived me by saying that I would take ; this, I guess, is the fulfillment of that prophecy.


Then  sent most of his army back to , while he himself took a thousand of the best warriors and went to the temple of  to sacrifice. When he wished to sacrifice at the altar the priest forbade him, saying that it was not holy for a stranger to sacrifice there.  ordered the helots to carry the priest away from the altar and whip him, and he performed the sacrifice. After doing this, he returned to .


But after his return his enemies brought him before the ephors, saying that he had been bribed not to take  when he might have easily taken it.  alleged (whether falsely or truly, I cannot rightly say; but this he alleged in his speech) that he had supposed the god's oracle to be fulfilled by his taking of the temple of ; therefore he had thought it best not to make any attempt on the city before he had learned from the sacrifices whether the god would deliver it to him or withstand him;

when he was taking omens in 's temple a flame of fire had shone forth from the breast of the image, and so he learned the truth of the matter, that he would not take . If the flame had come out of the head of the image, he would have taken the city from head to foot utterly; but its coming from the breast signified that he had done as much as the god willed to happen. This plea of his seemed to the  to be credible and reasonable, and he far outdistanced the pursuit of his accusers.


But  was so wholly deprived of men that their slaves took possession of all affairs, ruling and governing until the sons of the slain men grew up. Then they recovered  for themselves and cast out the slaves; when they were driven out, the slaves took possession of  by force.
For a while they were at peace with each other; but then there came to the slaves a prophet, , a man of  in  by birth; he persuaded the slaves to attack their masters. From that time there was a long-lasting war between them, until with difficulty the  got the upper hand.


The  say this was the reason  went mad and met an evil end; the  themselves say that ' madness arose from no divine agent, but that by consorting with  he became a drinker of strong wine, and the madness came from this.
The nomadic , after  had invaded their land, were eager for revenge, so they sent to  and made an alliance. They agreed that the  would attempt to invade Media by way of the river , and they urged the  to set out and march inland from  and meet the .
They say that when the  had come for this purpose,  kept rather close company with them, and by consorting with them more than was fitting he learned from them to drink strong wine. The  consider him to have gone mad from this. Ever since, as they themselves say, whenever they desire a strong drink they call for a  cup. Such is the  story of ; but to my thinking it was for what he did to  that he was punished thus.


When the  heard that  was dead, they sent messengers to  to cry out against  concerning the hostages that were held at . The  then assembled a court and gave judgment that  had done violence to the ; and they condemned him to be given up and carried to  in requital for the men that were held at .
But when the  were about to carry  away, a man of repute at ,  son of , said to them, Men of , what are you planning to do? To have the king of the  given up to you by the citizens and carry him away? If the  have now so judged in their anger, see that they do not bring utter destruction upon your country if you do this.
The  heard this and refrained from carrying the king away, and made an agreement that  should go with them to  and restore the men to the .


When  came to  and demanded back the hostages, the  were unwilling to give them back and made excuses, saying that two kings had given them the trust and they deemed it wrong to restore it to one without the other.

When the  refused to give them back,  said to them: Men of , do whichever thing you desire. If you give them back, you do righteously; if you do not give them back, you do the opposite. But I want to tell you the story of what happened at  in the matter of a trust.
We  say that three generations ago there was at  one , the son of . We say that this man added to his other excellences a reputation for justice above all men who at that time dwelt in .
But we say that at the fitting time this befell him: There came to  a certain man of , who desired to have a talk with  and made him this offer: I am a , and I have come to have the benefit of your justice, .
Since there is much talk about your justice throughout all the rest of , and even in , I considered the fact that  is always in danger while the  is securely established, and nowhere in  are the same men seen continuing in possession of wealth.
Considering and taking counsel concerning these matters, I resolved to turn half of my property into silver and deposit it with you, being well assured that it will lie safe for me in your keeping. Accept the money for me, and take and keep these tokens; restore the money to whoever comes with the same tokens and demands it back.

Thus spoke the stranger who had come from , and  received the trust according to the agreement. After a long time had passed, the sons of the man who had deposited the money came to ; they spoke with , showing him the tokens and demanding the money back.
But  put them off and answered in turn: I do not remember the matter, and nothing of what you say carries my mind back. Let me think; I wish to do all that is just. If I took the money, I will duly restore it; if I never took it at all, I will deal with you according to the customs of the . I will put off making my decision for you until the fourth month from this day.

So the  went away in sorrow, as men robbed of their possessions; but  journeyed to  to question the oracle. When he asked the oracle whether he should seize the money under oath, the  priestess threatened him in these verses:



When  heard this, he entreated the god to pardon him for what he had said. The priestess answered that to tempt the god and to do the deed had the same effect.

So  summoned the  strangers and gave them back their money. But hear now, , why I began to tell you this story: there is today no descendant of , nor any household that bears ' name; he has been utterly rooted out of . So good is it not even to think anything concerning a trust except giving it back on demand!


Thus spoke ; but even so the  would not listen to him, and he departed. The , before paying the penalty for the violence they had done to the  to please the , acted as follows: blaming the  and deeming themselves wronged, they prepared to take vengeance on the , who were now celebrating a quinquennial festival at . Suffering this from the , the  no longer put off devising all mischief against . But this happened later. The rich men of  gained mastery over the people, who had risen against them with , then made them captive and led them out to be killed. They had taken seven hundred of the people alive; as they led these out for slaughter one of them escaped from his bonds and fled to the temple gate of  the Lawgiver, where he laid hold of the door-handles and clung to them. They could not tear him away by force, so they cut off his hands and carried him off, and those hands were left clinging fast to the door-handles.


Thus the  dealt with each other. When the  came, they fought them at sea with seventy ships; the  were defeated in the sea-fight and asked for help from the , as they had done before. The  laid on them the payment of a fine of a thousand talents, five hundred each. The  confessed that they had done wrong and agreed to go free with a payment of a hundred talents, but the  made no such confession and remained stubborn. For this cause the  state sent no one to aid them at their request, but about a thousand came voluntarily, led by a captain whose name was , a man who practiced the pentathlon.
Most of these never returned, meeting their death at the hands of the  in ;  himself, their captain, fought in single combat and thus killed three men, but was slain by the fourth,  the son of .

Thus  and  grappled together in war. The  was going about his own business, for his servant was constantly reminding him to remember the , and the  were at his elbow maligning the ; moreover,  desired to take this pretext for subduing all the men of  who had not given him earth and water.

When these appointed generals on their way from the king reached the  plain in , bringing with them a great and well-furnished army, they camped there and were overtaken by all the fleet that was assigned to each; there also arrived the transports for horses, which in the previous year  had bidden his tributary subjects to make ready.

Holy men, why have you fled away, and so misjudged my intent? So return now to your homes and dwell on your island. He made this proclamation to the , and then piled up three hundred talents of frankincense on the altar and burnt it.

But it seems that all the plans of the  were unsound; they sent to the  for aid, but their counsels were divided.

While still in the city, the generals first sent to  the herald , an  and a long-distance runner who made that his calling. As  himself said when he brought the message to the , when he was in the  above  he encountered Pan.
Pan called out ' name and bade him ask the  why they paid him no attention, though he was of goodwill to the , had often been of service to them, and would be in the future.
The  believed that these things were true, and when they became prosperous they established a sacred precinct of Pan beneath the Acropolis. Ever since that message they propitiate him with annual sacrifices and a torch-race.


This  was in  on the day after leaving the city of , that time when he was sent by the generals and said that Pan had appeared to him. He came to the magistrates and said,

, the  ask you to come to their aid and not allow the most ancient city among the  to fall into slavery at the hands of the foreigners. Even now  has been enslaved, and  has become weaker by an important city.
He told them what he had been ordered to say, and they resolved to send help to the , but they could not do this immediately, for they were unwilling to break the law. It was the ninth day of the rising month, and they said that on the ninth they could not go out to war until the moon's circle was full.


So they waited for the full moon, while the foreigners were guided to Marathon by  son of . The previous night  had a dream in which he slept with his mother.
He supposed from the dream that he would return from exile to , recover his rule, and end his days an old man in his own country. Thus he reckoned from the dream. Then as guide he unloaded the slaves from  onto the island of the  called , and brought to anchor the ships that had put ashore at Marathon, then marshalled the foreigners who had disembarked onto land.
As he was tending to this, he happened to sneeze and cough more violently than usual. Since he was an elderly man, most of his teeth were loose, and he lost one of them by the force of his cough. It fell into the sand and he expended much effort in looking for it, but the tooth could not be found.

 He groaned aloud and said to those standing by him: This land is not ours and we will not be able to subdue it. My tooth holds whatever share of it was mine.


 supposed that the dream had in this way come true. As the  were marshalled in the precinct of , the  came to help them in full force. The  had put themselves under the protection of the , and the  had undergone many labors on their behalf. This is how they did it:

when the  were pressed by the , they first tried to put themselves under the protection of  son of  and the , who happened to be there. But they did not accept them, saying, We live too far away, and our help would be cold comfort to you. You could be enslaved many times over before any of us heard about it.
We advise you to put yourselves under the protection of the , since they are your neighbors and not bad men at giving help. The  gave this advice not so much out of goodwill toward the  as wishing to cause trouble for the  with the .
So the  gave this advice to the , who did not disobey it. When the  were making sacrifices to the twelve gods, they sat at the altar as suppliants and put themselves under protection. When the  heard this, they marched against the , but the  came to their aid.
As they were about to join battle, the , who happened to be there, prevented them and brought about a reconciliation. Since both sides desired them to arbitrate, they fixed the boundaries of the country on condition that the  leave alone those  who were unwilling to be enrolled as .  After rendering this decision, the  departed. The  attacked the  as they were leaving but were defeated in battle.
The  went beyond the boundaries the  had made for the , fixing the  as the boundary for the  in the direction of  and . So the  had put themselves under the protection of the  in the aforesaid manner, and now came to help at Marathon.


The  generals were of divided opinion, some advocating not fighting because they were too few to attack the army of the ; others, including , advocating fighting.
Thus they were at odds, and the inferior plan prevailed. An eleventh man had a vote, chosen by lot to be polemarch of , and by ancient custom the  had made his vote of equal weight with the generals.  of  was polemarch at this time.  approached him and said,

, it is now in your hands to enslave  or make her free, and thereby leave behind for all posterity a memorial such as not even  and  left. Now the  have come to their greatest danger since they first came into being, and, if we surrender, it is clear what we will suffer when handed over to . But if the city prevails, it will take first place among  cities.
I will tell you how this can happen, and how the deciding voice on these matters has devolved upon you. The ten generals are of divided opinion, some urging to attack, others urging not to.
If we do not attack now, I expect that great strife will fall upon and shake the spirit of the , leading them to medize. But if we attack now, before anything unsound corrupts the , we can win the battle, if the gods are fair.
All this concerns and depends on you in this way: if you vote with me, your country will be free and your city the first in . But if you side with those eager to avoid battle, you will have the opposite to all the good things I enumerated.


By saying this  won over . The polemarch's vote was counted in, and the decision to attack was resolved upon. Thereafter the generals who had voted to fight turned the presidency over to  as each one's day came in turn. He accepted the office but did not make an attack until it was his own day to preside.


When the presidency came round to him, he arrayed the  for battle, with the polemarch  commanding the right wing, since it was then the  custom for the polemarch to hold the right wing. He led, and the other tribes were numbered out in succession next to each other. The  were marshalled last, holding the left wing.
Ever since that battle, when the  are conducting sacrifices at the festivals every fourth year, the  herald prays for good things for the  and  together.
As the  were marshalled at Marathon, it happened that their line of battle was as long as the line of the . The center, where the line was weakest, was only a few ranks deep, but each wing was strong in numbers.


When they had been set in order and the sacrifices were favorable, the  were sent forth and charged the foreigners at a run. The space between the armies was no less than eight stadia.
The  saw them running to attack and prepared to receive them, thinking the  absolutely crazy, since they saw how few of them there were and that they ran up so fast without either cavalry or archers.
So the foreigners imagined, but when the  all together fell upon the foreigners they fought in a way worthy of record. These are the first  whom we know of to use running against the enemy. They are also the first to endure looking at Median dress and men wearing it, for up until then just hearing the name of the  caused the  to panic.


They fought a long time at Marathon. In the center of the line the foreigners prevailed, where the  and  were arrayed. The foreigners prevailed there and broke through in pursuit inland, but on each wing the  and  prevailed.
In victory they let the routed foreigners flee, and brought the wings together to fight those who had broken through the center. The  prevailed, then followed the fleeing  and struck them down. When they reached the sea they demanded fire and laid hold of the  ships.


In this labor  the polemarch was slain, a brave man, and of the generals  son of  died.  son of  fell there, his hand cut off with an ax as he grabbed a ship's figurehead. Many other famous  also fell there.


In this way the  overpowered seven ships. The foreigners pushed off with the rest, picked up the  slaves from the island where they had left them, and sailed around  hoping to reach the city before the . There was an accusation at  that they devised this by a plan of the , who were said to have arranged to hold up a shield as a signal once the  were in their ships.


They sailed around , but the  marched back to defend the city as fast as their feet could carry them and got there ahead of the foreigners. Coming from the sacred precinct of  in Marathon, they pitched camp in the sacred precinct of  in . The foreigners lay at anchor off , the  naval port at that time. After riding anchor there, they sailed their ships back to .


In the battle at Marathon about six thousand four hundred men of the foreigners were killed, and one hundred and ninety-two ; that many fell on each side.

 The following marvel happened there: an ,  son of , was fighting as a brave man in the battle when he was deprived of his sight, though struck or hit nowhere on his body, and from that time on he spent the rest of his life in blindness.
I have heard that he tells this story about his misfortune: he saw opposing him a tall armed man, whose beard overshadowed his shield, but the phantom passed him by and killed the man next to him. I learned by inquiry that this is the story  tells.


 journeyed with his army to , and when he arrived at  he saw a vision in his sleep. What that vision was is not told, but as soon as day broke  made a search of his ships. He found in a  ship a gilded image of , and asked where this plunder had been taken. Learning from what temple it had come, he sailed in his own ship to .
The  had now returned to their island, and  set the image in the temple, instructing the  to carry it away to , on the coast opposite .

 gave this order and sailed away, but the  never carried that statue away; twenty years later the  brought it to  by command of an oracle.


When  and  reached  in their voyage, they carried the enslaved  inland to .
Before the  were taken captive, king  had been terribly angry with them for doing him unprovoked wrong; but when he saw them brought before him and subject to him, he did them no harm, but settled them in a domain of his own called  in the  land; this place is two hundred and ten stadia distant from , and forty from the well that is of three kinds.
Asphalt and salt and oil are drawn from it in the following way: a windlass is used in the drawing, with half a skin tied to it in place of a bucket; this is dipped into the well and then poured into a tank; then what is drawn is poured into another tank and goes three ways: the asphalt and the salt congeal immediately; the oil, which the  call rhadinace, is dark and evil-smelling.
There king  settled the , and they dwelt in that place until my time, keeping their ancient language. Such was the fate of the .


After the full moon two thousand  came to , making such great haste to reach it that they were in  on the third day after leaving . Although they came too late for the battle, they desired to see the , so they went to Marathon and saw them. Then they departed again, praising the  and their achievement.


It is a wonder to me, and I do not believe the story, that the  would ever have agreed to hold up a shield as a sign for the  out of a desire to make  subject to foreigners and to ; for it is plain to see that they were tyrant-haters as much as  (son of  and father of ), or even more so.

 was the only  who dared to buy ' possessions when they were put up for sale by the state after ' banishment from ; and he devised other acts of bitter hatred against him.


 This  is worthy of all men's remembrance for many reasons: first, because he so excellently freed his country, as I have said; second, for what he did at , where he won a horserace, and was second in a four-horse chariot, after already winning a  prize, and was the cynosure of all  for the lavishness of his spending;

and third, for his behavior regarding his three daughters. When they were of marriageable age, he gave them a most splendid gift and one very pleasant to them, promising that each would wed that man whom she chose for herself from all the .


The  were tyrant-haters as much as , or not less so. Therefore I find it a strange and unbelievable accusation that they of all men should have held up a shield; at all times they shunned tyrants, and it was by their contrivance that the sons of  were deposed from their tyranny.
Thus in my judgment it was they who freed  much more than did  and . These only enraged the remaining sons of  by killing , and did nothing to end the tyranny of the rest of them; but the  plainly liberated their country, if they truly were the ones who persuaded the  priestess to signify to the  that they should free , as I have previously shown.


Perhaps out of some grudge against the  people they betrayed their country. But there were no others at  more esteemed or more honored than they;

therefore plain reason forbids believing that they of all men could have held up the shield for any such cause. A shield was held up; this cannot be denied, for it happened; but who did it I do not know, and I can say no further.


The  had been men of renown at  even in the old days, and from the time of  and then  their renown increased.
When the  from  came from  to the  oracle,  son of  worked with them and zealously aided them; when  heard from the  who visited the oracle of 's benefits to him, he summoned  to , and there made him a gift of as much gold as he could carry away at one time on his person.
Considering the nature of the gift,  planned and employed this device: he donned a wide tunic, leaving a deep fold in it, and put on the most spacious boots that he could find, then went into the treasury to which they led him.
Falling upon a heap of gold-dust, first he packed next to his legs as much gold as his boots would contain; then he filled all the fold of his tunic with gold and strewed the dust among the hair of his head, and took more of it into his mouth; when he came out of the treasury, hardly dragging the weight of his boots, he was like anything rather than a human being, with his mouth crammed full and all his body swollen.

 burst out laughing at the sight and gave him all the gold he already had and that much more again. Thus the family grew very rich;  came to keep four-horse chariots and won with them at .


In the next generation  the tyrant of  raised that house still higher, so that it grew much more famous in  than it had formerly been.  son of  son of  son of  had one daughter, whose name was . He desired to wed her to the best man he could find in .
It was the time of the  games, and when he was victor there with a four-horse chariot,  made a proclamation that whichever  thought himself worthy to be his son-in-law should come on the sixtieth day from then or earlier to , and  would make good his promise of marriage in a year from that sixtieth day.

From  came  of , son of , the most luxurious liver of his day (and  was then at the height of its prosperity), and  of , son of that  who was called the Wise.
