Then those of the envoys who were  replied to the demands of the council, saying that they would refer the question of the truce to their own government at home; as for the command, however, they themselves had been commissioned to say that the  had two kings, and the  but one. Now it was impossible to deprive either  of his command, but there was nothing to prevent the  from having the same right of voting as their two had.
At that, say the , they decided that the ' covetousness was past all bearing and that it was better to be ruled by the foreigners than give way to the . They then bade the envoys depart from the land of  before sunset, for they would otherwise be treated as enemies.


Such is the ' account of this matter, but there is another story told in , namely that before  set forth on his march against , he sent a herald to , who said on his coming (so the story goes),

Men of , this is the message to you from .  our forefather had, as we believe,  son of  for his father, and  daughter of  for his mother; if that is so, then we are descended from your nation. In all right and reason we should therefore neither march against the land of our forefathers, nor should you become our enemies by aiding others or do anything but abide by yourselves in peace. If all goes as I desire, I will hold none in higher esteem than you.
The  were strongly moved when they heard this, and although they made no promise immediately and demanded no share, they later, when the  were trying to obtain their support, did make the claim, because they knew that the  would refuse to grant it, and that they would thus have an excuse for taking no part in the war.


This is borne out, some of the  say, by the tale of a thing which happened many years afterwards. It happened that while  envoys,  son of , and the rest who had come up with him, were at , called the , about some other business, the  also had at this same time sent envoys to , asking of ' son  whether the friendship which they had forged with  still held good, as they desired, or whether he considered them as his enemies.  responded to this that it did indeed hold good and that he believed no city to be a better friend to him than .


Now, whether it is true that  sent a herald with such a message to , and that the  envoys came up to  and questioned  about their friendship, I cannot say with exactness, nor do I now declare that I consider anything true except what the  themselves say.
This, however, I know full well, namely if all men should carry their own private troubles to market for barter with their neighbors, there would not be a single one who, when he had looked into the troubles of other men, would not be glad to carry home again what he had brought.
The conduct of the  was accordingly not utterly shameful. As for myself, although it is my business to set down that which is told me, to believe it is none at all of my business. This I ask the reader to hold true for the whole of my history, for there is another tale current, according to which it would seem that it was the  who invited the  into , because the war with the  was going badly, and they would prefer anything to their present distresses.


Such is the end of the story of the . As for , envoys were sent there by the allies to hold converse with ,  from  among them. The ancestor of this , who settled at , was from the island of  which lies off . When the founding of  by  and the  of  was happening, he would not be left behind.
His descendants in time became and continue to be priests of the goddesses of the underworld; this office had been won, as I will show, by , one of their forefathers. There were certain  who had been worsted in party strife and had been banished to the town of , inland of .
These men  brought to  with no force of men but only the holy instruments of the goddesses worship to aid him. From where he got these, and whether or not they were his own invention, I cannot say; however that may be, it was in reliance upon them that he restored the exiles, on the condition that his descendants should be ministering priests of the goddesses.
Now it makes me marvel that  should have achieved such a feat, for I have always supposed that such feats cannot be performed by any man but only by such as have a stout heart and manly strength. , however, is reported by the dwellers in  to have had a soft and effeminate disposition.


At the death of  son of , who had been tyrant of  for seven years, and had been slain by a man of that city named , the sovereignty passed to ' brother . While  was tyrant, , a descendant of the ministering priest , was one of ' guard, as were  son of  and many others.
In no long time he was appointed for his worth to be captain of the entire cavalry, for his performance had been preeminent while he served under  in the assaults against , , , , , and many other of the foreigners' towns. None of these cities, with the exception of , escaped enslavement by ; the  were defeated in battle on the river .
They were, however, rescued by the  and , who made a peace for them on the condition that the  should deliver up to  , which had formerly been theirs.


When , too, after reigning the same number of years as his brother , came to his end near the town of from where he had marched against the then  made a pretence of serving the cause of ' sons  and , whose rule the citizens would no longer bear. When he had defeated the men of , however, he deposed the sons of  and held sway himself.
After this stroke of good fortune,  brought back from the town of  to  both the so-called landed gentry of , who had been driven into exile by the common people, and their slaves, the . He then took possession of that city also, for the  common people surrendered themselves and it to  at his coming.


When he had made  his own, he took less account of his rule over , which he gave in charge to his brother ; over  he reigned, and all his care was for .
Straightway that city grew and became great, for not only did  bring all the people of  to  and give them its citizenship, razing the township of , but he did the same thing to more than half of the townsmen of , and when the  in  surrendered to him on terms after a siege, he took the wealthier of them, who had made war on him and expected to be put to death for this, and brought them to  to be citizens there. As for the common people of , who had had no hand in the making of that war and expected that no harm would be done them, these too he brought to  and sold them for slaves to be taken out of .
He dealt in a similar way with the  of , making the same distinction. The reason for his treating the people of both places in this way was that he held the common people to be exceedingly disagreeable to live with.


By these means  had grown to greatness as a tyrant, and now, when the  envoys had come to , they had audience with him and spoke as follows: The  and their allies have sent us to win your aid against the foreigner, for it cannot be, we think, that you have no knowledge of the  invader of , how he proposes to bridge the  and lead all the hosts of the east from  against us, making an open show of marching against , but actually with intent to subdue all  to his will.
Now you are rich in power, and as lord of  you rule what is not the least part of ; therefore, we beg of you, send help to those who are going to free , and aid them in so doing. The uniting of all those of  stock entails the mustering of a mighty host able to meet our invaders in the field. If, however, some of us play false and others will not come to our aid, while the sound part of  is but small, then it is to be feared that all  lands alike will be destroyed.
Do not for a moment think that if the  defeats us in battle and subdues us, he will leave you unassailed, but rather look well to yourself before that day comes. Aid us, and you champion your own cause; in general a well-laid plan leads to a happy issue.


This is what they said, and , speaking very vehemently, said in response to this: Men of , it is with a self-seeking plea that you have dared to come here and invite me to be your ally against the foreigners; yet what of yourselves?
When I was at odds with the , and asked you to be my comrades against a foreign army, and when I desired that you should avenge the slaying of  son of  on the men of , and when I promised to free those trading ports from which great advantage and profit have accrued to you,then neither for my sake would you come to aid nor to avenge the slaying of . Because of your position in these matters, all these lands lie beneath the foreigners' feet.
Let that be; for all ended well, and our state was improved. But now that the war has come round to you in your turn, it is time for remembering !
Despite the fact that you slighted me, I will not make an example of you; I am ready to send to your aid two hundred triremes, twenty thousand men-at-arms, two thousand horsemen, two thousand archers, two thousand slingers, and two thousand light-armed men to run with horsemen. I also pledge to furnish provisions for the whole  army until we have made an end of the war.
All this, however, I promise on one condition, that I shall be general and leader of the  against the foreigner. On no other condition will I come myself or send others.


When  heard that, he could not contain himself; In truth, he cried, loudly would  son of  lament, when hearing that the  had been bereft of their command by  and his ! No, rather, put the thought out of your minds that we will give up the command to you. If it is your will to aid , know that you must obey the ; but if, as I think, you are too proud to obey, then send no aid.


Thereupon , seeing how unfriendly ' words were, for the last time declared his opinion to them: My  friend, the hard words that a man hears are likely to arouse his anger; but for all the arrogant tenor of your speech you will not move me to make an unseemly answer.
When you set such store by the command, it is but reasonable that it should be still more important to me since I am the leader of an army many times greater than yours and more ships by far. But seeing that your response to me is so haughty, we will make some concession in our original condition. It might be that you should command the army, and I the fleet; or if it is your pleasure to lead by sea, then I am ready to take charge of the army. With that you will surely be content, unless you want depart from here without such allies as we are.


Such was 's offer, and the  envoy answered him before the  could speak. King of the , he said,  sends us to you to ask not for a leader but for an army. You however, say no word of sending an army without the condition of your being the leader of ; it is the command alone that you desire.
Now as long as you sought the leadership of the whole force, we  were content to hold our peace, knowing that the  was well able to answer for both of us; but since, failing to win the whole, you would gladly command the fleet, we want to let you know how the matter stands. Even if the  should permit you to command it, we would not do so, for the command of the fleet, which the  do not desire for themselves, is ours. If they should desire to lead it, we will not withstand them, but we will not allow anyone else to be admiral.
It would be for nothing, then, that we possess the greatest number of seafaring men in , if we  yield our command to ,we who can demonstrate the longest lineage of all and who alone among the  have never changed our place of habitation; of our stock too was the man of whom the poet Homer says that of all who came to , he was the best man in ordering and marshalling armies. We accordingly cannot be reproached for what we now say. 


My  friend,  answered, it would seem that you have many who lead, but none who will follow. Since, then, you will waive no claim but must have the whole, it is high time that you hasten home and tell your  that her year has lost its spring.

 The significance of this statement was that 's army was the most notable part of the  army, just as the spring is the best part of the year. He accordingly compared  deprived of alliance with him to a year bereft of its spring.


After such dealings with  the  envoys sailed away. , however, feared that the  would not be able to overcome the barbarian, while believing it dreadful and intolerable that he, the tyrant of , should go to the  to be at the beck and call of . For this reason he took no more thought of this plan but followed another instead.
As soon as he was informed that the  had crossed the , he sent  son of Scythes, a man of , to  with three fifty-oared ships, bringing them money and messages of friendship.  was to observe the outcome of the battle, and if the barbarian should be victorious, he was to give him both the money, and earth and water on behalf of 's dominions. If, however, the  were victorious, he was to bring everything back again.


This  had previously inherited from his father the tyranny of . Although the tyranny was well established, he nevertheless handed the government over to the whole body of  of his own free will. This he did under no constraint of danger, but out of a sense of justice, and he then went to , where he was given by the  the city of  which he colonized and changed its name to .
This is how  had come, and it was he whom  now sent because of his sense of justice. What I will now relate was not the least of the many just acts of ' life; he had in his possession great wealth entrusted to him by  and might have kept it. He nevertheless would not do so, but when the  had prevailed in the sea-fight and  had headed home,  returned to  with all that money.


There is, however, another story told by the : even though he was to be under  authority,  would still have aided the  had it not been for  son of , the tyrant of . This man, who had been expelled from  by  son of , sovereign ruler of , at this very time brought against  three hundred thousand , , , , , , and , led by  son of , the king of the .  had induced him to do this partly through the prerogative of personal friendship, but mainly through the efforts of  son of Cretines, tyrant of . He had handed over his own children as hostages to , and brought him into  to the help of his father-in-law; for  had as his wife ' daughter . Accordingly  sent the money to , because he could not aid the .


They add this tale toothat  and  won a victory over  the  in  on the same day that the  defeated the  at . This  was, on his father's side, a , and a  on his mother's and had been made king of  for his virtue. When the armies met and he was defeated in the battle, it is said that he vanished from sight, for  looked for him everywhere but was not able to find him anywhere on earth, dead or alive.


The story told by the  themselves seems to have some element of truth. They say that the barbarians fought with the  in  from dawn until late evening (so long, it is said, the battle was drawn out), during which time  stayed in his camp offering sacrifice and striving to obtain favorable omens by burning whole bodies on a great pyre. When he saw his army routed, he cast himself into the fire where he was pouring libations on the sacrifice; he was consumed by this and was not seen any more.
Whether he vanished as the  say, or in the manner related by the  and , sacrifice is offered to him, and monuments have been set up in all the colonists' cities, the greatest of which is in  itself.


This is how the campaign in  fell out. As for the , their answer to the envoys and their acts were as I will show. The men who had gone to  sought their aid too, using the same arguments which they had used with . The  straightaway promised to send help and protection, declaring that they would not allow  to perish, for if she should fall, the very next day would certainly see them also enslaved. They would accordingly have to help to the best of their ability.
Now this answer seemed fair enough, but when the time came for sending help, their minds changed. They manned sixty ships and put out to sea, making for the coast of the . There, however, they anchored off  and  in the  territory, waiting like the others to see which way the war should incline. They had no hope that the  would prevail, but thought that the  would win a great victory and be lord of all .
Their course of action, therefore, had been planned with a view to being able to say to the , O king, we whose power is as great as any and who could have furnished as many ships as any state save ,we, when the  attempted to gain our aid in this war, would not resist you nor do anything displeasing to you. This plea, they hoped, would win them some advantage more than ordinary; and so, I believe, it would have been.
They were, however, also ready with an excuse which they could make to the , and in the end they made it; when the  blamed them for sending no help, they said that they had manned sixty triremes, but that they could not round  because of the  winds. It was for this reason, they said, that they could not arrive at ; it was not cowardliness which made them late for the sea-fight. With such a plea they put the  off.


But the , when the  appointed to deal with them were trying to gain their aid, acted as I will show. They sent messengers to , inquiring if it would be to their advantage to help the .
The  answered them, Foolish men, was not the grief enough which  sent upon your people for the help given to , out of anger that those others would not help to avenge his death at , while you helped them to avenge the stealing of that woman from  by a barbarian? When this was brought to the ears of the , they would have nothing to do with aiding the .


Now , it is said, went to , which is now called , in search for , and perished there by a violent death. Presently all the  except the men of  and  were bidden by a god to go with a great host to . Here they besieged the town of , where in my day the men of  dwelt, for five years.
Presently, since they could neither take it nor remain there because of the famine which afflicted them, they departed. However, when they were at sea off , a great storm caught and drove them ashore. Because their ships had been wrecked and there was no way left of returning to , they founded there the town of , and made this their dwelling place, accordingly changing from  to  of , and from islanders to dwellers on the mainland.
From  they made settlements in those other towns which a very long time afterwards the  attempted to destroy, thereby suffering great disaster. The result was that no one has ever heard of so great a slaughter of  as that of the  and ; three thousand townsmen of the latter, men who had been coerced by  son of  to come and help the , were killed, and no count was kept of the  slain.

 was a servant of  and had been left in charge of ; it was he who was banished from  and settled in  of , and who set up those many statues at .


In relating the matter of the  and , however, I digress from the main thread of my history. The  say that when  was left desolate, it was populated especially by , among other peoples. Then, in the third generation after , the events surrounding the Trojan War, in which the  bore themselves as bravely as any in the cause of , took place.
After this, when they returned from , they and their flocks and herds were afflicted by famine and pestilence, until  was once more left desolate. Then came a third influx of , and it is they who, with those that were left, now dwell there. It was this that the priestess bade them remember, and so prevented them from aiding the  as they were previously inclined.


The  had at first sided with the , not willingly but of necessity. This their acts revealed, because they disliked the plans of the ; as soon as they heard that the  was about to cross over into , they sent messengers to the Isthmus, where men chosen from the cities which were best disposed towards  were assembled in council for the  cause.
To these the  messengers came and said, Men of , the pass of  must be guarded so that  and all  may be sheltered from the war. Now we are ready to guard it with you, but you too must send a great force. If you will not send it, be assured that we will make terms with the , for it is not right that we should be left to stand guard alone and so perish for your sakes.
If you will not send help, there is nothing you can do to constrain us, for no necessity can prevail over lack of ability. As for us, we will attempt to find some means of deliverance for ourselves. These are the words of the men of .


Thereupon the  resolved that they would send a land army to  by sea to guard the pass. When the forces had assembled, they passed through the  and came to  in , where they disembarked and took the road for , leaving their ships where they were. They then came to the pass of , which runs from the lower  into  along the river , between the mountains  and .
There the  were encamped, about ten thousand men-at-arms altogether, and the cavalry was there as well. The general of the  was  son of , chosen from among the , yet not of the royal house, and  son of  was the general of the .
They remained there for only a few days, for messengers came from  son of , the . These, pointing out the size of the army and the great number of ships, advised them to depart and not remain there to be trodden under foot by the invading host. When they had received this advice from the messengers (as they thought their advice was sound and that the  meant well by them), the  followed their counsel.
To my thinking, however, what persuaded them was fear, since they had found out that there was another pass leading into  by the hill country of  through the country of the , near the town of ; this was indeed the way by which ' army descended on . The  accordingly went down to their ships and made their way back to the Isthmus.


This was the course of their expedition into , while the king was planning to cross into  from  and was already at . The , now bereft of their allies, sided with the  wholeheartedly and unequivocally. As a result of this they, in their acts, proved themselves to be most useful to the king.


When they had come to the Isthmus, the , taking into account what was said by , deliberated as a body how and where they should stand to fight. It was decided that they should guard the pass of , for they saw that it was narrower than the pass into  and nearer home.
The pass, then, which brought about the fall of those  who fell at , was unknown to them until they came to  and learned of it from the men of . This pass they were resolved to guard and so stay the barbarian's passage into , while their fleet should sail to  in the territory of . These places are near to each other, and each force could therefore be informed of the other's doings. As for the places themselves, their nature is as follows.


 is where the wide  contracts until the passage between the island of  and the mainland of  is but narrow. This strait leads next to , which is a beach on the coast of , on which stands a temple of .
The pass through  into  is fifty feet wide at its narrowest point. It is not here, however, but elsewhere that the way is narrowest, namely, in front of  and behind it; at , which lies behind, it is only the breadth of a cart-way, and it is the same at the Phoenix stream, near the town of .
To the west of  rises a high mountain, inaccessible and precipitous, a spur of ; to the east of the road there is nothing but marshes and sea. In this pass are warm springs for bathing, called the Basins by the people of the country, and an altar of  stands nearby. Across this entry a wall had been built, and formerly there was a gate in it.
It was the  who built it for fear of the  when these came from  to dwell in the  land, the region which they now possess. Since the  were trying to subdue them, the  made this their protection, and in their search for every means to keep the  from invading their country, they then turned the stream from the hot springs into the pass, so that it might be a watercourse.
The ancient wall had been built long ago and most of it lay in ruins; those who built it up again thought that they would in this way bar the foreigner's way into . Very near the road is a village called , and it is from here that the  expected to obtain provisions.


These places, then, were thought by the  to suit their purpose. After making a thorough survey, they concluded that the barbarians could not make use of their entire army, nor of their horsemen. They therefore resolved, that they would meet the invader of  here. Then, when they heard that the  was in , they broke up from the Isthmus and set out with their army to  and with their fleet to .


So with all speed the  went their several ways to meet the enemy. In the meantime, the , who were afraid for themselves and for , consulted the god. They were advised to pray to the winds, for these would be potent allies for .
When they had received the oracle, the  first sent word of it to those  who desired to be free; because of their dread of the barbarian, they were forever grateful. Subsequently they erected an altar to the winds at , the present location of the precinct of  the daughter of , and they offered sacrifices to them. This, then, is the reason why the  to this day offer the winds sacrifice of propitiation.


' fleet, however, set forth from the city of , and the ten swiftest of the ships laid their course straight for , where there lay an advance guard of three  ships, a , an , and an Attic. These, when they sighted the foreigners ships, took to flight.


The ship of , of which  was captain, was pursued and straightway captured by the foreigners, who brought the best of its fighting men and cut his throat on the ship's prow, thinking that the sacrifice of the foremost and fairest of their  captives would be auspicious. The name of the sacrificed man was , and it was perhaps his name that he had to thank for it.


The  trireme, of which  was captain, did however give them some trouble. On board this ship was  son of , who acted heroically on that day. When his ship had been taken, he would not stop fighting until he had been entirely hacked to mincemeat.
When he finally did fall, he still had life in him, and the  soldiers on the ships took great pains to keep him alive for his valor, tending his wounds with ointments and wrapping him in bandages of linen cloth.
Upon returning to their own station, they showed him to the whole host, and made much of him and treated him with kindness. The rest of those whom they took in that ship, however, they used as slaves.


Two of the ships, then, were made captive, and the third trireme, of which  an  was captain, ran aground in her flight at the mouth of the ; the barbarians took her hull but not the crew, for the , as soon as they had run their craft aground, leapt out and made their way through  to .


The  who were stationed at  were informed of these matters by beacons from . They were frightened by this and accordingly changed their anchorage from  to , proposing to guard the  and leaving watchmen on the heights of .
Three of the ten barbarian ships ran aground on the reef called the Ant, which lies between  and . The barbarians then brought a pillar of stone and set it on the reef, and when their course was plain before them, the whole fleet set forth and sailed from , eleven days after the king had marched from there.
It was  of  who showed them where in the strait the reef lay. After sailing along all day, the foreign fleet reached  in  and the beach between the town of  and the  headland.


Until the whole host reached this place and  it suffered no hurt, and calculation proves to me that its numbers were still such as I will now show. The ships from  were twelve hundred and seven in number, and including the entire host of nations involved, there were a total of two hundred and forty-one thousand and four hundred men, two hundred being reckoned for each ship.

On board all these ships were thirty fighting men of the  and  and  in addition to the company which each had of native fighters; the number of this added contingent is thirty-six thousand, two hundred and ten.
To this and to the first number I add the crews of the ships of fifty oars, calculating eighty men for each, whether there were actually more or fewer. Now seeing that, as has already been said, three thousand of these vessels were assembled, the number of men in them must have been two hundred and forty thousand.
These, then, were the ships' companies from , and the total number of them was five hundred and seventeen thousand, six hundred and ten. There were seven hundred thousand and one hundred footsoldiers and eighty thousand cavalrymen; to these I add the  camel-riders and  charioteers, estimating them to have been twenty thousand in number.
The forces of sea and land added together would consist of two million, three hundred and seventeen thousand, six hundred and ten men. So far I have spoken of the force which came from  itself, without the train of servants which followed it and the companies of the grain-bearing craft.


I must, however, also take into account the force brought from , and I will rely on my best judgment in doing so. The  of  and the islands off  furnished one hundred and twenty ships, and the companies of these ships must then have consisted of twenty-four thousand men.
As regards the land army supplied by all the nations, , , , , , , , , , , , , dwellers on the coast of of all these I suppose the number to have been three hundred thousand.
When these numbers are added to the numbers from , the sum total of fighting men is two million, six hundred and forty-one thousand, six hundred and ten.


This then is the number of soldiers. As for the service-train which followed them and the crews of the light corn-bearing vessels and all the other vessels besides which came by sea with the force, these I believe to have been not fewer but more than the fighting men.
Suppose, however, that they were equal in number, neither more nor fewer. If they were equal to the fighting contingent, they made up as many tens of thousands as the others. The number, then, of those whom  son of  led as far as the  headland and  was five million, two hundred and eighty-three thousand, two hundred and twenty.


That is the number of ' whole force. No one, however, can say what the exact number of cooking women, and concubines, and eunuchs was, nor can one determine the number of the beasts of draught and burden, and the  dogs which accompanied the host; so many of them were there. It is accordingly not surprising to me that some of the streams of water ran dry. I do, however, wonder how there were provisions sufficient for so many tens of thousands,

for calculation shows me, that if each man received one choenix of wheat a day and no more, eleven hundred thousand and three hundred and forty bushels would be required every day. In this calculation I take no account of the provisions for the women, eunuchs, beasts of burden and dogs. Of all those tens of thousands of men, there was not one, as regards looks and grandeur, worthier than  himself to hold that command.


The  fleet put to sea and reached the beach of the  land, between the city of  and the headland of Sepia. The first ships to arrive moored close to land, with the others after them at anchor; since the beach was not large, they lay at anchor in rows eight ships deep out into the sea.
They spent the night in this way, but at dawn a storm descended upon them out of a clear and windless sky, and the sea began to boil. A strong east wind blew, which the people living in those parts call .
Those who felt the wind rising or had proper mooring dragged their ships up on shore ahead of the storm and so survived with their ships. The wind did, however, carry those ships caught out in the open sea against the rocks called the Ovens at  or onto the beach. Some ships were wrecked on the  headland, others were cast ashore at the city of  or at . The storm was indeed unbearable.


The story is told that because of an oracle the  invoked , the north wind, to help them, since another oracle told them to summon their son-in-law as an ally. According to the  story,  had an Attic wife, , the daughter of , ancient king of .
Because of this connection, so the tale goes, the  considered  to be their son-in-law. They were stationed off  in , and when they saw the storm rising, they then, if they had not already, sacrificed to and called upon  and  to help them by destroying the barbarian fleet, just as before at .
I cannot say whether this was the cause of  falling upon the barbarians as they lay at anchor, but the  say that he had come to their aid before and that he was the agent this time. When they went home, they founded a sacred precinct of  beside the .


They say that at the very least no fewer than 400 ships were destroyed in this labor, along with innumerable men and abundant wealth. This shipwreck proved useful to  son of , a man of  who owned land around , for he later picked up many gold and silver cups cast up on shore, found the  treasures, and acquired other untold riches. Although he became very rich from his findings, he did not enjoy luck in everything, for he suffered greatly when his son was murdered.


There was no counting how many grain-ships and other vessels were destroyed. The generals of the fleet were afraid that the  might attack them now that they had been defeated, so they built a high palisade out of the wreckage.
The storm lasted three days. Finally the  made offerings and cast spells upon the wind, sacrificing also to  and the . In this way they made the wind stop on the fourth dayor perhaps it died down on its own. They sacrificed to  after hearing from the  the story that it was from this place that  had carried her off and that all the headland of Sepia belonged to her and to the other .


The storm, then, ceased on the fourth day. Now the scouts stationed on the headlands of  ran down and told the  all about the shipwreck on the second day after the storm began.
After hearing this they prayed to  as their savior and poured libations. Then they hurried to  hoping to find few ships opposing them. So they came to  a second time and made their station there. From that time on they call  their savior.


The barbarians, when the wind ceased and the waves no longer ran high, put to sea and coasted along the mainland; they sailed around the headland of  and sailed straight into the gulf which stretches toward .
There is a place on this gulf in , where, it is said,  was sent for water and was left behind by  and his comrades of the , when they were sailing to  in  for the fleece; their purpose was to draw water from there and then to put out to sea. This is the reason why that place has been called . Here ' men made their anchorage.


Fifteen of those ships had put to sea a long time after all the rest, and it chanced that they sighted the  ships off . Supposing these to be their own fleet, the barbarians proceeded into the midst of their enemies. Their captain was the viceroy from  in ,  son of . This man, who was one of the king's judges, had once before been taken and crucified by  because he had given unjust judgment for a bribe.
When  had been hung on the cross,  found on consideration that his good services to the royal house outweighed his offenses. The king then perceived that he had acted with more haste than wisdom and set  free.
In this way he escaped from being put to death by . Now that he was taken into the midst of the , however, he was not to escape a second time, for when the  saw the  bearing down on them, they perceived their mistake and putting to sea, easily took them captive.


In one of these ships they took , the tyrant of  in , and in another the  captain , son of Demonous; of the twelve ships which he had brought from  he had lost eleven in the storm off the  headland and was in the one which remained when he was taken as he headed down on . Having questioned these men and learned what they desired to know of ' force, the  sent them away to the isthmus of  in bonds.


So the foreign fleet, of which, with the exception of fifteen ships  was captain, came to .  and his land army marched through  and , and it was three days since he had entered . In  he held a race for his own cavalry; this was also a test of the  horsemen, whom he had heard were the best in . The  horses were far outpaced in this contest. Of the  rivers, the  was the only one which could not provide enough water for his army to drink. In , however, even the greatest river there, the , gave out, remaining but a sorry trickle.


When  had come to  in , his guides, desiring to inform him of all they knew, told him the story which is related in that country concerning the worship of , namely how  son of  plotted ' death with , and further, how the  by an oracle's bidding compel  descendants to certain tasks.
They order the eldest of that family not to enter their town-hall (which the  call the ) and themselves keep watch there. If he should enter, he may not come out, save only to be sacrificed. They say as well that many of those who were to be sacrificed had fled in fear to another country, and that if they returned at a later day and were taken, they were brought into the town-hall. The guides showed  how the man is sacrificed, namely with fillets covering him all over and a procession to lead him forth.
It is the descendants of ' son  who are treated in this way, because when the  by an oracle's bidding made  son of  a scapegoat for their country and were about to sacrifice him, this  came from  in  and delivered him, thereby bringing the god's wrath on his own descendants.
Hearing all this, , when he came to the temple grove, refrained from entering it himself and bade all his army do likewise, holding the house and the precinct of ' descendants alike in reverence.


These were ' actions in  and . From here he came into  along a gulf of the sea, in which the tide ebbs and flows daily. There is low-lying ground about this gulf, sometimes wide and sometimes very narrow, and around it stand high and inaccessible mountains which enclose the whole of  and are called the Rocks of .
Now the first town by the gulf on the way from  is , near to which the river  flows from the country of the  and issues into the sea. About twenty furlongs from that river is another named , which is said to have risen from the ground to aid  against the fire that consumed him and twenty furlongs again from that there is another river called the .


The town of  is five furlongs away from this . Here is the greatest distance in all this region between the sea and the hills on which  stands, for the plain is twenty-two thousand plethra in extent. In the mountains which hem in the  land there is a ravine to the south of , through which the river  flows past the lower slopes of the mountains.


There is another river south of the , the , a little stream which flows from those mountains into the . Near this stream is the narrowest place; there is only space for a single cart-way.  is fifteen furlongs away from the river Phoenix.
Between the river and  there is a village named , past which the  flows out into the sea, and there is a wide space around it in which stand a temple of , seats for the , and a temple of  himself


 lay encamped in  in  and the  in the pass. This place is called  by most of the , but by the natives and their neighbors . Each lay encamped in these places.  was master of everything to the north from , and the  of all that lay toward the south on the mainland.


The  who awaited the  in that place were these: three hundred  armed men; one thousand from  and , half from each place; one hundred and twenty from  in  and one thousand from the rest of ; that many , four hundred from , two hundred from , and eighty . These were the  present; from  there were seven hundred  and four hundred .


In addition, the  in full force and one thousand  came at the summons. The  had called upon them through messengers who told them that this was only the advance guard, that the rest of the allies were expected any day now, and that the sea was being watched, with the  and  and all those enrolled in the fleet on guard. There was nothing for them to be afraid of.
The invader of  was not a god but a human being, and there was not, and never would be, any mortal on whom some amount of evil was not bestowed at birth, with the greatest men receiving the largest share. The one marching against them was certain to fall from pride, since he was a mortal. When they heard this, the  and  marched to  to help.


Each city had its own general, but the one most admired and the leader of the whole army was a , , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of , son of .  had gained the kingship at  unexpectedly.


Since he had two older brothers,  and , he had renounced all thought of the kingship. , however, died without male offspring, and , who had met his end in , was also no longer alive. The succession therefore fell to  since he was older than ' youngest son  and had married ' daughter.
He now came to  with the appointed three hundred he had selected, all of whom had sons. He also brought those  whom I counted among the number and whose general was  son of .

 took pains to bring only the  among the , because they were accused of medizing; he summoned them to the war wishing to know whether they would send their men with him or openly refuse the  alliance. They sent the men but intended something quite different


The  sent the men with  on ahead so that the rest of the allies would see them and march, instead of medizing like the others if they learned that the  were delaying. At present the  was in their way, but once they had completed the festival, they intended to leave a garrison at  and march out in full force with all speed.
The rest of the allies planned to do likewise, for the  coincided with these events. They accordingly sent their advance guard, not expecting the war at  to be decided so quickly.


This is what they intended, but the  at , when the  drew near the pass, fearfully took counsel whether to depart. The rest of the  were for returning to the  and guarding the isthmus, but the  and  were greatly angered by this counsel.  voted to remain where they were and send messengers to the cities bidding them to send help, since they were too few to ward off the army of the .


While they debated in this way,  sent a mounted scout to see how many there were and what they were doing. While he was still in , he had heard that a small army was gathered there and that its leaders were , including , who was of the  clan.
Riding up to the camp, the horseman watched and spied out the place. He could, however, not see the whole camp, for it was impossible to see those posted inside the wall which they had rebuilt and were guarding. He did take note of those outside, whose arms lay in front of the wall, and it chanced that at that time the  were posted there.
He saw some of the men exercising naked and others combing their hair. He marvelled at the sight and took note of their numbers. When he had observed it all carefully, he rode back in leisure, since no one pursued him or paid him any attention at all. So he returned and told  all that he had seen.


When  heard that, he could not comprehend the fact that the  were actually, to the best of their ability, preparing to kill or be killed. What they did appeared laughable to him, so he sent for  the son of , who was in his camp.
When this man arrived, he asked him about each of these matters, wanting to understand what it was that the  were doing.  said, You have already heard about these men from me, when we were setting out for , but when you heard, you mocked me, although I told you how I expected things to turn out. It is my greatest aim, O King, to be truthful in your presence.
So hear me now. These men have come to fight us for the pass, and it for this that they are preparing. This is their custom: when they are about to risk their lives, they arrange their hair.
Rest assured that if you overcome these men and those remaining behind at , there is no one else on earth who will raise his hands to withstand you, my King. You are now attacking the fairest kingdom in  and men who are the very best.
What he said seemed completely incredible to , so he then asked how they, who were so few in number, would fight against his army.  answered, My King, take me for a liar if this does not turn out as I say. So he spoke, but he did not persuade .


He let four days go by, expecting them to run away at any minute. They did not leave, and it seemed to him that they stayed out of folly and lack of due respect. On the fifth day he became angry and sent the  and  against them, bidding them take them prisoner and bring them into his presence.
The  bore down upon the  and attacked. Many fell, but others attacked in turn, and they made it clear to everyone, especially to the king himself, that among so many people there were few real men. The battle lasted all day.


When the  had been roughly handled, they retired, and the  whom the king called Immortals, led by , attacked in turn. It was thought that they would easily accomplish the task.
When they joined battle with the , they fared neither better nor worse than the Median army, since they used shorter spears than the  and could not use their numbers fighting in a narrow space.
The  fought memorably, showing themselves skilled fighters amidst unskilled on many occasions, as when they would turn their backs and feign flight. The barbarians would see them fleeing and give chase with shouting and noise, but when the  were overtaken, they would turn to face the barbarians and overthrow innumerable . A few of the  themselves were also slain. When the  could gain no inch of the pass, attacking by companies and in every other fashion, they withdrew.


It is said that during these assaults in the battle the king, as he watched, jumped up three times from the throne in fear for his army. This, then, is how the fighting progressed, and on the next day the barbarians fought no better. They joined battle supposing that their enemies, being so few, were now disabled by wounds and could no longer resist.
The , however, stood ordered in ranks by nation, and each of them fought in turn, except the , who were posted on the mountain to guard the path. When the  found nothing different from what they saw the day before, they withdrew.


The king was at a loss as to how to deal with the present difficulty.  son of , a , thinking he would get a great reward from the king, came to speak with him and told him of the path leading over the mountain to . In so doing he caused the destruction of the  remaining there.
Later he fled into  in fear of the , and while he was in exile, a price was put on his head by the  when the  assembled at . Still later he returned from exile to  and was killed by , a .

 slew  for a different reason, which I will tell later in my history, but he was given no less honor by the . It was in this way, then, that  was later killed.


There is another story told, namely that  son of , a , and  of  are the ones who gave the king this information and guided the  around the mountain, but I find it totally incredible.
One must judge by the fact that the  set a price not on  and  but on  the , and I suppose they had exact knowledge; furthermore, we know that  was banished on this charge.

 might have known the path, although he was not a , if he had often come to that country, but  was the one who guided them along the path around the mountain. It is he whom I put on record as guilty.


 was pleased by what  promised to accomplish. He immediately became overjoyed and sent out  and the men under  command, who set forth from the camp at about lamp-lighting time. This path had been discovered by the native , who used it to guide the  into  when the  had fenced off the pass with a wall and were sheltered from the war. So long ago the  had discovered that the pass was in no way a good thing.


The course of the path is as follows: it begins at the river  as it flows through the ravine, and this mountain and the path have the same name, . This  stretches along the ridge of the mountain and ends at , the  city nearest to , near the rock called  and the seats of the , where it is narrowest.


This, then, was the nature of the pass. The  crossed the  and travelled all night along this path, with the  on their right and the  on their left. At dawn they came to the summit of the pass.

 In this part of the mountain one thousand armed men of the  were on watch, as I have already shown, defending their own country and guarding the path. The lower pass was held by those I have mentioned, but the  had voluntarily promised  to guard the path over the mountain.


The  learned in the following way that the  had climbed up: they had ascended without the ' notice because the mountain was entirely covered with oak trees. Although there was no wind, a great noise arose like leaves being trodden underfoot. The  jumped up and began to put on their weapons, and in a moment the barbarians were there.
When they saw the men arming themselves, they were amazed, for they had supposed that no opposition would appear, but they had now met with an army.  feared that the  might be  and asked  what country the army was from. When he had established what he wanted to know with certainty, he arrayed the  for battle.
The , assailed by thick showers of arrows and supposing that the  had set out against them from the start, fled to the top of the mountain and prepared to meet their destruction. This is what they intended, but the  with  and  paid no attention to the  and went down the mountain as fast as possible.


The seer , examining the sacrifices, first told the  at  that death was coming to them with the dawn. Then deserters came who announced the circuit made by the . These gave their signals while it was still night; a third report came from the watchers running down from the heights at dawn.
The  then took counsel, but their opinions were divided. Some advised not to leave their post, but others spoke against them. They eventually parted, some departing and dispersing each to their own cities, others preparing to remain there with .


It is said that  himself sent them away because he was concerned that they would be killed, but felt it not fitting for himself and the  to desert that post which they had come to defend at the beginning.
I, however, tend to believe that when  perceived that the allies were dispirited and unwilling to run all risks with him, he told then to depart. For himself, however, it was not good to leave; if he remained, he would leave a name of great fame, and the prosperity of  would not be blotted out.
When the  asked the oracle about this war when it broke out, the  had foretold that either  would be destroyed by the barbarians or their king would be killed. She gave them this answer in hexameter verses running as follows:



Considering this and wishing to win distinction for the  alone, he sent away the allies rather than have them leave in disorder because of a difference of opinion.


Not the least proof I have of this is the fact that  publicly dismissed the seer who attended the expedition, for fear that he might die with them. This was  the , said to be descended from , the one who told from the sacrifices what was going to happen to them. He was dismissed but did not leave; instead he sent away his only son who was also with the army.


Those allies who were dismissed went off in obedience to , only the  and  remaining with the . The  remained against their will and desire, for  kept them as hostages. The  very gladly remained, saying they would not abandon  and those with him by leaving; instead they would stay and die with them. Their general was  son of .


 made libations at sunrise and waiting till about mid-morning, made his assault.  had advised this, for the descent from the mountain is more direct, and the way is much shorter than the circuit and ascent.

 and his barbarians attacked, but  and his , knowing they were going to their deaths, advanced now much farther than before into the wider part of the pass. In all the previous days they had sallied out into the narrow way and fought there, guarding the defensive wall.
Now, however, they joined battle outside the narrows and many of the barbarians fell, for the leaders of the companies beat everyone with whips from behind, urging them ever forward. Many of them were pushed into the sea and drowned; far more were trampled alive by each other, with no regard for who perished.
Since the  knew that they must die at the hands of those who had come around the mountain, they displayed the greatest strength they had against the barbarians, fighting recklessly and desperately.


By this time most of them had had their spears broken and were killing the  with swords. , proving himself extremely valiant, fell in that struggle and with him other famous , whose names I have learned by inquiry since they were worthy men. Indeed, I have learned by inquiry the names of all three hundred.
Many famous  also fell there, including two sons of ,  and , born to  by  daughter of .  was the brother of king  and son of  son of . When he gave his daughter in marriage to , he gave his whole house as dowry, since she was his only child.


Two brothers of  accordingly fought and fell there. There was a great struggle between the  and  over ' body, until the  by their courageous prowess dragged it away and routed their enemies four times. The battle went on until the men with  arrived.
When the  saw that they had come, the contest turned, for they retired to the narrow part of the way, passed behind the wall, and took their position crowded together on the hill, all except the . This hill is at the mouth of the pass, where the stone lion in honor of  now stands.
In that place they defended themselves with swords, if they still had them, and with hands and teeth. The barbarians buried them with missiles, some attacking from the front and throwing down the defensive wall, others surrounding them on all sides.


This then is how the  and  conducted themselves, but the   is said to have exhibited the greatest courage of all. They say that he made the following speech before they joined battle with the : he had learned from a  that there were so many of the barbarians that when they shot their missiles, the sun was hidden by the multitude of their arrows.
He was not at all disturbed by this and made light of the multitude of the , saying that their  foreigner brought them good news. If the  hid the sun, they could fight them in the shade instead of in the sun. This saying and others like it, they claim,  the  left behind as a memorial.


Next after him two  brothers,  and , sons of , are said to have been most courageous. The  who gained most renown was one whose name was  son of .


There is an inscription written over these men, who were buried where they fell, and over those who died before the others went away, dismissed by . It reads as follows:




That inscription is for them all, but the  have their own: 




That one is to the , this one to the seer: 




Except for the seer's inscription, the  are the ones who honored them by erecting inscriptions and pillars. That of the seer  was inscribed by  son of  because of his tie of guest-friendship with the man.


It is said that two of these three hundred,  and , could have agreed with each other either to come home safely together to , since  had dismissed them from the camp and they were lying at  very sick of ophthalmia, or to die with the others, if they were unwilling to return home. They could have done either of these things, but they could not agree and had different intentions. When  learned of the  circuit, he demanded his armor and put it on, bidding his helot to lead him to the fighting. The helot led him there and fled, but he rushed into the fray and was killed. , however, lost his strength and stayed behind.
Now if  alone had been sick and returned to , or if they had both made the trip, I think the  would not have been angry with them. When, however, one of them died, and the other had the same excuse but was unwilling to die, the  had no choice but to display great anger towards .


Some say that  came home safely to  in this way and by this excuse. Others say that he had been sent out of the camp as a messenger and could have gotten back in time for the battle but chose not to, staying behind on the road and so surviving, while his fellow-messenger arrived at the battle and was killed.


When  returned to , he was disgraced and without honor. He was deprived of his honor in this way: no  would give him fire or speak with him, and they taunted him by calling him . In the battle at , however, he made up for all the blame brought against him.


It is said that another of the three hundred survived because he was sent as a messenger to . His name was . When he returned to , he was dishonored and hanged himself.


The , whose general was , fought against the king's army as long as they were with the  and under compulsion. When, however, they saw the  side prevailing and the  with  hurrying toward the hill, they split off and approached the barbarians, holding out their hands. With the most truthful words ever spoken, they explained that they were Medizers, had been among the first to give earth and water to the king, had come to  under constraint, and were guiltless of the harm done to the king.
By this plea they saved their lives, and the  bore witness to their words. They were not, however, completely lucky. When the barbarians took hold of them as they approached, they killed some of them even as they drew near. Most of them were branded by  command with the kings marks, starting with the general . His son  long afterwards was murdered by the  when, as general of four hundred , he seized the town of .


This, then, is how the  fought at .  then sent for  and questioned him, saying first,  you are a good man. I hold that proven by the plain truth, for things have turned out no differently than you foretold. Now, tell me this: how many  are left, and how many of them are warriors like these? or is it so with them all?

My king, said , the number of the  is great, and so too the number of their cities. But what you would like to know, I will tell you: there is in  a city called , a city of about eight thousand men, all of them equal to those who have fought here; the rest of the  are not equal to these, yet they are valiant men.

And how, , answered , can we overcome those men with the least trouble to ourselves? Come, disclose that to me, for you have been their king and know the plan and order of their counsels.


My king,  replied, if you in sincerity ask my counsel, it is but right that I should point out to you the best way. It is this, namely that you should send three hundred ships of your fleet to the  land.
There is an island lying off their coasts called . , a man of much wisdom among us, says about it that it would be better for the  if  were beneath the sea rather than above it. This he said because he expected that it would provide an opportunity for attack just as I am suggestingnot that he had any foreknowledge of your force, but he dreaded all men's forces alike.
Let them then make that island their station and set out from there to strike fear into the . If these have a war of their own on their borders, you will have no cause to fear that they will send men to save the rest of  from being overrun by your armies; furthermore, the enslavement of the rest of  must weaken  if it is left to stand alone.
If, however, you do not do this, then expect what I will now tell you: a narrow isthmus leads to the ; all the  will be banded together there against you, and you may expect battles more stubborn than those that you have fought already. But if you do as I have said, then you may have that isthmus and all their cities without striking a blow.


Next spoke , ' brother and admiral of the fleet; it chanced that he was present during their conversation, and he feared that  would be persuaded to follow ' counsel. O king, he said, I see that you are listening to a man who is jealous of your good fortune or is perhaps even a traitor to your cause. These are the ways that are dear to the hearts of all : they are jealous of success and they hate power.
No, if after the recent calamity which has wrecked four hundred of your ships you send away three hundred more from your fleet to sail round the , your enemies will be enough to do battle with you; while your fleet is united, however, it is invincible, and your enemies will not be so many as to be enough to fight; moreover, all your navy will be a help to your army and your army to your navy, both moving together. If you separate some of your fleet from yourself, you will be of no use to them, nor they to you.
My counsel is rather that you make your own plans well, and take no account of the business of your adversaries, what battlefields they will choose, what they will do, and how many they are. They are able enough to think for themselves, and we similarly for ourselves. As for the , if they meet the  in the field, they will in no way repair their most recent losses.


,  answered, I think that you speak well, and I will do as you counsel. Despite the fact that your advice is better than his,  does say what he supposes to be most serviceable to me,

for assuredly I will never believe that he is no friend to my cause. I believe this of him because of all that he has already said and by what is the truth, namely, that if one citizen prospers, another citizen is jealous of him and shows his enmity by silence, and no one, (except if he has attained the height of excellence; and such are seldom seen) if his own townsman asks for counsel, will give him what he thinks to be the best advice.
If one stranger prospers, however, another stranger is beyond all men his well-wisher and will, if he is asked, impart to him the best counsel he has. It is for this reason that I bid you all to refrain from maligning , seeing that he is a stranger and a friend.


Having spoken in this way,  passed over the place where the dead lay and hearing that  had been king and general of the , he gave orders to cut off his head and impale it.
It is plain to me by this piece of evidence among many others, that while  lived, king  was more incensed against him than against all others; otherwise he would never have dealt so outrageously with his dead body, for the  are beyond all men known in the habit of honoring valiant warriors. They, then, who received these orders did as I have said.


I return now to that place in my history where it earlier left off. The  were the first to be informed that the king was equipping himself to attack ; with this knowledge it was that they sent to the oracle at , where they received the answer about which I spoke a little while ago. Now the way in which they were informed of this was strange.

 son of , an exile among the , was, as I suppose (reason being also my ally), no friend to the , and I leave it to be imagined whether what he did was done out of goodwill or spiteful triumph. When  was resolved to march against , , who was then at  and had knowledge of this, desired to send word of it to the .
He, however, feared detection and had no other way of informing them than this trick:taking a double tablet, he scraped away the wax from it, and then wrote the king's plan on the wood. Next he melted the wax back again over the writing, so that the bearer of this seemingly blank tablet might not be troubled by the way-wardens.
When the tablet came to , the  could not guess its meaning, until at last (as I have been told) , ' daughter and ' wife, discovered the trick herself and advised them to scrape the wax away so that they would find writing on the wood. When they did so, they found and read the message, and presently sent it to the rest of the . This is the story, as it is told.

l.#text: Then take care to keep bleating goats far from the coasts of

Will redden the sea with blood. To  the day of freedom
