l: But this was to happen after the king had marched away.

p.#text:
The  appointed to serve in the fleet were these: the  furnished a hundred and twenty-seven ships; the  manned these ships with the , not that they had any knowledge of seamanship, but because of mere valor and zeal. The  furnished forty ships and the  twenty;

the  manned twenty, the  furnishing the ships; the  eighteen, the  twelve, the  ten, the  eight, the  seven, the  five, the  two, and the  two, and two fifty-oared barks; the  brought seven fifty-oared barks to their aid.


These are the forces which came to  for battle, and I have now shown how they individually furnished the whole sum. The number of ships mustered at  was two hundred and seventy-one, besides the fifty-oared barks.
The , however, provided the admiral who had the chief command, , son of , for the allies said that if the  were not their leader, they would rather make an end of the fleet that was assembling than be led by the .


In the first days, before the sending to  for alliance, there had been talk of entrusting the command at sea to the . However, when the allies resisted, the  waived their claim, considering the safety of  of prime importance and seeing that if they quarrelled over the leadership,  must perish. In this they judged rightly, for civil strife is as much worse than united war as war is worse than peace.
Knowing that, they gave ground and waived their claim, but only so long as they had great need of the others. This is clear, for when they had driven the  back and the battle was no longer for their territory but for his, they made a pretext of ' highhandedness and took the command away from the . All that, however, took place later.


But now, the  who had at last come to  saw a multitude of ships launched at  and forces everywhere, and contrary to all expectation, the barbarian was shown to be in much different shape than they had supposed. They accordingly lost heart and began to deliberate about flight from  homewards into .
Then the , noticing that they were making such plans, entreated  to wait a little while, till they themselves had removed their children and households. When they could not prevail with him, they tried another way and gave , the  admiral, a bribe of thirty talents on the condition that the  fleet should remain there and fight, when they fought, to defend .


This was the way in which  made the  stay where they were: he gave  for his share five talents of that money, as though he were making the present of his own money. When  had been won over in this way, none of the rest was inclined to resist save , son of , the  admiral, who said that he would not remain but sail away from ; to him , adding an oath, said:

No, you of all men will not desert us, for I will give you a greater gift than the king of the  would send you for deserting your allies. With that he sent three talents of silver to  ship.
These two, then, were won over by gifts, the  got what they wanted, and  himself was the gainer. No one knew that he had kept the rest of the money, and those who had received a part of it supposed that it had been sent for that purpose by the .


So the  remained in  and fought there; this came about as I will now reveal. Having arrived at  in the early part of the afternoon, the barbarians saw for themselves the few  ships that they had already heard were stationed off , and they were eager to attack so that they might take them.
They were not prepared to make a head-on attack since they feared that the  would see them coming and turn to flee with night close upon them as they fled; it was their belief that the  would save themselves by flight, and they did not want even so much as a firebearer to be saved.


Taking these things into consideration, they devised the following plan; separating two hundred ships from the whole number, they sent them to cruise outside  so that the enemies might not see them sailing round  and by way of  round  to the  so that they might catch the  between them, the one part holding that course and barring the retreat, and they themselves attacking in front.
Upon making these plans they sent the appointed ships on their way, intending not to make an attack upon the  either on that day or before the signal should be seen, whereby the ships that sailed round were to declare their coming. So they sent those ships to sail round, and set about counting the rest at .


Now when they were engaged in this count, there was in the fleet one , a man of ; he was the best diver of the time, and in the shipwreck at  he had saved for the  much of their possessions and gotten much for himself in addition; this  had before now, it would seem, intended to desert to the , but he never had had so fair an occasion as now.
By what means he did at last make his way to the , I cannot with exactness say. If the story is true, it is marvellous indeed, for it is said that he dove into the sea at  and never rose to the surface till he came to , thus passing underneath the sea for about eighty furlongs.
There are many tales about this man, some similar to lies and some true, but as regards the present business it is my opinion that he came to  in a boat. After arriving, he straightway told the admirals the story of the shipwreck, and of the ships that had been sent round .


Hearing that, the  took counsel together; there was much talk, but the opinion prevailed that they should remain and encamp where they were for that day, and then, after midnight, to put to sea and meet the ships which were sailing around. Presently, however, meeting with no opposition, they waited for the late afternoon of the day and themselves advanced their ships against the barbarian, desiring to put to the proof his fashion of fighting and the art of breaking the line.


When ' men and their generals saw the  bearing down on them with but a few ships, they thought that they were definitely mad and put out to sea themselves, thinking that they would win an easy victory; this expectation was very reasonable, since they saw that the  ships so few while their own were many times more numerous and more seaworthy. With this assurance, they hemmed in the  in their midst.
Now all the  who were friendly to the  came unwillingly to the war and were distressed to see the  surrounded. They supposed that not one of them would return home, so powerless did the  seem to them to be.
Those who were glad about the business, however, vied each with each that he might be the first to take an Attic ship and receive gifts from the king, for it was the  of whom there was most talk in the fleet.


But the , when the signal was given them, first drew the sterns of their ships together, their prows turned towards the foreigners; then at the second signal they put their hands to the work, despite the fact that they were hemmed in within a narrow space and were fighting face-to-face.
There they took thirty of the foreigners ships as well as the brother of  king of ,  son of , a man of note in the fleet. The first  to take an enemy ship was an , , son of , and he it was who received the prize for valor.
They fought that sea-fight with doubtful issue, and nightfall ended the battle; the  sailed back to , and the barbarians to , after faring far below their hopes in the fight. In that battle  of , the only one of the  siding with the , deserted to the , and for that the  gave him land in .


When darkness came on, the season being then midsummer, there was abundance of rain all through the night and violent thunderings from . The dead and the wrecks were driven towards , where they were entangled with the ships' prows and jumbled the blades of the oars.
The ships crews who were there were dismayed by the noise of this, and considering their present bad state, expected utter destruction; for before they had recovered from the shipwreck and the storm off , they next endured a stubborn sea-fight, and after the sea-fight, rushing rain and mighty torrents pouring seaward and violent thunderings.


This is how the night dealt with them. To those who were appointed to sail round , however, that same night was still more cruel since it caught them on the open sea. Their end was a terrible one, for when the storm and the rain came on them in their course off the Hollows of , they were driven by the wind in an unknown direction and were driven onto the rocks. All this was done by the god so that the  power might be more equally matched with the , and not much greater than it.


These men, then, perished at the Hollows of . As for the barbarians at , when to their great comfort the day dawned, they kept their ships unmoved, being in their evil plight well content to do nothing for the moment. Now fifty-three Attic ships came to aid the ,

who were encouraged both by the ships coming and by the news that the barbarians sailing round  had all perished in the recent storm. They waited then for the same hour as before, and fell upon certain  ships when they put to sea. After destroying these when night fell, they sailed back to .


On the third day, however, the barbarian admirals, finding it hard to bear that so few ships should do them hurt and fearing ' anger, waited no longer for the  to begin the fight, but gave the word and put out to sea about midday. So it came to pass that these sea-battles were fought on the same days as the land-battles at ;

the seamen's whole endeavor was to hold the  while ' men strove to guard the passage; the  were ordered to give the barbarian no entry into , and the  to destroy the  host and win the strait.


So when ' men ordered their battle and advanced, the  remained in their station off , and the barbarians made a half circle of their ships striving to encircle and enclose them. At that the  charged and joined battle. In that sea-fight both had equal success.

' fleet did itself harm by its numbers and size. The ships were thrown into confusion and ran foul of each other; nevertheless they held fast and did not yield, for they could not bear to be put to flight by a few ships.
Many were the  ships and men that perished there, and far more yet of the foreigners' ships and men; this is how they fought until they drew off and parted from each other.


In that sea-fight of all ' fighters the  conducted themselves with the greatest valor; besides other great feats of arms which they achieved, they took five  ships together with their crews. As regards the , it was the  who bore themselves best on that day, and of the  son of . He brought to the war two hundred men and a ship of his own, all at his own expense.


So they parted, and each hurried gladly to his own place of anchorage. When the  had withdrawn and come out of the battle, they were left in possession of the dead and the wrecks. They had, however, had a rough time of it themselves, chiefly the , half of whose ships had suffered some damage. Now their counsel was to flee to the inner waters of 


 thought that if the  and  nations were removed from the forces of the barbarians, the  might be strong enough to prevail over the rest. Now it was the custom of the  to drive their flocks down to the sea there. Gathering the admirals together, he told them that he thought he had a device whereby he hoped to draw away the best of the king's allies.
So much he revealed for the moment, but merely advised them to let everyone slay as many from the  flocks as he wanted; it was better that the fleet should have them, than the enemy. Moreover, he counselled them each to order his men to light a fire; as for the time of their departure from that place, he would see to it that they would return to  unscathed. All this they agreed to do and immediately lit fires and set upon the flocks.


Now the  had neglected the oracle of , believing it to be empty of meaning, and neither by carrying away nor by bringing in anything had they shown that they feared an enemy's coming. In so doing they were the cause of their own destruction,

for ' oracle concerning this matter runs as follows

To these verses the  gave no heed; but in the evils then present and soon to come they suffered the greatest calamity.


While the  were doing as I have said, there came to them their lookout from . There was a scout at , one , a native of , who was charged (and had a rowing boat standing ready for it), if the fleet should suffer a reverse to declare it to the men at . Similarly, if any ill should befall the land army,  son of , an , was with , ready for his part to bring the news in a thirty-oared bark to the  at .
So this  came and declared to them the fate of  and his army. When the  learned this, they no longer delayed their departure but went their ways in their appointed order, the  first and last of all the .


, however, picked out the seaworthiest  ships and made his way to the places where drinking water could be found. Here he engraved on the rocks words which the  read on the next day when they came to . This was what the writing said: Men of , you do wrongly to fight against the land of your fathers and bring slavery upon .
It would best for you to join yourselves to us, but if that should be impossible for you, then at least now withdraw from the war, and entreat the  to do the same as you. If neither of these things may be and you are fast bound by such constraint that you cannot rebel, yet we ask you not to use your full strength in the day of battle. Remember that you are our sons and that our quarrel with the barbarian was of your making in the beginning.
To my thinking  wrote this with a double intent, namely that if the king knew nothing of the writing, it might induce the  to change sides and join with the , while if the writing were maliciously reported to , he might thereby be led to mistrust the  and keep them out of the sea-fights.


Such was ' writing. Immediately after this there came to the barbarians a man of  in a boat, telling them of the flight of the  from . Not believing this, they kept the bringer of the news in confinement and sent swift ships to spy out the matter. When the crews of these brought word of the truth, the whole armada sailed all together to  at the crack of dawn. Here they waited till midday and then sailed to . Upon their arrival they took possession of the ' city and overran all the villages on the seaboard of the  region, which is a district belonging to .


While they were there,  sent a herald to the fleet. Before sending him,  had made the following preparations: of all his own soldiers who had fallen at  (that is, as many as twenty thousand) he left about a thousand, and the rest he buried in trenches, which he covered with leaves and heaped earth so that the men of the fleet might not see them.
When the herald had crossed over to , he assembled all the men of the fleet and said: Men of our allies,  permits any one of you who should so desire to leave his place and come to see how he fights against those foolish men who thought they could overcome the king's power.


After this proclamation, there was nothing so hard to get as a boat, so many were they who wanted to see this. They crossed over and went about viewing the dead. All of them supposed that the fallen  were all  and , though helots were also there for them to see.
For all that, however, those who crossed over were not deceived by what  had done with his own dead, for the thing was truly ridiculous; of the  a thousand lay dead before their eyes, but the  lay all together assembled in one place, to the number of four thousand.
All that day they spent in observation, and on the next the shipmen returned to their fleet at  while ' army set forth on its march.


There had come to them a few deserters, men of , lacking a livelihood and desirous to find some service. Bringing these men into the king's presence, the  inquired of them what the  were doing, there being one who put this question in the name of all.
When the  told them that the  were holding the  festival and viewing sports and horseraces, the  asked what was the prize offered, for which they contended. They told him of the crown of olive that was given to the victor. Then  son of  uttered a most noble saying (but the king deemed him a coward for it);

when he heard that the prize was not money but a crown, he could not hold his peace, but cried, Good heavens, , what kind of men are these that you have pitted us against? It is not for money they contend but for glory of achievement! Such was ' saying.


In the meantime, immediately after the misfortune at , the  sent a herald to the , because they bore an old grudge against them and still more because of their latest disaster.
Now a few years before the king's expedition, the  and their allies had invaded  with their whole army but had been worsted and roughly handled by the .
When the  were besieged on , they had with them the diviner  of ;  devised a stratagem for them: he covered six hundred of the bravest  with gypsum, themselves and their armor, and led them to attack the  by night, bidding them slay whomever they should see not whitened.
The  sentinels were the first to see these men and to flee for fear, supposing falsely that it was something supernatural, and after the sentinels the whole army fled as well. The  made themselves masters of four thousand dead, and their shields, of which they dedicated half at  and the rest at .
A tithe of what they won in that fight went to the making of the great statues that stand around the tripod in front of the shrine at , and there are others like them dedicated at .


This is what the besieged  did with the  footsoldiers. When the  horsemen rode into their country, the  did them mortal harm; they dug a great pit in the pass near  and put empty jars inside it. They then covered it with earth till all was like the rest of the ground and awaited the onset of the . These rode on intending to sweep the  before them, and fell in among the jars, whereby their horses' legs were broken.


These two deeds had never been forgiven by the , and now they sent a herald with this message: Men of , it is time now that you confess yourselves to be no match for us.
We were even formerly preferred to you by the , as long as we were on their side, and now we bear such weight with the foreigner that it lies in our power to have you deprived of your lands and to have you enslaved. Nevertheless, although we could easily do these things, we bear you no ill-will for the past. Pay us fifty talents of silver for what you did, and we promise to turn aside what threatens your land.


This was the ' offer. The  alone of all that region would not take the ' side, and that for no other reason (if I argue correctly) than their hatred of the .
Had the  aided the  side, then the  would certainly have stood for the . They replied to the offer of the  that they would give no money; they could do as the  did and take the  part, if for any cause they so wished, but they would not willingly betray the cause of .

So he went to tell the  of this miracle, but when the barbarians came with all speed near to the temple of , they were visited by miracles yet greater than the aforesaid. Marvellous indeed it is, that weapons of war should of their own motion appear lying outside in front of the shrine, but the visitation which followed was more wondrous than anything else ever seen.
When the barbarians were near to the temple of , they were struck by thunderbolts from the sky, and two peaks broken off from  came rushing among them with a mighty noise and overwhelmed many of them. In addition to this a shout and a cry of triumph were heard from the temple of .


All of this together struck panic into the barbarians, and the , perceiving that they fled, descended upon them and killed a great number. The survivors fled straight to . Those of the barbarians who returned said (as I have been told) that they had seen other divine signs besides what I have just described: two men-at-arms of stature greater than human,they said, had come after them, slaying and pursuing.

At the request of the , the fleet of the  came from  and put in at . The  requested them to put in at  so that they take their children and women out of  and also take counsel what they should do. While the others put in at , the  landed in their own country. When they arrived, they made a proclamation that every  should save his children and servants as he best could. Thereupon most of them sent the members of their households to , and some to  and .
They were anxious to get everything out safely because they wished to obey the oracle, and also not least because of this: the  say that a great snake lives in the sacred precinct guarding the acropolis. They say this and even put out monthly offerings for it as if it really existed. The monthly offering is a honey-cake.
In all the time before this the honey-cake had been consumed, but this time it was untouched. When the priestess interpreted the significance of this, the  were all the more eager to abandon the city since the goddess had deserted the acropolis. When they had removed everything to safety, they returned to the camp.
