They provided these alone, since the  did not fight with the  at  for this reason: when the  departed from  and were off , the  landed on the opposite shore of  and attended to the removal of their households. In bringing these to safety they were left behind.
The , while the  ruled what is now called , were , bearing the name of . When  was their king they were called , and when  succeeded to the rule, they changed their name and became . When, however, Ion son of  was commander of the  army, they were called after him .


The  provided the same number as at . The  came to help with seven ships, and the , who are  from , with three.


Of the islanders, the  provided thirty ships. They had other manned ships, but they guarded their own land with these and fought at  with the thirty most seaworthy. The  are  from , and their island was formerly called .
After the  came the  with their twenty ships from , and the  with the same seven; these are . Next were the ,  from , with the same ships as before.
The  provided four ships. They had been sent by their fellow citizens to the , like the rest of the islanders, but they disregarded their orders and came to the  at the urging of , an esteemed man among the townsmen and at that time captain of a trireme. The  are  descended from .
The  provided the same number of ships as at , and the  one trireme and a fifty-oared boat; these are both . The , , and  also took part, since they were the only islanders who had not given earth and water to the barbarian.


All these people who live this side of  and the  took part in the war. The  border on the  and , who were the ones who came from the most distant countries to take part in the war. The only ones living beyond these to help  in its danger were the , with one ship. Its captain was , three times victor in the  games. The  are  by birth.


All of these came to the war providing triremes, except the  and  and , who brought fifty-oared boats. The  (who are of  stock) provided two; the  and , who are  from , one each. The total number of ships, besides the fifty-oared boats, was three hundred and seventy-eight.


When the generals from the aforementioned cities, met at , they held a council and  proposed that whoever wanted to should give his opinion on what place under their control was most suitable for a sea battle.  was already lost, and he proposed that they consider the places which were left.
The consensus of most of the speakers was to sail to the Isthmus and fight at sea for the , giving this reason: if they were defeated in the fight at  they would be besieged on an island, where no help could come to them, but if they were at the Isthmus they could go ashore to their own lands.


While the generals from the  considered this argument, an  came with the message that the barbarians had reached  and were destroying all of it by fire.
The army with  had made its way through  and burnt the city of the , who had abandoned it and gone to the , and  likewise. Now the army had come to  and was devastating everything there. The army burnt  and  upon learning from the  that they had not medized.


Since the crossing of the , where the barbarians began their journey, they had spent one month there crossing into  and in three more months were in , when  was archon at .
When they took the town it was deserted, but in the sacred precinct they found a few , stewards of the sacred precinct and poor people, who defended themselves against the assault by fencing the acropolis with doors and logs. They had not withdrawn to  not only because of poverty but also because they thought they had discovered the meaning of the oracle the  had given, namely that the wooden wall would be impregnable. They believed that according to the oracle this, not the ships, was the refuge.


The  took up a position on the hill opposite the acropolis, which the  call the , and besieged them in this way: they wrapped arrows in tar and set them on fire, and then shot them at the barricade. Still the besieged  defended themselves, although they had come to the utmost danger and their barricade had failed them.
When the  proposed terms of surrender, they would not listen but contrived defenses such as rolling down boulders onto the barbarians when they came near the gates. For a long time  was at a loss, unable to capture them.


In time a way out of their difficulties was revealed to the barbarians, since according to the oracle all the mainland of  had to become subject to the . In front of the acropolis, and behind the gates and the ascent, was a place where no one was on guard, since no one thought any man could go up that way. Here some men climbed up, near the sacred precinct of ' daughter , although the place was a sheer cliff.
When the  saw that they had ascended to the acropolis, some threw themselves off the wall and were killed, and others fled into the chamber. The  who had come up first turned to the gates, opened them, and murdered the suppliants. When they had levelled everything, they plundered the sacred precinct and set fire to the entire acropolis.


So it was that  took complete possession of , and he sent a horseman to  to announce his present success to . On the day after the messenger was sent, he called together the  exiles who accompanied him and asked them go up to the acropolis and perform sacrifices in their customary way, an order given because he had been inspired by a dream or because he felt remorse after burning the sacred precinct. The  exiles did as they were commanded.


I will tell why I have mentioned this. In that acropolis is a shrine of , called the , and in the shrine are an olive tree and a pool of salt water. The story among the  is that they were set there by  and  as tokens when they contended for the land. It happened that the olive tree was burnt by the barbarians with the rest of the sacred precinct, but on the day after its burning, when the  ordered by the king to sacrifice went up to the sacred precinct, they saw a shoot of about a cubit's length sprung from the stump, and they reported this.


When this business concerning the  acropolis was announced to the  at , some of the  generals became so alarmed that they did not even wait for the proposed matter to be decided, but jumped into their ships and hoisted their sails for flight. Those left behind resolved that the fleet should fight for the Isthmus. Night fell, and they dissolved the assembly and boarded their ships.


When  returned to his ship, , an , asked him what had been decided. Learning from him that they had resolved to sail to the Isthmus and fight for the , he said,

If they depart from , you will no longer be fighting for one country. Each will make his way to his own city, and neither  nor any other man will be able to keep them from disbanding the army.  will be destroyed by bad planning. If there is any way at all that you could persuade  to change his decision and remain here, go try to undo this resolution.


This advice greatly pleased . He made no answer and went to the ship of . When he arrived there, he said he wanted to talk with him on a matter of common interest, so  bade him come aboard and say what he wanted.

 sat next to him and told him all that he had heard from , pretending it was his own idea and adding many other things. Finally by his entreaty he persuaded him to disembark and gather the generals for a council of war.


When they were assembled and before  had a chance to put forward the reason he had called the generals together,  spoke at length in accordance with the urgency of his request. While he was speaking, the  general  son of  said, , at the games those who start before the signal are beaten with rods.  said in justification, Those left behind win no crown.


He answered the  mildly and said to  nothing of what he had said before, how if they put out from  they would flee different ways, for it would be unbecoming for him to accuse the allies in their presence. Instead he relied on a different argument and said,


It is in your hands to save , if you will obey me and remain here to fight, and not obey the words of these others and move your ships back to the Isthmus. Compare each plan after you have heard. If you join battle at the Isthmus, you will fight in the open sea where it is least to our advantage, since our ships are heavier and fewer in number. You will also lose  and  and , even if we succeed in all else. Their land army will accompany their fleet, and so you will lead them to the  and risk all .

But if you do what I say, you will find it useful in these ways: first, by engaging many ships with our few in the strait, we shall win a great victory, if the war turns out reasonably, for it is to our advantage to fight in a strait and to their advantage to fight in a wide area. Second,  will survive, where we have carried our children and women to safety. It also has in it something you are very fond of: by remaining here you will be fighting for the  just as much as at the Isthmus, and you will not lead them to the , if you exercise good judgment.

If what I expect happens and we win the victory with our ships, you will not have the barbarians upon you at the Isthmus. They will advance no further than  and depart in no order, and we shall gain an advantage by the survival of , , and , where it is prophesied that we will prevail against our enemies. Men usually succeed when they have reasonable plans. If their plans are unreasonable, the god does not wish to assent to human intentions.


As  said this,  the  attacked him again, advising that a man without a city should keep quiet and that  should not ask the vote of a man without a city. He advised  to contribute his opinion when he provided a cityattacking him in this way because  was captured and occupied.

 This time  said many things against him and the , declaring that so long as they had two hundred manned ships, the  had both a city and a land greater than theirs, and that none of the  could repel them if they attacked.


Next he turned his argument to , saying more vehemently than before, If you remain here, you will be an noble man. If not, you will ruin . All our strength for war is in our ships, so listen to me.
If you do not do this, we will immediately gather up our households and travel to  in , which has been ours since ancient times, and the prophecies say we must found a colony there. You will remember these words when you are without such allies.


When  said this,  changed his mind. I think he did so chiefly out of fear that the  might desert them if they set sail for the Isthmus. If the  left, the rest would be no match for the enemy, so he made the choice to remain there and fight.


After this skirmish of words, since  had so resolved, the men at  prepared to fight where they were. At sunrise on the next day there was an earthquake on land and sea,

and they resolved to pray to the gods and summon the sons of  as allies. When they had so resolved, they did as follows: they prayed to all the gods, called  and  to come straight from , and sent a ship to  for  and his sons.


 son of , an  exile who had become important among the , said that at the time when the land of  was being laid waste by ' army and there were no  in the country, he was with  the  on the  plain and saw advancing from  a cloud of dust as if raised by the feet of about thirty thousand men. They marvelled at what men might be raising such a cloud of dust and immediately heard a cry. The cry seemed to be the  of the mysteries,

and when , ignorant of the rites of , asked him what was making this sound,  said, , there is no way that some great disaster will not befall the king's army. Since  is deserted, it is obvious that this voice is divine and comes from  to help the  and their allies.
If it descends upon the , the king himself and his army on the mainland will be endangered. If, however, it turns towards the ships at , the king will be in danger of losing his fleet.
Every year the  observe this festival for the Mother and the Maiden, and any  or other  who wishes is initiated. The voice which you hear is the  they cry at this festival. To this  replied, Keep silent and tell this to no one else.
If these words of yours are reported to the king, you will lose your head, and neither I nor any other man will be able to save you, so be silent. The gods will see to the army.
Thus he advised, and after the dust and the cry came a cloud, which rose aloft and floated away towards  to the camp of the . In this way they understood that ' fleet was going to be destroyed.  son of  used to say this, appealing to  and others as witnesses.


When those stationed with ' fleet had been to see the  disaster at , they crossed over from  to , waited three days, and then sailed through the , and in three more days they were at , the port of . I think no less a number invaded  by land and sea than came to Sepias and .
Those killed by the storm, at , and in the naval battles at , I offset with those who did not yet follow the king: the  and  and  and the whole force of  except the  and ; and the  and  and  and all the rest of the islanders, except the five cities whose names I previously mentioned. The farther into  the  advanced, the more nations followed him.


All these came to  except the . The  stayed behind in  watching to see which way the war turned out. When the rest of them reached ,  himself went down to the ships, wishing to mix with the sailors and hear their opinions.
He came and sat on his throne, and present at his summons were the tyrants of all the peoples and the company leaders from the fleet. They sat according to the honor which the king had granted each of them, first the king of , then the king of , then the rest. When they sat in order one after another,  sent  to test each by asking if they should fight at sea.


 went about questioning them, starting with the , and all the others were unanimous, advising to fight at sea, but  said,


Tell the king, , that I, who neither was most cowardly in the sea battles off  nor performed the least feats of arms, say this: Master, it is just for me to declare my real opinion, what I consider to be best for your cause. And I say to you this: spare your ships, and do not fight at sea. Their men are as much stronger than your men by sea as men are stronger than women.
Why is it so necessary for you to risk everything by fighting at sea? Do you not possess , for which you set out on this march, and do you not have the rest of ? No one stands in your way. Those who opposed you have received what they deserved.

I will tell you how I think the affairs of your enemies will turn out: If you do not hurry to fight at sea, but keep your ships here and stay near land, or even advance into the , then, my lord, you will easily accomplish what you had in mind on coming here.
The  are not able to hold out against you for a long time, but you will scatter them, and they will each flee to their own cities. I have learned that they have no food on this island, and it is not likely, if you lead your army against the , that those of them who have come from there will sit still, nor will they care to fight at sea for .

But if you hurry to fight at sea immediately, I fear that your fleet if reduced to cowardice may also injure your army on land. In addition, my King, take this to heart: Good people's slaves tend to be base, and the slaves of the base tend to be good. You, who are best among men, have base slaves, who are accounted your allies, the  and  and  and , who are of no use at all.


When she said this to , all who were well disposed towards  lamented her words, thinking she would suffer some ill from the king because she advised against fighting at sea. Those who were jealous and envied her, because she was given honor among the chief of all the allies, were glad at her answer, thinking she would be killed.
But when the counsels were reported to , he was greatly pleased by 's opinion. Even before this he had considered her of excellent character, and now he praised her much more highly. Still he ordered that the majority be obeyed, for he believed that at  they had purposely fought badly because he was not there. This time he had made preparations to see the battle in person.


When the command to put out to sea was given, they set sail for  and were calmly marshalled in line. There was not enough daylight left for them to fight, since night came on, so they made preparations for the next day.

 Fear and dread possessed the , especially those from the . They were afraid because they were stationed in  and were about to fight at sea on behalf of the land of the , and if they were defeated they would be trapped on an island and besieged, leaving their own land unguarded.


That very night the land army of the barbarians began marching to the . Yet every possible device had been used to prevent the barbarians from invading by the mainland. As soon as the  learned that  and his men at  were dead, they ran together from their cities and took up their position at the Isthmus. Their general was  son of , the brother of .

 When they were in position at the Isthmus, they demolished the  road and then, after resolving in council, built a wall across the Isthmus. Since there were many tens of thousands and everyone worked, the task was completed, as they brought in stones and bricks and logs and baskets full of sand. At no moment of the day or night did those who had marched out there rest from their work.


These were the  who marched out in a body to the Isthmus: the  and all the , the  and  and  and  and  and  and . These were the ones who marched out and feared for  in her peril. The rest of the  cared nothing, though the  and  festivals were now past.


Seven nations inhabit the . Two of these are aboriginal and are now settled in the land where they lived in the old days, the  and . One nation, the , has never left the , but it has left its own country and inhabits another nation's land.
The four remaining nations of the seven are immigrants, the  and  and  and . The  have many famous cities, the  only , the   and  near , the  all the .
The  are aboriginal and seem to be the only , but they have been Dorianized by time and by  rule. They are the  and the perioikoi. All the remaining cities of these seven nations, except those I enumerated, stayed neutral. If I may speak freely, by staying neutral they medized.


Those at the Isthmus were involved in so great a labor, since all they had was at stake and they did not expect the ships to win distinction. Those at  heard of their labors but still were full of dread, fearing not for themselves but for the .
For a time each man talked quietly to his neighbor, wondering at ' folly, but finally it came out into the open. They held an assembly and talked at length on the same matters as before: some said they must sail away to the  and risk battle for that country, not stay and fight for a captured land; but the  and  and  said they must stay and defend themselves.


When the  were outvoting him,  secretly left the assembly, and sent a man by boat to the Median fleet after ordering him what to say. His name was , and he was ' servant and his sons' attendant. Later  enrolled him as a , when the  were adopting citizens, and made him wealthy with money.
He now came by boat and said to the generals of the barbarians, The  general has sent me without the knowledge of the other . He is on the king's side and prefers that your affairs prevail, not the '. I am to tell you that the  are terrified and plan flight, and you can now perform the finest deed of all if you do not allow them to escape.
They do not all have the same intent, and they will no longer oppose you. Instead you will see them fighting against themselves, those who are on your side against those who are not. After indicating this to them he departed.


Finding the message credible, they first landed many of the  on the islet of , which lies between  and the mainland. When it was midnight, they brought their western wing in a circle towards , and those stationed at  and  also put out to sea, occupying all the passage as far as  with their ships.
They launched their ships in this way so that the  would have no escape: they would be trapped at  and pay the penalty for the battles at . The purpose of their landing  on the islet called  was this: when the battle took place, it was chiefly there that the men and wrecks would be washed ashore, for the island lay in the path of the impending battle. The  would be able to save some of those who washed up and kill the others.

 They did this in silence for fear that their enemies hear, making their preparations at night without sleep.


I cannot say against oracles that they are not true, and I do not wish to try to discredit them when they speak plainly. Look at the following matter: 





Considering this, I dare to say nothing against  concerning oracles when he speaks so plainly, nor will I consent to it by others.


Among the generals at  there was fierce argument. They did not yet know that the barbarians had encircled them with their ships, supposing them still marshalled in the place where they had seen them by day.


As the generals disputed,  son of , an , crossed over from . Although he had been ostracized by the people, I, learning by inquiry of his character, have come to believe that he was the best and most just man in .
This man stood at the assembly and called  out, although he was no friend of his, but his bitter enemy. Because of the magnitude of the present ills, he deliberately forgot all that and called him out, wanting to talk to him. He had already heard that those from the  were anxious to set sail for the Isthmus,

so when  came out he said, On all occasions and especially now our contention must be over which of us will do our country more good.
I say that it is all the same for the  to speak much or little about sailing away from here, for I have seen with my own eyes that even if the  and  himself wanted to, they would not be able to escape. We are encircled by the enemy. Go in and indicate this to them.


 answered, Your exhortation is most useful and you bring good news. You have come as an eyewitness of just what I wanted to happen. Know that I am the cause of what the  are doing. When the  would not willingly enter battle, it was necessary to force them against their will. Since you have come bringing good news, tell it to them yourself.
If I say these things, they will think I invented it, and they will not believe that the barbarians are doing this. Go in yourself and let them know how it stands. It would be best if they believe you when you tell them, but if they find these things incredible it is all the same to us. They will not be able to run away, if indeed we are surrounded on all sides as you say.


 went in and told them, saying that he had come from  and had barely made it past the blockade when he sailed out, since all the  camp was surrounded by ' ships. He advised them to prepare to defend themselves. He said this and left, and again a dispute arose among them. The majority of the generals did not believe the news.


While they were still held by disbelief, a trireme of  deserters arrived, captained by  son of , which brought them the whole truth. For this deed the  were engraved on the tripod at  with those who had conquered the barbarian.
With this ship that deserted at  and the  which deserted earlier at , the  fleet reached its full number of three hundred and eighty ships, for it had fallen short of the number by two ships.


When they found the words of the  worthy of belief, the  prepared to fight at sea. As dawn glimmered, they held an assembly of the fighting men, and  gave the best address among the others. His entire speech involved comparing the better and lesser elements in human nature and the human condition.
He concluded his speech by advising them to choose the better of these, then gave the command to mount the ships. Just as they embarked, the trireme which had gone after the sons of  arrived from .


Then the  set sail with all their ships, and as they were putting out to sea the barbarians immediately attacked them.  The rest of the  began to back water and tried to beach their ships, but  of , an , charged and rammed a ship. When his ship became entangled and the crew could not free it, the others came to help  and joined battle.
The  say that the fighting at sea began this way, but the  say that the ship which had been sent to  after the sons of  was the one that started it. The story is also told that the phantom of a woman appeared to them, who cried commands loud enough for all the  fleet to hear, reproaching them first with, Men possessed, how long will you still be backing water?


The  were marshalled against the , holding the western wing toward . Against the  were the , on the eastern wing toward , and a few of them fought badly according to ' instructions, but the majority did not.
I can list the names of many captains who captured  ships, but I will mention none except  son of  and  son of , both .
I mention only these because  was appointed tyrant of  by the  for this feat, and  was recorded as a benefactor of the king and granted much land. The king's benefactors are called orosangae in the  language.


Thus it was concerning them. But the majority of the ships at  were sunk, some destroyed by the , some by the . Since the  fought in an orderly fashion by line, but the barbarians were no longer in position and did nothing with forethought, it was likely to turn out as it did. Yet they were brave that day, much more brave than they had been at , for they all showed zeal out of fear of , each one thinking that the king was watching him.


I cannot say exactly how each of the other barbarians or  fought, but this is what happened to , and it gave her still higher esteem with the king:
When the king's side was all in commotion, at that time 's ship was pursued by a ship of . She could not escape, for other allied ships were in front of her and hers was the nearest to the enemy. So she resolved to do something which did in fact benefit her: as she was pursued by the Attic ship, she charged and rammed an allied ship, with a  crew and  himself, king of the , aboard.
I cannot say if she had some quarrel with him while they were still at the , or whether she did this intentionally or if the ship of the  fell in her path by chance.
But when she rammed and sank it, she had the luck of gaining two advantages. When the captain of the Attic ship saw her ram a ship with a barbarian crew, he decided that 's ship was either  or a deserter from the barbarians fighting for them, so he turned away to deal with others.


Thus she happened to escape and not be destroyed, and it also turned out that the harmful thing which she had done won her exceptional esteem from .
It is said that the king, as he watched the battle, saw her ship ram the other, and one of the bystanders said, Master, do you see how well  contends in the contest and how she has sunk an enemy ship? When he asked if the deed was truly 's, they affirmed it, knowing reliably the marking of her ship, and they supposed that the ruined ship was an enemy.
As I have said, all this happened to bring her luck, and also that no one from the  ship survived to accuse her. It is said that  replied to what was told him, My men have become women, and my women men. They say this is what  said.


In this struggle the general  died, son of  and the brother of . Many other famous men of the  and  and other allies also died, but only a few , since they knew how to swim. Those whose ships were sunk swam across to , unless they were killed in action,

but many of the barbarians drowned in the sea since they did not know how to swim. Most of the ships were sunk when those in the front turned to flee, since those marshalled in the rear, as they tried to go forward with their ships so they too could display some feat to the king, ran afoul of their own side's ships in flight.


It also happened in this commotion that certain  whose ships had been destroyed came to the king and accused the  of treason, saying that it was by their doing that the ships had been lost. It turned out that the  generals were not put to death, and those  who slandered them were rewarded as I will show.
While they were still speaking, a  ship rammed an Attic ship. The  ship sank and an  ship bore down and sank the  ship, but the , being javelin-throwers, by pelting them with missiles knocked the fighters off the ship that had sunk theirs and boarded and seized it.
This saved the . In his deep vexation  blamed everyone.  When he saw the  performing this great feat, he turned to the  and commanded that their heads be cut off, so that they who were base not slander men more noble.
Whenever , as he sat beneath the mountain opposite  which is called , saw one of his own men achieve some feat in the battle, he inquired who did it, and his scribes wrote down the captain's name with his father and city of residence. The presence of , a  and a friend of the , contributed still more to this calamity of the .  Thus they dealt with the . 


The barbarians were routed and tried to flee by sailing out to , but the  lay in wait for them in the strait and then performed deeds worth telling. The  in the commotion destroyed those ships which either resisted or tried to flee, the  those sailing out of the strait. Whoever escaped from the  charged right into the .


The ships of , as he was pursuing a ship, and of  son of , an , then met.  had rammed a  ship, the one which had captured the  ship that was on watch off , and on it was  son of , the one the  marvelled at when severely wounded and kept aboard their ship because of his virtue. This  ship carrying him with the  was now captured, so  came back safe to .
When  saw the Attic ship, he recognized it by seeing the flagship's marking and shouted to , mocking and reproaching him concerning the Medizing of the . After ramming an enemy ship,  hurled these insults at . The barbarians whose ships were still intact fled and reached  under cover of the land army.


In this battle the  with the reputation as most courageous were the , then the . Among individuals they were  the  and the   of  and  of , the one who pursued . If he had known she was in that ship, he would not have stopped before either capturing it or being captured himself.
Such were the orders given to the  captains, and there was a prize offered of ten thousand drachmas to whoever took her alive, since they were indignant that a woman waged war against . But she escaped, as I said earlier, and the others whose ships survived were also in .


The  say that when the ships joined battle, the  general , struck with bewilderment and terror, hoisted his sails and fled away. When the  saw their flagship fleeing, they departed in the same way,

but when in their flight they were opposite the sacred precinct of  on , by divine guidance a boat encountered them. No one appeared to have sent it, and the  knew nothing about the affairs of the fleet when it approached. They reckon the affair to involve the gods because when the boat came near the ships, the people on the boat said,

, you have turned your ships to flight and betrayed the , but they are overcoming their enemies to the fulfillment of their prayers for victory.  did not believe them when they said this, so they spoke again, saying that they could be taken as hostages and killed if the  were not seen to be victorious.
So he and the others turned their ships around and came to the fleet, but it was all over. The  spread this rumor about them, but the  do not agree at all, and they consider themselves to have been among the foremost in the battle. The rest of  bears them witness.


 son of , the  whom I mentioned a little before this as a valiant man, did this in the commotion that arose at : taking many of the armed men who were arrayed along the shore of , he brought them across and landed them on the island of , and they slaughtered all the  who were on that islet.


When the battle was broken off, the  towed to  as many of the wrecks as were still there and kept ready for another battle, supposing that the king could still make use of his surviving ships.
A west wind had caught many of the wrecks and carried them to the shore in  called . Thus not only was all the rest of the oracle fulfilled which  and  had spoken about this battle, but also what had been said many years before this in an oracle by , an  soothsayer, concerning the wrecks carried to shore there. Its meaning had eluded all the :




When  understood the calamity which had taken place, he feared that some of the  might advise the , if they did not think of it themselves, to sail to the  and destroy the bridges. He would be trapped in  in danger of destruction, so he resolved on flight. He did not want to be detected either by the  or by his own men, so he attempted to build a dike across to , and joined together  cargo ships to be both a bridge and a wall, making preparations as if to fight another sea battle.
All who saw him doing this confidently supposed that he fully intended to stay and fight there, but none of this eluded , who had the most experience of the king's intentions. While doing all this,  sent a messenger to  to announce the disaster.


While  did thus, he sent a messenger to  with news of his present misfortune. Now there is nothing mortal that accomplishes a course more swiftly than do these messengers, by the ' skillful contrivance. It is said that as many days as there are in the whole journey, so many are the men and horses that stand along the road, each horse and man at the interval of a day's journey. These are stopped neither by snow nor rain nor heat nor darkness from accomplishing their appointed course with all speed.
The first rider delivers his charge to the second, the second to the third, and thence it passes on from hand to hand, even as in the  torch-bearers' race in honor of . This riding-post is called in , angareion.


When the first message came to , saying that  had taken , it gave such delight to the  who were left at home that they strewed all the roads with myrtle boughs and burnt incense and gave themselves up to sacrificial feasts and jollity.
The second, however, coming on the heels of the first, so confounded them that they all tore their tunics, and cried and lamented without ceasing, holding  to blame; it was not so much in grief for their ships that they did this as because they feared for  himself.


Such was the plight of the  for all the time until the coming of  himself ended it. , however, seeing that  was greatly distressed because of the sea-fight, and suspecting that he planned flight from , thought that he would be punished for persuading the king to march against  and that it was better for him to risk the chance of either subduing  or dying honorably while engaged in a noble cause; yet his hope rather inclined to the subduing of . Taking all this into account, he made this proposal:

Sire, be not grieved nor greatly distressed because of what has befallen us. It is not on things of wood that the issue hangs for us, but on men and horses; furthermore, there is no one among these men, who thinks that he has now won a crowning victory and will disembark from his ship in an attempt to withstand you, no, nor anyone from this mainland. Those who have withstood us have paid the penalty.
If then you so desire, let us straightway attack the , or if it pleases you to wait, that also we can do. Do not be downcast, for the  have no way of escaping guilt for their former and their later deeds and from becoming your slaves. It is best then that you should do as I have said, but if you have resolved to lead your army away, even then I have another plan.
Do not, O king, make the  the laughing-stock of the , for if you have suffered harm, it is by no fault of the . Nor can you say that we have anywhere done less than brave men should, and if  and  and  and  have so done, it is not the  who have any part in this disaster.
Therefore, since the  are in no way to blame, be guided by me; if you are resolved not to remain, march homewards with the greater part of your army. It is for me, however, to enslave and deliver  to you with three hundred thousand of your host whom I will choose.


When  heard that, he was as glad and joyful as a man in his situation might be and said to  that he would answer him after deliberating which of the two plans he would follow. When he consulted with those  whom he summoned, he resolved to send for  as well, because he saw that she alone at the former sitting had discerned what was best to do.
When  came,  bade all others withdraw, both  councillors and guards, and said to her: It is ' advice that I should follow here and attack the , for the , he says, and the land army are not to blame for our disaster; of that they would willingly give proof.
Therefore he advises me to do this, or else he offers to choose three hundred thousand men of the army and deliver  to me enslaved, while I myself by his counsel march homeward with the rest of the host.
Now I ask of you, seeing that you correctly advised me against the late sea-fight, counsel me as to which of these two things would be best for me to do.


When she was asked for advice, she replied: It is difficult, O king, to answer your plea for advice by saying that which is best, but in the present turn of affairs I think it best that you march back and that , if he so wishes and promises to do as he says, be left here with those whom he desires.
For if he subdues all that he offers to subdue and prospers in his design, the achievement, Sire, is yours since it will be your servants who have accomplished it. If, on the other hand, the issue is contrary to ' expectation, it is no great misfortune so long as you and all that household of yours are safe;

for while you and the members of your household are safe, many a time will the  have to fight for their lives. As for , if any disaster befalls him, it is does not much matter, nor will any victory of the  be a real victory when they have but slain your servant. As for you, you will be marching home after the burning of , which thing was the whole purpose of your expedition.


's counsel pleased , for it happened that she spoke what he himself had in mind. In truth, I think that he would not have remained even if all men and women had counselled him so to doso panic-stricken was he. Having then thanked , he sent her away to take his sons to , for he had some bastard sons with him.


With these sons he sent  as guardian. This man was by birth of , and the most honored by  of all his eunuchs. The people of  dwell above . The following thing happens among these people: when anything untoward is about to befall those who dwell about their city, the priestess of  then grows a great beard. This had already happened to them twice.


, who came from , had achieved a fuller vengeance for wrong done to him than had any man whom we know. When he had been taken captive by enemies and put up for sale, he was bought by one  of , a man who had set himself to earn a livelihood out of most wicked practices. He would procure beautiful boys and castrate and take them to  and  where he sold them for a great price,

for the barbarians value eunuchs more than perfect men, by reason of the full trust that they have in them. Now among the many whom  had castrated was , who was not entirely unfortunate; he was brought from  together with other gifts to the king, and as time went on, he stood higher in ' favor than any other eunuch.


Now while the king was at  and preparing to lead his  army against ,  came for some business down to the part of  which is inhabited by  and called . There he found .
Perceiving who he was, he held long and friendly converse with him, telling him that it was to him that he owed all this prosperity and promising that he would make him prosperous in return if he were to bring his household and dwell there.  accepted his offer gladly, and brought his children and his wife.
When  had gotten the man and all his household into his power, he said to him: Tell me, you who have made a livelihood out of the wickedest trade on earth, what harm had I or any of my forefathers done to you or yours, that you made me to be no man, but a thing of nought? You no doubt thought that the gods would have no knowledge of your former practices, but their just law has brought you for your wicked deeds into my hands. Now you will be well content with the fullness of that justice which I will execute upon you.
With these words of reproach, he brought ' sons before him and compelled him to castrate all four of themhis own children; this  was compelled to do. When he had done this, the sons were compelled to castrate their father in turn. This, then, was the way in which  was overtaken by vengeance at the hands of .


Having given his sons to 's charge to be carried to ,  called  to him and bade him choose whom he would from the army, and make his words good so far as endeavor availed. That is as far as matters went on that day; in the night, however, the admirals, by the king's command, put out to sea from  and made for the  again with all speed to guard the bridges for the king's passage.
When the barbarians came near to the Girdle in their course, they thought that certain little headlands, which here jut out from the mainland, were ships, and they fled for a long way. When they learned at last that they were no ships but headlands, they drew together and went on their way.


When it was day, the  saw the land army abiding where it had been and supposed the ships also to be at . Thinking also that there would be a sea-fight they prepared to defend themselves. When, however, they learned that the ships were gone, they straightway resolved on pursuit; so they pursued ' fleet as far as , but failed to catch sight of it. When they came to , they held a council there.

 declared his opinion that they should hold their course through the islands, and having pursued the ships, should sail forthwith to the  to break the bridges. , on the other hand, offered a contrary opinion, saying that to break the bridges would be the greatest harm that they could do to .

For, said he, if the  is cut off and compelled to remain in , he will attempt not to be inactive. This he will do because if he remains inactive, he can neither make his cause prosper nor find any way of return home, but his army will perish of hunger. If, on the other hand, he is enterprising and active, it may well be that every town and nation in  will join itself to him, by conquest or, before that, by compact. He will then live on whatever yearly fruits of the earth  produces.
But, as I think that the  will not remain in  after his defeat in the sea-fight, let us permit him to flee to his own country. Thereafter let it be that country and not ours which is at stake in the war. With that opinion the rest of the  admirals also agreed.


When  perceived that he could not persuade the greater part of them to sail to the , he turned to the  (for they were the angriest at the ' escape, and they were minded to sail to the  even by themselves, if the rest would not) and addressed them as follows:

This I have often seen with my eyes and heard yet more often, namely that beaten men, when they be driven to bay, will rally and retrieve their former mishap. Therefore I say to you,as it is to a fortunate chance that we owe ourselves and , and have driven away so mighty a band of enemieslet us not pursue men who flee,

for it is not we who have won this victory, but the gods and the heroes, who deemed  and  too great a realm for one man to rule, and that a wicked man and an impious one who dealt alike with temples and bones, burning and overthrowing the images of the gods,yes, and one who scourged the sea and threw fetters into it.
But as it is well with us for the moment, let us abide now in  and take thought for ourselves and our households. Let us build our houses again and be diligent in sowing, when we have driven the foreigner completely away. Then when the next spring comes, let us set sail for the  and .
This he said with intent to have something to his credit with the , so that he might have a place of refuge if ever (as might chance) he should suffer anything at the hands of the and just that did in fact happen.


Thus spoke  with intent to deceive, and the  obeyed him; since he had always been esteemed wise and now had shown himself to be both wise and prudent, they were ready to obey whatever he said.
Having won them over,  straightway sent men in a boat whom he could trust not to reveal under any question the message which he charged them to deliver to the king; one of these was his servant . When these men came to , the rest remained with the boat, and  went up to ;

 son of , he said, who is the  general and of all the allies the worthiest and wisest, has sent me to tell you this:  the  has out of his desire to do you a service stayed the  when they wanted to pursue your ships and break the bridges of the . Now he bids you go your way, none hindering you. With that message, the men returned in their boat.


But the , now that they were no longer minded to pursue the barbarians' ships farther or sail to the  and break the way of passage, besieged  so that they might take it,

for the men of that place, the first islanders of whom  demanded money, would not give it. When, however,  gave them to understand that the  had come with two great gods to aid them, Persuasion and Necessity, and that the  must therefore certainly give money, they said in response, It is then but reasonable that  is great and prosperous, being blessed with serviceable gods.
As for us , we are but blessed with a plentiful lack of land, and we have two unserviceable gods who never quit our island but want to dwell there forever, namely Poverty and Helplessness. Since we are in the hands of these gods, we will give no money; the power of  can never be stronger than our inability.


It was for giving this answer and refusing to give what was asked of them that they were besieged. There was no end to ' avarice; using the same agents whom he had used with the king, he sent threatening messages to the other islands, demanding money and saying that if they would not give what he asked he would bring the  armada upon them and besiege and take their islands.
Thereby he collected great sums from the  and , for these were informed that  was besieged for taking the  side and that  was of all the generals the most esteemed. This frightened them so much that they sent money. I suppose that there were other islanders too who gave and not these alone, but I cannot with certainty say.
Nevertheless, the  got no respite from misfortune by doing this. The , however, propitiated  with money and so escaped the force. So  went away from  and took money from the islanders, unknown to the other generals.


Those who were with  waited for a few days after the sea-fight and then marched away to  by the road by which they had come.  wanted to give the king safe conduct and thought the time of year unseasonable for war; it was better, he thought, to winter in , and then attack the  in the spring.
When they had arrived in ,  first chose all the  called Immortals, save only  their general who said that he would not quit the king's person, and next, the  cuirassiers and the thousand horse and the  and  and  and , alike their infantrymen and the rest of the horsemen.
These nations he chose in their entirety; of the rest of his allies he picked out a few from each people, the best men and those whom he knew to have done some good service. The  whom he chose (men who wore torques and bracelets) were more in number than those of any other nation and next to them the ; these indeed were as many as the , but not such stout fighters. Thereby the whole number, together with the horsemen, grew to three hundred thousand men.


Now while  was choosing his army and  was in , there came an oracle from  to the , that they should demand justice of  for the slaying of  and take whatever he should offer them. The  then sent a herald with all speed. He found the army yet undivided in , came into ' presence, and spoke as follows:

The  and the  of  demand of you, king of the , that you pay the penalty for the death of their king, whom you killed while he defended . At that  laughed, and after a long while, he pointed to , who chanced to be standing by him and said, Then here is , who shall pay those you speak of such penalty as befits them.


So the herald took that response and departed, but  left  in . He himself journeyed with all speed to the  and came in forty-five days to the passage for crossing, bringing back with him as good as none (if one may say so) of his host.
Wherever and to whatever people they came, they seized and devoured its produce. If they found none, they would eat the grass of the field and strip the bark and pluck the leaves of the trees, garden and wild alike, leaving nothingsuch was the degree of their starvation.
Moreover, pestilence and dysentery broke out among them on their way, from which they died. Some who were sick  left behind, charging the cities to which he came in his march to care for them and nourish them, some in  and some in  of  and in .
In  he had left the sacred chariot of  when he was marching to , but on his return he did not get it back again. The  had given it to the , and when  demanded it back, they said that the horses had been carried off from pasture by the  of the hills who dwelt about the headwaters of the .


It was then that a monstrous deed was done by the  king of the  and the  country. He had refused to be of his own free will ' slave, and fled to the mountains called . He forbade his sons to go with the army to ,

but they took no account of that; they had always wanted to see the war, and they followed the ' march. For this reason, when all the six of them returned back scatheless, their father tore out their eyes.


This was their reward. Now the , journeying through  to the passage, made haste to cross to  in their ships, for they found the bridges no longer made fast but broken by a storm. There their march halted, and more food was given them than on their way.
Then by reason of their immoderate gorging and the change of the water which they drank, many of the army that had survived died. The rest came with  to .


There is, however, another tale, which is this: when  came in his march from  to  on the , he travelled no farther than that by land, but committed his army to  to be led to the . He himself embarked and set sail for  in a  ship.
In the course of this voyage he was caught by a strong wind called the , which lifted up the waves. This storm bearing the harder upon him by reason of the heavy load of the ship (for the  of his company who were on the deck were so many), the king grew afraid and cried to the ship's pilot asking him if there were any way of deliverance. To this the man said,

Sire, there is none, if we do not rid ourselves of these many who are on board. Hearing that, it is said,  said to the , Now it is for you to prove your concern for your king, for it seems that my deliverance rests with you.
At this they bowed and leapt into the sea. The ship, now much lighter, came by these means safe to . No sooner had  disembarked on land, than he made the pilot a gift of a golden crown for saving the king's life but cut off his head for being the death of many .


This is the other tale of ' return; but I for my part believe neither the story of the ' fate nor any other part of it. For if indeed the pilot had spoken to  in this way, I think that there is not one in ten thousand who would not say that the king would have bidden the men on deck (who were  and of the best blood of ) descend into the ship's hold, and would have taken from the  rowers a number equal to the number of the  and cast them into the sea. No, the truth is that  did as I have already said, and returned to  with his army by road.


There is further proof of this, for it is known that when  came to  in his return, he made a compact of friendship with its people and gave them a golden sword and a gilt tiara. As the people of  say (but for my part I wholly disbelieve them), it was here that  in his flight back from  first loosed his girdle, as being here in safety. Now  lies nearer to the  than the  and , where they say that he took ship.


As for the , not being able to take , they went to . When they had laid it waste, they returned to . First of all they set apart for the gods, among other first-fruits, three  triremes, one to be dedicated at the Isthmus, where it was till my lifetime, the second at , and the third for  at  where they were.
After that, they divided the spoils and sent the first-fruits of it to ; of this was made a man's image twelve cubits high, holding in his hand the figurehead of a ship. This stood in the same place as the golden statue of  the .


Having sent the first-fruits to , the , in the name of the country generally, made inquiry of the god whether the first-fruits which he had received were of full measure and whether he was content. To this he said that he was content with what he had received from all other , but not from the . From these he demanded the victor's prize for the sea-fight of . When the  learned that, they dedicated three golden stars which are set on a bronze mast, in the angle, nearest to ' bowl.


After the division of the spoils, the  sailed to the Isthmus, there to award the prize of excellence to him who had shown himself most worthy of it in that war.
But when the admirals came and at the altar of  gave their votes to judge who was first and who second among them, each of them voted for himself, supposing himself to have done the best service. The greater part of them, however, united in giving the second place to . So they each gained but one vote, while  far outstripped them in votes for the second place.


The  were too jealous to assign the prize and sailed away each to his own place, leaving the matter undecided; nevertheless,  was lauded, and throughout all of  was deemed the wisest man by far of the .
However, because he had not received from those that fought at  the honor due to his preeminence, he immediately afterwards went to  in order that he might receive honor there. The  welcomed him and paid him high honor. They bestowed on  a crown of olive as the reward of excellence and another such crown on  for his wisdom and cleverness. They also gave him the finest chariot in ,

and with many words of praise, they sent him home with the three hundred picked men of  who are called Knights to escort him as far as the borders of .  was the only man of whom we know to whom the  gave this escort.


But when  returned to  from ,  of , who was one of ' enemies but not a man of note, was crazed with envy and spoke bitterly to  of his visit to , saying that the honors he had from the  were paid him for ' sake and not for his own.
This he kept saying until  replied, This is the truth of the matter: if I had been a man of  I would not have been honored in this way by the , nor would you, sir, for all you are a man of . Such was the end of that business.


 son of , who was already a notable man among the  and grew to be yet more so through the  business, escorted the king as far as the passage with sixty thousand men of the army that  had chosen.

, then, was now in , and when  came near  in his return (for  was wintering in  and  and making no haste to come to the rest of his army), he thought it right that he should enslave the people of , whom he found in revolt.
When the king had marched away past the town and the  fleet had taken flight from ,  had openly revolted from the barbarians and so too had the rest of the people of .


Thereupon  laid siege to , and suspecting that  too was plotting revolt from the king, he laid siege to it also. This town was held by  who had been driven from the  by the . Having besieged and taken , he brought these men to a lake and there cut their throats and delivered their city over to the charge of  of  and the  people. It was in this way that the  gained possession of .


Having taken ,  dealt immediately with , and his zeal was aided by  the general of the , who agreed to betray the place to him. I do not know how the agreement was first made, since there is no information available about it. The result, however, was as I will now show. Whenever  wrote a letter to be sent to , or  to , they would wrap it around the shaft of an arrow at the notches, attach feathers to the letter, and shoot it to a place upon which they had agreed.

' plot to betray  was, however, discovered, for  in shooting an arrow to the place agreed upon, missed it and hit the shoulder of a man of . A throng gathered quickly around the man when he was struck (which is a thing that always happens in war), and they straightway took the arrow, found the letter, and carried it to their generals; the rest of their allies of  were also there present.
The generals read the letter and perceived who was the traitor, but they resolved for 's sake that they would not condemn  with a charge of treason, for fear that the people of  should hereafter be called traitors.


This is how ' treachery was brought to light. But when  had besieged  for three months, there was a great ebb-tide in the sea which lasted for a long while, and when the foreigners saw that the sea was turned to a marsh, they prepared to pass over it into .
When they had made their way over two-fifths of it, however, and three yet remained to cross before they could be in , there came a great flood-tide, higher, as the people of the place say, than any one of the many that had been before. Some of them who did not know how to swim were drowned, and those who knew were slain by the , who came among them in boats.
The  say that the cause of the high sea and flood and the  disaster lay in the fact that those same  who now perished in the sea had profaned the temple and the image of  which was in the suburb of the city. I think that in saying that this was the cause they are correct. Those who escaped alive were led away by  to  in . This is how the men who had been the king's escort fared.


All that was left of ' fleet, having in its flight from  touched the coast of  and ferried the king and his army over from the  to , wintered at . Then early in the first dawn of spring they mustered at , where some of the ships had wintered. The majority of their fighting men were  and .

 son of  and  son of  came to be their admirals, and  chose also his own nephew  to have a share in the command. But by reason of the heavy blow dealt them they went no further out to sea westwards, nor did anyone insist that they should so do. They did, however, lie off  keeping watch against a revolt in . The whole number of their ships,  and other, was three hundred.
In truth they did not expect that the  would come to , but rather that they would be content to guard their own country. This they thought because the  had not pursued them when they fled from , but had been glad to be quit of them. In regard to the sea, the  were at heart beaten men, but they supposed that on land  would easily prevail.
So they were at , and there planned to do what harm they could to their enemies and to listen in the interim for news of how ' affairs were proceeding.


As for the , the coming of spring and ' being in  moved them to action. They had not yet begun the mustering of their army, but their fleet, one hundred and ten ships, came to .
Their general and admiral was  son of , who traced his lineage from son to father through , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , to  who was the son of . He was of the second royal house.
All the aforesaid had been kings of , save the seven named first after . The general of the  was  son of .


When all the ships had arrived at , there came to the  quarters messengers from the , the same who a little while before that had gone to  and entreated the  to free .
One of these was  the son of . These, who at first were seven, made a faction and conspired to slay , the tyrant of , but when their conspiracy became known, one of the accomplices having revealed their enterprise, the six who remained got them secretly out of , from where they went to  and now to , entreating the  to sail to .
The  took them as far as , and that not readily, for they, having no knowledge of those parts and thinking that armed men were everywhere, feared all that lay beyond. They supposed too that  was no nearer to them than the Pillars of . So it happened that the barbarians were too disheartened to dare to sail farther west than , while at the same time the  dared to go at the ' request no farther east than . It was fear which kept the middle space between them.


The , then, sailed to , and  wintered in . Having his headquarters there he sent a man of  called Mys to visit the places of divination, charging him to inquire of all the oracles which he could test. What it was that he desired to learn from the oracles when he gave this charge, I cannot say, for no one tells of it. I suppose that he sent to inquire concerning his present business, and that alone.


This man Mys is known to have gone to  and to have bribed a man of the country to go down into the cave of  and to have gone to the place of divination at  in . He went first to  where he inquired of  (sacrifice is there the way of divination, as at ), and moreover he bribed one who was no  but a stranger to lie down to sleep in the shrine of .
No  may seek a prophecy there, for  bade them by an oracle to choose which of the two they wanted and forgo the other, and take him either for their prophet or for their ally. They chose that he should be their ally. Therefore no  may lie down to sleep in that place.


But at this time there happened, as the  say, a thing at which I marvel greatly. It would seem that this man Mys of  came in his wanderings among the places of divination to the precinct of . This temple is called , and belongs to the . It lies by a hill, above lake , very near to the town .
When the man called Mys entered into this temple together with three men of the town who were chosen on the state's behalf to write down the oracles that should be given, straightway the diviner prophesied in a foreign tongue.
The  who followed him were astonished to hear a strange language instead of  and knew not what this present matter might be. Mys of , however, snatched from them the tablet which they carried and wrote on it that which was spoken by the prophet, saying that the words of the oracle were . After writing everything down, he went back to .


 read whatever was said in the oracles, and presently he sent a messenger to , , a , son of . Him he sent, partly because the  were akin to him; , a , had taken to wife  's sister and ' daughter, who had borne to him that  of  who was called by the name of his mother's father, and to whom the king gave  a great city in  for his dwelling. Partly too he sent him because he learned that  was a protector and benefactor to the .
It was thus that he supposed he could best gain the  for his allies, of whom he heard that they were a numerous and valiant people, and knew that they had been the chief authors of the calamities which had befallen the  at sea.
If he gained their friendship he thought he would easily become master of the seas, as truly he would have been. On land he supposed himself to be by much the stronger, and he accordingly reckoned that thus he would have the upper hand of the . This chanced to be the prediction of the oracles which counseled him to make the  his ally. It was in obedience to this that he sent his messenger.


This  was seventh in descent from , who got for himself the tyranny of  in the way that I will show. Three brothers of the lineage of  came as banished men from  to ,  and  and ; and from  they crossed over into the highlands of  till they came to the town .
There they served for wages as thetes in the king's household, one tending horses and another oxen. , who was the youngest, tended the lesser flocks. Now the king's wife cooked their food for them, for in old times the ruling houses among men, and not the common people alone, were lacking in wealth.
Whenever she baked bread, the loaf of the thete  grew double in size. Seeing that this kept happening, she told her husband, and it seemed to him when be heard it that this was a portent signifying some great matter. So he sent for his thetes and bade them depart from his territory.
They said it was only just that they should have their wages before they departed. When they spoke of wages, the king was moved to foolishness and said, That is the wage you merit, and it is that I give you, pointing to the sunlight that shone down the smoke vent into the house.

 and , who were the elder, stood astonished when they heard that, but the boy said, We accept what you give, O king, and with that he took a knife which he had with him and drew a line with it on the floor of the house round the sunlight. When he had done this, he three times gathered up the sunlight into the fold of his garment and went his way with his companions.


So they departed, but one of those who sat nearby declared to the king what this was that the boy had done and how it was of set purpose that the youngest of them had accepted the gift offered. When the king heard this, he was angered, and sent riders after them to slay them. There is, however, in that land a river, to which the descendants from  of these men offer sacrifice as their deliverer.
This river, when the sons of  had crossed it, rose in such flood that the riders could not cross. So the brothers came to another part of  and settled near the place called the garden of  son of , where roses grow of themselves, each bearing sixty blossoms and of surpassing fragrance.
In this garden, according to the  story,  was taken captive. Above it rises the mountain called , which none can ascend for the wintry cold. From there they issued forth when they had won that country and presently subdued also the rest of .


From that   was descended, being the son of , who was the son of ; ' father was , and his was ; ' father was , and his again was , who won that lordship.


Such was the lineage of  son of . When he came to  from  who had sent him, he spoke as follows : This, , is what  says to you:there is a message come to me from the king, saying, I forgive the  all the offenses which they have committed against me;

and now, , I bid you do this:Give them back their territory and let them choose more for themselves besides, where ever they will, and dwell under their own laws. Rebuild all their temples which I burnt, if they will make a pact with me. This is the message, and I must obey it (says ), unless you take it upon yourselves to hinder me.
This too I say to you:Why are you so insane as to wage war against the king? You cannot overcome him, nor can you resist him forever. As for the multitude of ' army, what it did, you have seen, and you have heard of the power that I now have with me. Even if you overcome and conquer us (whereof, if you be in your right minds, you can have no hope), yet there will come another host many times as great as this.
Be not then minded to match yourselves against the king, and thereby lose your land and always be yourselves in jeopardy, but make peace. This you can most honorably do since the king is that way inclined. Keep your freedom, and agree to be our brothers in arms in all faith and honesty.

This , is the message which  charges me to give you. For my own part I will say nothing of the goodwill that I have towards you, for it would not be the first that you have learned of that. But I entreat you to follow ' counsel.
Well I see that you will not have power to wage war against  forever. If I saw such power in you, I would never have come to you with such language as this, for the king's might is greater than human, and his arm is long.
If, therefore, you will not straightway agree with them, when the conditions which they offer you are so great, I fear what may befall you. For of all the allies you dwell most in the very path of the war, and you alone will never escape destruction, your country being marked out for a battlefield.
No, rather follow his counsel, for it is not to be lightly regarded by you who are the only men in  whose offenses the great king is ready to forgive and whose friend he would be.


These were the words of . The , however, had heard that  had come to  to bring the  to an agreement with the barbarian. Remembering the oracles, how that they themselves with the rest of the  must be driven out of the  by the  and the , they were greatly afraid that the  should agree with the , and they straightway resolved that they would send envoys.
Moreover, it so fell out for both that they made their entry at one and the same time, for the  delayed and waited for them, being certain that the  were going to hear that the messenger had come from the  for an agreement. They had heard that the  would send their envoys with all speed. Therefore it was of set purpose that they did this in order that they might make their will known to the .


So when  had made an end of speaking, the envoys from  said, We on our part have been sent by the  to entreat you to do nothing harmful to  and accept no offer from the barbarian.
That would be unjust and dishonorable for any , but for you most of all, on many counts; it was you who stirred up this war, by no desire of ours, and your territory was first the stake of that battle in which all  is now engaged.
Apart from that, it is unbearable that not all this alone but slavery too should be brought upon the  by you , who have always been known as givers of freedom to many. Nevertheless, we grieve with you in your afflictions, seeing that you have lost two harvests and your substance has been for a long time wasted.
In requital for this the  and their allies declare that they will nourish your women and all of your household members who are unserviceable for war, so long as this war will last. Let not  the  win you with his smooth-tongued praise of ' counsel. It is his business to follow that counsel,

for as he is a tyrant so must he be the tyrant's fellow-worker; it is not your business, if you are men rightly minded, for you know that in foreigners there is no faith nor truth. These are the words of the envoys.


But to  the  replied as follows: We know of ourselves that the power of the  is many times greater than ours. There is no need to taunt us with that. Nevertheless in our zeal for freedom we will defend ourselves to the best of our ability. But as regards agreements with the barbarian, do not attempt to persuade us to enter into them, nor will we consent.
Now carry this answer back to  from the , that as long as the sun holds the course by which he now goes, we will make no agreement with . We will fight against him without ceasing, trusting in the aid of the gods and the heroes whom he has disregarded and burnt their houses and their adornments.
Come no more to  with such a plea, nor under the semblance of rendering us a service, counsel us to act wickedly. For we do not want those who are our friends and protectors to suffer any harm at  hands.


Such was their answer to , but to the  envoys they said, It was most human that the  should fear our making an agreement with the barbarian. We think that it is an ignoble thing to be afraid, especially since we know the  temper to be such that there is nowhere on earth such store of gold or such territory of surpassing fairness and excellence that the gift of it should win us to take the  part and enslave .
For there are many great reasons why we should not do this, even if we so desired; first and foremost, the burning and destruction of the adornments and temples of our gods, whom we are constrained to avenge to the utmost rather than make pacts with the perpetrator of these things, and next the kinship of all  in blood and speech, and the shrines of gods and the sacrifices that we have in common, and the likeness of our way of life, to all of which it would not befit the  to be false.
Know this now, if you knew it not before, that as long as one  is left alive we will make no agreement with . Nevertheless we thank you for your forethought concerning us, in that you have so provided for our wasted state that you offer to nourish our households.
For your part, you have given us full measure of kindness, yet for ourselves, we will make shift to endure as best we may, and not be burdensome to you. But now, seeing that this is so, send your army with all speed,

for as we guess, the barbarian will be upon us and invade our country in no long time as soon as the message comes to him that we will do nothing that he requires of us; therefore, before he comes into , now is the time for us to march first into . At this reply of the  the envoys returned back to .

The bronze three-headed serpent supporting the cauldron was intended apparently to commemorate the whole  alliance against . The serpent pedestal still exists, in the  (formerly ) at , whither it was transported by ; it has been fully exposed and its inscription deciphered since . l: Many a Median archer, by death untimely overtaken will fall
There in the battle when the day of his doom is upon him.

p.#text:
When  returned and told him what he had heard from the ,  set forth from  and led his army with all zeal against ; he also took with him all the people to whose countries he came along the way. The rulers of  did not repent of what they had already done and were readier than before to further his march.  of , who had given  safe-conduct in his flight, now, without any attempt of concealment, opened a passage for  into .


But when, in the course of its march, the army had come into , the  attempted to stay , advising him that he could find no country better fitted than theirs for encampment; he should not (they begged) go further, but rather halt there and subdue all  without fighting.
As long as the  who were previously in accord remained so, it would be difficult even for the whole world to overcome them by force of arms; but if you do as we advise, said the , you will without trouble be master of all their battle plans.
Send money to the men who have power in their cities, and thereby you will divide  against itself; after that, with your partisans to aid you, you will easily subdue those who are your adversaries.


Such was their counsel, but he would not follow it. What he desired was to take  once more; this was partly out of mere perversity, and partly because he intended to signify to the king at  by a line of beacons across the islands that he held .

 When he came to , however, he found the city as unpopulated as before, for, as he learned, the majority of them were on shipboard at . So he took the city, but without any of its men. There were ten months between the kings taking of the place and the later invasion of .


When  came to , he sent to  a certain , a man from , bearing the same offer as  the  had ferried across to the .
He sent this for the second time because although he already knew the ' unfriendly purpose, he expected that they would abandon their stubbornness now that  was the captive of his spear and lay at his mercy.


For this reason he sent  to  who came before the council and conveyed to them  message. Then , one of the councillors, said that it seemed best to him to receive the offer brought to them by  and lay it before the people.
This was the opinion which he declared, either because he had been bribed by , or because the plan pleased him. The  in the council were, however, very angry; so too were those outside when they heard of it. They made a ring round  and stoned him to death.  the , however, they permitted to depart unharmed.
There was much noise at  over the business of ; and when the  women learned what was afoot, one calling to another and bidding her follow, they went on their own impetus to the house of  and stoned to death his wife and his children.


Now this was how the  had crossed over to . As long as they expected that the  army would come to their aid, they remained in . But when the  took longer and longer to act and the invader was said to be in  already, they then conveyed all their goods out of harms way and themselves crossed over to . They also sent envoys to , who were to upbraid the  for permitting the barbarian to invade  and not helping the  to meet him in ; and who were to remind the  of the promises which the  had made to  if she would change sides, and warn them that the  would devise some means of salvation for themselves if the  sent them no help.


The  were at this time celebrating the festival of , and their chief concern was to give the god his due; moreover, the wall which they were building on the Isthmus was by now getting its battlements. When the  envoys arrived in , bringing with them envoys from  and , they came before the ephors and said:


The  have sent us with this message: the king of the  is ready to give us back our country, and to make us his confederates, equal in right and standing, in all honor and honesty, and to give us whatever land we ourselves may choose besides our own.
But we, since we do not want to sin against  the god of  and think it shameful to betray , have not consented. This we have done despite the fact that the  are dealing with us wrongfully and betraying us to our hurt; furthermore, we know that it is more to our advantage to make terms with the  than to wage war with him, yet we will not make terms with him of our own free will. For our part, we act honestly by the ;


but what of you, who once were in great dread lest we should make terms with the ? Now that you have a clear idea of our sentiments and are sure that we will never betray , and now that the wall which you are building across the Isthmus is nearly finished, you take no account of the , but have deserted us despite all your promises that you would withstand the  in , and have permitted the barbarian to march into .
For the present, then, the  are angry with you since you have acted in a manner unworthy of you. Now they ask you to send with us an army with all speed, so that we may await the foreigner's onset in ; since we have lost , in our own territory the most suitable place for a battle is the  plain.


When the ephors heard that, they delayed answering till the next day, and again till the day after. This they did for ten days, putting it off from day to day. In the meantime all the  were doing all they could to fortify the Isthmus, and they had nearly completed the task.
I cannot say for certain why it was that when  the  came to  the  insisted that the  should not join the side of the , yet now took no account of that; it may be that with the Isthmus fortified, they thought they had no more need of the , whereas when  came to , their wall was not yet built and they were working at this in great fear of the .


The nature of their response was as follows: on the day before the final hearing of the  delegation, , a man of , who had more authority with the  than any other of their guests, learned from the ephors all that the  had said.
