Upon hearing this he, as the tale goes, said to the ephors, Sirs, if the  are our enemies and the barbarians allies, then although you push a strong wall across the Isthmus, a means of access into the  lies wide open for the . No, give heed to what they say before the  take some new resolve which will bring calamity to .


This was the counsel he gave the ephors, who straightway took it to heart. Without saying a word to the envoys who had come from the cities, they ordered five thousand  to march before dawn. Seven helots were appointed to attend each of them, and they gave the command to  son of .
The leader's place rightfully belonged to  son of , but he was still a boy, and  his guardian and cousin. , ' father and ' son, was no longer living.
After he led the army which had built the wall away from the Isthmus, he lived but a little while before his death. The reason for  leading his army away from the Isthmus was that while he was offering sacrifice for victory over the , the sun was darkened in the heavens.  chose as his colleague a man of the same family,  son of .


So ' army had marched away from ; but as soon as it was day, the envoys came before the ephors, having no knowledge of the expedition, and being minded themselves too to depart each one to his own place. When they arrived, You , they said, remain where you are, observing your  and celebrating, leaving your allies deserted. For the wrong that you do them and for lack of allies, the , will make their peace with the  as best they can,

and thereafter, in so far as we will be king's allies, we will march with him against whatever land his men lead us. Then will you learn what the issue of this matter will be for you. In response to this the ephors swore to them that they believed their army to be even now at , marching against the strangers, as they called the barbarians.
Having no knowledge of this, the envoys questioned them further as to the meaning of this and thereby learned the whole truth; they marvelled at this and hastened with all speed after the army. With them went five thousand men-at-arms of the  countrymen.


So they made haste to reach the Isthmus. The , however, had already promised  that they would prevent the  from going out to war. As soon as they were informed that  and his army had departed from , they sent as their herald to  the swiftest runner of long distances whom they could find.
When he came to , he spoke to  in the following manner: I have been sent by the  to tell you that the young men have gone out from  to war, and that the  cannot prevent them from so doing; therefore, make plans accordingly.


So spoke the herald, and went back again. When  heard that, he no longer desired to remain in . Before he had word of it, he had held his land, desiring to know the ' plan and what they would do; he neither harmed nor harried the land of , for he still supposed that they would make terms with him.
But when he could not prevail upon them and learned the truth of the matter, he withdrew before ' army prior to its entering the Isthmus. First, however, he burnt , and utterly overthrew and demolished whatever wall or house or temple was left standing.
The reason for his marching away was that  was not a land fit for horses, and if he should be defeated in a battle, there was no way of retreat save one so narrow that a few men could prevent his passage. He therefore planned to retreat to  and do battle where he had a friendly city at his back and ground suitable for horsemen.


So  drew his men off, and when he had now set forth on his road there came a message that in addition to the others, an advance guard of a thousand  had arrived at . When he heard this, he deliberated how he might first make an end of these. He accordingly turned about and led his army against , his cavalry going first and overrunning the lands of that city. That was the westernmost place in  which this  army reached.


Presently there came a message to  that the  were gathered together on the Isthmus. Thereupon he marched back again through ; the rulers of  sent for those of the  country who lived nearby, and these guided him to  and from there to .
Here he camped for the night, and on the next day he turned from there to , where he was in  territory. There he laid waste the lands of the , though they sided with the  part. This he did, not for any ill-will that he bore them, but because sheer necessity drove him to make a stronghold for his army and to have this for a refuge if the fortune of battle were other than he wished.
His army, stationed along the , covered the ground from  past  and up to the lands of . I do not mean to say that the walled camp which he made was of this size; each side of it was of a length of about ten furlongs.


While the barbarians were engaged in this task,  son of , a , made great preparations and invited  with fifty who were the most notable of the  to be his guests at a banquet. They came as they were bidden; the dinner was held at . What follows was told me by  of , one of the most notable men of that place.  too (he said) was invited to this dinner, and fifty  in addition.  made them sit, not each man by himself but on each couch a  and a  together.
Now as they were drinking together after dinner, the  who sat with him asked  in the  tongue from what country he was.  answered that he was from . Then said the : Since you have eaten at the board with me and drunk with me afterwards, I would like to leave a memorial of my belief, so that you yourself may have such knowledge as to take fitting counsel for your safety.
Do you see these  at the banquet and that host which we left encamped by the river side? In a little while you shall see but a small remnant left alive of all these. As he said this, the  wept bitterly.
Marvelling at these words,  answered: Must you not then tell this to  and those honorable  who are with him? Sir, said the , that which a god wills to send no man can turn aside, for even truth sometimes finds no one to believe it.
What I have said is known to many of us , but we follow, in the bonds of necessity. It is the most hateful thing for a person to have much knowledge and no power. This tale I heard from  of  who told me in addition that he had straightway told this to others before the battle of .


So  was making his encampment in . All the  of that region who sided with the  furnished fighting men, and they joined with him in his attack upon , with the exception of the ; as for taking the  side, that they did right away, though from necessity rather than willingly.
A few days after the ' coming to , a thousand  men-at-arms under the leadership of , the most notable of their countrymen, arrived. When these men too were in ,  sent horsemen and bade the  take their station on the plain by themselves.
When they had done so, the whole of the  cavalry appeared, and presently word was spread through all of the  army which was with , and likewise among the  themselves, that  would shoot them to death with javelins.
Then their general  exhorted them: Men of , he said, seeing that death at these fellows' hands is staring us in the face (we being, as I surmise, maligned by the ), it is now time for every one of you to be noble; for it is better to end our lives in action and fighting than tamely to suffer a shameful death. No, rather we will teach them that they whose slaying they have devised are men of . Thus he exhorted them.


But when the horsemen had encircled the , they rode at them as if to slay them, and drew their bows to shoot; it is likely too that some did in fact shoot. The  opposed them in every possible way, drawing in together and closing their ranks to the best of their power. At this the horsemen wheeled about and rode back and away.
Now I cannot with exactness say whether they came at the ' desire to slay the , but when they saw the men preparing to defend themselves, they feared lest they themselves should suffer some hurt, and so rode away (for such was ' command),or if  wanted to test the ' mettle.
When the horsemen had ridden away,  sent a herald, with this message: Men of , be of good courage, for you have shown yourselves to be valiant men, and not as it was reported to me. Now push this war zealously forward, for you will outdo neither myself nor the king in the rendering of service. This is how the matter of the  turned out.


As for the , when they had come to the Isthmus, they encamped there. When the rest of the  who chose the better cause heard that, seeing the  setting forth to war, they thought that they should not lag behind the  in so doing.
Accordingly, they all marched from the Isthmus (the omens of sacrifice being favorable) and came to . When they had offered sacrifice there also and the omens were favorable, they continued their march, having now the  with them, who had crossed over from  and joined with them at .
When they came (as it is said) to  in , they learned that the barbarians were encamped by the . Taking note of that, they arrayed themselves opposite the enemy on the lower hills of .


When the  did not come down into the plain,  sent against them his entire cavalry, whose commander was  (whom the  call ), a man much honored among the ; he rode a  horse which had a golden bit and was elaborately adorned all over. Thereupon the horsemen rode up to the  and charged them by squadrons; as they attacked, they did them much hurt, and called them women all the while.


Now it chanced that the  were posted in that part of the field which was most open to attack, and here the horsemen found the readiest approach. Therefore, being hard-pressed by the charges, the  sent a herald to the generals of the , who came to them and spoke as follows :

From the men of  to their allies: we cannot alone withstand the  cavalry (although we have till now held our ground with patience and valor, despite the fact that we were hard-pressed) in the position to which we were first appointed. Know that now we will abandon our post, unless you send others to take our place there.
This the herald reported, and  inquired among the  if any would offer to go to that place and relieve the  by holding the post. All the others did not want to, but the  took it upon themselves, that is three hundred picked men of , whose captain was  son of .


Those who volunteered themselves, were posted at  in front of the whole  army, and they took with them the archers also. They fought for a long time and the end of the battle was as I will now tell. The cavalry charged by squadrons, and ' horse, being at the head of the rest, was struck in the side by an arrow. Rearing up in pain, it threw ,

who when he fell, was straightaway set upon by the . His horse they took then and there, and he himself was killed fighting. They could not, however, kill him at first, for he was outfitted in the following manner: he wore a purple tunic over a cuirass of golden scales which was within it; thus they accomplished nothing by striking at the cuirass, until someone saw what was happening and stabbed him in the eye. Then he collapsed and died.
But as chance would have it, the rest of the horsemen knew nothing of this, for they had not seen him fall from his horse, or die. They wheeled about and rode back without perceiving what was done. As soon as they halted, however, they saw what they were missing since there was no one to give them orders. Then when they perceived what had occurred, they gave each other the word, and all rode together to recover the dead body.


When the  saw the horsemen riding at them, not by squadrons as before, but all together, they cried to the rest of the army for help. While all their infantry was rallying to aid, there was a bitter fight over the dead body.
As long as the three hundred stood alone, they had the worst of the battle by far, and were ready to leave the dead man. When the main body came to their aid, then it was the horsemen who could no longer hold their ground, nor help to recover the dead man, but rather lost others of their comrades in addition to . They accordingly withdrew and halted about two furlongs away, where they deliberated what they should do. Since there was no one to give them orders, they resolved to report to .


When the cavalry returned to camp,  and the whole army mourned deeply for , cutting their own hair and the hair of their horses and beasts of burden, and lamenting loudly; the sound of this was heard over all , for a man was dead who, next to , was most esteemed by all  and the king.


So the barbarians honored ' death in their customary way, but the  were greatly encouraged that they withstood and drove off the charging horsemen. First they laid the dead man on a cart and carried him about their ranks, and the body was well worth seeing, because of its stature and grandeur; therefore, they would even leave their ranks and come to view .
Presently they resolved that they would march down to , for they saw that the ground there was generally more suited for encampment than that at , and chiefly because it was better watered. It was to this place and to the  spring which was there, that they resolved to go and pitch camp in their several battalions;
They took up their arms and marched along the lower slopes of  past  to the lands of , and when they arrived, they arrayed themselves nation by nation near the  spring and the precinct of the hero , among low hills and in a level country.


During the drawing up of battle formation there arose much dispute between the  and the , for each of them claimed that they should hold the second wing of the army, justifying themselves by tales of deeds new and old.
First the  spoke: We, among all the allies, have always had the right to hold this position in all campaigns, of the united  armies, both ancient and recent, ever since that time when the  after ' death attempted to return to the .
We gained because of the achievement which we will relate. When we marched out at the Isthmus for war, along with the  and  who then dwelt in the , and encamped opposite the returning exiles, then (it is said)  announced that army should not be risked against army in battle, but that that champion in the host of the  whom they chose as their best should fight with him in single combat on agreed conditions.
The , resolving that this should be so, swore a compact that if  should overcome the  champion, the  should return to the land of their fathers, but if he were himself beaten, then the  should depart and lead their army away, not attempting to return to the  until a hundred years had passed.
Then our general and king , son of ' son , volunteered and was chosen out of all the allied host; he fought that duel and killed . It was for that feat of arms that the  granted us this in addition to other great privileges which we have never ceased to possess, namely that in all united campaigns we should always lead the army's second wing.
Now with you, men of , we have no rivalry, but forbear and bid you choose the command of whichever wing you want. We do, however, say that our place is at the head of the other, as it has always been. Quite apart from that feat which we have related, we are worthier than the  to hold that post,

for we have fought many battles which turned out favorably for you, men of , and others besides. It is accordingly we and not the  who should hold the second wing, for neither at some earlier period nor recently, have they achieved such feats of arms as we.


To these words the  replied: It is our belief that we are gathered for battle with the barbarian, and not for speeches; but since the man of  has made it his business to speak of all the valorous deeds, old and new, which either of our nations has at any time achieved, we must prove to you how we, rather than , have by virtue of our valor a hereditary right to the place of honor. These  say that they killed the leader of the  at the Isthmus.
Now when those same  had been rejected by every  people to whom they resorted to escape the tyranny of the , we alone received them. With them we vanquished those who then inhabited the , and we broke the pride of .
Furthermore, when the  who had marched with  against  had there made an end of their lives and lay unburied, know that we sent our army against the  and recovered the dead and buried them in .
We also have on record our great victory against the , who once came from the river  and broke into , and in the hard days of  we were second to none. But since it is useless to recall these mattersfor those who were previously valiant may now be of lesser mettle, and those who lacked mettle then may be better men now

enough of the past. Supposing that we were known for no achievement (although the fact is that we have done more than any other of the ), we nevertheless deserve to have this honor and more beside because of the role we played at Marathon, seeing that alone of all  we met the  singlehandedly and did not fail in that enterprise, but overcame forty-six nations.
Is it not then our right to hold this post, for that one feat alone? Yet seeing that this is no time for wrangling about our place in the battle, we are ready to obey you, men of  and take whatever place and face whatever enemy you think fitting. Wherever you set us, we will strive to be valiant men. Command us then, knowing that we will obey.

This was the ' response, and the whole army shouted aloud that the  were worthier to hold the wing than the . It was in this way that the  were preferred to the men of , and gained that place.

Presently the whole  army was arrayed as I will show, both the later and the earliest comers. On the right wing were ten thousand ; five thousand of these, who were , had a guard of thirty-five thousand light-armed helots, seven appointed for each man.
The  chose the  for their neighbors in the battle, both to do them honor, and for their valor; there were of these fifteen hundred men-at-arms. Next to these in the line were five thousand , at whose desire  permitted the three hundred  from  then present to stand by them.
Next to these were six hundred  from , and after them three thousand men of . By these one thousand  were posted, and after them two hundred men of , then four hundred from  and , and next to them one thousand from . By these stood three hundred men of .
Next to the men of  were six hundred  and ; next to them, four hundred ; next again, five hundred . After these stood eight hundred  and , and next to them two hundred from  in ;

after them in the array, five hundred ; by them stood three thousand men of , and next to these six hundred . At the end, and first in the line, were the  who held the left wing. They were eight thousand in number, and their general was  son of .


All these, except the seven appointed to attend each , were men-at-arms, and the whole sum of them was thirty-eight thousand and seven hundred. This was the number of men-at-arms that mustered for war against the barbarian; as regards the number of the light-armed men, there were in the  array seven for each man-at-arms, that is, thirty-five thousand, and every one of these was equipped for war.
The light-armed from the rest of  and  were as one to every man-at-arms, and their number was thirty-four thousand and five hundred.


So the total of all the light-armed men who were fighters was sixty-nine thousand and five hundred, and of the whole  army mustered at , men-at-arms and light-armed fighting men together, eleven times ten thousand less eighteen hundred. The  who were present were one hundred and ten thousand in number, for the survivors of the  were also present with the army, eighteen hundred in number. These then were arrayed and encamped by the .


When ' barbarians had finished their mourning for  and heard that the  were at , they also came to the part of the  nearest to them. When they were there, they were arrayed for battle by  as I shall show. He posted the  facing the .
Seeing that the  by far outnumbered the , they were arrayed in deeper ranks and their line ran opposite the  also. In his arraying of them he chose out the strongest part of the  to set it over against the , and posted the weaker by them facing the ; this he did being so informed and taught by the .
Next to the  he posted the  opposite the men of , , , and ; next to the , the , opposite the men of , , , , , and .
After the  he set the , opposite the men of  and  and  and . Next to the  he posted the , opposite the , , , , and ;

next to the , and opposite the , , , the , , , , and the thousand that came from ; for not all the  took the  side, but some of them gave their aid to the  cause; these had been besieged on , and issued out from there to harry ' army and the  who were with him. Beside these, he arrayed the  also and those who lived in the area of  opposite the .


These which I have named were the greatest of the nations set in array by , but there was also in the army a mixture of , , , , and the rest, besides  and the  swordsmen called  and , who are the only fighting men in .
These had been fighters on shipboard, till  while yet at  disembarked them from their ships; for the  were not appointed to serve in the land army which  led to . Of the barbarians, then, there were three hundred thousand, as I have already shown. As for the  allies of , no one knows the number of them (for they were not counted), I suppose them to have been mustered to the number of fifty thousand. These were the footmen that were set in array; the cavalry were separately ordered.


On the second day after they had all been arrayed according to their nations and their battalions, both armies offered sacrifice. It was  who sacrificed for the , for he was with their army as a diviner; he was an  by birth, a  of the  clan, and the  gave him the freedom of their city.
This they did, for when  was inquiring of the oracle at  concerning offspring, the priestess prophesied to him that he should win five great victories. Not understanding that oracle, he engaged in bodily exercise, thinking that he would then be able to win in similar sports. When he had trained himself for the Five Contests, he came within one wrestling bout of winning the  prize, in a match with  of .
The , however, perceived that the oracle given to  spoke of the lists not of sport but of war, and they attempted to bribe  to be a leader in their wars jointly with their kings of ' line.
When he saw that the  set great store by his friendship, he set his price higher, and made it known to them that he would do what they wanted only in exchange for the gift of full citizenship and all of the citizen's rights.
Hearing that, the  at first were angry and completely abandoned their request; but when the dreadful menace of this  host hung over them, they consented and granted his demand. When he saw their purpose changed, he said that he would not be content with that alone; his brother  too must be made a  on the same terms as himself.


By so saying he imitated , in so far as one may compare demands for kingship with those for citizenship. For when the women of  had gone mad, and the  wanted him to come from  and heal them of that madness,  demanded half of their kingship for his wages.
This the  would not put up with and departed. When, however, the madness spread among their women, they promised what  demanded and were ready to give it to him. Thereupon, seeing their purpose changed, he demanded yet more and said that he would not do their will except if they gave a third of their kingship to his brother ; now driven into dire straits, the  consented to that also.


The  too were so eagerly desirous of winning  that they granted everything that he demanded. When they had granted him this also,  of , now a , engaged in divination for them and aided them to win five very great victories. No one on earth save  and his brother ever became citizens of .
Now the five victories were these: one, the first, this victory at ; next, that which was won at  over the  and ; after that, over all the  save the  at ; next, over the  at ; lastly, the victory at  over the  and , which was the last won of the five victories.


This  had now been brought by the  and was the diviner of the  at . The sacrifices boded good to the  if they would just defend themselves, but evil if they should cross the  and be the first to attack.


' sacrifices also foretold an unfavorable outcome if he should be zealous to attack first, and good if he should but defend himself. He too used the  manner of sacrifice, and  of  was his diviner, the most notable of the sons of . This man had been put in prison and condemned to die by the  for the great harm which he had done them.
Being in such bad shape inasmuch as he was in peril of his life and was likely to be very grievously maltreated before his death, he did something which was almost beyond belief; made fast in iron-bound stocks, he got an iron weapon which was brought in some way into his prison, and straightway conceived a plan of such courage as we have never known; reckoning how best the rest of it might get free, he cut off his own foot at the instep.
This done, he tunneled through the wall out of the way of the guards who kept watch over him, and so escaped to . All night he journeyed, and all day he hid and lay hidden in the woods, till on the third night he came to , while all the people of  sought him. The latter were greatly amazed when they saw the half of his foot which had been cut off and lying there but not were unable to find the man himself.
This, then, is the way in which he escaped the  and took refuge in , which at that time was unfriendly to . After he was healed and had made himself a foot of wood, he declared himself an open enemy of the . Yet the enmity which he bore them brought him no good at the last, for they caught him at his divinations in  and killed him.


The death of , however, took place after the  business. At the present he was by the , hired by  for no small wage, where he sacrificed and worked zealously, both for the hatred he bore the  and for gain.
When no favorable omens for battle could be won either by the  themselves or by the  who were with them (for they too had a diviner of their own,  of ), and the  kept flocking in and their army grew,  son of , a , advised  to guard the outlet of the pass over , telling him that the  were coming in daily and that he would thereby cut off many of them.


The armies had already lain hidden opposite each other for eight days when he gave this counsel.  perceived that the advice was good, and when night had fallen, he sent his horsemen to the outlet of the pass over  which leads towards . This pass the  call the , and the  the . The horsemen who were sent out did not go in vain,

for they caught both five hundred beasts of burden which were going into the low country, bringing provisions from the  for the army, and men who came with the wagons. When they had taken this quarry, the  killed without mercy, sparing neither man nor beast. When they had their fill of slaughter, they encircled the rest and drove them to  and his camp.


After this deed they waited two days more, neither side desiring to begin the battle, for although the barbarians came to the  to test the  intent, neither army crossed it. ' cavalry, however, kept pressing upon and troubling the , for the , in their zeal for the  part, waged war heartily, and kept on guiding the horsemen to the encounter; thereafter it was the turn of the  and , and they and none other would do deeds of valor.


Until ten days had passed, no more was done than this. On the eleventh day from their first encampment opposite each other, the  growing greatly in number and  being greatly vexed by the delay, there was a debate held between  son of  and  son of , who stood as high as only few others in ' esteem.
Their opinions in council were as I will show.  thought it best that they should strike their camp with all speed and lead the whole army within the walls of . Here there was much food stored and fodder for their beasts of burden; furthermore, they could sit at their ease here and conclude the business by doing as follows:

they could take the great store they had of gold, minted and other, and silver drinking-cups, and send all this to all places in  without stint, excepting none, but especially to the chief men in the cities of . Let them do this (he said) and the  would quickly surrender their liberty; but do not let the  risk the event of a battle.
This opinion of his was the same as the , inasmuch as he too had special foreknowledge. ' counsel, however, was more vehement and intemperate and not at all leaning to moderation. He said that he thought that their army was much stronger than the  and that they should give battle with all speed so as not to let more  muster than were mustered already. As for the sacrifices of , let them pay no heed to these, nor seek to wring good from them, but rather give battle after  custom.


No one withstood this argument, and his opinion accordingly prevailed; for it was he and not  who was commander of the army by the king's commission. He therefore sent for the leaders of the battalions and the generals of those  who were with him and asked them if they knew any oracle which prophesied that the  should perish in .
Those who were summoned said nothing, some not knowing the prophecies, and some knowing them but thinking it perilous to speak, and then  himself said: Since you either have no knowledge or are afraid to declare it, hear what I tell you based on the full knowledge that I have.
There is an oracle that  are fated to come to  and all perish there after they have plundered the temple at . Since we have knowledge of this same oracle, we will neither approach that temple nor attempt to plunder it; in so far as destruction hinges on that, none awaits us.
Therefore, as many of you as wish the  well may rejoice in that we will overcome the . Having spoken in this way, he gave command to have everything prepared and put in good order for the battle which would take place early the next morning.


Now for this prophecy, which  said was spoken of the , I know it to have been made concerning not them but the  and the army of the . There is, however, a prophecy made by  concerning this battle:




I know that these verses and others very similar to them from  referred to the . As for the river , it flows between  and .


After this inquiry about oracles and ' exhortation, night fell, and the armies posted their sentries. Now when the night was far advanced and it seemed that all was still in the camps and the men were sleeping deeply, at that hour  son of , the general and king of the , rode up to the  outposts and wanted to speak to their generals.

 The greater part of the sentries remained where they were, but the rest ran to their generals and told them that a horseman had ridden in from the  camp, imparting no other word save that he desired to speak to the generals and called them by their names.


Hearing that, the generals straightway went with the men to the outposts. When they had come,  said to them: Men of , I give you this message in trust as a secret which you must reveal to no one but , or else you will be responsible for my undoing. In truth I would not tell it to you if I did not care so much for all ;
I myself am by ancient descent a , and I would not willingly see  change her freedom for slavery. I tell you, then, that  and his army cannot get omens to his liking from the sacrifices. Otherwise you would have fought long before this. Now, however, it is his purpose to pay no heed to the sacrifices, and to attack at the first glimmer of dawn, for he fears, as I surmise, that your numbers will become still greater. Therefore, I urge you to prepare, and if (as may be)  should delay and not attack, wait patiently where you are; for he has but a few days' provisions left.
If, however, this war ends as you wish, then must you take thought how to save me too from slavery, who have done so desperate a deed as this for the sake of  in my desire to declare to you ' intent so that the barbarians may not attack you suddenly before you yet expect them. I who speak am  the . With that he rode away back to the camp and his own station there.


The  generals went to the right wing and told  what they had heard from . At the message  was terrified by the , and said:

Since, therefore, the battle is to begin at dawn, it is best that you  should take your stand opposite the , and we opposite the  and the  who are posted opposite you; for you have fought with the  at Marathon and know them and their manner of fighting while we have no experience or knowledge of those men. We  have experience of the  and , but not one of us has experience with the .
No, rather let us take up our equipment and change places, you to this wing and we to the left. We, too, the  answered, even from the moment when we saw the  posted opposite you, had it in mind to make that suggestion which now has first come from you. We feared, however, that we would displease you by making it. But since you have spoken the wish yourselves, we too hear your words very gladly and are ready to do as you say.


Since both were satisfied with this, they exchanged their places in the ranks at the first light of dawn. The  noticed that and made it known to . When he heard this, he straight away attempted to make a change for himself also, by moving the  opposite the . When  perceived what was being done, he saw that his action had been discovered and led the  back to the right wing;  did the same thing on the left of his army.


When all were at their former posts again,  sent a herald to the  with this message: Men of , you are said by the people of these parts to be very brave men. It is their boast of you that you neither flee from the field nor leave your post, but remain there and either slay your enemies or are yourselves killed. It would seem, however, that there is no truth in all this,

for before we could attack and fight hand to hand, we saw you even now fleeing and leaving your station, using  for the first trial of your enemy and arraying yourselves opposite those who are but our slaves.
This is not the action of brave men. No, we have been grievously mistaken about you, for in accordance with what we heard about you, we expected that you would send us a herald challenging the  and none other to fight with you. That we were ready to do; but we find you making no such offer, but rather quailing before us. Now, therefore, since the challenge comes not from you, take it from us instead.
What is there to prevent us from fighting with equal numbers on both sides, you for the  (since you have the reputation of being their best), and we for the barbarians? If it is desirable that the others fight also, let them fight after us, but if, on the contrary the opinion prevails that we alone suffice, then let us fight it out. Let the winner in this contest determine victory for the whole army.


This is the proclamation made by the herald; and when he had waited a while and no one answered him, he went back again, and at his return told what had happened to him.  was overjoyed and proud of this semblance of victory, and sent his cavalry to attack the .
The horsemen rode at them and shot arrows and javelins among the whole  army to its great hurt, since they were mounted archers and difficult to deal with in an encounter; they spoiled and blocked the  spring, from which the entire  army drew its water.
None indeed but the  were posted near the spring, and it was far from the several stations of the other , whereas the  was near; nevertheless, they would always go to the spring, since they were barred from the , not being able to draw water from that river because of the horsemen and the arrows.


When this happened, seeing that their army was cut off from water and thrown into confusion by the horsemen, the generals of the  went to  on the right wing, and debated concerning this and other matters; for there were other problems which troubled them more than what I have told. They had no food left, and their followers whom they had sent into the  to bring provisions had been cut off by the horsemen and could not make their way to the army.


So they resolved in their council that if the  held off through that day from giving battle, they would go to the Island. This is ten furlongs distant from the  and the  spring, near which their army then lay, and in front of the town of .
It is like an island on dry land because the river in its course down from  into the plain is parted into two channels, and there is about three furlongs space in between till presently the two channels unite again, and the name of that river is , who (as the people of the country say ) was the daughter of .
To that place then they planned to go so that they might have plenty of water for their use and not be harmed by the horsemen, as now when they were face to face with them; and they resolved to change places in the second watch of the night, lest the  should see them setting forth and the horsemen press after them and throw them into confusion.
Furthermore, they resolved that when they had come to that place, which is encircled by the divided channels of ' daughter  as she flows from , they would in that night send half of their army to , to remove their followers who had gone to get the provisions; for these were cut off from them on .


Having made this plan, all that day they suffered constant hardship from the cavalry which continually pressed upon them. When the day ended, however, and the horsemen stopped their onslaught, then at that hour of the night at which it was agreed that they should depart, most of them rose and departed, not with intent to go to the place upon which they had agreed. Instead of that, once they were on their way, they joyfully shook off the horsemen and escaped to the town of . In the course of their flight they came to the temple of  which is outside of that town, twenty furlongs distant from the  spring and piled their arms in front of the temple.


So they encamped around the temple of . , however, seeing their departure from the camp, gave orders to the  to take up their arms likewise and follow the others who had gone ahead, supposing that these were making for the place where they had agreed to go.
Thereupon, all the rest of the captains being ready to obey ,  son of , the leader of the  battalion, refused to flee from the barbarians or (save by compulsion) bring shame on ; the whole business seemed strange to him, for he had not been present in the council recently held.

 and  were outraged that  disobeyed them. Still more, however, they disliked that his refusing would compel them to abandon the  battalion, for they feared that if they fulfilled their agreement with the rest of the  and abandoned him,  and his men would be left behind to perish.
Bearing this in mind, they kept the  army where it was and tried to persuade  that he was in the wrong.


So they reasoned with , he being the only man left behind of all the  and . As for the , they stood unmoved at their post, well aware that the purposes and the promises of  were not alike.
But when the army left its station, they sent a horseman of their own to see whether the  were attempting to march or whether they were not intending to depart, and to ask  what the  should do.


When the messenger arrived among the , he saw them arrayed where they had been, and their chief men by now in hot dispute. For though  and  reasoned with , that the  should not be endangered by remaining there alone, they could in no way prevail upon him. At last, when the  messenger came among them, angry words began to pass.
In this wrangling  took up a stone with both hands and threw it down before ' feet, crying that it was the pebble with which he voted against fleeing from the strangers (meaning thereby the barbarians).  called him a madman; then when the  messenger asked the question with which he had been charged,  asked the man to tell the  of his present condition, and begged them to join themselves to the  and, as for departure, to do as they did.


The messenger then went back to the . When dawn found the dispute still continuing, , who had up to this point kept his army where it was, now gave the word and led all the rest away between the hillocks, the  following, for he supposed that  would not stay behind when the rest of the  left him; this was in fact exactly what happened.
The  marshalled themselves and marched, but not by the same way as the , who stayed close to the broken ground and the lower slopes of  in order to stay clear of the  horse. The  marched down into the plain instead.


Now  at first supposed that  would never have the heart to leave him and his men, and he insisted that they should remain where they were and not leave their post. When ' men had already proceeded some distance, he thought that they had really left him. He accordingly bade his battalion take up its arms and led it in marching step after the rest of the column,

which after going a distance of ten furlongs, was waiting for  by the stream  and the place called , where there is a shrine of . The reason for their waiting was that, if  and his battalion should not leave the place where it was posted but remain there, they would then be able to assist him.
No sooner had ' men come up than the barbarians' cavalry attacked the army, for the horsemen acted as they always had. When they saw no enemy on the ground where the  had been on the days before this, they kept riding forward and attacked the  as soon as they overtook them.


When  learned that the  had departed under cover of night and saw the ground deserted, he called to him  of  and his brothers  and  and said:

What will you say now, sons of , when you see this place deserted? For you, who are their neighbors, kept telling me that  fled from no battlefield and were the masters of warfare. These same men, however, you just saw changing their post, and now you and all of us see that they have fled during the night. The moment they had to measure themselves in battle with those that are in very truth the bravest on earth, they plainly showed that they are men of no account, and all other  likewise.
Now you, for your part, were strangers to the , and I could readily pardon you for praising these fellows, who were in some sort known to you; but I marvelled much more that , be he ever so frightened, should give us a coward's advice to strike our camp, and march away to be besieged in . Of this advice the king will certainly hear from me, but it will be discussed elsewhere.
Now we must not permit our enemies to do as they want; they must be pursued till they are overtaken and pay the penalty for all the harm they have done the .


With that, he led the  with all speed across the  in pursuit of the , supposing that they were in flight; it was the army of  and  alone which was his goal, for the  marched another way over the broken ground, and were out of his sight.
Seeing the  setting forth in pursuit of the , the rest of the barbarian battalions straightway raised their standards and also gave pursuit, each at top speed, no battalion having order in its ranks nor place assigned in the line.


So they ran pell-mell and shouting, as though they would utterly make an end of the . , however, when the cavalry attacked him, sent a horseman to the  with this message: Men of , in this great contest which must give freedom or slavery to , we  and you  have been betrayed by the flight of our allies in the night that is past.
I have accordingly now resolved what we must do; we must protect each other by fighting as best we can. If the cavalry had attacked you first, it would have been the duty of both ourselves and the , who are faithful to , to aid you; but now, seeing that the whole brunt of their assault falls on us, it is right that you should come to the aid of that division which is hardest pressed.
But if, as may be, anything has befallen you which makes it impossible for you to aid us, do us the service of sending us your archers. We are sure that you will obey us, as knowing that you have been by far more zealous than all others in this present war.


When the  heard that, they attempted to help the  and defend them with all their might. But when their march had already begun, they were set upon by the  posted opposite them, who had joined themselves to the king. For this reason, being now under attack by the foe which was closest, they could at the time send no aid.
The  and  accordingly stood alone, men-at-arms and light-armed together; there were of the  fifty thousand and of the , who had never been parted from the , three thousand. These offered sacrifice so that they would fare better in battle with  and the army which was with him.
They could get no favorable omen from their sacrifices, and in the meanwhile many of them were killed and by far more wounded (for the  set up their shields for a fence, and shot showers of arrows). Since the  were being hard-pressed and their sacrifices were of no avail,  lifted up his eyes to the temple of  at  and called on the goddess, praying that they might not be disappointed in their hope.


While he was still in the act of praying, the men of  leapt out before the rest and charged the barbarians, and immediately after ' prayer the sacrifices of the  became favorable. Now they too charged the , and the  met them, throwing away their bows.
First they fought by the fence of shields, and when that was down, there was a fierce and long fight around the temple of  itself, until they came to blows at close quarters. For the barbarians laid hold of the spears and broke them short.
Now the  were neither less valorous nor weaker, but they had no armor; moreover, since they were unskilled and no match for their adversaries in craft, they would rush out singly and in tens or in groups great or small, hurling themselves on the  and so perishing.


Where  was himself, riding a white horse in the battle and surrounded by a thousand picked men who were the flower of the , there they pressed their adversaries hardest. So long as  was alive the  stood their ground and defended themselves, overthrowing many .
When, however,  was killed and his guards, who were the strongest part of the army, had also fallen, then the rest too yielded and gave ground before the men of . For what harmed them the most was the fact that they wore no armor over their clothes and fought, as it were, naked against men fully armed.


On that day the , as the oracle had foretold, gained from  their full measure of vengeance for the slaying of , and the most glorious of victories of all which we know was won by , the son of , who was the son of .

(I have named the rest of ' ancestors in the lineage of , for they are the same for both.) As for , he was killed by , a  of note who long after the  business led three hundred men to battle at  against the whole army of , and was there killed, he and his three hundred.


At , however, the , routed by the , fled in disorder to their own camp and inside the wooden walls which they had made in the territory of .
It is indeed a marvel that although the battle was right by the grove of , there was no sign that any  had been killed in the precinct or entered into it; most of them fell near the temple in unconsecrated ground. I thinkif it is necessary to judge the ways of the godsthat the goddess herself denied them entry, since they had burnt her temple, the shrine at .


This, then, is what happened in this battle. But  son of  had from the very first disapproved of the king's leaving , and now all his counselling not to join battle had been of no avail. In his displeasure at what  was doing, he himself did as I will show.
He had with him a great army, as many as forty thousand men. He knew full well what the outcome of the battle would be, and no sooner had the  and  met than he led these with a fixed purpose, telling them to follow him all together wherever he should lead them, whatever they thought his intent might be.
With that command he pretended to lead them into battle. As he came farther on his way, he saw the  already fleeing and accordingly led his men, no longer in the same array, but took to his heels and fled with all speed not to the wooden fort nor to the walled city of , but to , so that he might make his way with all haste to the .


So  and his army turned that way. All the rest of the  who were on the king's side fought badly on purpose, but not so the ; they fought for a long time against the . For those  who were on the  side had great enthusiasm in the battle, and did not want to fight in a cowardly manner. As a result of this, three hundred of their first and best were killed there by the . At last, however, the  too yielded and they fled to , but not by the way which the  had fled and the multitude of the allies which had fought no fight to the end nor achieved any feat of arms.


This flight of theirs which took place before the actual closing of battle and was prompted because they saw the  flee, proves to me that it was on the  that the fortune of the barbarians hung. They accordingly all fled, save the cavalry,  and other; this helped the fleeing men in so far as it remained between them and their enemies and shielded its friends from the  in their flight.


So the , now having the upper hand, followed ' men, pursuing and slaying. During this steadily growing rout there came a message to the rest of the , who were by the temple of  and had stayed out of the fighting, that there had been a battle and that ' men were victorious. When they heard this, they set forth in no ordered array, those who were with the  keeping to the spurs of the mountain and the hill country, by the road that led upward straight to the temple of , and those who were with the  and  taking the most level route over the plain.
However, when the  and  had come near the enemy, the  horsemen (whose captain was  son of ) caught sight of them approaching in haste and disorder, and rode at them; in this attack they trampled six hundred of them, and pursued and drove the rest to .


So these perished without anyone noticing. But when the  and the rest of the multitude had fled within the wooden wall, they managed to get up on the towers before the coming of the ; then they strengthened the wall as best they could. When the  arrived, an intense battle for the wall began.
For as long as the  were not there, the barbarians defended themselves and had a great advantage over the  who had no skill in the assault of walls. When the  came up, however, the fight for the wall became intense and lasted for a long time. In the end the , by valor and constant effort, scaled the wall and breached it. The  poured in through the opening they had made;

the first to enter were the , and it was they who plundered the tent of , taking from it besides everything else the feeding trough of his horses which was all of bronze and a thing well worth looking at. The  dedicated this feeding trough of  in the temple of . Everything else which they took they brought into the common pool, as did the rest of the .
As for the barbarians, they did not form a unified body again once the wall was down, nor did anyone think of defense because the terrified men in the tiny space and the many myriads herded together were in great distress.
Such a slaughter were the  able to make, that of two hundred and sixty thousand who remained after  had fled with his forty thousand, scarcely three thousand were left alive. Of the  from  ninety-one all together were killed in battle; of the , seventeen and of the , fifty-two.


Among the barbarians, the best fighters were the  infantry and the cavalry of the , and of men, it is said, the bravest was . Among the , the  and  conducted themselves nobly, but the  excelled all in valor.
Of this my only clear proof is (for all these conquered the foes opposed to them) the fact that the  fought with the strongest part of the army, and overcame it. According to my judgment, the bravest man by far was , who had been reviled and dishonored for being the only man of the three hundred that came alive from ; next after him in valor were , , and .
Nevertheless, when there was a general discussion about who had borne himself most bravely, those  who were there judged that , who plainly wished to die because of the reproach hanging over him and so rushed out and left the battle column behind, had achieved great deeds, but that , who had no wish to die, proved himself a courageous fighter, and so in this way he was the better man.
This they may have said merely out of jealousy, but all the aforesaid who were killed in that fight received honor, save ; he, because he desired death because of the reproach previously mentioned, received none.


These won the most renown of all who fought at . For , who, when he came to the army, was the finest not only of the , but also of all the other , died away from the battle. , who was sitting in his place when  was offering sacrifice, was wounded in the side by an arrow.
While his comrades were fighting, he was carried out of the battle and died a lingering death, saying to , a , that it was not a source of grief to him to die for ' sake; his sorrow was rather that he had struck no blow and achieved no deed worthy of his merit, despite all his eager desire to do so.


Of the ,  son of  is said to have won renown, a man from the town of , whose people once did a deed that was of eternal value, as the  themselves say.
For in the past when the sons of  were trying to recover , after breaking into  with a great host, they turned the towns upside down because they did not know where  had been hidden, then (it is said) the  (and, as some say,  himself, because he was angered by the pride of  and feared for the whole land of ) revealed the whole matter to the sons of , and guided them to , which , one of the autochthonoi, handed over to to the .
For that deed the  have always had and still have freedom at  from all dues and chief places at feasts. In fact, even as recently as the war which was waged many years after this time between the  and , the  laid no hand on  when they harried the rest of .


From that town was , who now was the best  fighter in the battle, and about him two tales are told. According to the first, he bore an iron anchor attached to the belt of his cuirass with a chain of bronze. He would cast this anchor whenever he approached his enemies in an attack so that the enemy, as they left their ranks, might not be able to move him from his place. When they were put to flight, it was his plan that he would pull up his anchor and so pursue them.
So runs this tale. The second which contradicts with the first and relates that he wore no iron anchor attached to his cuirass, but that his shield, which he constantly whirled round and never held still, had on it an anchor as a device.


There is yet another glorious deed which  did; when the  were besieging , he challenged and killed  the , a victor in the Five Contests. Long after this,  met his death when he was general of the  with , son of . He was killed at  by the  in a battle for the gold-mines.


Immediately after the  had devastated the barbarians at , a woman, who was the concubine of  a , son of , deserting from the enemy, came to them. She, learning that the  were ruined and the  victorious, decked herself (as did also her attendants) with many gold ornaments and the fairest clothing that she had, and alighting thus from her carriage came to the  while they were still in the midst of slaughtering. When she saw , whose name and country she had often heard of, directing everything, she knew that it was he, and supplicated him clasping his knees:

Save me, your suppliant, O king of , from captive slavery, for you have aided me till now, by making an end of those men who hold sacred nothing of the gods or of any divinities.  I am by birth, the daughter of , son of ; in  the  seized me by force and held me prisoner.

Take heart, lady,  answered, for you are my suppliant, and furthermore if you are really the daughter of  of , he is my closest friend of all who dwell in those lands. For the present, he then entrusted her to those of the ephors who were present. Later he sent her to , where she herself desired to go.


Immediately after the arrival of this woman, the men of  came when everything was already over. Upon learning that they had come too late for the battle, they were extremely upset and said that they ought to punish themselves for that.
When they heard that those  with  were fleeing, they would have pursued them as far as . The , however, would not permit them to pursue the fleeing men.
So when they returned to their own land, the  banished the leaders of their army from the country. After the  came the men of , who also went away extremely upset, and after their departure, they too banished their leaders. Such were the doings of the  and .


There was at  in the army of the  one , son of , a leading man of . He hastened to  with really outrageous counsel and coming upon him, said to him:

son of , you have done a deed of surpassing greatness and glory; the god has granted to you in saving  to have won greater renown than any  whom we know. But now you must finish what remains for the rest, so that your fame may be greater still and so that no barbarian will hereafter begin doing reckless deeds against the .
When  was killed at ,  and  cut off his head and set it on a pole; make them a like return, and you will win praise from all  and the rest of  besides. For if you impale , you will be avenged for your father's brother .


This is what , thinking to please, said. , however, answered him as follows: , I thank you for your goodwill and forethought, but you have missed the mark of right judgment. First you exalt me and my fatherland and my deeds, yet next you cast me down to mere nothingness when you advise me to insult the dead, and say that I shall win more praise if I do so. That would be an act more proper for barbarians than for  and one that we consider worthy of censure even in barbarians.
No, as for myself, I would prefer to find no favor either with the people of  or anyone else who is pleased by such acts. It is enough for me if I please the  by righteous deeds and speech. As for , whom you would have me avenge, I think that he has received a full measure of vengeance; the uncounted souls of these that you see have done honor to him and the rest of those who died at . But to you this is my warning: do not come again to me with words like these nor give me such counsel. Be thankful now that you go unpunished.


With that  departed. Then  made a proclamation that no man should touch the spoils, and ordered the helots to gather all the stuff together. They, spreading all over the camp, found there tents adorned with gold and silver, and couches gilded and silver-plated, and golden bowls and cups and other drinking-vessels;

and sacks they found on wagons, in which were seen cauldrons of gold and silver. They stripped from the dead who lay there their armlets and torques, and golden daggers; as for the embroidered clothing, it was disregarded.
Much of all this the helots showed, as much as they could not conceal, but much they stole and sold to the . As a result the  laid the foundation of their great fortunes by buying gold from the helots as though it were bronze.


Having brought all the loot together, they set apart a tithe for the god of . From this was made and dedicated that tripod which rests upon the bronze three-headed serpent, nearest to the altar; another they set apart for the god of , from which was made and dedicated a bronze figure of , ten cubits high; and another for the god of the Isthmus, from which was fashioned a bronze  seven cubits high. When they had set all this apart, they divided what remained, and each received, according to his worth, concubines of the  and gold and silver, and all the rest of the stuff and the beasts of burden.
How much was set apart and given to those who had fought best at , no man says. I think that they also received gifts, but tenfold of every kind, women, horses, talents, camels, and all other things also, was set apart and given to .


This other story is also told. When  fled from , he left to  his own establishment. , seeing ' establishment with its display of gold and silver and gaily colored tapestry, ordered the bakers and the cooks to prepare a dinner such as they were accustomed to do for .
They did his bidding, but , when he saw golden and silver couches richly covered, and tables of gold and silver, and all the magnificent service of the banquet, was amazed at the splendor before him, and for a joke commanded his own servants to prepare a dinner in  fashion. When that meal, so different from the other, was ready,  burst out laughing and sent for the generals of the .
When these had assembled,  pointed to the manner in which each dinner was served and said: Men of , I have brought you here because I desired to show you the foolishness of the leader of the  who, with such provisions for life as you see, came here to take away from us our possessions which are so pitiful. In this way, it is said,  spoke to the generals of the .


Long after these events many of the  also found chests full of gold and silver and other things.
Moreover, when their bodies (which the  gathered into one place) were laid bare of flesh, a skull was found of which the bone was all of one piece without suture. A jawbone also came to light in which the teeth of the upper jaw were one whole, a single bone, front teeth and grinders, and one could see the body of a man of five cubits stature.


As for the body of , it was removed on the day after the battle; by whom, I cannot with certainty say. I have, however, heard of very many countries that buried , and I know of many that were richly rewarded for that act by ' son .

 Which of them it was that stole and buried the body of  I cannot learn for certain. Some report that it was buried by , an . Such was the manner of ' burial.


But the , when they had divided the spoils at , buried each contingent of their dead in a separate place. The  made three tombs; there they buried their irens, among whom were , , , and .
In one of the tombs, then, were the irens, in the second the rest of the , and in the third the helots. This, then is how the  buried their dead. The , however, buried all theirs together in a place apart, and the  did similarly with their own dead. So too did the  and  with those who had been killed by the horsemen.
All the tombs of these peoples were filled with dead; but as for the rest of the states whose tombs are to be seen at , their tombs are but empty barrows that they built for the sake of men that should come after, because they were ashamed to have been absent from the battle. There is one there called the tomb of the , which, as I learn by inquiry, was built as late as ten years after, at the ' desire, by their patron and protector  son of , a .


As soon as the  had buried their dead at , they resolved in council that they would march against  and demand surrender of those who had taken the  sideparticularly of  and , who were chief among their foremost men. If these men were not delivered to them, they would not withdraw from the area in front of the city till they had taken it.
They came with this purpose on the eleventh day after the battle and laid siege to the , demanding the surrender of the men. When the  refused this surrender, they laid waste to their lands and assaulted the walls.


Seeing that the  would not cease from their harrying and nineteen days had passed,  spoke as follows to the : Men of , since the  have resolved that they will not raise the siege till  is taken or we are delivered to them, do not let the land of  increase the measure of its ills for our sake.
No, rather if it is money they desire and their demand for our surrender is but a pretext, let us give them money out of our common treasury (for it was by the common will and not ours alone that we took the  side). If, however, they are besieging the town for no other reason than to have us, then we will give ourselves up to be tried by them. This seemed to be said well and at the right time, and the  immediately sent a herald to , offering to surrender the men.


On these terms they made an agreement, but  escaped from the town. His sons were seized, but  held them free of guilt, saying that the sons were not accessory to the treason. As for the rest of the men whom the  surrendered, they supposed that they would be put on trial, and were confident that they would defeat the impeachment by bribery. , however, had that very suspicion of them, and when they were put into his hands he sent away the whole allied army and carried the men to , where he put them to death. This is what happened at  and .


 the son of  was by now far on his way in his flight from . The , when he came among them, entertained him hospitably and inquired of him concerning the rest of the army, knowing nothing of what had happened at .

 understood that if he told them the whole truth about the fighting, he would endanger his own life and the lives of all those with him, for he thought that every man would set upon him if they heard the story. Therefore, although he had revealed nothing to the , he spoke as follows to the :

I myself, men of , am pressing on with all speed and diligence to march into , being despatched from the army for a certain purpose with the men whom you see.  and his army are expected marching close on my heels. It is for you to entertain him, and show that you do him good service, for if you so do, you will not afterwards regret it.
So saying, he used all diligence to lead his army away straight towards  through  and  without any delay, following the shortest inland road. So he came to , but he left behind many of his army who had been cut down by the  or overcome by hunger and weariness. From  he crossed over in boats. In such a way  returned to .


Now on the same day when the  were so stricken at , it so happened that they suffered a similar fate at  in . When the  who had come in their ships with  the  were encamped at , certain messengers came to them there from ,  of ,  son of , and  son of . The  had sent these, keeping their despatch secret from the  and the tyrant  son of , whom the  had made tyrant of .
When they came before the generals,  spoke long and vehemently: If the  but see you, he said, they will revolt from the , and the barbarians will not remain; but if they do remain, you will have such a prey as never again.  He begged them in the name of the gods of their common worship to deliver  from slavery and drive the barbarian away.
That, he said, would be an easy matter for them, for the  ships are unseaworthy and no match for yours; and if you have any suspicion that we may be tempting you deceitfully, we are ready to be taken in your ships as hostages.


As the  stranger was pleading so earnestly,  asked him (whether it was that he desired to know for the sake of a presage, or through some happy chance of a god),  stranger, what is your name? , he replied.
Then  cut short whatever else  had begun to say, and cried: I accept the omen of your name,  stranger; now see to it that before you sail from here you and those who are with you pledge that the  will be our zealous allies.


He said this and added deed to word. For straightway the  bound themselves by pledge and oath to alliance with the .
This done, the rest sailed away, but  bade  to sail with the  because of the good omen of his name. The  waited through that day, and on the next they sought and received favorable augury; their diviner was  son of , a man of that  which is in the  gulf. This man's father  had once fared as I will now relate.


There is at  a certain flock sacred to the Sun, which in the daytime is pastured beside the river , which flows from the mountain called  through the lands of  and empties into the sea by the harbor of . By night, those townsmen who are most notable for wealth or lineage are chosen to watch it, each man serving for a year, for the people of  set great store by this flock, being so taught by a certain oracle. It is kept in a cave far distant from the town.
Now at the time of which I speak,  was the chosen watchman. But one night he fell asleep, and wolves, coming past his guard into the cave, killed about sixty of the flock. When  was aware of it, he held his peace and told no man, intending to restore what was lost by buying others.
This matter was not, however, hidden from the people of , and when it came to their knowledge they brought him to judgment and condemned him to lose his eyesight for sleeping at his watch. So they blinded , but from the day of their so doing their flocks bore no offspring, nor did their land yield fruit as before.
Furthermore, a declaration was given to them at  and , when they inquired of the prophets what might be the cause of their present ill: the gods told them by their prophets that they had done unjustly in blinding , the guardian of the sacred flock, for we ourselves (they said) sent those wolves, and we will not cease from avenging him until you make him such restitution for what you did as he himself chooses and approves; when that is fully done, we ourselves will give  such a gift as will make many men consider him happy.


This was the oracle given to the people of . They kept it secret and charged certain of their townsmen to carry the business through; they acted as I will now show. Coming and sitting down by  at the place where he sat, they spoke of other matters, till at last they fell to commiserating his misfortune. Guiding the conversation in this way, they asked him what compensation he would choose, if the people of  should promise to requite him for what they had done.
He, knowing nothing of the oracle, said he would choose for a gift the lands of certain named townsmen whom he thought to have the two fairest estates in , and a house besides which he knew to be the fairest in the town; let him (he said) have possession of these, and he would lay aside his anger, and be satisfied with that by way of restitution.
So he said this, and those who were sitting beside him said in reply: , the people of  hereby make you that restitution for the loss of your sight, obeying the oracle given to them. At that he was very angry, for he learned through this the whole story and saw that they had cheated him. They did, however, buy from the possessors and give him what he had chosen, and from that day he had a natural gift of divination, through which he won fame.


, the son of this , had been brought by the , and was the army's prophet. But I have heard it said before now, that  was not the son of , but made a wrongful use of that name and worked for wages up and down .


Having won favorable omens, the  put out to sea from  for . When they were now near  in the  territory, they anchored there near the temple of  which is in those parts, and prepared for a sea-fight. The , learning of their approach, also put out to sea and made for the mainland with all their ships save the , whom they sent sailing away. It was determined by them in council that they would not do battle by sea,

for they thought themselves overmatched; the reason of their making for the mainland was that they might be under the shelter of their army at , which had been left by ' command behind the rest of his host to hold . There were sixty thousand men in it, and , the noblest and tallest man in , was their general.
It was the design of the  admirals to flee to the shelter of that army, and there to beach their ships and build a fence round them which should be a protection for the ship and a refuge for themselves.


With this design they put to sea. So when they came past the temple of the Goddesses at  to the  and , where there is a temple of  (which was built by  son of  when he went with  son of  to the founding of ), they beached their ships and fenced them round with stones and the trunks of orchard trees which they cut down; they drove in stakes around the fence and prepared for siege or victory, making ready, after consideration, for either event.


When the  learned that the barbarians had gone off to the mainland, they were not all pleased that their enemy had escaped them, and did not know whether to return back or set sail for the . At last they resolved that they would do neither, but sail to the mainland.
Equipping themselves for this with gangways and everything else necessary for a sea-fight, they held their course for . When they approached the camp, no one put out to meet them. Seeing the ships beached within the wall and a great host of men drawn up in array along the strand,  first sailed along in his ship, keeping as near to the shore as he could, and made this proclamation to the  by the voice of a herald:

Men of , you who hear us, understand what I say, for by no means will the  understand anything I charge you with when we join battle; first of all it is right for each man to remember his freedom and next the battle-cry : and let him who hears me tell him who has not heard it.
The purpose of this act was the same as ' purpose at ; either the message would be unknown to the barbarians and would prevail with the , or if it were thereafter reported to the barbarians, it would cause them to mistrust their  allies.


After this counsel of , the  brought their ships to land and disembarked on the beach, where they formed a battle column. But the , seeing the  prepare for battle and exhort the , first of all took away the ' armor, suspecting that they would aid the ;

for indeed when the barbarian's ships brought certain  captives, who had been left in  and taken by ' army, the  had set them all free and sent them away to  with provisions for the journey; for this reason in particular they were held suspect, as having set free five hundred souls of ' enemies.
Furthermore, they appointed the  to guard the passes leading to the heights of , alleging that they were best acquainted with the country. Their true reason, however, for so doing was that the  should be separate from the rest of their army. In such a manner the  safeguarded themselves from those  who (they supposed) might turn against them if opportunity were given for themselves: they set their shields close to make a barricade.


The , having made all their preparations advanced their line against the barbarians. As they went, a rumor spread through the army, and a herald's wand was seen lying by the water-line. The rumor that ran was to the effect that the  were victors over ' army at a battle in .
Now there are many clear indications of the divine ordering of things, seeing that a message, which greatly heartened the army and made it ready to face danger, arrived amongst the  the very day on which the ' disaster at  and that other which was to befall them at  took place.


Moreover, there was the additional coincidence, that there were precincts of  on both battlefields; for at  the fight was near the temple of , as I have already said, and so it was to be at  also.
It happened that the rumor of a victory won by the  with  was true, for the defeat at  happened while it was yet early in the day, and the defeat of  in the afternoon. That the two fell on the same day of the same month was proven to the  when they examined the matter not long afterwards.
Now before this rumor came they had been faint-hearted, fearing less for themselves than for the  with , that  should stumble over . But when the report sped among them, they grew stronger and swifter in their onset. So  and barbarians alike were eager for battle, seeing that the islands and the  were the prizes of victory.


As for the  and those whose place was nearest them, that is, for about half of the line, their way lay over the beach and level ground; for the  and those that were next to them, their way lay through a ravine and among hills. While the  were making a circuit, those others on the other wing were already fighting.
As long as the ' shields stood upright, they defended themselves and held their own in the battle, but when the  and their neighbors in the line passed the word and went more zealously to work, that they and not the  might win the victory, immediately the face of the fight changed.
Breaking down the shields they charged all together into the midst of the , who received the onset and stood their ground for a long time, but at last fled within their wall. The  and  and  and , who were next to each other in the line, followed close after and rushed in together. But when the walled place had been razed, the barbarians made no further defense, but took to flight, all save the ,

who gathered into bands of a few men and fought with whatever  came rushing within the walls. Of the  leaders two escaped by flight and two were killed;  and , who were admirals of the fleet, escaped;  and , the general of the land army, were killed fighting.


While the  still fought, the  and their comrades came up and finished what was left of the business. The  too lost many men there, notably the men of  and their general .
As for the  who served in the Median army and had been disarmed, they, seeing from the first that victory hung in the balance, did what they could in their desire to aid the . When the other  saw the  set the example, they also abandoned the  and attacked the foreigners.


The  had for their own safety appointed the  to watch the passes, so that if anything should happen to the  army such as did happen to it, they might have guides to bring them safely to the heights of . This was the task to which the  were appointed for the reason mentioned above and so that they might not be present with the army and so turn against it. They acted wholly contrary to the charge laid upon them; they misguided the fleeing  by ways that led them among their enemies, and at last they themselves became their worst enemies and killed them. In this way  revolted for the second time from the .


In that battle those of the  who fought best were the , and the  who fought best was one who practised the pancratium,  son of . This  on a later day met his death in a battle at  in  during a war between the  and , and lay dead on . Those who fought best after the  were the men of  and  and .


When the  had made an end of most of the barbarians, either in battle or in flight, they brought out their booty onto the beach, and found certain stores of wealth. Then after burning the ships and the whole of the wall, they sailed away.
When they had arrived at , they debated in council over the removal of all  from , and in what  lands under their dominion it would be best to plant the , leaving the country itself to the barbarians; for it seemed impossible to stand on guard between the  and their enemies forever. If, however, they should not so stand, they had no hope that the  would permit the  to go unpunished.
In this matter the  who were in charge were for removing the people from the lands of those  nations which had sided with the  and giving their land to the  to dwell in. The  disliked the whole plan of removing the  from , or allowing the  to determine the lot of  colonies, and as they resisted vehemently, the  yielded.
