It accordingly came about that they admitted to their alliance the , , , and all other islanders who had served with their forces, and bound them by pledge and oaths to remain faithful and not desert their allies. When the oaths had been sworn, the  set sail to break the bridges, supposing that these still held fast. So they laid their course for the .


The few barbarians who escaped were driven to the heights of , and made their way from there to . While they were making their way along the road,  son of , who happened to have been present at the  disaster, reviled the admiral  very bitterly, telling him (with much beside) that such generalship as his proved him worse than a woman, and that no punishment was too severe for the harm he had done the king's estate. Now it is the greatest of all taunts in  to be called worse than a woman.
These many insults angered  so much that he drew his sword upon  to kill him, but  son of  of , who stood behind  himself saw him run at , and caught him round the middle and lifted and hurled him to the ground. In the meantime ' guards had also come between them.
By doing so  won the gratitude of  himself and , for saving the king's brother. For this deed he was made ruler of all  by the king's gift. Then they went on their way without anything further happening and came to .


Now it happened that the king had been at  ever since he came there in flight from  after his overthrow in the sea-fight. Being then at  he became enamored of ' wife, who was also there. But as all his messages could not bring her to yield to him, and he would not force her to his will, out of regard for his brother  (which indeed counted with the woman also, for she knew well that no force would be used against her),  found no other way to accomplish his purpose than that he should make a marriage between his own son  and the daughter of this woman and , for he thought that by doing so he would be most likely to win her.
So he betrothed them with all due ceremony and rode away to . But when he had come and had taken ' bride into his house, he thought no more of ' wife, but changed his mind and wooed and won this girl , ' wife and ' daughter.


As time went on, however, the truth came to light, and in such manner as I will show. ' wife, , wove and gave to him a great gaily-colored mantle, marvellous to see.  was pleased with it, and went to  wearing it.
Being pleased with her too, he asked her what she wanted in return for her favors, for he would deny nothing at her asking. Thereuponfor she and all her house were doomed to evilshe said to , Will you give me whatever I ask of you? He promised this, supposing that she would ask anything but that; when he had sworn, she asked boldly for his mantle.

 tried to refuse her, for no reason except that he feared that  might have clear proof of his doing what she already guessed. He accordingly offered her cities instead and gold in abundance and an army for none but herself to command. Armies are the most suitable of gifts in . But as he could not move her, he gave her the mantle; and she, rejoicing greatly in the gift, went flaunting her finery.


 heard that she had the mantle, but when she learned the truth, it was not the girl with whom she was angry. She supposed rather that the girl's mother was guilty and that this was her doing, and so it was ' wife whom she plotted to destroy.
She waited therefore till  her husband should be giving his royal feast. This banquet is served once a year, on the king's birthday; the  name for it is tukta, which is in the  language perfect. On that day (and none other) the king anoints his head and makes gifts to the . Waiting for that day,  then asked of  that ' wife should be given to her.

 considered it a terrible and wicked act to give up his brother's wife, and that too when she was innocent of the deed; for he knew the purpose of the request.


Nevertheless, since  was insistent and the law compelled him (for at this royal banquet in  every request must of necessity be granted), he unwillingly consented, and delivered the woman to . Then, bidding her do what she wanted, he sent for his brother and spoke as follows:

, you are ' son and my brother, and a good man; hear me then. You must no longer live with her who is now your wife. I give you my daughter in her place. Take her for your own, but do away with the wife that you have, for it is not my will that you should have her.
At that  was amazed; Sire, he said, what is this evil command that you lay upon me, telling me to deal with my wife in this way? I have by her young sons and daughters, of whom you have taken a wife for your own son, and I am very content with her herself. Yet you are asking me to get rid of my wife and wed your daughter?
Truly, O king, I consider it a great honor to be accounted worthy of your daughter, but I will do neither the one nor the other. No, rather, do not force me to consent to such a desire. You will find another husband for your daughter as good as I, but permit me to keep my own wife.
This was ' response, but  was very angry and said: You have come to this pass, . I will give you no daughter of mine as a wife, nor will you any longer live with her whom you now have. In this way you will learn to accept that which is offered you. Hearing that,  said No, sire, you have not destroyed me yet! and so departed.


In the meantime, while  talked with his brother,  sent for ' guards and treated ' wife very cruelly; she cut off the woman's breasts and threw them to dogs, and her nose and ears and lips also, and cut out her tongue. Then she sent her home after she had undergone this dreadful ordeal.


Knowing nothing of this as yet, but fearing evil,  ran home. Seeing what had been done to his wife, he immediately took counsel with his children and set out for  with his own sons (and others too), intending to raise the province of  in revolt and do the king the greatest of harm.
This he would have done, to my thinking, had he escaped to the country of the  and . They were fond of him, and he was viceroy over the . But it was of no use, for  learned what he intended and sent against him an army which killed him on his way, and his sons and his army. Such is the story of ' love and ' death.


The  who had set out from  for the  first anchored off  having been stopped by contrary winds, and came from there to , where they found the bridges broken which they thought would still be in place; these were in fact the chief cause of their coming to the .
The  then who were with  decided to sail away to , but the , with  their general, that they would remain there and attack the . So the rest sailed away, but the  crossed over to the  and laid siege to .


Now when the  heard that the  were at the , they had come in from the neighboring towns and assembled at this same , seeing that it was the strongest walled place in that region. Among them there was a  named  from , and he had carried the equipment of the bridges there.  was held by the  of the country, but with him were  and a great multitude of their allies.


This province was ruled by ' viceroy , a cunning man and a wicked one; witness the deceit that he practised on the king in his march to , how he stole away from  the treasure of  son of .
This was the way of it; there is at  in the  the tomb of , and a precinct around it, which contained much treasure: vessels of gold and silver, bronze, clothing, and other dedications; all of which  carried off by the king's gift.

Sire, he said deceitfully to , there is here the house of a certain , who met a just death for invading your territory with an army; give me this man's house, so that all may be taught not to invade your territory. One would think that this plea would easily persuade  to give him a man's house, since the latter had no suspicion of ' meaning. His reason for saying that  had invaded the king's territory was that the  believe all  to belong to themselves and whoever is their king. So when the treasure was given to him, he carried it away from  to , and planted and farmed the precinct. He would also come from  and have intercourse with women in the shrine. Now, when the  laid siege to him, he had made no preparation for it; he did not think that the  would come, and he had no way of escaping from their attack.


Since the siege continued into the late autumn, the  grew weary of their absence from home and their lack of success at taking the fortress. They accordingly entreated their generals to lead them away again, but the generals refused to do that till they should take the place or be recalled by the  state. At that the men endured their plight patiently.


But those who were within the walls were by now reduced to the last extremity, so much so that they boiled the thongs of their beds for food. At last, however, even these failed them, and  and  and all the  made their way down from the back part of the fortress, where the fewest of their enemies were, and fled at nightfall.

 When morning came, the people of the  signified from their towers to the  what had happened, and opened their gates. The greater part of the  then went in pursuit, while the rest stayed to hold the town.


As  was making his escape into , the  of that country caught and sacrificed him in their customary manner to  the god of their land; as for his companions, they did away with them by other means.

 and his company had begun their flight later, and were overtaken a little way beyond the , where after they had defended themselves a long time, some of them were killed and the rest taken alive. The  bound them and carried them to , and together with them  and his son also in bonds.


It is related by the people of the  that a marvellous thing happened one of those who guarded . He was frying dried fish, and these as they lay over the fire began to leap and writhe as though they had just been caught.
The rest gathered around, amazed at the sight, but when  saw this strange thing, he called the one who was frying the fish and said to him: , do not be afraid of this portent, for it is not to you that it has been sent; it is to me that  of  is trying to signify that although he is dead and dry, he has power given him by the god to take vengeance on me, the one who wronged him.
Now therefore I offer a ransom, the sum of one hundred talents to the god for the treasure that I took from his temple. I will also pay to the  two hundred talents for myself and my son, if they spare us.
But  the general was unmoved by this promise, for the people of  desired that  should be put to death in revenge for , and the general himself was so inclined. So they carried  away to the headland where  had bridged the strait (or, by another story, to the hill above the town of ), and there nailed him to boards and hanged him. As for his son, they stoned him to death before his father's eyes.


This done, they sailed away to , carrying with them the cables of the bridges to be dedicated in their temples, and all sorts of things in addition. This, then, is all that was done in this year.


This  who was crucified was the grandson of that  who instructed the  in a design which they took from him and laid before ; this was its purport:

Seeing that  grants lordship to the  people, and to you, , among them, let us, after reducing , depart from the little and rugged land which we possess and occupy one that is better. There are many such lands on our borders, and many further distant. If we take one of these, we will all have more reasons for renown. It is only reasonable that a ruling people should act in this way, for when will we have a better opportunity than now, when we are lords of so many men and of all ?

 heard them, and found nothing to marvel at in their design; Go ahead and do this, he said; but if you do so, be prepared no longer to be rulers but rather subjects. Soft lands breed soft men; wondrous fruits of the earth and valiant warriors grow not from the same soil.
The  now realized that  reasoned better than they, and they departed, choosing rather to be rulers on a barren mountain side than dwelling in tilled valleys to be slaves to others.
